fields.headline: Javed Miandad confirmed as coach
fields.trailText: First Test Sri Lanka made 88 for two against Pakistan on a rain-affected first day of the second Test in Peshawar.
fields.body:
Javed Miandad has been confirmed as Pakistan's coach in succession to Intikhab Alam. He will take charge after the series against Sri Lanka. "It's an honour and my immediate task is that the team does well in the West Indies," he said. Pakistan will play three Test matches against West Indies and a triangular series, also including Zimbabwe, following the Sharjah tournament. Yesterday Sri Lanka made 88 for two against Pakistan on a rain-affected first day of the second Test in Peshawar, with only 37 overs bowled.

The former Zimbabwe captain Alistair Campbell was 103 not out at tea with his side on 411 for eight in the first innings on the second day of their match against the West Indies Board XI.

webTitle: Boje spins India towards the brink

fields.headline: Boje spins India towards the brink
fields.trailText: India were sent spinning towards their first home series defeat since 1987 by the South African slow left-armer Nicky Boje after the fourth day of the second Test in Bangalore.
fields.body:
India were sent spinning towards their first home series defeat since 1987 by the South African slow left-armer Nicky Boje after the fourth day of the second Test in Bangalore.

Boje, whose 85 after coming in as nightwatchman had helped South Africa to a first-innings lead of 321, took three quick wickets and India, having lost the first Test in three days, resume today on 196 for five needing 125 to avoid an innings defeat.

Exploiting the crumbling pitch, Boje dismissed India's openers Rahul Dravid, for 18, and Wasim Jaffer, who made 23 including four boundaries off Allan Donald, both to slip catches.

Saurav Ganguly, due to take over as captain from Sachin Tendulkar after this match, laboured for two hours to reach 13 before Boje trapped him lbw. Tendulkar (20) was caught by Herschelle Gibbs at point trying to force Donald to the fence and Kallis removed Mohammad Kaif (23).

India's former captain Mohammad Azharuddin, recalled after a seven-month absence for his 99th Test, offered the only authentic resistance and was 73 not out at the close, reaching his 22nd Test half-century by launching Boje over long-off for six.

Meanwhile India's strike bowler Javagal Srinath has been rested for the limited-overs matches against South Africa starting on Thursday.

fields.headline: Kewell fuels Leeds title charge
fields.trailText: Leeds 3 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
Manchester United, among others, will be interested to learn that as the season steps smartly towards a potentially intriguing crescendo Leeds have at last begun to appreciate that work-rate and end product are not always necessarily connected.

So much of the success enjoyed by David O'Leary's players in the past few months has been a by-product of youthful enthusiasm - relentless running and prodigious effort.

But titles are won as much in the mind as with the feet and yesterday at Elland Road Coventry City were strolled to death.

A measured and composed performance moved the Yorkshire side back on to United's coat-tails at the top of the Premiership, just four points adrift with 11 games apiece to play.

"We must just keep plugging away," said O'Leary. "We'll try and win our remaining games and see where that takes us. We played wonderful football; there was only one team out there today."

Leeds's furious early pressure had its reward with a little gem of a goal, Harry Kewell arrowing a gorgeous drive into the bottom corner after Ian Harte rolled a free-kick into his path.

Kewell's marvellous strike came after just five minutes but the potency and precision of Leeds's football, particularly in central midfield, was such that it was actually overdue.

One could only feel sympathy for Colin Hendry upon his return to English football, for containing the ebullient Kewell has constantly proved to be a thankless task for fleet-footed Premiership defenders 10 years his junior.

To be fair, the 34-year-old Hendry did well enough even if the lack of support afforded to him by his full-backs David Burrows and Barry Quinn too often saw him standing in splendid isolation with his finger jammed in the dam.

If Leeds sensed early that Coventry's resistance would be token and that here was a game for the taking, their attempts to remove any doubt about the outcome were a little laboured.

They played well enough to ensure that their domination was never seriously threatened but there was a naivety to much of their finishing.

After Noel Whelan had squandered Coventry's one half-decent chance of the opening half, Leeds struck for a second time to send an almost tangible sigh of relief rolling around a stadium that seemed to be bracing itself for anti-climax.

This time Kewell was the provider, surgically slicing open the Coventry defence with a nicely weighted pass that sent Michael Bridges skipping clear down the centre. There was still work to be done, however, something Bridges accomplished with a neat shimmy that took him around Magnus Hedman.

Coventry's will to fight on was promptly diluted to such an extent that an eerie calm settled upon - or rather smothered - proceedings.

Leeds guarded possession so jealously and were so comfortable on the ball that they seemed capable of scoring at any moment of their choosing.

Strange, then, that they chose to add only one more goal, Jason Wilcox steering home a cross from the substitute Darren Huckerby with five minutes remaining.

Perhaps they were preserving strength for the greater tests that lie ahead; perhaps they were simply tired after their Italian job.

In the end, it did not really matter because long before the final whistle Coventry had decided it was better to accept an emphatic defeat while back-pedalling than run the risk of taking a bigger beating while moving forwards.

Their manager was almost too upset to rant.

"It was a waste of time coming along," he said. "We have 11 players injured but that is not the point. I hope they do feel the same way as I do - that they wasted everybody's time today."

 Leeds's title odds have been cut from 7-1 to 5-1 second favourites by William Hill, who make Manchester United 3-10 favourites and also offer 12-1 for Arsenal, Chelsea and Liverpool.

fields.headline: Warnock blast awakens United
fields.trailText: Sheff Utd 1 - 1 QPR
fields.body:
The 11,000-plus fans who gave up their Yorkshire puddings and opted for Bramall Lane might have regretted the decision a little.

United have been anything but dreary since Neil Warnock took over as manager but it required a half-time rollicking for the home side finally to shake their torpor. "The players were disappointed at being booed off at half-time but I told them they were lucky to get even that," said Warnock. "If I had paid to see that I would have had a go at them too. Dire is a word that springs to mind, but they did much better in the second half."

United's revival leaves them unbeaten at home in the league, winning all six games before yesterday, but even they could not break QPR's developing habit of drawing games.

This was QPR's sixth stalemate in succession, five of them finishing 1-1. They were worth the point and owed it to a goal in the 25th minute from Mikkel Beck.

The Danish international striker has missed his fair share of chances in the past few seasons, but it was difficult to make a mistake from three yards. The chance was made by a deep cross from Jermaine Darlington, knocked back across the face of goal by Paul Murray for Beck to apply a finishing touch.

Though the QPR manager Gerry Francis would be delighted to make his loan permanent, he dismissed the notion yesterday: "There is absolutely no chance of Mikkel joining us permanently; he is on far too much money for us. That will not happen even though I'm pleased with him. He has done well considering he hasn't had much first-team football."

Beck's goal was the result of a bright first-half performance but QPR needed the lead when they were forced to defend in the second half. United drew level in the 54th minute when Alex Notman, on loan from Manchester United, rounded off a move between Paul Devlin and Curtis Woodhouse.

webTitle: Viduka's feat all in vain in Celtic flop

fields.headline: Viduka's feat all in vain in Celtic flop
fields.trailText: Hibernian 2 - 1 Celtic
fields.body:
Celtic last night once again stared opportunity in the face and turned their backs on it. Given the chance to keep their championship hopes alive after Rangers' slip against St Johnstone the previous day, they were never in the hunt.

Hibs, who had not scored a goal against Celtic in their past five games, swarmed all over them, leaving their manager Alex McLeish to wonder why they cannot find this level of performance every week.

Pat McGinlay and Kenny Miller scored their goals and the fact that Mark Viduka equalled the Premier League record of scoring in 10 successive matches will be no consolation to Kenny Dalglish. The interim manager might have been impressed by the late rally but three points thrown away were ruinous.

The improbable thought that Celtic had a chance of going top of the league by Saturday night was surely incentive enough and the fact that Hibs had won only once in the past 23 times the clubs had met to contest points was also a comforting statistic.

But the Edinburgh side, ensconced in the middle of the table, has the disconcerting habit of raising its game in the unlikeliest of circumstances.

Dalglish gave Eyal Berkovic his first start under the new management while Hibs had to play without Russell Latapy, on duty with Trinidad in a World Cup qualifying match. But those who were present gave another masterly display in showing how unremitting, if not exactly intelligent, Scottish football can be.

There is one good reason to watch Hibs this season, for they have uncovered a genuine new talent in the form of their young striker Kenny Miller, who has caused much excitement among English managers.

The striker's early and quite startling runs seemed to bother Celtic, who are not always used to other teams attacking them with much abandon.

Although Miller was not involved in the opening goal, he set the tone for his side's rousing first-half performance.

In the 23rd minute, Celtic failed to defend a long diagonal ball that allowed Dirk Lehmann to head the ball forward in the direction of the Finn, Mixu Paataleinen. He in turn scooped the ball back across the goal for McGinlay to rush it into the net.

The half was fairly calamitous for Celtic. They lost their goalkeeper Dmitri Kharine six minutes later with what looked like a bad injury and Jonathan Gould was forced to come on.

His initial task was to defend a corner, which ended with Martin McIntosh heading the ball into the net. Fortunately for Celtic, the referee spotted an infringement off the play.

Celtic's problems were compounded in the 63rd minute after Johan Mjallby became the first player booked. From the free kick, Franck Sauzée fired a 30-yard shot that broke to Lehmann, whose effort was well saved by Gould. But the ball rebounded to Miller, who struck the shot into the net.

Mjallby redeemed himself in the 73rd minute with a pass to Mark Burchill that was transferred to Viduka to keep his record going. But the second goal would not arrive even after Alan Stubbs hit the bar. The goalkeeper Nick Colgan and his defenders somehow stood firm.

fields.headline: The ungilded Palace of Lim
fields.trailText: C Palace 1 - 1 Man City
fields.body:
These are strange days at Selhurst and Joe Royle seemed as bemused as anyone. Manchester City had carried their stuttering new year form into March, had been slightly fortunate to escape with a point and yet somehow they had managed to climb into an automatic promotion slot.

"This strange little game of ours does surprise you at times and we have actually gone up in the table," the City manager announced, Ipswich's loss to Portsmouth having done the job for him.

City's record in 2000 now reads won 3, drawn 4, lost 1, which is hardly an irresistible case for promotion. But with 13 matches to go the onus is on their rivals.

As Crystal Palace's manager Steve Coppell said: "It's a strange division. The best teams will obviously gravitate to the top but every team is capable of beating every other."

There were mitigating circumstances for City on Saturday. Their 17-goal top scorer Shaun Goater was missing on World Cup duty with Bermuda and Ian Bishop and Kevin Horlock, their midfield think-tank, were both rested.

In their absence the visitors worked tremendously hard but apart from the goal, which came in the eighth minute when Robert Taylor headed in from close range, they were short on imagination and rarely looked like scoring.

Struggling Palace equalled them in all areas of play and the rapidity with which they bounced back with an even closer-range header from Clinton Morrison was worthy of praise. Probably the only credit they are going to get at the moment.

Palace, who are in administration with £20m debts, are hoping this week they will finally be taken over by Jerry Lim - who is so mysterious that Radio 5 said he was Chinese, then Malaysian, then said that it was a pseudonym anyway.

Coppell too was unable to shed any light on Lim. "I've met him twice but I don't know any more about him than most people. But it's a good sign that he hasn't been shouting from the rooftops. He's been constant in his wanting to buy the club, we've had nobody else, so I'm grateful. Just as long as he's got a big cheque."

In the meantime Palace's supporters have mobilised to form a somewhat optimistic appeal fund. As the Supporters Trust brochure has it: "Put in the simplest of terms we need 10,000 people to contribute £31,000 each in order to raise £310m. That should be enough to buy us control of the club."

So don't hold your breath. At the moment Palace are still out on a Lim.

webTitle: The Duke is hitting the high notes

fields.headline: The Duke is hitting the high notes
fields.trailText: Bristol Rovers 1 - 1 Wigan Athletic
fields.byline: David Foot  at the Memorial Stadium
fields.body:
Just as Welsh rugby was once renowned for conveyor belts laden with talented fly-halves, Bristol Rovers has come to specialise, it seems, in discovering strikers. The latest, Nathan "The Duke" Ellington could be the best of them all.

This envied knack emanates from necessity. Rovers need to sign, refine and sell in order to survive. Marcus Stewart and Barry Hayles left regrets and tears when they went. Then came Jason Roberts, a young Wolves reserve, whose scoring feats have already increased his value tenfold.

Roberts was in the West Indies at the weekend on World Cup duty. And into his place came Ellington, an 18-year-old bought from Walton and Hersham a year ago for £150,000. There has been much internal excitement about his innate, often unorthodox, skills. He plays like a joyful schoolboy, leaping so high for the crosses that he is in danger of getting lost in the low clouds.

Against Wigan, promotion rivals who mocked their recent depressing form, Ellington twice nearly won the game. He was thwarted by Roy Carroll's fine save, then he was brought down just outside the box. Before that he combined dazzlingly with Jamie Cureton to set up Trevor Challis's equaliser.

Ian Holloway, the Rovers manager, said: "Gracious me, what a player Nathan is going to be!" Rawness and inaccuracy can still be seen. But Wigan's central defenders were extended by his unpredictability.

Wigan's manager John Benson continues to leave his leading scorer, Stuart Barlow, on the bench. Now the club could face a midfield problem: Alan McLaughlin (back spasm) and Mike O'Neill (hamstring) both left the field before the interval.

This was a competitive, at times attractive, match. Andy Liddell, given too much room on the right in the first half, put Wigan ahead from a free-kick in the fourth minute. Challis equalised after 19 minutes, the ball going in off the defender Scott Green. Near the end Mark Walters, agelessly ambitious, manoeuvred down the middle, only to chip into the goalkeeper's arms.

fields.headline: Preston have Wright answers
fields.standfirst: Showman fails to deliver but Burnley is booming with his arrival
fields.trailText: Burnley 0 - 3 Preston
fields.body:
Three weeks into life among the Second Division hoi polloi there remains something surreal about the latest stop of the Ian Wright circus - this epitome of cool, with his London swagger and gold teeth, rolling up at a town where Status Quo haircuts are still de rigueur. Something does not add up.

Perhaps the answer is obvious, as it was the time Mrs Merton asked Debbie McGee: "What is it that first attracted you to the millionaire Paul Daniels?"

But, even if Burnley have pushed out the boat to entice the former England international to the most unlikely of settings, it is a financial gamble which is already paying off. Witness the number of fans queuing outside the club shop for an Ian Wright Wright Wright foam hand (£5), the Wrighty scarf (£5) or the T-shirt (£9).

The crowd, 22,310, was the biggest at Turf Moor since the League Cup semi-final against Liverpool in 1983 and twice that of the corresponding fixture last season. Such is the frenzy that a season ticket has been introduced for their remaining home games. Had Posh Spice dumped David Beckham for Stan Ternent, it is difficult to imagine there would have been more of a fuss in the old cotton-mill town.

It is a pity, then, that the biggest showbiz attraction in these parts since Gerry and the Pacemakers appeared at the Mecca ballroom was left with only a bit-part role during a bruising, occasionally X-rated afternoon of good old-fashioned derby conflict.

His 36 years are perhaps beginning to take their toll, Wright managed only one effort on target, when the visiting centre-halves failed to clear a long punt from the goalkeeper Paul Crichton. In fairness to the ageing showman, it was probably Burnley's most incisive through-ball of the day.

"We handled him well all afternoon but we knew what to expect because our striker Steve Basham had played against him for Southampton last season," said the Preston defender Michael Jackson. "Their defenders said he was always nipping them, whispering things into their ears and other stuff. He was chirping away all game, saying this and that, but the secret is not to rise to the bait, otherwise he is al ready one up on you. Everyone in this division has total respect for Ian Wright but you cannot be in awe of him."

Burnley look safe bets for the play-offs but Preston have higher aspirations. Fluid and compact, they were always in control once Jackson had arrowed a header into the roof of the net after 84 seconds.

They refused to be embroiled in open warfare in the face of some less than subtle Burnley tactics, most diabolically a two-footed, studs-up lunge by Lenny Johnrose on Sean Gregan that left the visiting captain with six stitches to a shin wound. That was missed by the referee John Kirkby but before long the hosts' recklessness proved to be their own downfall, Dean West seeing red after chopping down Iain Anderson twice in quick succession.

His exit, after 38 minutes, left an air of vulnerability to Burnley in the second half, with the home side forced into attack and gaps appearing for their opponents to exploit. Jon Macken and Rob Edwards duly obliged with two daisy-cutters and the party had been well and truly pooped.

To more than a few splutters of indignation Wright somehow managed to be named as the sponsors' man of the match. By then, however, the champagne was probably flat anyway.

fields.headline: Little success, much intrigue
fields.trailText: WBA 0 - 3 Birmingham
fields.body:
Do not be too surprised if Brian Little seeks advice from his local trading standards officers in the not-too-distant future.

What he has discovered since becoming West Bromwich manager appears to bear little resemblance to the brochure that attracted him to the job.

Having worked for Doug Ellis at Aston Villa, Little is no stranger to the vagaries and often impossible demands of football suits. It appears, though, that when it comes to comparing his former and present boardrooms, Deadly Doug plays Squirrel Nutkin to the Hawthorns and their Borgias.

"Too many people are poking their noses into my business," Little said after this defeat had consigned Albion to the relegation zone.

"Clubs have been approached for players without my knowledge and managing here is very difficult. I seem to be battling against every element and everyone seems to be talking behind my back."

At least the dwindling band of supporters were up front enough to make very public their dissatisfaction with Little as Albion continued their freefall down the First Division. But no amount of managerial know-how can legislate for the philanthropy dispensed by Albion's defenders, who ensured the game was over after only eight minutes.

Dele Adebola capitalised fully, scoring twice, prompting Trevor Francis to describe the striker as "unstoppable". The manager could also have added that his central defensive pairing of David Holdsworth and Darren Purse was immovable.

When Marcelo headed a third for Blues - after Albion's Icelandic central defender Larus Sigurdsson had been sent off - it was difficult to tell what was the louder: the cheering from visiting supporters or the noise of seats hitting their moorings as the home fans headed for the exit.

At least one, however, remained. "Sign him up as a striker, Brian," he urged as the Blues winger Stan Lazaridis dispatched the ball into Row Z.

Black humour survives along with the intrigue at the Hawthorns.

webTitle: Charlton ready for better than first in the First

fields.headline: Charlton ready for better than first in the First
fields.trailText: Bolton 0 - 2 Charlton
fields.byline: Martin Howey at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
Charlton's relentless surge towards an instant Premiership return shows no sign of abating. This was a club-record-breaking 11th successive league win and it not only swept them 10 points clear of their nearest rivals Manchester City but also served as a warning to some of the more complacent big guns in the Premiership.

Relegated sides are not generally famed for responding positively to a spot of downgrading. Taking this season as an example, you need look no further than last year's fellow dumped clubs Nottingham Forest and Blackburn Rovers.

But for Charlton, it is a different story. Not quite good enough for the Premiership last time around, they have made it their business to prove that the First Division is no longer quite good enough for them.

And, under the wily guidance of the likeable Alan Curbishley, they are running away with the championship while the so-called bigger duo of Forest and Rovers continue to wallow in their own misery.

Charlton are adamant that if - they don't like to use the word when - they return to the big time, they will be far better prepared. They are big enough to admit that perhaps a certain naivity cost them dearly last year, and are determined not to find themselves entangled in football's yo-yo syndrome.

Late goals from Martin Pringle and the hugely underrated Andy Hunt left Bolton bewildered if not entirely bewitched. The Wanderers had managed to keep Dean Kiely on his toes for the bulk of the second half before Pringle danced his way through a ragged rearguard for a stunning 80th-minute finish.

Hunt then calmly steered home his 19th of the season after the hapless South Africa defender Mark Fish had erred for the second time within a minute. Costly errors indeed for the FA Cup semi-finalists, for whom promotion has now been reduced to a pipe dream.

Charlton's industrious midfield man Graham Stuart said: "Promotion is there for us on a plate now, although we will not be getting carried away. The only thing that can stop us now is ourselves."

Curbishley's side, still clinging to the homespun philosophy that makes the club so popular with football lovers, are exuding such confidence that they will doubtless re-enter the Premiership with something of a swagger.

"That was our 11th league win on the spin," said the Charlton manager. "And I've never known anything like that throughout my entire career. Maybe I will now be able to rest one or two players."

The game will be all the better for it should Charlton manage to go up and stay up. They thrive on a simple style based on crisp passing and outstanding movement off the ball, which is sadly no longer enough in the land of the overpriced and overpaid.

So, if you can't beat them, then join them. No one will need to tell the First Division's runaway leaders that an injection of hard cash will be necessary this summer.

webTitle: Taylor looks to the cut that lies beyond the miracle or not

fields.headline: Taylor looks to the cut that lies beyond the miracle or not
fields.trailText: Watford 1 - 2 West Ham
fields.body:
This, thought Graham Taylor, was where the miracle was going to begin, the miracle of Premiership survival. "You can't give up on that belief," he said before this defeat, Watford's 15th in 19 games, "but I'm probably in a minority of one."

It may be one now. It looked like two on Saturday morning. Watford were 11 points short of safety and the defender Mark Williams was warning against complacency. It fell on deaf or disbelieving ears.

In three minutes brisk attacking and slack marking had given Steve Lomas a goal. In six, as Peter Kennedy crashed a header against the bar, Taylor must have felt much like the public have over cash machines: heads the bank wins, tails the customer loses.

By half-time Paulo Wanchope had gangled past Robert Page for a second goal. Watford had hardly offered. "For the first time," said Taylor, admitting it hurt him to say it, "it looked as if the players had given up, saying 'we are not up to it'. Either you say something or do something. It saves words if you make three substitutions." Heidar Helguson's goal gave the home side half an hour to find an equaliser. Page's last-minute header was tipped over by Craig Forrest. Pride was salvaged but no point.

Williams, one of those substituted, may have reckoned without West Ham regrouping after conceding four goals in each of their previous two games with a suspect keeper. Marc-Vivien Foé and Frank Lampard brought central cohesion. Trevor Sinclair, pushed up, restored thrust in Paolo di Canio's continuing absence. Joe Cole was rested, a luxury too far.

Taylor, by contrast, reckoned on his team maintaining the level of performance they had shown against Leicester and Chelsea. If, internationally, he could spot a journeyman at 50 paces - and pick him - at club level he has always had an eye for men of heart who respond to his tactical pragmatism and respect his honest enthusiasm. His spirit at least is undimmed, his financial responsibility exemplary.

"We've got to look realistically at the progress we've made," he said, "and remember where we've come from. A culture of change is emerging in professional football. If we don't meet those changes, there can be no guarantee we'll get another chance. We've got to get the football infrastructure right and that can be achieved whatever division we play in next season."

Taylor believes they are ready for the "massive cut this summer, at the next TV deal, when it will be imperative to be a top-30 club". So many will float, the rest sink.

"There are big decisions to be made at boardroom level," he said, daring to let slip the words "parachute money". He had ended his programme notes with "Keep the faith".

Reverting to the first half, he said there would be "soul-searching". The day's Elton John song before kick-off was Recover Your Soul. That, though, is the one thing intact, thanks to Taylor. The miracle now must be a little bigger.

webTitle: Gunners leave chase to the last

fields.headline: Gunners leave chase to the last
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1 - 1 Arsenal
fields.body:
The chase for a place in the Premiership often wandered wearily off course here yesterday. A 1-1 draw, secured by Lee Dixon's second goal in four days, restored Arsenal to fourth in the table but the overall performance of Arsène Wenger's team did not suggest a passionate desire to finish in the top three and reach next season's Champions League.

Aston Villa seemed to be heading for the victory their greater urgency deserved when Richard Walker, a 22-year-old striker starting his first Premier League game, nodded them in front just past the hour. It was only then that Arsenal appeared to realise they were not playing in a testimonial match.

While Villa will be disappointed not to have won, the result has extended their unbeaten league run to 10 matches. The clouds of doubt over John Gregory's future as manager have now dispersed and, while Villa may struggle to earn a Uefa Cup place through their league position, an FA Cup semi-final against Bolton Wanderers ought to see them at Wembley in May.

Yesterday Gregory's team needed half a game to get going. They began by showing Arsenal too much respect, the defence falling back and leaving one of the best passing sides in the Premier League a generous amount of space in which to demonstrate their craft.

After half-time, however, Arsenal were given less time to turn with the ball and found their forward runs blocked. Villa, moreover, showed a greater inclination to push men forward and reach the byline.

Such vapid Premier League displays by Arsenal away from Highbury are becoming a habit. Yesterday's performance, a sharp contrast to their 5-1 win over Deportivo La Coruna in the Uefa Cup three days earlier, mirrored the pattern of their 3-2 defeat at Coventry on Boxing Day, when they did not increase the tempo of their game until late on.

None of Wenger's attacking talents distinguished himself. Dennis Bergkamp, suffering from a knee injury, gave way to Marc Overmars for the second half but the addition of much needed width on Arsenal's left flank merely brought out the excellence of Mark Delaney, the Villa right wing-back.

In midfield Patrick Vieira and Emmanuel Petit were dominant before half-time but saw their authority eroded by Ian Taylor and Steve Stone. Eventually Petit, having had a spat with Stone before being booked for a foul on Paul Merson two minutes later, was quickly taken off to spare the Frenchman further punishment.

Since Petit offered a one-fingered gesture to the stands as he walked to the bench such a thought may prove optimistic. The Football Association comes down hard on players who indulge in digital monosyllabics.

For an inordinately long time the match had the passion and excitement of a car boot sale. Arsenal saw a lot of the ball but rather less of Aston Villa's goal since everybody showed reluctance to shoot from close range.

In the first half Villa relied on drawing the opposition forward so they could catch them with quick counter-attacks and, but for the experience and judgment of David Seaman, the plan might have worked. After 15 minutes Stone caught Vieira in possession and sent Julian Joachim scurrying through to meet Seaman one-on-one but the Arsenal goalkeeper flicked the ball away with one hand.

Seven minutes before half-time Walker set up Joachim with a similar chance but again Seaman was equal to the moment. In Joachim, at that point, lay the game's principal hope of salvation although Arsenal presented more of a threat once Wenger had abandoned the idea of using Thierry Henry as a lone striker supported by Bergkamp and Nwankwo Kanu.

Once Overmars appeared, Henry joined Kanu up front but by then Villa had found a more impressive attacking momentum. After 63 minutes Merson, whose touches had partly redeemed the depressing spectacle, curled a free- kick into a crowded goalmouth and Walker rose above Martin Keown and Petit to head in off the far post.

Arsenal at last roused themselves and saved the game when Dixon gathered Kanu's cleverly angled pass and drove the ball low past Peter Enckelman. If Dixon had ever before scored twice in four days he did not mention it.

Once Overmars appeared, Henry joined Kanu up front but by then Villa had found a more impressive attacking momentum. After 63 minutes Merson, whose touches had partly redeemed the depressing spectacle, curled a free- kick into a crowded goalmouth and Walker rose above Martin Keown and Petit to head in off the far post. Arsenal at last roused themselves and saved the game when Dixon gathered Kanu's cleverly angled pass and drove the ball low past Peter Enckelman. If Dixon had ever before scored twice in four days he did not mention it.

fields.headline: Collymore homes in with hat-trick
fields.standfirst: Things look up for Collymore
fields.trailText: Leicester 5 - 2 Sunderland
fields.body:
Stan Collymore was trouble from first to last again yesterday, trouble that is for a Sunderland team who could not handle the threat from this remarkable footballer. His hat-trick on his Leicester home debut included two of the finest goals you could wish to see.

It was a truly spectacular performance from a complex man who enjoys a colourful lifestyle off the field and who awoke yesterday to discover that a Sunday tabloid had revealed details of an alleged all-night drinking session in the team hotel the night before Leicester's Worthington Cup triumph last week. After this display the Sunderland players will testify that Collymore does not need a fire extinguisher or a large bar bill to wreak havoc.

At the finish he walked off clutching the match ball, submerged amid the back-slapping congratulations of his team-mates and with an angry riposte aimed towards the press. "It's just part of the topsy-turvy world of Stan Collymore," he said later. "I have not played a lot of football over the last 12 to 18 months and this is a superb feeling."

It was some vindication of Martin O'Neill's gamble in taking on a personality that Aston Villa could not wash their hands of quickly enough. He combined superbly throughout with Emile Heskey, who also contributed a goal. Peter Reid's side could count themselves unfortunate to have gone down to this scoreline - and to have met Collymore in this form.

Yet Stan being Stan there was every likelihood that this would be a signing that would backfire on Filbert Street. Within a week of his arrival O'Neill found it necessary to put the former England forward on a yellow card after a pre-Wembley trip to Spain ended in Collymore-inspired controversy and brought his team back early and under a cloud.

Yesterday Collymore was under no pressure from the Leicester faithful, who were still buoyed by their Wembley victory over Tranmere and in the mood to forgive any transgression. An early Collymore volley from a difficult angle warmed them up for what was to come.

His first goal came from the direct route - Ken Bates, eat your heart out. Gerry Taggart's free-kick was launched high and long and before it reached Heskey, Collymore was already making a run off him. As the ball bounced he needed no second invitation and a crashing volley zipped past Thomas Sorensen before the goalkeeper could move.

Leicester were two ahead by the break. Neil Lennon emerged strongest from a challenge with Chris Makin and his low pass gave Heskey the chance to drive between the goalkeeper's legs. It was somewhat harsh on a visiting side, who had twice hit the woodwork via a Kevin Kilbane free-kick and a deflected Alex Rae cross, though Reid had feared the worst.

"When I woke up and saw the papers I had an inkling it was going to be one of those days and that's how it turned out," Reid said.

Kevin Phillips suggested there was still life in the contest with a sharply taken goal on the turn but there was no upstaging Collymore, who cannot recall when he last notched a hat-trick in the Premiership. From a square-on position, 15 yards out as he received Lennon's diagonal pass, he somehow managed to apply pace and direction to his header for a memorable second.

After Niall Quinn had squeezed home a second Sunderland reply Collymore completed his hat-trick with a close-in shot that was really a miskick. Stefan Oakes's deflected free-kick compounded the Wearsiders' woe.

Reid, still awaiting any kind of Sunderland win in 2000, bemoaned his side's "sloppy, naive defending".

fields.headline: Things look up for Collymore
fields.standfirst: You wait 16 months for a Premiership goal and three come at once
fields.trailText: Leicester's new striker awoke yesterday to more lurid headlines about alleged drinking sessions with his team-mates. He finished the day with a hat-trick in Leicester's 5-2 demolition of Sunderland. As the man said after the game: "Welcome to the topsy-turvy world of Stan Collymore."
fields.body:
Leicester's new striker awoke yesterday to more lurid headlines about alleged drinking sessions with his team-mates. He finished the day with a hat-trick in Leicester's 5-2 demolition of Sunderland. As the man said after the game: "Welcome to the topsy-turvy world of Stan Collymore."

Collymore's goals were his first in the Premiership this season and he had not scored in the division since netting for Aston Villa, the club he departed under a cloud last month, against Tottenham 16 months ago.

After another alleged indiscretion even for this talented player it was hard to imagine how he could turn the spotlight back on to his football in his home debut for Leicester.

"My brief was to come here and score goals and repay the faith that Martin O'Neill has put in me and this is a good start," he said.

Collymore is now considering legal action over the newspaper report that he was involved in rowdy scenes which included a fight in the team hotel on the night before Leicester's triumph over Tranmere at Wembley in the Worthington Cup final last weekend.

It follows a controversial start to his Leicester career. O'Neill fined him two weeks' wages and handed him a final warning after the squad were forced to return home early and in disgrace from a pre- Wembley trip to Spain when Collymore let off a fire extinguisher in a hotel bar.

Last night he refused to discuss the latest story on legal advice but felt that a headline-grabbing performance on the pitch had done his talking for him.

"I have not played much football over the last 12 to 18 months and this feels superb," added the former England striker, who during a turbulent and unhappy stay with Aston Villa spent time undergoing treatment for stress.

"I only knew just before kick-off that I was playing. For me it's now all about building my match fitness and hopefully I can get a run of games in the side.

"My family have been tremendously supportive over the last couple of years and I hope that they will be able to enjoy a drink tonight."

Filbert Street's new hero did not say whether he would be joining them.

webTitle: Everton's salvation is a mixed blessing

fields.headline: Everton's salvation is a mixed blessing
fields.trailText: Everton 1 - 1 Sheff Wed
fields.body:
Here was something of a novelty for the less discerning, an end-of-season fixture played out beneath azure skies in the warm, milky sunshine of an early March afternoon.

If the preposterous notion of European qualification is discounted, Everton's season of water-treading and some progress effectively ended the previous week when the trouncing of West Ham ensured salvation was theirs.

If that achievement is not to be ridiculed, it hardly represents good box office. Only the most devout will continue to put hand in pocket as a series of now-meaningless fixtures unfold at Goodison Park.

As for Sheffield Wednesday, their season began to fall in upon itself back on opening day, when Liverpool won at Hillsborough with something to spare. The corpse has twitched a couple of times but generally Wednesday have been an embarrassment all the way down a line that leads directly to Nationwide football.

Wednesday are not the Premiership's worst side, they have simply convinced themselves they are. The betrayal of the manager Danny Wilson - and the recently departed chairman Dave Richards for that matter - by players who accept large salaries but little or no responsibility has been disgusting.

Wilson still believes in miracles but the manner in which his team spurned a glorious invitation to seize all three points suggest that those in boots rather than suits regard the die as cast. "Who knows, when it's all over this may be the one point which makes all the difference to us," he said. "We still have almost a third of the season to go and we in the dressing room still think we can get out of it. We need to put together a run and this might be the start of that run."

Wednesday grabbed a point in spite of their forwards, who spent the afternoon impaling themselves upon Everton's back line without once hinting at enterprise. Everton's lack of invention beggared belief but they still led at the interval, David Weir heading firmly into the top corner as Wednesday's defence stood in appreciation of Nick Barmby's corner.

Alan Quinn's vicious volley four minutes into a dour second period secured the Yorkshire side their point but the game's defining moment was delayed until the 67th minute, when Gilles de Bilde opted not to fall under David Unsworth's clumsy challenge. The suspicion remains that, in staying on his feet, De Bilde was merely avoiding the possibility of missing another spot-kick.

webTitle: Chelsea heed the call against all doubt

fields.headline: Chelsea heed the call against all doubt
fields.trailText: Newcastle 0 - 1 Chelsea
fields.byline: David Hopps  at St James' Park
fields.body:
We all thought we knew about Chelsea. Was this not supposed to be the collection of foreign imports who feel more at home in the Champions League than the Premiership, the side that would rather swank around European capitals than endure the bleaker callings of a Premiership winter?

In the first half of the season evidence abounded for such a contention. To find, therefore, that this Chelsea victory had propelled them, however briefly, into the top three of the Premiership and raised their expectations of qualifying for another Champions League campaign was to find a prejudice banished. Their undefeated run now extends to 11 league games.

Chelsea were unyielding, organised and even withstood a few flurries of north-east sleet without a shudder. They inflicted Newcastle's first Premiership defeat at St James' Park since Bobby Robson became manager, and they thoroughly deserved it.

For Newcastle, heading for mid-table stability, this match felt like a dress rehearsal for the FA Cup semi-final on April 9. That might have influenced Robson's unexpected experiment with a five-man defence, complete with Aaron Hughes man-marking Gianfranco Zola. The ruse was abandoned after half-an-hour, with Chelsea in control and a goal up, courtesy of Gus Poyet's near-post header.

For Chelsea there was little thought of FA Cup semi-finals, especially with Gianluca Vialli presenting the rest of the Premier campaign as "12 finals". If this season's Champions League initially encouraged Chelsea's Premiership complacency, the desire to qualify for the next Champions League is now driving them forward. A side showing five changes from the mid-week defeat in Marseille settled immediately.

For Ed De Goey, there was a club record of 22 clean sheets but Vialli was right to emphasise that this was an achievement Chelsea's goalkeeper must share with his team. They wrenched control of midfield, where Dennis Wise and Jody Morris thoroughly enjoyed themselves and, in central defence, Frank Leboeuf and Emerson Thome confronted Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson with great skill and presence of mind.

Leboeuf can rarely get through a match without encouraging mild derision. His indignation can be measured by the redness of his neck and, when Ferguson's holding and shoving persistently escaped punishment, the Frenchman became so enraged that he could have brought traffic to a halt in the city centre. For all that, he had quite a game.

Robson's first match in charge, a 1-0 defeat at Chelsea, followed Newcastle's disastrous start; Shearer said he wanted Chelsea to discover the extent of their improvement. That desire must wait until April 9.

Newcastle's best period brought a flurry of chances just before half-time - Ferguson twice heading wide - but the improvement did not carry over to the second half. Both Chris Sutton, who failed to punish Steve Howey's error, and Zola, who shot straight at Shay Given in stoppage time, should have made Chelsea's victory more emphatic.

For Newcastle supporters, this was a game best left unseen, or observed from the back of the new main stand, which some claim amounts to much the same thing. Was it really politic for the Prime Minister to be a guest of the club in the week of their shoddy high court victory against supporters campaigning against the loss of their seats to corporate hospitality? All this New Labour courting of business can go too far.

fields.headline: Nationwide round-up
fields.trailText:
First Division
Charlton's victory at Bolton kept the Addicks 10 points clear at the top but the performance of the day belonged to Portsmouth, who ended an 18-match unbeaten run by Ipswich with a 1-0 win at Portman Road.
fields.body:
First Division
Charlton's victory at Bolton kept the Addicks 10 points clear at the top but the performance of the day belonged to Portsmouth, who ended an 18-match unbeaten run by Ipswich with a 1-0 win at Portman Road.

The goal, almost inevitably, came from Steve Claridge, who bagged his 11th of the season after 26 minutes.

This defeat enabled Manchester City to move above Ipswich into second spot on goal difference.

 Huddersfield revived their fading promotion challenge with a 2-0 home win over Wolves. Martin Smith scored in the 20th and 34th minutes, his first goals since arriving from Sheffield United.

 Fulham suddenly found their goal touch at Craven Cottage, scoring three times in 34 minutes to send Port Vale deeper into trouble at the foot of the table.

Second Division

Bristol Rovers' draw with Wigan keeps them top of the table ahead of Preston, who won 3-0 at Burnley, but their neighbours Bristol City saw their 11-match unbeaten run end in a 4-1 defeat away to Millwall. They went 3-0 down in the first half, when Tim Cahill scored his second goal.

 Stoke City kept their play-off hopes alive with a storming 5-1 victory over bottom- of-the-table Chesterfield.

Peter Thorne turned the match into a personal triumph with four goals inside 53 minutes before David Reeves put the Spireites on the score sheet. The Norwegian Anders Jacobsen got the fifth in the dying minutes.

 Notts County, also pushing for a top-six finish, came unstuck at Blackpool, losing 2-1. Chris Lumsdon gave the Seasiders the lead on half-time; Mark Stallard equalised with his 11th of the season and Phil Clarkson got the winner on 75 minutes to lift Blackpool out of the bottom three.

 Gillingham left it late against struggling Oxford , but took the points with a Junior Bent effort in the 89th minute. They still have games in hand, thanks to their FA Cup exploits, and should make the play-offs.

 Danny Allsopp's 55th-minute winner for Wrexham made it 11 games without a clean sheet for Luton, and Scunthorpe have gone seven games without a win after a goalless draw with Colchester.

 Reading eased away from the danger zone with a 2-0 win over Bournemouth.

Third Division

Rotherham's lead was cut to three points after they struggled to a 1-1 draw at home to Plymouth.

It took a 76th-minute goal by Paul Warne to preserve the Millers' eight-match unbeaten run, after the visitors snatched the early lead through Chris Hargreaves.

 Second-placed Swansea closed the gap at the top with a 1-0 win at Barnet. Steve Watkin's 27th-minute goal means the former league leaders have now gone seven games without recording a clean sheet.

 Darlington also kept it tight at the top with a 4-1 win over Rochdale, stretching their unbeaten run at Feetham's to 17 games. The Quakers' Peter Duffield scored the first of his two goals after only two minutes, with Neil Wainwright and Marco Gabbiadini also finding the net.

 Hartlepool ended Northampton's five-match unbeaten run, Paul Stephenson and Graeme Lee scoring for the home side in their 2-1 victory.

 Peterborough moved up to fourth spot after goals from Andy Clarke and Jason Lee handed them a 2-0 win over lowly York.

 Bobby Zamora was once more the hero for Brighton with two goals as the Seagulls overcame Chris Wilder's 20th-minute strike to beat Halifax 2-1. Darryn Stamp was sent off after 55 minutes - the Shaymen's first red card of the season - and Brighton's Gary Hart also received his marching orders.

fields.headline: Scottish round-up
fields.trailText:
Teddies too nice

Rangers' recent stumble has offered the faint chance that the race for the Scottish championship may not be a foregone conclusion. With six out of the last 12 points dropped they are stumbling at precisely the wrong time of the season.
fields.body:
Teddies too nice

Rangers' recent stumble has offered the faint chance that the race for the Scottish championship may not be a foregone conclusion. With six out of the last 12 points dropped they are stumbling at precisely the wrong time of the season.

The manager Dick Advocaat, hunting around to make sense of the downturn, said after the goalless draw against St Johnstone at Ibrox: "Maybe the players should get angrier with each other. They are behaving like nice guys.

"In truth, it was just one of those silly games. Six days earlier they seemed able to score every time they attacked and ran up seven at Dundee. They gave the Saints a similar pounding but could not squeeze the ball over the line. These things happen."

The day will be long remembered by the 22-year-old Stephen Robertson, the third-choice goalkeeper for the club, thrown into the match in the 43rd minute after Allan Ferguson suffered a broken knee-cap. His saves prevented an upset but he remained sanguine. "It's up to the boss whether he sticks with me or goes out and buys someone older," he said.

 Dundee saved their best for last. After conceding 13 goals in the week they were a further two adrift at Kilmarnock with 15 minutes left before Eddie Annand and James Grady won them a point.

 Kilmarnock remain bottom but their manager Bobby Williamson was gracious. "After their week, they could have folded," he said, "but they didn't and all credit to them."

They are behaving like nice guys. "In truth, it was just one of those silly games. Six days earlier they seemed able to score every time they attacked and ran up seven at Dundee. They gave the Saints a similar pounding but could not squeeze the ball over the line. These things happen." The day will be long remembered by the 22-year-old Stephen Robertson, the third-choice goalkeeper for the club, thrown into the match in the 43rd minute after Allan Ferguson suffered a broken knee-cap. His saves prevented an upset but he remained sanguine. "It's up to the boss whether he sticks with me or goes out and buys someone older," he said.  Dundee saved their best for last. After conceding 13 goals in the week they were a further two adrift at Kilmarnock with 15 minutes left before Eddie Annand and James Grady won them a point.  Kilmarnock remain bottom but their manager Bobby Williamson was gracious. "After their week, they could have folded," he said, "but they didn't and all credit to them."

fields.headline: The greatest hyperbole ever
fields.trailText: Screen break Since when has Friday night at Edgeley Park been part of the on-screen build-up for Old Trafford on Saturday, asks Martin Kelner?
fields.body:
If Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole had stood in the centre circle, daggers drawn, and fought a duel to the death, while David and Victoria tried for their second child in front of the crowd at the scoreboard end, the Manchester United-Liverpool match might almost have lived up to the build-up Sky were giving it.

They started running promotions for the game last Tuesday. "The build-up to the big match starts with Arsenal v Deportivo," said Richard Keys, "and continues on Friday with the Nationwide League match between Stockport and Barnsley."

Eh? Quite apart from what Arsenal fans might make of their Uefa Cup tie being relegated to the status of starter for the Manchester United main course, since when has Friday night at Edgeley Park been part of the build-up for Old Trafford on Saturday? Has somebody started selling Greater Manchester weekend football packages; a gritty league match at Stockport, followed by the glamour of the full-on Old Trafford experience, and including a voucher for two free drinks at Quaffers night club?

If nobody has, I should like first refusal, plus the chance to have the Sky boys make the commercials. The opening sequence for Saturday morning's match was a classic; shots of the football alongside pictures of urban desolation - bomb craters, graffiti-spattered walls - setting up a classic confrontation. Just as well they gave it the heritage treatment, since a Liverpool teamsheet beginning Westerveld, Heggem, Henchoz and Hyypia, and managed by Monsieur Gérard Houllier, was not exactly hewn out of the cobbled streets around Stanley Park.

Even if you have no interest in football, it is worth tuning in to Sky for these opening and closing sequences. Invariably lovely to look at, they also give you the chance to catch up on any Britpop hits you may have missed.

Eleven o'clock on a Saturday morning was a little early, though, for such an assault on the senses, being rather too close to Friday night for some people and for others, Stan Collymore for instance, actually part of it.

Not that the awkward start time was about to knock the cheerleader in chief off his stride. "They could play this one at midnight, and we'd still be here to cover it," said Keys. What he failed to add was that if there were a commercial advantage Sky and the Premier League would not hesitate to switch the kick-off time to midnight.

"How different is the feeling in your stomach?" Keys asked his guest Lou Macari. This turned out to be not a cheeky reference to how the former United star might have spent his Friday night, but an invitation to participate in Sky's festival of bombast, which was in full swing.

"At any moment, in any season, and at any time of day, this is one of the most attractive fixtures in the world," said Keys, in that understated way Sky have made their own. "There was a European tie here on Wednesday," he said to Macari. "But this is the big one, isn't it Lou?" Dissent was clearly not an option for Macari, at least not until BSkyB's cheque clears.

Interestingly, ITV took an entirely different view. Despite anything you may have heard to the contrary, United's European tie against Bordeaux was in fact the big one. "The sights and sounds and feel of European nights on ITV will become very familiar by the end of March," said Sir Desmond, who went on to discuss with Kevin Keegan how interesting these European matches are compared to all that boring Premiership stuff, for which ITV, coincidentally, does not hold the rights.

In truth, sports broadcasting has become so competitive and subject to so much hype that the fan must now decide for him or herself what the big one is. Leicester v Sunderland, for instance, yesterday afternoon, appeared to be of limited box office appeal. However, on Sky Sports' Soccer Extra in the morning, Brian Woolnough of the Murdoch-owned Sun built its significance by referring to an exclusive story in the Murdoch-owned News Of The World alleging Stan Collymore's involvement in what the paper called a "5am bar brawl".

"That story will obviously run through the day," said Woolnough. "I wonder whether Martin O'Neill will stick by his promise to sack Collymore if he gets into any more trouble. It will be interesting to see if he picks him for the Leicester v Sunderland match, live on Sky this afternoon." Note the "live on Sky" line. Not strictly part of the news story, but Woolnough, bless him, knows on which side his bread is buttered, and he did give those who might otherwise have missed it the chance to marvel at the apparently beneficial effects of Stan's matutinal alcohol intake.

Finally, Film Four, as noted in these pages on Saturday, is running a season of movies about sport. Richard Harris's barely articulate rugby league player in This Sporting Life last night seemed a dead ringer psychologically for Collymore, Gazza, or any number of troubled soccer stars, although Saturday night's film Jerry Maguire might be considered more relevant to Premiership football, in light of the regular repetition of the catch phrase "show me the money".

webTitle: Liverpool lay down marker for future

fields.headline: Liverpool lay down marker for future
fields.trailText: Man Utd 1 - 1 Liverpool
fields.body:
So far this has been a non-vintage season for Manchester United - not a bad one by any means but, by United's own recent standards, rather ordinary.

Of course, the majority of the teams below Sir Alex Ferguson's side in the Premiership would dearly love to achieve such ordinariness, even for one game. And should Manchester United win the championship yet again, sentiments expressed by Graeme Souness when Liverpool completed a hat-trick of championships in 1984 may come to mind.

The decisive point having been achieved through a drab goalless draw at Notts County, Souness declared that "maybe by our own standards we don't deserve the title this time but by everybody else's standards we do".

Quite so. Having completed the historic treble of Premiership, FA Cup and European Cup last season with that as tonishing comeback against Bayern Munich at the Nou Camp, United were always going to be hard pressed to achieve much that was going to be considered out of the ordinary the next time around.

Now Ferguson's players are even treating the Champions League as a matter of routine and will this morning fly to Bordeaux confident of repeating in the Lescure Stadium their easy win over the French champions last Wednesday.

For, fitful though United's performances may occasionally be, no opponents have yet been able to sow a seed of self-doubt in the players' minds: not Chelsea, who defeated them 5-0 last October, and not Fiorentina, their conquerors in the second group phase of the Champions League.

Yet for a couple of seconds on Saturday a player well capable of sending a chill down Old Trafford's spine looked set to bring Liverpool a victory which might well have had Manchester United looking nervously over their shoulders.

Michael Owen, recovered from his latest hamstring problem, had just come off the bench for the last quarter-hour and wasted no time outpacing United's defenders as he gathered a through-pass from Danny Murphy and broke clear. Even with Rai mond van der Gouw quick to narrow the angle a goal appeared likely but, after seeing his shot beat the United goalkeeper, Owen then watched it bounce wide of the far post.

The scare was enough to persuade Ferguson to shuffle his back four, with Gary Neville moved in alongside Jaap Stam, Denis Irwin switched to right-back and Mickael Silvestre moved to left-back, where he would not be in Owen's sights.

After the match the United manager said that his was the one team trying to win but Owen should have won it for Liverpool all the same.

With Ryan Giggs rampant and David Beckham's crosses immaculate United dominated large areas of the game in terms of possession and territory.

But the policy of containment and counter-attack which had brought Liverpool a creditable victory at Arsenal and one stunning example of the shooting which had beaten Leeds at Anfield might have seen Gérard Houllier's team take a lead of two or three goals in the opening 36 minutes.

This is a much tougher Liverpool team than the pretty-passing, preening side that greeted Houllier on his arrival at Anfield to share the management with Roy Evans. As Ferguson observed: "I think Gérard has done very well. Not only did he make important decisions but he made them quickly. Now they're a very physical team. Apart from Vladimir Smicer everyone's over 6ft. This is a team that will battle hard in the English league."

Saturday morning's match was more a battle of wits than a muscular conflict although arguably the game did turn on one ugly tackle which went unpunished.

Manchester United had fallen behind shortly before the half-hour to another of Patrik Berger's thunderous free-kicks, this one awarded after Silvestre and Stam had become entangled trying to stop Erik Meijer, with Stam pulling the German back as he threatened to break clear.

Berger then saw a goalbound header saved by Van der Gouw and a shot on target from Titi Camara struck the unwitting Stam with the keeper exposed to emphasise the grip Liverpool were beginning to take on the match.

Then six minutes before half-time Ole Gunnar Solskjaer caught Sami Hyypia, Liverpool's most dominant centre-back, with a lunge which left the Finn needing stitches in a gashed leg.

Hoping, vainly as it turned out, that Hyypia could continue after half-time and having already lost Vegard Heggem with a hamstring problem, Houllier withdrew Jamie Carragher to his back four and played on with 10 men.

But in first-half stoppage time Solskjaer beat Dominic Matteo to a cross from Ryan Giggs and deftly turned the ball past Sander Westerveld.

Later Carragher denied United victory by clearing shots from Solskjaer, Giggs and Teddy Sheringham off the goal-line. For Liverpool it was an important point of order.

fields.headline: Pahars illuminates Hoddle's faith
fields.trailText: Southampton 1 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
To whisper "Eileen" around the Dell is to invite open hostility: such is the connection between Glenn Hoddle's faithful healer and negative publicity. Mention "Marian" though and the whole place lights up.

When the former England coach arrived on the south coast there was the usual helping of Hoddle-speak and self-delusion. When he then said that the Southampton squad, never far from relegation permutations, had quality in abundance, he aroused even more puzzlement.

However in Marian Pahars, Hoddle has inherited a dazzling talent from Dave Jones, whose gamble it was to attempt to transfer Latvian potential into the hurly-burly of the English game.

Gamble? How could it be when this electrifying front runner can combine speed with adhesive control? Gifts he can employ with deadly efficiency now Hoddle has shifted him over to the right touch-line, from where he can confront defenders head on.

Pahars also possesses the confidence to conjure goals such as the one that put Southampton ahead. Cutting infield he applied such pace and curl on the ball that it left Mark Schwarzer groping. The goalkeeper's excellence before that merely underlined the accuracy of the strike.

Paradoxically Hoddle was left wishing his team had found less exotic means to break the deadlock. "It was a wonderful goal and it lifted the whole stadium and maybe because of that our concentration levels dropped," he said.

He was referring to Middlesbrough's success in finding an equaliser within 30 seconds of the restart, Claus Lundekvam's tug on Hamilton Ricard yielding a penalty that the Colombian put away. It was a point Boro deserved.

webTitle: Spurs see the need for Hartson

fields.headline: Spurs see the need for Hartson
fields.trailText: Tottenham 1 - 1 Bradford
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin  at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Having turned to a former Arsenal manager for salvation, Tottenham are now looking to a one-time Highbury striker to solve their goalscoring crisis. By tomorrow John Hartson should have arrived for £6m. The 24-year-old has certainly looked a classic Spurs forward in recent months: injured.

Hartson has not played for Wimbledon since mid-December because of a knee problem but he is close to full fitness - if not match fitness - and held talks with Tottenham's chairman Alan Sugar and their director of football David Pleat at the weekend.

"Hopefully it will be completed by Tuesday," Pleat said yesterday. "It doesn't hinge on too much. There are one or two discussions yet to take place, but it looks hopeful."

Spurs undoubtedly know what they are getting. Their manager George Graham made Hartson Britain's costliest teenager when he brought him to Arsenal from Luton for £2.5m in January 1995, a month before his dismissal. The man who groomed him and then sold him at Luton was none other than Pleat. Sugar presumably sold the Welshman a computer at some point.

Given the chance to join up with two people who launched his career, Hartson is under standably enthusiastic. "John would love to sign if the deal is right," said his agent Jonathan Barnett. "Tottenham would be a dream move for him."

Spurs hope it will be a dream signing, though Graham insisted his search for new strikers would not end here. Hartson could thrive on David Ginola's crosses but Graham surely also sees him as a player off whom the talented Steffen Iversen can prosper. Despite his 6ft 1in frame, Iversen is most effective alongside someone good in the air and strong with his back to goal; a Les Ferdinand without the doctor's note.

Pleat feels Hartson could play an important role: "He's young, he's British, he's an excellent hold-up player and very good in the air," he said. "And if he's fit and fine he's excellent."

It is hard to imagine Hartson booting a team-mate in the head in a training session run by Graham but discipline remains a problem. Against Spurs in September he scored and was sent off. In a season interrupted by injury and suspension he has managed eight goals in 14 league matches.

That makes Wimbledon's willingness to sell bizarre. The chairman Bjorn Rune Gjelsten, skiing in Norway, said: "All decisions regarding buying and selling players are initiated by Egil [Olsen], and Sam [Hammam] is still involved like in the good old days."

This was nothing like the good old glory, glory days for Spurs. They could have been out of sight inside 35 minutes but had only Iversen's header to show and, after Jamie Lawrence's excellent equaliser, they lost their way. Perhaps Hartson would have taken one of the two chances that fell to Chris Armstrong.

"We've been short of firepower," Graham said. "That's probably what's let us down, with the injuries to the front men." Buying, he insisted, was more difficult than ever: "I don't think there's the quantity of quality players available."

Darren Anderton was neat in central midfield but, as Ginola faded, so did Tottenham's imagination. Bradford's spirit and occasional burst suggested that, with home games against Derby and Wimbledon to come, they could yet survive.

webTitle: Wimbledon left in disarray as Kinkladze restores home pride

fields.headline: Wimbledon left in disarray as Kinkladze restores home pride
fields.trailText: Derby 4 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.body:
Jim Smith billed this as "the point of no return" in County's relegation struggle. Giorgi Kinkladze took the manager at his dramatic word, responding with such skill and purpose as to mock doubters of the Georgian midfielder's talents.

Pride Park rose as one when Kinkladze departed with suspected calf trouble, after 72 minutes of a virtuoso performance in which he was carrier, supplier and, to boot, scorer of the breakthrough goal, his first for the club. Derby added three goals in his absence but the spectacle was never quite the same.

This is a foreign influence that Derby's supporters have taken to their hearts. They cannot wait for him to be converted from a loan player from Ajax into a permanent Pride performer.

Wimbledon's fans, having witnessed the heaviest of four successive defeats on the road, went away muttering darkly about the greater foreign influence at their club. It soon turned to loud protest with the news of John Hartson's impending exit to Tottenham. Andreas Lund, the latest Norwegian import, is no replacement in their minds.

The striker's transfer seems curiously timed with Egil Olsen freely admitting his team "are in a relegation battle" and can only compound doubts about the motivations of the Nordic regime, especially as Hartson's agent Jonathan Barnett says: "Tottenham have always been interested but have always been knocked back by Sam [Hammam]."

Wimbledon should become £6m richer but they will be immeasurably poorer if they ultimately surrender top-flight membership. Hammam, Wimbledon's former owner, has warned that, if relegated, the Dons will never come back. They are close to a point of no return.

Three of the four second-half goals they let in here were sucker punches. Olsen, looking more doleful than ever, was scathing. "It's about discipline and attitude," he said. "The second half was a relegation performance. We lost our heads, did some silly things; we were like small schoolboys."

After Neil Sullivan uncharacteristically let in Kinkladze's low, half-hit shot, collective rot set in. Derby's impressive 20-year-old newcomer, Malcolm Christie, having set up the Georgian, exploited indecision to fire his fifth goal in six games. Two substitutes, Deon Burton and Dean Sturridge, scored at leisure with a header and jab.

Wimbledon's fans, having witnessed the heaviest of four successive defeats on the road, went away muttering darkly about the greater foreign influence at their club. It soon turned to loud protest with the news of John Hartson's impending exit to Tottenham. Andreas Lund, the latest Norwegian import, is no replacement in their minds. The striker's transfer seems curiously timed with Egil Olsen freely admitting his team "are in a relegation battle" and can only compound doubts about the motivations of the Nordic regime, especially as Hartson's agent Jonathan Barnett says: "Tottenham have always been interested but have always been knocked back by Sam [Hammam]." Wimbledon should become £6m richer but they will be immeasurably poorer if they ultimately surrender top-flight membership. Hammam, Wimbledon's former owner, has warned that, if relegated, the Dons will never come back. They are close to a point of no return. Three of the four second-half goals they let in here were sucker punches. Olsen, looking more doleful than ever, was scathing. "It's about discipline and attitude," he said. "The second half was a relegation performance. We lost our heads, did some silly things; we were like small schoolboys." After Neil Sullivan uncharacteristically let in Kinkladze's low, half-hit shot, collective rot set in. Derby's impressive 20-year-old newcomer, Malcolm Christie, having set up the Georgian, exploited indecision to fire his fifth goal in six games. Two substitutes, Deon Burton and Dean Sturridge, scored at leisure with a header and jab.

webTitle: Labour on Livingstone: 'The people who know him best do not trust him'

fields.headline: Labour on Livingstone: 'The people who know him best do not trust him'
fields.standfirst: Guardian political editor Michael White on how the Labour party sees its maverick MP now
fields.trailText: Guardian political editor Michael White on how the Labour party sees its maverick MP now.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's claims to stand for London mayor in ''defence of Londoners' right to decide for themselves'' won little sympathy among fellow-Labour MPs tonight. There is little love lost between the the former LGC leader and colleagues at Westminster.

''The people who know him best do not trust him,'' said Frank Dobson, the man whose near-certainty of victory on May 4 - once he became Labour's official candidate last month - is now threatened by confirmation that he will now have a rival for Labour votes in Mr Livingstone.

Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, moved quickly to suspend Mr Livingstone from his party membership of 31 years - pending the result of an investigation which was also set in train tonight or his ''automatic'' self-expulsion if he files formal nomination papers by April 4.

And he will. After two weeks of uncertainty, as he tested the water and watched for opinion polls which might boost his chances, Mr Livingstone knew he could no longer hesitate. The die is cast.

Party officials at Millbank and ministers purport to be relieved that the uncertainty is now over. ''He'll have to defend his policies now. He loves playing the hero against the machine, that's what made him in 1987 and again now. But it won't be easy from here on,'' predicted one cabinet minister.

Mr Dobson's belated campaign for Labour's nomination was accident-prone and derided. But the ex-health secretary closed the gap as voting ended. The reason for hostility towards ''Chat Show Ken'' as his detractors call him is complex. Any MP who can attract more than his fair share of media attention always earns jealousy among less deft colleagues.

Mr Livingstone is a media star, as good a spin doctor as Alastair Campbell, as funny on TV as Tony Banks. That makes him a formidable populist, capable of running an ''insurgency'' campaign with media help against the party machines - just as Senator John McCain of Arizona is doing from the populist right in the US presidential race.

More serious charges are that (like Senator McCain) he is not a good team player, but a compulsive loner - ''the ego has landed'' was Mr Dobson's jibe tonight - who is an instinctive oppositionist, as likely to torment New Labour in government as he did the Thatcher government in the 1980s.

''With me, it's visceral,'' said one Northern Labour MP tonight. ''I hate the guy. All he's done since I was elected in 1992 is to attack the Labour party. What's he managed to achieve since he was elected in 1987, 13 wasted years.''

Mr Livingstone won 8 leftwing votes (plus his own) from London's 57 MPs in the electoral college. Several of those MPs look likely to back him in all but name - to do so would cost them their seats. But the Brent MP never took command of even the Campaign Group to become its post-Benn champion.

Tony Blair says he would like to have harnessed Mr Livingstone's talents despite his own experience as an unknown party foot-soldier during the heyday of the Livingstone-led GLC. ''People simply voted Labour out of loyalty,'' Mr Blair now says. ''Cuddly Ken is just a myth,'' says one senior colleague. The gloves are coming off.

webTitle: The murderer returns to the scene of the crime

fields.headline: The murderer returns to the scene of the crime
fields.standfirst: Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, writes from Santiago
fields.body:
The murderer returned to the scene of the crime walking, even though he was too sick to face trial, according to the British authorities. He arrived home on a sunny summer morning, smiling and saluting his supporters unaided, although he was released on humanitarian grounds for being gravely ill.

Once again Augusto Pinochet was laughing at the world and making a mockery of international law, as he had done throughout his 17-year dictatorship. Chileans witnessed the dictator's recovery, and perhaps had disturbing memories of that Tuesday in September 1973 when the armed forces took power. Once again the army was staging a display of force - another coup d'etat, though on a smaller scale.

The general got a Prussian-style, if low-key, reception when he set down in Chile. He was received at the air force's group 10 complex at Santiago airport, taken to a military hospital, and then, in an impressive military operation led by the "Cobra" elite unit, driven to his home on the outskirts of Santiago.

The government had no idea what had been going on. Juan Gabriel Valdés, minister for foreign affairs, later said the reception ceremony had been "a disgrace". But it was too late. The armed forces had shown without a shadow of doubt that they were in power. And on the same morning, the president, Eduardo Frei, left for the north of the country, and the president elect, Ricardo Lagos, went off to the resort town of Viña del Mar to chair a meeting of the future cabinet.

The murderer returned to the scene of the crime. He walked to the accompaniment of tunes such as Erika and Lily Marlene played by the army band - an image reminiscent of the time of the Nazi atrocities. The tyrant is indeed back home, and we still know of the concentration camps, the torture centres, the mass rapes and mass graves, and the untold suffering and injustice.

"We have withstood a lot of pain in the last 503 days," said Lucía Pinochet, one of the dictator's daughters. But what does she know about pain? This father was never in prison, but in a mansion in Surrey, and he was never tortured, never taken away in the middle of the night to vanish forever, never blindfolded and stripped naked and never had electricity applied to his genitals, tongue or head.

Viviana Díaz, who chairs the Association of Relatives of the Disappeared, believes that the former dictator's detention was a landmark as it ensured that no dictator would be able to travel around the world thinking himself immune from prosecution. Even though Pinochet went home in the end, the case set a precedent. "It is the most important trial since the Nuremberg trials," she said.

Yet Pinochet is still free. And contrary to the medical reports it seems his health is not so bad. He was supposed to be too senile and mentally incapacitated to face trial, but he had no problems recognising and embracing every commander-in-chief of the armed forces. He was so ill, we were told, that he would have to spend several days in hospital for a check-up - but, after spending only a few hours there, he was discharged from hospital.

The situation is shameful, sickening, and an affront to the relatives and friends of all those massacred by Pinochet's army. It is an affront to Patricio who learned one day that his brother had been arrested by the secret police. In the concentration camp, he was young and thin, but always smiling. But then his smile froze on his childish face, his dark eyes rolled back, and he never spoke again.

It is also an insult to Angélica, whose pregnant body was found riddled with bullets one cold winter dawn. She was kidnapped by the secret police and tortured before being murdered. Her assassins are still at large, just like Pinochet.

Only a fool would believe that Pinochet will be sent for trial in Chile, and that was why more than 6,000 took to the streets of Santiago to demonstrate their anger when his plane touched down. Human rights organisations, students, workers, shantytown dwellers and ordinary people gathered peacefully outside the presidential palace, but again met repression from the police. Even so, they managed to lower all the flags at Constitution Square to half-mast.

This murderer could turn up at the inauguration of the new president on March 11. And it would be highly embarrassing for the government, which did its utmost to bring the former dictator back to Chile, and for the British home secretary, Jack Straw, who released him. Above all, it would be an offence to the Chilean people.
