fields.headline: Warrior in the war-room
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: You might just think that this has been a busier, more confrontational, week than usual for Alastair Campbell. There was his savage letter to London Evening Standard editor Max Hastings complaining about the paper's coverage of Tony Blair's speech about the NHS. There was a trenchant article in the Daily Telegraph ridiculing the claim that the Times has become a government poodle and challenging the notion that the only real journalism is critical journalism. There was a note to Panorama editor Peter Horrocks about the programme's "outrageous" claim that the government is losing control of its devolution project.
fields.body:
You might just think that this has been a busier, more confrontational, week than usual for Alastair Campbell. There was his savage letter to London Evening Standard editor Max Hastings complaining about the paper's coverage of Tony Blair's speech about the NHS. There was a trenchant article in the Daily Telegraph ridiculing the claim that the Times has become a government poodle and challenging the notion that the only real journalism is critical journalism. There was a note to Panorama editor Peter Horrocks about the programme's "outrageous" claim that the government is losing control of its devolution project.

In between, there were the usual twice-daily encounters with lobby correspondents that have become the stuff of legend. If they were televised, these contests between Campbell and the parliamentary journalists would surely win a Bafta. If you want just a flavour - expletives deleted, all contributions summarised - log on to the government's website www.number-10.gov.uk/default.asp?PageID=31 and enjoy! Friday's questioning on Mozambique is a fine example of the genre.

Convinced that the government has acted too slowly, and confident that there has been a row between ministries, if not ministers, the journalists ask the same question over and over while Campbell, obviously in increasing frustration, repeats a series of denials. A verbatim account would be a great deal more informative (and entertaining) but the fact that we can all get some idea what is said at lobby briefings does help to crack the ridiculous mystique of this outdated ritual.

Anyway, to get back to the point. The week was, in fact, business as usual for Campbell. Both the public and private rebukes to the press do not represent a turning point. He isn't doing anything particularly unusual. That's how life is nowadays at the No 10 press office or war-room, as it should be known.

While it's doubtful that the government will, in the words of my colleague, Polly Toynbee, "launch a full-frontal attack on the press," it is certainly going to maintain its guerrilla war.

An analysis of the Evening Standard story shows why. First, the headline: "Crisis? What health crisis?" This suggested that Blair was refusing to accept that the NHS was facing difficulties. Yet in a key passage of his speech he said: "There are real problems, some of a deep and long-term nature and they will require time and money and change to put right."

Given that sentence, how can the editor defend such a biased headline? Incidentally, it was doubly bad because it was a calculated echo of an infamous headline in 1979 ("Crisis? What crisis?") which is generally thought to have sunk another Labour prime minister, James Callaghan, when he came back to Britain during a period of strikes known as the winter of discontent.

Yet Callaghan never said those words. They were composed by an editor and have been misattributed to Callaghan ever since. They were a disgrace then, and the Standard's headline was equally heinous.

One further point from the Standard dispute. The paper made much of the fact that a woman who shouted "liar" at Blair "was quickly escorted from the building," suggesting that she had been evicted by government officials. In his letter to Hastings, Campbell pointed out that the woman left the building of her own accord. webTitle: They're only 0.3mm long - but look like rhinos and eat your skin

fields.headline: They're only 0.3mm long - but look like rhinos and eat your skin
fields.standfirst: Simon Hacker  on the creepy-crawlies that live in your car
fields.trailText: Simon Hacker on the creepy-crawlies that live in your car
fields.body:
As all integrated transport fans know, we're spending far too much time in our cars. Well-informed biologists will also point out that wherever humans hang around, a parasitic convoy of small creatures happily follow. Whether it's the moist delights of the air conditioning or the sumptuous comforts of the upholstery, your car is becoming a des res for all manner of creepy crawlies.

Some are so small that you have no chance of spotting them. Take the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei, measuring just a quarter of a millimetre. Responsible for the (pre-car) deaths of Herod, Antiochus and pope Clement VIII, the bug can stop over on textiles before boring under your skin, so causing the unpleasant irritation known as scabies. Sarcoptes is usually transferred between very friendly humans, but merely sitting in a recently occupied car seat can facilitate its transmission.

Parasitologist professor Dennis Jacobs of the Royal Veterinary College says Sarcoptes has the ability to survive in car upholstery, though he stresses that we should be more concerned about the cat flea (Ctenocephalides felis), which likes nothing more than a human meal and is a far more successful car-seat parasite. "Cat fleas live on cats and dogs and when you're transporting either, the fleas' eggs can drop off into the upholstery, where the first life cycle stages take place, before the parasite moves off to feed. We advise pet owners spraying their homes for fleas to always fumigate their cars as well."

Then there's the common dust mite Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus (see right), a mere 0.3 mm long but similar to a rhino in shape. These mites feed on skin scales that have been predigested by mould fungi, and, particularly if you have dandruff, are not averse to hanging around on your headrest. Their airborne excrement can trigger asthma and other allergic reactions.

There are more visible hazards of course. Zurich Insurance recently paid out against a write-off after the driver lost control of her car because a spider was dangling from her sun visor. Winged bugs, say insurers, can be just as lethal. Dundee driver Ross Keany got into such a flap that he wrote his Ford Escort off when a wasp buzzed him. "By the time I'd got it out of the window" he said, "I looked around to see a stationary car in front. I slammed on the brakes, but it was too late."

Still, Norwich Union's research of bug invasions suggests that the nastiest incidents are in hotter countries. "There's a particular problem in Florida where air conditioning vents are big enough to allow creepy crawlies through," says a spokeswoman. "One woman driver set off and switched on the air conditioning, whereupon a scorpion shot out of the dash and onto her lap. She then crashed."

Air conditioning houses other nasties, too. If you find your nostrils being assailed by a stale whiff when you prod the AC button, your system has contracted a sort of air-con flu, caused by a range of germy micro-organisms. Larry Morgan, the boss of VRS, London's biggest air-conditioning fitting specialists, says the bacteria like to colonise insulation material and the evaporation box, where it's warm and wet. "Systems need to be regularly cleaned with manufacturer-recommended biocides," says Morgan.

The AA is taking a keen interest in research on the air-conditioning stink. "Although they are not likely to cause human infections, they may, in the worst cases, trigger asthma-like symptoms," says technical expert John Stubbs. "The main problem is inexplicable smells."

The smell is attributable to airborne particles from the resident bugs. Cleaning your car will not remove such odours, but Rentokil advise that a tidy interior is one that is less likely to be blighted by unwanted organisms of all sizes.

It's not just creepy-crawlies who will move in and call your car home. Mice will too, given the opportunity. According to classic car collector Teri Olcott, "Mice eat through seat covers and chew off pieces of foam and padding for nests and stuff it into air vents and other small places." They also, she says, chew up wires and generally cause a stench. "They can squeeze through tiny holes. If you can stick a pencil through any hole in your car, a mouse can get in."

Predictions of a warmer climate suggest UK cars will become even more of a target for pests, some of which may be quite unexpected. Specific orders of insects can live only within certain sets of seasonal temperatures, so if our mean temperatures jump just a notch, we may well play host to the kind of exotic crawlies that are, just for now, safely abroad.

webTitle: Me and my motor  Mike Oldfield

fields.headline: Me and my motor  Mike Oldfield
fields.trailText:
What are you driving?

A new green Mercedes S500.
fields.body:
What are you driving?

A new green Mercedes S500.

What does that say about you?

I like comfort.

What do you like about it?

It does everything for you. The steering wheel lifts up to let you in and the doors lock themselves. I particularly like the GPS navigation system. I can programme in my local pub or restaurant and it takes me there. It's big enough for all my 5 kids to squeeze into. There's a radar so if anything comes close it lets me know. The only downside is that it's large so parking can be a nightmare.

Why did you buy it?

I want to be comfortable when I'm driving and not hassled.

What kind of driver are you?

I need to drive slowly because my daughter suffers from car sickness.

Any bad habits?

Once in Ibiza I ended up on a crash barrier. I was banned for a year for drink driving. I learned my lesson.

What was your first car?

A mini, which cost £60 from a scrap garage.

What do you use your car for?

Going to restaurants, pubs, tootling around town and theme parks for the kids.

Have you ever experienced roadrage?

No. I don't understand it.

What sort of state is your car in?

I like to keep it perfect and beautiful. I get annoyed with people who drop sweet wrappers. I do smoke in the car but the ash tray is tucked away.

What's in the boot and the glove compartment?

Nothing but manuals.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

Yes, but not in this one. Not yet. I did in my Porsche. It's true what they say with the windows - they do get steamed up.

What do you listen to on the road?

I hate having music on. I've gone off radio with DJs chattering like idiots. I love the silence of a quiet car. I just listen to the computer's instructions.

What would be your dream car?

I'm driving it. I've had all the cars I want: Ferrari, Porsche, Bentley.

Who would be your dream passenger?

It would be me. When I was banned I enjoyed being the passenger. It's tiresome having to steer. I enjoy looking around. I don't like people who chatter.

fields.headline: Big deal
fields.standfirst: Ford has finally dropped some prices, but it will take more than that to get us into their showrooms.   Richard Simpson  on where the bargains really are
fields.trailText: Ford has finally dropped some prices, but it will take more than that to get us into their showrooms. Richard Simpson on where the bargains really are
fields.body:
Last Autumn Ford's chairman and managing director Ian McAllister took out full page advertisements in national newspapers promising car buyers that they could buy a new Ford with confidence, because despite all the "rip-off Britain" talk Ford's new car prices weren't about to be slashed. And to back this up he promised anyone who did buy a new Ford a refund if the company did subsequently cut prices; although that guarantee only lasted until the end of last year.

If you took Mr McAllister at his word and bought a new Ford Focus last autumn you might be advised to look away now, because last Friday Ford dropped - or "realigned" in Fordspeak - the prices of their Focus range by up to £1,000. So the 1.4 litre CL 5-door Focus, previously £13,000, has just come down to £12,000 - a cut of just over 7.5%.

The Consumers' Association has enraged much of the British car industry with their ceaseless attacks on what they see as rip-off car prices, and Phil Evans, their senior policy adviser, is in no doubt as to the significance of Ford's announcement: "Every pound taken off the price of a Focus is an admission of guilt. This announcement is proof that they have been taking British consumers for a ride and makes a mockery of their so-called 'price promise'."

Another explanation for Ford's decision is that competition has simply got stiffer, not least because private buyers have been giving car dealerships a wide berth for months, and Ford has simply been forced to respond to market movements. During the few months in which Ford has been trying to hold the line on prices many other car makers have cut theirs very substantially. Recently Mitsubishi cut their prices by an average of 10%, and other car makers have been doing much the same, albeit more subtly.

Saab and others have been enhancing the specification of their models substantially without increasing prices, while Nissan used the launch of their new Almera, which went on sale last week, to radically alter their pricing structure. The new Almera is an altogether superior car to the model it replaces, yet the new 1.5 litre E model is priced at £10,700 - some £800 less than the outgoing equivalent. And what's even more significant is that even at Ford's new prices the £12,000 Focus 1.4 litre Zetec 3-door is still £1,300 more than the equivalent Almera.

Ford doesn't only have its direct competition to worry about either, because the internet is causing problems too. Online buyers can now cut out British franchised dealers and simply import their new cars from Europe. The Consumers' Association will launch their own carbusters.com import service at the end of this month, and they expect to undercut even Ford's new prices. For instance the Focus 1.6 LX 5-door is now listed at £13,500, down £500, but that saving seems insignificant when carbusters.com claims that it expects to be able to sell you the same car for just £10,323.

Meanwhile Vauxhall has stolen a march on Ford when it comes to selling in cyberspace, because their ".com" range of cars is only available over the net and is attractively priced. For example the Astra.com costs £11,500 - excellent value against the nearest equivalent Focus at £13,500. To make matters worse for Ford the online brokers offer good deals on the Focus too: newcarsdirect.co.uk was offering the Focus 1.4 CL for just £11,851.55 when I checked, and that was based on the old list price of £13,000. However the list price is now down to £12,000, but newcarsdirect.com's MD Richard Sanders says that Ford's realignment will simply allow him to cut the car's online price further - maybe right down to £10,850.

So does all this price cutting and on-line competition suggest that prices still have further to fall? Once again Phil Evans of the Consumers' association is in no doubt. "Prices must be cut further across the board. Our message to consumers is to hold off from buying a new car in the UK as your pressure on the car manufacturers is beginning to bite."

However some trade observers such as CAP, which publishes the trade car price bible, the Black Book, suggests that this analysis is simplistic. What really matters is the actual selling price of a new car - called the transaction price - rather than the list price. CAP's senior editor Daren Wiseman says that "the list price tends to be a starting point for negotiations, and by waiting for it to come down consumers are missing out on some tremendous deals". And CAP's chief economist Mark Cowling adds that he thinks that at the new prices the highly-rated and in-demand Focus represents "a very good buy indeed".

So Mark Cowling's view is that the new Focus's prices won't fall further in the short term, but this doesn't mean that he thinks everything in the market is good value now, nor that overall prices haven't got further to fall. "Overall we expect prices to stay flat or to fall slightly, and I'd expect to see some good tactical deals this summer on cars that are in the middle of their life cycle, or are that bit older." As an example Cowling points to the deals available on the Citroën Saxo at present, and he adds that while the VW Golf's price is unlikely to fall there may be special deals on the older, less fashionable Passat.

The complicating factor in all this is that trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has now received the competition commission's report into car pricing, and although the department of trade and industry can't say when the report will be published it seems likely that it will see the light of day within the next two months. Some rumours suggest that Byers will come down hard on the car industry, which would almost certainly mean further price cuts, but even if he doesn't it's hard to see car prices going up again in the short term.

So unless you need a new car badly I'd be inclined to hang on a little longer, although it's worth doing some shopping online, using car brokers like newcarsdirect and vehicle locators like Autohit.com. And don't forget the real world dealers, because they're hurting badly and the car makers are trying to support them with juicy marketing incentives - which all helps to bring that all-important transaction price down. Because of this, Mark Cowling of CAP argues that this is a good time to go out and see dealers and listen to what they can offer - just don't buy until you see the tears in their eyes.

fields.body:
What is AltaVista?

AltaVista is a search engine which allows users to find information on any topic listed on web pages. It claims to have 45 million users across the world. Like other search engines, such as Yahoo!, AltaVista is branching out by turning itself into a portal, or a web destination in its own right. One of the few remaining independent search engines in the US, AltaVista is owned by internet incubator CMGI, which bought it from Compaq Computers. There has been widespread speculation that AltaVista may go public this year. Last year, AltaVista was estimated to be worth $5bn.

What is AltaVista's free access plan for the UK?

AltaVista is offering free and unlimited access to the web in the UK for an initial fee of between £30 and £50, with an annual renewal of £10 or £20. Once the initial fee is paid, AltaVista will give users a connection to a freephone 0800 number for internet use.

Is AltaVista the first to offer free access?

A few companies already offer completely free access. Screaming.net allows users to log on for free at weekends and off-peak times, but anyone wanting to use this service must sign up with the telephone company, Locatel, to access it. AltaVista's is the most wide-ranging scheme yet and could dramatically boost internet usage in the UK.

Will this lead to savings for British consumers?

Yes. Until now free access to the web in the UK has been a bit of a misnomer. Although companies like Freeserve, Britain's leading internet service provider (ISP), does not charge for access, users still have to pay for the phone charges. In the UK, unlike most of the US, internet access is charged at local phone call rates - estimated to cost each user about £126 a year, on average. The new deal could save Britain's internet users up to £700m a year in phone charges. The British government has welcomed AltaVista's plan, saying it should boost e-commerce.

How does Freeserve differ from AltaVista?

Freeserve customers pay no upfront fees but face phone charges of up to four pence a minute for daytime access. While Freeserve encouraged millions of people on to the web, the shock of big phone bills has deterred users from surfing for long. A Freeserve user spends about six hours a month on line compared with the 30 or so hours spent by net surfers in the US. AltaVista will not charge for phone calls.

How do companies like Freeserve make money from free access?

Freeserve and other internet service providers charge customers the cost of a local telephone call, and recover their own costs by taking a proportion of that telephone revenue (which British Telecommunications is required to share with the ISP's telecoms company of choice). AltaVista has not named its telecoms provider, but said it was not BT.

Won't AltaVista be swamped by new customers?

To cope with demand, AltaVista is to limit access to the scheme to 500,000 users in the first six months. Cable TV company Telewest suffered a series of service failures because of heavy demand when it launched its unmetered package last month. A stream of smaller ventures have suffered similar problems, hence AltaVista's graduated approach.

How are AltaVista's competitors going to respond?

Freeserve says it is working on its own cheap packages. BT has promised to launch unmetered access in the spring, but its plans have been delayed by a dispute with Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, and other ISPs. Other companies can be expected to match AltaVista, so it may not have the luxury of six months to limit access.

How is AltaVista going to make money from the scheme?

Its rivals say AltaVista stands to make big losses when it launches in three months' time. The company says it will make money from sponsorship and advertising and if it can show a huge customer base, it should be able to attract these sources of revenue.

Does AltaVista have the same scheme in the US?

The company has a similar service in North America, called Free Access, which has two million users and is adding about 10,000 a day. Unlike Free Access, the service for UK users will not carry a built-in advertising window.

Freeserve

webTitle: 'You can run but you cannot hide'

fields.headline: 'You can run but you cannot hide'
fields.standfirst: Reaction to the announcement
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair
"It is just important that people understand why I argued so strongly against Ken Livingstone as mayoral candidate, and it is because I believe passionately that he would be a disaster - a financial disaster, a disaster in terms of crime and police and business ... At least in a sense he is not my responsibility any more and it is up to the public to decide who they want to vote for."
fields.body:
Tony Blair
"It is just important that people understand why I argued so strongly against Ken Livingstone as mayoral candidate, and it is because I believe passionately that he would be a disaster - a financial disaster, a disaster in terms of crime and police and business ... At least in a sense he is not my responsibility any more and it is up to the public to decide who they want to vote for."

Frank Dobson, Labour candidate
"I have one message for him today - Ken, you can run but you cannot hide your politics from Londoners. I will expose your policies and the people that surround you every day, every week of this campaign and I will do it because you are dangerous for London."

Steven Norris, Tory candidate
"He's great good fun, he's got terrific one-liners, but he would be a lethal mayor,"

Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat candidate
"Ken Livingstone promised Labour that he would not stand, and now he has broken his word. If he's unreliable on this issue, how can we trust him to run London?"

John Prescott, deputy prime minister
"It would be hard for a government or an assembly to work with Ken Livingstone as Mayor when he's shown that you simply can't trust his word. He now joins the likes of David Owen and Derek Hatton in walking off into the wilderness, trying to split the party for the sake of personal advancement."

Professor Patrick Dunleavy, academic who devised the system to elect a mayor
"Livingstone's decision will energise the whole process. It will push turn-out up from 30% to around 50%. It's good for democracy."

Glenda Jackson MP, defeated Labour candidate
"I'm both surprised and sad.I can't think of anything worse than leaving the Labour party after being a lifelong member. That clearly is very hard... We are now in a position where the real, actual campaigning can begin... We have an intelligent electorate here in London and they will be asking tough questions about the politics."

Simon Sperryn, chief executive of the London Chamber of Commerce
"Whilst there is some support for Mr Livingstone, he still has a great deal of work to do to convince the business community as a whole that he is the right person for the job of mayor." he said.

William Hague
"Londoners will now get a real choice in May: between Ken Livingstone, a far left extremist who would be lethal for London; and Steve Norris, a Conservative who will deliver action not politics for London. This leaves the Dobson campaign dead in the water and the Labour party spilt down the middle. Frank Dobson was always a Downing Street stooge who never really wanted the job of Mayor - and today we know he'll never get it."

Paul Flynn MP
"I believe that there hasn't been an enormous amount of enthusiasm shown by Frank for this post and he knows that he is likely to face the nightmare of losing as the official Labour candidate and that is going to be humiliation for him. I believe there is another alternative which is a much more attractive one, that he says 'In the interests of fairness, I lost that election, I don't have the support of the Labour Party, Ken is the moral victor, for God's sake let Ken go ahead'."

Paul Boateng, home office minister
"On crime and jobs, Livingstone's is an empty candidacy. There is a void that cannot be filled by ego alone. Alone and isolated, without a single supporter amongst Greater London Assembly candidates, a Ken Livingstone candidacy, let alone a mayoralty, would be rudderless and at the mercy of every fad and faction."

fields.headline: Modern Times?
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade  passes judgment on two broadsheet revamps
fields.trailText: The Times, it is a-changin'. From next Monday it will look - well, in a superficial sense - rather like the Guardian. In other words, the main broadsheet paper will be complemented by a second section, tabloid-sized, just like G2 and named, wouldn't you just know it, Times 2.
fields.body:
The Times, it is a-changin'. From next Monday it will look - well, in a superficial sense - rather like the Guardian. In other words, the main broadsheet paper will be complemented by a second section, tabloid-sized, just like G2 and named, wouldn't you just know it, Times 2.

This transformation, planned in great secrecy with very few senior staff "in the loop", is the culmination of a long internal campaign by the editor, Peter Stothard, to change a paper which has not had a coherent configuration for more than a decade.

Due to publishing and printing problems, The Times has never found a successful way of presenting its sport, business, features and arts content, not to mention peripatetic TV listings. In a variety of ways these key topics have been tucked inside each other. Arts particularly has suffered and the introduction of a third broadsheet section about a year ago was also a compromise, hiding features away between business and sport sections.

Suddenly, though, and quicker than Stothard expected, News International's Wapping management solved the technical problems, and owner Rupert Murdoch was able to give the project the go-ahead. Stothard, editor for almost eight years, says: "At last, we can produce a classic broadsheet paper with the key core elements succeeding each other in a logical order: home news, foreign news, opinion and comment, obituaries, business and sport. In addition there will be a modern features paper, with arts, books, science, health, TV programmes and so on. It is a thrilling prospect."

It is also a daunting prospect, of course. Editors who press for editorial changes requiring investment and a great deal of management fuss must deliver. As one senior executive said: "It's a great vote of confidence in Peter. But he must make it work."

Murdoch, who was in London last week and evidently gave the new Times package the thumbs-up, will surely expect improved sales. But circulation has been erratic in the past year. the Times's six-monthly average shows that it is selling almost 4% fewer copies than a year ago.

Yet the Times was voted Newspaper of the Year in the recent What the Papers Say awards and can point to a good run of stories: the Glenn Hoddle interview that led to his resignation; the Michael Portillo interview about his past gay experiences; the exposure of an aged woman spy; and the revelations about Tory treasurer Michael Ashcroft's financial affairs.

None of this has shaken its main rightwing rival, the Daily Telegraph, from its sales perch above a million, and that old Murdochian dream of overtaking the Telegraph seems as remote as ever. There is a gap of nearly 300,000 between them and precious little sign of it narrowing. Unless, that is, Murdoch can find a way round the Office of Fair Trading's concerns and launch another phase of the price war. He has already agreed to the spending of "a substantial sum" on a TV advertising campaign. Will he dig deeper still?

Ahead of the Times's change come the revamp of the Independent on Sunday. Last week, six months after becoming editor, Janet Street-Porter unveiled a new-look paper. It was, surprisingly, rather restrained and dare one say it, sensible.

The paper has been reorganised in a more logical fashion. The Sunday review section, one of the paper's undoubted strengths, has been tidied up and rightly regained the book reviews. Will Self is an excellent choice as television columnist, ensuring that readers turn to the culture section. The strengthening of headlines gives the paper a better look, though the blue-backed masthead isn't in the best possible taste.

Reality, a new magazine replacing the old newsprint section, was unimpressive. It's difficult to know the reason: the A4 format, perhaps, the jazzy design or the hit-and-miss content. It doesn't come close to challenging the Mail on Sunday's You magazine.

But the real problem with the Independent on Sunday has never been the design, nor the lighter sections. What this supposedly serious paper lacks is seriousness. Apart from Alan Watkins, who remains readable but lacks verve, it has no regular political columnists to attract readers away from the heavyweight battalions at the Sunday Times, Observer and Sunday Telegraph.

Street-Porter's own column is hardly any compensation; just another one of those top-of-the-head, unresearched, unnecessary bits of floss based on wild generalisations and unrelieved by the genuine ability evident in, say, Julie Burchill's work.

One oddity is the decision to drop the seven-day TV listings. I understand some senior executives thought this too risky and reader reaction will be monitored. If there are too many complaints, they will be restored.

So will the new Sindy work? Having increased the cover price to £1.10p, after spending the past six months offering a range of price cuts, it is still touch and go whether it can halt the sales decline. After all, real sales, leaving aside 30,000 bulks, were just above 200,000 in January.

fields.headline: Reaping the whirlwind
fields.standfirst:
Alastair Campbell went into overdrive last week, attacking the press for its 'anti-Blair' stance. But is he losing it? Bernard Ingham warns him not to get into a war with the media.

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Alastair Campbell went into overdrive last week, attacking the press for its 'anti-Blair' stance. But is he losing it? Bernard Ingham warns him not to get into a war with the media.
fields.body:
It happens to all of them who get too close to the Parliamentary Lobby Journalists, to give the Lobby their Sunday name. After a tremendous love-in with the media, Harold Wilson made the fundamental mistake of giving preferential treatment to a group of senior Lobby correspondents who became known as "the White Commonwealth". The Lobby proles not unnaturally objected. John Major set his cap at the Lobby as a reaction to what he thought was the fierce Thatcher/Ingham regime - and look where that got him.

And now Alastair Campbell, the ventriloquist to Tony Blair's dummy, has cracked. After nearly three years of an unprecedentedly servile press and broadcasting in spite of his carrot-and-stick treatment of them - contempt combined with showering them with gifts of news of recycled initiatives and Blair articles - he is demonstrating he can't take it. Last week this already hyperactive political commissar who passes for a press secretary went into frenzied overdrive, laying about most of the Fourth Estate now that, to quote him in the Daily Telegraph, "the fashion is broadly to dump on [Blair]" since it is no longer "the fashion to be hugely pro-Blair."

To be fair to Campbell, with whom I had a civilised relationship when I was No. 10 press secretary and he was on the Mirror, the media are impossible. In their desperate quest for stories, they combine journalistic licence - the massaging of the facts to capture and hold attention - with gross over-simplification, selection (which means discarding the inconvenient qualifications), interpretation, the sort of heroic deduction which makes Sherlock Holmes look like nobut a starter, sensationalism, prejudice and, God help us, opinions. They are, in short, commercial.

In their quest for profit as well as truth and beauty, they render normal life impossible as they bait you, and in the background your leader seeks to ban this or that newspaper from the office, goes ballistic over the latest reported BBC excess and comes under pressure from party mischief makers. I can only imagine what it is like in Blair's No. 10 which practises government by media and focus group and consequently achieves little other than to secure a BBC ban on discussing Peter Mandelson's private life "under any circumstances".

But you can't have a free society without a free press, as Margaret Thatcher used to say through clenched teeth. And that means the media are free to be wrong, to be nasty, to be awkward, to be outrageous and, yes, to be irresponsible until such time as society cries "enough!"

Campbell's problem is that, as a political obsessive, he doesn't believe in a free press. As others have suggested, he was probably never a journalist, only a propagandist. He has no philosophical resources to fall back on. So this week he's gone barmy.

First, the government let it be known, according to this newspaper's Polly Toynbee, that it "is preparing to launch a full-frontal attack on the press - the prime 'force of conservatism'." That very night Campbell sent a letter to Evening Standard editor Max Hastings "despairing" of today's press for not saying nice things about his leader's umpteenth plan to improve the NHS.

And in between he started putting summaries of his morning and afternoon Lobby briefings on No 10's new website. This was the logical thing to do if you wish to find a way of preventing the purity of your message from being filtered into subversive hostility by Denis Thatcher's "reptiles." What's more, the idea is not new. Only the technology has changed. Sir Donald Maitland, the entirely rational press secretary to Edward Heath in the early 70s, canvassed the idea of a government newspaper until some of us departmental heads of information scornfully asked who would read such boring guff.

Moreover, Campbell's recourse to the internet in no way breaks the confidentiality of the Lobby confessional as it would have done in my day. In my time all Lobby briefings were unattributable and supposed to be between the government, if not solely the No 10 press office, and Lobby journalists. But Campbell put his briefings on the record. Journalists can now quote the prime minister's official spokesman - or PMOS as he appears on the internet.

Campbell has now opened up his twice daily press briefings to scrutiny via the internet by, among others, journalists, academics and political opponents and fellow obsessives. From now on, his daily contact with journalists will be monitored for mistakes of fact, for examples of party political propaganda, which would require the website to be funded by the Labour party instead of the taxpayer, and for paranoia. This last emerged on Day 1 with a splendid rant against "journalist spin doctors" over GM foods.

Why, he was even reduced to my level of ridicule of media obsession. He had, he said, "never heard the crowd at Burnley baying about GM foods" just as I used to tell the Lobby, when they pursued their own freedom of information act agenda: "That is not the first topic of conversation in the Two Ferrets in Hebden Bridge." There is nothing new under the sun - except the internet and Campbell's declaration of war on the media.

This is not exactly the way to keep friends in the media and influence people - as Joe Haines discovered when he pulled up Harold Wilson's drawbridge to the Lobby. Nor is it wise. The media always have the last word. They always fire the last shot. And when they choose to do so, they have a lot of scores to settle with this government, having been misled, stitched up, seen favourires rewarded, been abused and had themselves rubbished with their editors. Campbell was always going to reap the whirlwind.

What I had not expected of "homo sapiens" - as the Express's Peter Oborne compared Campbell to my "Neanderthal man" in the evolution of press secretaries - was to create the circumstances in which it was bound to start blowing. The function of a press secretary is to manage relations with the media not to make war with them, whatever the provocations. Yet Campbell has announced that a state of hostilities exists and has started deploying his weaponry. It would serve him right if the broadcasters behaved logically, now that he has broken Lobby silence by broadcasting his briefings on the internet, and demanded the right to put microphones and cameras into them.

Does Blair want him regularly fighting in the Lobby trench on telly, advertising this Government's belligerent decay? Think about it, Alastair.

In their desperate quest for stories, they combine journalistic licence - the massaging of the facts to capture and hold attention - with gross over-simplification, selection (which means discarding the inconvenient qualifications), interpretation, the sort of heroic deduction which makes Sherlock Holmes look like nobut a starter, sensationalism, prejudice and, God help us, opinions. They are, in short, commercial. In their quest for profit as well as truth and beauty, they render normal life impossible as they bait you, and in the background your leader seeks to ban this or that newspaper from the office, goes ballistic over the latest reported BBC excess and comes under pressure from party mischief makers. I can only imagine what it is like in Blair's No. 10 which practises government by media and focus group and consequently achieves little other than to secure a BBC ban on discussing Peter Mandelson's private life "under any circumstances". But you can't have a free society without a free press, as Margaret Thatcher used to say through clenched teeth. And that means the media are free to be wrong, to be nasty, to be awkward, to be outrageous and, yes, to be irresponsible until such time as society cries "enough!" Campbell's problem is that, as a political obsessive, he doesn't believe in a free press. As others have suggested, he was probably never a journalist, only a propagandist. He has no philosophical resources to fall back on. So this week he's gone barmy. First, the government let it be known, according to this newspaper's Polly Toynbee, that it "is preparing to launch a full-frontal attack on the press - the prime 'force of conservatism'." That very night Campbell sent a letter to Evening Standard editor Max Hastings "despairing" of today's press for not saying nice things about his leader's umpteenth plan to improve the NHS. And in between he started putting summaries of his morning and afternoon Lobby briefings on No 10's new website. This was the logical thing to do if you wish to find a way of preventing the purity of your message from being filtered into subversive hostility by Denis Thatcher's "reptiles." What's more, the idea is not new. Only the technology has changed. Sir Donald Maitland, the entirely rational press secretary to Edward Heath in the early 70s, canvassed the idea of a government newspaper until some of us departmental heads of information scornfully asked who would read such boring guff. Moreover, Campbell's recourse to the internet in no way breaks the confidentiality of the Lobby confessional as it would have done in my day. In my time all Lobby briefings were unattributable and supposed to be between the government, if not solely the No 10 press office, and Lobby journalists. But Campbell put his briefings on the record. Journalists can now quote the prime minister's official spokesman - or PMOS as he appears on the internet. Campbell has now opened up his twice daily press briefings to scrutiny via the internet by, among others, journalists, academics and political opponents and fellow obsessives. From now on, his daily contact with journalists will be monitored for mistakes of fact, for examples of party political propaganda, which would require the website to be funded by the Labour party instead of the taxpayer, and for paranoia. This last emerged on Day 1 with a splendid rant against "journalist spin doctors" over GM foods. Why, he was even reduced to my level of ridicule of media obsession. He had, he said, "never heard the crowd at Burnley baying about GM foods" just as I used to tell the Lobby, when they pursued their own freedom of information act agenda: "That is not the first topic of conversation in the Two Ferrets in Hebden Bridge." There is nothing new under the sun - except the internet and Campbell's declaration of war on the media. This is not exactly the way to keep friends in the media and influence people - as Joe Haines discovered when he pulled up Harold Wilson's drawbridge to the Lobby. Nor is it wise. The media always have the last word. They always fire the last shot. And when they choose to do so, they have a lot of scores to settle with this government, having been misled, stitched up, seen favourires rewarded, been abused and had themselves rubbished with their editors. Campbell was always going to reap the whirlwind. What I had not expected of "homo sapiens" - as the Express's Peter Oborne compared Campbell to my "Neanderthal man" in the evolution of press secretaries - was to create the circumstances in which it was bound to start blowing. The function of a press secretary is to manage relations with the media not to make war with them, whatever the provocations. Yet Campbell has announced that a state of hostilities exists and has started deploying his weaponry. It would serve him right if the broadcasters behaved logically, now that he has broken Lobby silence by broadcasting his briefings on the internet, and demanded the right to put microphones and cameras into them. Does Blair want him regularly fighting in the Lobby trench on telly, advertising this Government's belligerent decay? Think about it, Alastair.

webTitle: Can Levi's pull its pants up?

fields.headline: Can Levi's pull its pants up?
fields.standfirst: This week Levi's unveils its biggest-ever advertising campaign in a bid to claw back a slump in sales.  Belinda Archer  reveals life after Flat Eric
fields.trailText: This week Levi's unveils its biggest-ever advertising campaign in a bid to claw back a slump in sales. Belinda Archer reveals life after Flat Eric
fields.body:
Not since Nick Kamen oh so famously dropped his jeans in a launderette 15 years ago has there been such a significant moment in the history of Levi's advertising.

On Thursday night, the jeanswear giant will unveil its most ambitious campaign to date. Backed by its biggest annual spend ever (a notable 25% increase on last year) the offensive marks the fashion icon's unashamedly desperate bid to claw back lost territory in the casualwear market and salvage its ailing fortunes.

It has much to do: last year, Levi's reported a 14% slump in sales, marking its third year of decline and the steepest since 1985. Numerous factories have been shutting and nearly 13,000 staff worldwide have lost their jobs over the past few years.

Basically, no one is wearing jeans any more. Combats, cargo pants and khakis have taken over the flagging 501 in the youth leisurewear market, with Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger and Gap making damaging inroads.

But what has really torpedoed the appeal of Levi's for any self-respecting follower of fashion has been the sight of motoring pundit Jeremy Clarkson and, worse, Tony Blair sporting their very own denims. I mean, really, what clubbing teenager wants to dress like the prime minister? And when a youth icon has stopped, well, appealing to "youth", then something drastic has to happen.

Kenny Wilson, European marketing director of Levi's, comments: "We're in a very similar situation to the one we were in 15 years ago, when jeans as a category was in decline and there was a general lack of interest in denim. This is an important campaign. There's a lot riding on it, but we believe that we've got a strong product and an excellent campaign."

The new advertisements by Bartle Bogle Hegarty, the jean-maker's agency of 18 years' standing, embrace three 30-second TV commercials, back-cover ads in the style press and six-sheet posters around major UK cities.

Just like the hip, heavily soundtracked work that has been flogging the 501s for the past 15 years, it uses strong tracks (by Archive and Death in Vegas, as it happens) and makes the product the hero - only this time the product is not the 501, but a bold reinvention of the traditional five-pocket western denims, trademarked Levi's Engineered Jeans (or LEJs) and loftily dubbed "the next blueprint in denim design".

These new-fangled jeans were launched in stores across the nation a few weeks ago. They might look like any pair of baggy denims spotted on backsides in Notting Hill, but they are £50-worth of ergonomical design that closely follows the curves of the human frame. They have bigger front pockets (almost big enough to hold a moby, in fact), a curved bottom hem to make them lie more snugly across your trainers and a new peculiarly twisted side-seam, aimed at providing greater comfort and generally easier movement.

The campaign, specifically targeting 15-25-year-olds, picks up on this last feature with the endline "The twisted original". Each of the three commercials depicts an interesting twist on a traditional love scenario, showing - in one - a young couple getting increasingly sweaty together as they put more and more clothes on. The parents return, naked, and are shocked by the sight of the fully dressed youngsters. In the second there is a twist on the tale of Romeo and Juliet, as two star-crossed blow-up dolls dressed in the jeans come to a sticky end on a barbed wire fence. The third depicts two pairs of LEJs being separated on a production line, only to be reunited when they pass one day on the street, much to the embarrassment of their teenage owners.

Nigel Bogle, chairman of BBH, explains: "Levi's advertising has always come out of the form and function of the jeans. It is essentially product demonstration advertising, and we have executed this new work in a way that is very fresh and young. It has a speed and pace that is absolutely right for now - we are giving the brand back to young people."

The blitz will be concentrated over a four-week period to guarantee that the ads are seen by "young kids" everywhere. Not since 1997, in fact, has there been a campaign to promote Levi's jeans: last year, lest we forget, there was Flat Eric, but wildly successful though he was, his advertising was just a fun sideshow for the sub-brand Sta-Prest rather than a serious bid to promote the ailing main jeanswear.

Bogle says: "Flat Eric was a bridge campaign. He drew the curtain down on one era of Levi's advertising heritage and set up what we are doing now." The company's dilemma, of course, is that of any number of big brands today, from Marks & Spencer to Nike to British Airways, all of which are battling against the tide of a fast-changing, highly competitive world in which global domination is cruelly short-lived.

Winston Fletcher, communications director of FCB Europe, comments: "Resurrecting brands is not impossible to achieve but it fails more often than it succeeds. It will be tough going for Levi's. It is the name as well as the product that is the brand here, and, in the fashion arena, image is even more important than for more workaday products. To renovate a fashion brand is doubly difficult."

No doubt with rebirth in mind, the jeans giant brought in Philip Marineau from PepsiCo last September to be global chief executive officer - the man who is credited with reviving the Pepsi brand with the launch of Pepsi One, so one who must know something about this thorny predicament.

But certainly the company stands as good a chance as any of recovery: the new campaign is strong and, most importantly, there are the new LEJs themselves. These are funky, different and new, and the best thing is, Tony Blair would not be seen dead in them. Or let's hope not. Otherwise Levi's will have flung an estimated $35m in product innovation and a multi-million pound advertising budget down the proverbial.

fields.headline: A week of spin
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText:
MONDAY
In the lobby, Alastair Campbell gives his verdict on press reports of Tony Blair's "u-turn" on GM foods. A precis is published, as with all lobby briefings, on the Downing Street website:
fields.body:
MONDAY
In the lobby, Alastair Campbell gives his verdict on press reports of Tony Blair's "u-turn" on GM foods. A precis is published, as with all lobby briefings, on the Downing Street website:

"The journalists were putting their own spin on the prime minister's words in pursuit of their own agendas. This demonstrated one of the reasons why the prime minister believed it was difficult to have a sensible, multi-dimensional debate about a complex issue. The PMOS [prime minister's official spokesman] concluded that coverage of the issue was pathetic."

TUESDAY

Campbell writes to Max Hastings about the London Evening Standard's NHS coverage:

"It would appear to be impossible to get the press to cover policy issues seriously. The headline on the report of the prime minister's speech today, and the report, are exactly the kind of exaggerated, wilful misinterpretation that dogs not just health, but so many other serious policy issues. It is not just the government spokesman but the journalist in me that despairs of today's press."

Campbell also writes to Tony Hall, the BBC's head of news and current affairs, saying that Monday night's Panorama on the battle to be London's mayor was nothing less than a "poisonous piece of propaganda".

WEDNESDAY

Guardian columnist, Polly Toynbee, ups the ante by revealing the government's plans for the press:

"The government is preparing to launch a full-frontal attack on the press - the prime 'force of conservatism'. Not quite yet, but when the time is right. Now it would look like whingeing while down in a bad news trough: the London mayor debacle, the dome, NHS waiting lists, Section 28, the Afghans and asylum seekers in general . . . But things can only get better, as the old song goes. And when they do, the government intends to spring back off the ropes and punch its enemies on the nose. Not before time, many in the party think."

FRIDAY

Campbell writes an article in the Daily Telegraph about another "unhealthy" aspect of today's press:

"The way that so much of the media moves as a herd. It was once media fashion - and still is abroad - to be hugely pro-Blair. The current fashion is broadly to dump on him, the more venomous the better. Failure, charlatan, phoney, liar, quisling, fascist, Hitler. Where do they go next?"

webTitle: A gambler - and proud of it

fields.headline: A gambler - and proud of it
fields.standfirst:
Last week John Dugdale argued that BBC1 was showing the effects of underfunding. Here Peter Salmon, the channel's controller, puts the case for the corporation
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Last week John Dugdale argued that BBC1 was showing the effects of underfunding. Here Peter Salmon, the channel's controller, puts the case for the corporation
fields.body:
It is a leap year and spring is approaching, and thoughts are turning to love. Only, in the case of the BBC, the idea is one of tough love. Chris Smith did it. Greg Dyke is thinking about doing it. John Dugdale, however favours more "tough" and a lot less "love".

He accused BBC1 of failing to live up to expectations. Everywhere he turned - albeit often with a Nelsonian blind eye to the channel's achievements - he saw doom, gloom and disaster. Each grudging whiff of a bouquet was knocked for six by a brickbat. His opening premise was that BBC1 needs more money to avoid repeats. Do I want an extra few million pounds to deliver more original drama, more new comedy and more live sport? You bet.

Do I regret the number of repeats on the channel? Hardly. BBC1 has shown fewer repeats in peak than any other network, and while I'm wholly committed to the principle of boosting original programming in peak beyond our current level of 87%, I can't believe Dugdale is seriously suggesting that quality programmes such as The Royle Family or Men Behaving Badly should get only one outing?

I was also intrigued by the accusation of being a programming gambler, which "has resulted, again and again, in glory co-existing with disaster". Though the accusation is far fetched, I suppose I'm guilty as charged. And proud of it. Dugdale appears to argue that glory can come only with high ratings attached. I don't agree. That is not what a flagship public service network is about. That's where the gambling comes in. I believe in an appetite for adventure. In a quest for originality. In a risk-taking channel, not a copycat one. But that risks failure - and, in my books, that means honourable failure.

Castaway 2000 was one such new beginning. Dugdale dismisses the project as a "fiasco", ignoring the mismatch between the press reports and the enthusiastic audience response.

Our successful and unique strategy for science also gets scant regard. Child of Our Time is another hugely ambitious project from BBC Science. Whereas Walking with Dinosaurs expressed its creative ambition through mastery of new technology, this project marries observational documentary with the pursuit of some of the most fundamental questions about human nature, and we hope it will reach a climax in 2020. A 20-year gamble.

Yet risk and re-invention is in no way limited to our factual or specialist producers. Some critics bemoan the lack of single dramas which replicate the innovation and intensity of the BBC's Play For Today. But this tradition has surely been reawakened, albeit in a series form, in Paul Abbott's Clocking Off, which sat in the very heart of the Sunday peaktime schedule. And then there's comedy. Let's be honest, the BBC is the only mainstream broadcaster in the game when it comes to original production. Can the memory of Dinnerladies, The Royle Family and the Vicar of Dibley have faded so quickly?

It has not all worked. Starting Out, the series from Marks and Gran, probably won't return. Neither might Mrs Merton and Malcolm. But others show green shoots of growth. My Hero, Beast and Kiss Me Kate will return. The point is that we will keep trying. Risks in new comedy are scarily high, hence ITV's aversion to the genre.

As for sport, there are major issues to tackle, but the alarm at an alleged dearth of big sport events on the BBC looks a tad overstated in a year that will bring Euro 2000 football, Wimbledon, the Grand National, the Open golf championship and the Olympics. And if we are under attack for BBC1 being a "brilliant sixth-form college", as Dugdale dubs it, for the strength of our educational and factual output, I'll survive the carping. With 14 genres in peak and the only mainstream channel with prime-time news, it's a criticism I welcome.

I had at least as much fun in my sixth form as I had lessons, but the learning hasn't stopped. In fact I'm focusing on the curriculum right now - Risk, Range and Regeneration. As Jim Royle would say: "BBC1 my Rs."

fields.headline: Bursting the soap bubble
fields.standfirst: Like many before him, Ross Kemp has left the comfy world of soap to try his hand at mainstream drama. In the run-up to his debut starring role on ITV, he talks to  Maggie Brown about shaking off his hard man image
fields.trailText: Like many before him, Ross Kemp has left the comfy world of soap to try his hand at mainstream drama. In the run-up to his debut starring role on ITV, he talks to Maggie Brown about shaking off his hard man image
fields.body:
Ross Kemp is sipping tea, answering my questions politely in his educated Essex voice. But his grey eyes are wandering. He's tense. Watching the foyer. In the cinema next door, Kemp's first big two-hour drama for ITV, Hero of the Hour, broadcast next Sunday, is playing before an audience of journalists. Kemp, superstar of EastEnders and last seen in October crashing into the Thames to fake death then hopping off to Spain and a dodgy new life, is watching to see if anyone walks out. It's not an act. He is seriously worried.

In his new role he is attempting a clean break from 10 years of "hard man" typecasting, by playing an ordinary family man, Richie Liddle. He has four kids and is employed as a supermarket security guard. When raiders attack him and shoot him in the leg because he refuses to open the safe he suddenly becomes a national hero. But his heroism is flawed. Why? Because he tried to pocket £100,000 to pay for an operation for his daughter to remove a large birthmark. Grant Mitchell would never have done that, now would he?

"I see people like that at my rugby club: some turn up in Ferraris, others on bikes," Kemp says. "There is so much pressure on people to succeed, but Richie can't compete. He's not the brightest thing on this earth, not dedicated to his laptop.

"Generally we don't see this sort of character on TV, they're thought not as interesting to people as the person who drives a Ferrari. He's different from Grant Mitchell. And I love the relationship with his daughter."

After a decade of playing a troubled character who plumbed every dysfunctional storyline - setting fire to his pub for insurance while one wife was upstairs, sleeping with his mother-in-law, and exploiting a tribe of women - Kemp, aged 35, is now trying warm and cuddly.

He is not the first soap star to make the leap into comparatively short-run drama. And he won't be the last. Amanda Burton (from Brookside to Silent Witness); Michelle Collins (from EastEnders to Sunburn); Nick Berry (from EastEnders to Heartbeat); and Sarah Lancashire (Coronation Street to Clocking Off) have all made the jump. Television executives have an increasing obsession with stars who can, at least, pull people in for the first episode of a new drama. What viewers do after that is presumably their own business.

"I lay awake at night over this," Kemp says of his journey away from the relative safety of Albert Square. "After 10 years [on EastEnders] there's no way anything is guaranteed as an actor. You'd be incredibly arrogant to believe that. You have to have self-doubt, or you don't achieve. All good actors are pushing themselves to develop what they do. In this Richie has violence done to him, where Grant would have been the one waving the gun. The danger is that he's a bit boring.

It's true, Kemp admits, that a 1997 script had him raping his wife, Tiffany, on Christmas day. He smiles: "What do you think about that? At twelve, before you have your turkey? I think it was totally wrong, misjudged. No way it was going ahead, unless they could have made it animatronic."

There is, he says, a continual pressure for sensation and shock.

"How many have now gone for those youthful storylines - affair with teacher, teenage pregnancy? They've always tried to do that, to reflect areas of life, but you are under constant pressure. It's a commodity you know.

"Plagiarism is rife in any art form - if you want to call soaps arts. Shakespeare knew that. There is always an element of retelling stories, or stealing. Storylines in EastEnders are now very similar to ones four years ago. Audiences don't seem to mind that too much, I suppose characters are different. And it's told and written in a quality way.

"But if it's not then it's very easy for people to start saying it was much better when we saw it the first time.

"At the end of EastEnders [filming ended in August] I started being called Grant less, Ross more, and that was weird because Grant gave you that kind of shield; they're talking about something I play, not who I am.

"When people shout Ross in the street I tend to look around, I assume it's people I know."

Did you get worried that people thought you were like Grant? "The media love to play up the idea that people can't differentiate between the person and the character. Admittedly some people can't play out of type, but hopefully I wasn't one of those. Some people are very similar to the characters. In their mannerisms.

"People come up to me and say, 'you're Grant Mitchell, do you want a fight?' I say: 'No, Grant Mitchell is in his dressing room in Elstree, go round there if you want'."

Kemp's girlfriend is Rebekah Wade, deputy editor of the Sun and his on-off fiancee for five years. Does he want to marry her? "I hope so. I would love to have kids."

Under her influence he has become media savvy and much more relaxed. "You can't reject the media in this country. It's impossible to do so like it is in the States. To a certain extent you have to play the game, it's just how far you get into bed, and I think if you start selling stories for money you are walking into the lion's den offering meat. But if you are polite, cordial and sensitive it's all right. I never hide from paparazzi.

"It obviously helps having a girlfriend who is in the media, but I've always treated it with respect. I'm aware of the harm that can be done to you if you don't." (In fact his younger brother, Darren, is a BBC journalist about to switch from the Today programme to Panorama.)

"I never used to do any interviews when I was on EastEnders because I saw doing publicity for a programme on three times a week, for an hour and a half, gaining viewing figures when I was in it [he laughs] of 18 or 19m as pointless."

Has he mellowed since those days?

"Oh, it is stressful. But it's a different kind of stress. When I was in EastEnders it was an ensemble piece, I was the shop steward there, leading the cast as it were. A spokesman. Now all I have to concentrate on doing is being a actor."

fields.headline: Open letter
fields.standfirst: Last week Helen Boaden was appointed Radio 4 controller. In an open letter Maggie Brown pleads for a steady hand
fields.trailText: Dear Helen,
fields.body:
Dear Helen,

Congratulations on landing the job. It was nice hearing you use that quaint word "cherish" to depict your approach to Radio 4. Those cliches about it being the greatest speech network in the world are welcome, too: they're true. It's not perfect, but commercial radio will never aspire to such an eccentric cultural mix.

But as listeners, we want more than tender loving stewardship. Please treat us with respect. Don't start a wholesale shake-up of staff, or introduce another big review of schedules. Change for the sake of it makes us nervous, and is devastating for the morale of dedicated producers. Birtism and obsessive self-examination now belong in another country. What's wrong with a network at ease with itself?

The latest Rajar audience figures confirmed that it is in basic rude health... 8.9m regular listeners tuning in for longer and longer. A Radio 4 controller's job is to refresh the network, but in a self-effacing way: not to impose his or her personality. So bring back a challenging media show, along the lines of Medium Wave, the programme so hated by your predecessor. And don't bury it in some silly slot.

What Boyle's era surely proved is that no one can magic up scores of successful new programmes overnight, and many of the failures have already been eased out. Alongside good initiatives such as moving Woman's Hour to 10am, a logical start point, and the accessible Front Row which replaced Kaleidoscope, please take an urgent look at the failed 1.30pm quiz slot. It is filled with a dire melange of programmes including a watered-down Feedback and the awful Open Country.

It's important to restore more edge to the network by adding a fresh current affairs and newsy bite, alongside the pillars including From Our Own Correspondent - which should be right up your street. The solution is to create a News Hour, or something approaching it, between 1pm and 2pm (the current half an hour is too short). It is wrong to think dedicated Radio 4 listeners should have to switch to Radio 5 Live for a news fix laced with sport.

I also miss the 9am phone in, Call Nick Ross. The Radio 4 afternoon phone-ins at 3pm are a pathetic substitute, more concerned with counselling, money and touchie-feelie issues than mainstream topics. While on the subject, please stop the sprawl of You & Yours. We're not all pensioners, obsessive investors, or people with disabilities. Also, I sometimes try, but usually fail, to stick with the 2.15pm drama. In fact, the afternoon schedules have me baffled. It's a time of day I say, thank God for Classic FM.

It is obvious, Helen, that you love public service broadcasting and will be an effective advocate for radio producers and the medium itself. After years of being undervalued, forced to scrabble for commissions and being second guessed, the omens for Radio 4 are good.

Yours, Maggie

fields.headline: Joining the dots
fields.standfirst: Television or the internet - which is the way forward in the race for media convergence? This week's Production Show media fair will be the place to find out, says  Alex Benady
fields.trailText: Television or the internet - which is the way forward in the race for media convergence? This week's Production Show media fair will be the place to find out, says Alex Benady
fields.body:
Those who feel overwhelmed by the idea of 500 television channels would do well to give the Olympia exhibition centre in London a wide berth this week. From Wednesday to Friday it plays host to the Production Show, one of the UK's largest and most influential television, film and advertising fairs.

In previous years, the emphasis of the show has been on "luvvie" issues such as copyright and how to pitch ideas. But this year the "luvvies" have been upstaged by "nerds" surfing a wave of technomania, promising not 500 but 500,000 potential television channels in the foreseeable future.

The show has been running for 10 years now and this year's is the biggest yet. With 150 exhibitors and sponsors (including the Guardian) and more than 40 different discussions, the organisers say it addresses every aspect of creating, making and financing films of all kinds. Hence its move from the elegant confines of the Islington Business Centre to Olympia.

"The impact of technology on every area of TV, film, advertising and even game production is immense. At the same time, these industries are going through a phase of growth which will change them beyond recognition in a comparatively short time," says Tim Macpherson, event director for organisers Emap Media.

So for the first time the show is taking a serious look at the potential of "webcasting" - using the internet (as opposed to cable, satellite or the airwaves) to disseminate programmes. It's a timely change of emphasis designed to highlight the potential impact of ASDL (asymmetric digital subscriber lines), new super telephone connections that can carry hundreds of times more information than ordinary phone lines, which are due to be launched next month.

This means that it will now be possible to send reasonable-quality video images down a phone line. "As the technology already exists in domestic computers to digitise images, ASDL removes the last obstacle to anyone becoming a global broadcaster from their own home," says Jason Thomson, marketing director of internet video company Numedia.

This raises the spectre of a 500,000-channel future in which The Fast Show's Channel 9 is a showcase of high production values and consummate craft skills. The implications for the big media corporations are immense, say the nerds. "The internet service providers and telecoms providers will become the new media barons because they will control the means of distribution," predicts Thomson.

However, in the short term, there are still significant restrictions on what webcasting can achieve. Limited bandwidth will continue to mean that until fibre-optic connections (1,100 times faster than ASDL) become widespread, the best webcasts will be strong, simple, slow-moving images.

Developing programming with these attributes takes special skills, so Numedia will be staging a live demonstration of webcasting, broadcasting vox pops and set-piece features. Such is the demand anticipated by the show's organisers that it has scheduled 45-minute seminars on web production over three days.

This reflects the fact that beneath the showbiz glitz of the exhibition lies a significant economic and cultural subtext; the struggle currently going on between the nerds, who believe that computing will become the dominant entertainment mode in the future, and the television industry, which hopes that in years to come computing will be just another channel on your television set.

The TV industry is putting its faith in digital television to win the race for convergence. The keynote lecture delivered by Steve Morrison, chief executive of Granada Media Group, will deal with the potential of online broadcasting. Morrison, who has overseen the launch of online entertainment service GWizz, and is also joint chief of the UK edition of the Ask Jeeves search engine and one of the key players behind ONdigital, will look at the opportunities that multimedia content creation presents for producers.

Despite the opinion of those like Jason Thomson, who regard digital television as as an evolutionary cul-de-sac - "just a stepping stone to internet TV, which is more flexible and more interactive," he says - it is the cutting edge of broadcasting for at least the foreseeable future.

The Production Show will reflect this commercial reality, with debates on interactive opportunities for producers and the opportunities for independents offered by digital production and distribution. Among those taking part will be John Holland, the BBC's head of interactive TV, and Mark Rowland, managing director of Mentorn International.

In a session titled Working with Dinosaurs, Jim Hytner, marketing director of Channel 5, will examine the implications for traditional mixed scheduling of a fragmented, view-when-you-like era of niche networks and interactivity.

But even the nerdiest of nerds agrees that if anyone can become a global television broadcaster, what will distinguish success from failure is not access to a distribution platform but quality of output. "Content is king" is the rallying cry of the luvvies.

The leading edge of the show may be to do with technological issues, but Tim Macpherson points out that "the remaining 70% will still deal with luvvie issues". To this end, there will be eight sessions with commissioning editors from BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and Discovery. There will also be sessions on production, including a masterclass with Brookside and Hollyoaks producer Phil Redmond on what he sees as the major issues facing producers in the coming years.

But the show is not just about television. The future of advertising will also be addressed in a session examining the effect of the new media revolution on the creative process. A presentation by Joe Stanton, knowledge and futures director at advertising agency Leo Burnett, will explore the impact of new technologies on brands and the consumer.

Of course, battling for the future is hungry work. The luvvies will need a lot more than sweaty cheese sandwiches and a styrofoam cup of coffee to fuel their struggle with the nerds. Enter St Terence Conran, protector and nourisher of all luvvies, who is setting up a 200-seat branch of his Soho food barn Mezzo for the duration of the proceedings.

The Production Show 2000: highlights

Production Show 2000 is the UK's biggest showcase of creativity in the moving picture business. Key sessions include:

 Keynote speech by Steve Morrison, chief executive of the Granada Media Group, on his company's online strategy and production opportunities.

 Monty Python's Terry Jones on his life as a director.

 Brookside and Hollyoaks creator Phil Redmond on the challenges and opportunities of the next few years, particularly the potential of digital interactive content.

 Yasmin Anwar, commissioning editor for multicultural programmes at Channel 4 and Dianne Nelmes, ITV's controller of daytime output, will also lead sessions.

For more information go to www.productionshow.co.uk
