fields.headline: Grief encounter
fields.standfirst: Rising numbers of reporters say the police have harassed or assaulted them. Are they paying the price for activists posing as journalists? Or is it an attack on press freedom?  Andrew Wasley reports
fields.trailText: Rising numbers of reporters say the police have harassed or assaulted them. Are they paying the price for activists posing as journalists? Or is it an attack on press freedom? Andrew Wasley reports
fields.body:
Covering the anti-World Trade Organisation rally at London's Euston Station on November 30 last year was nothing out of the ordinary for Express journalist Danny Penman. He'd reported on Britain's protest movement since the early 90s and seen everything from peaceful treetop occupations at the Newbury bypass to full-scale riots in the capital.

The "N30 event" - as it was dubbed by the organisers - was to prove different, however. Just after 7pm the police moved in to clear the station concourse, resulting in considerable disorder. Penman found himself herded into a nearby park, where he claims he was viciously attacked by police in riot gear. "I suddenly found myself being repeatedly struck with batons. I made it clear that I was a journalist, and I couldn't believe it when they continued hitting out at me. I was only rescued after the BBC's Kate Adie intervened." Penman suffered cuts and bruises and a broken arm, the bone so severely shattered it required a steel plate and a dozen bolts to hold it together.

The incident mirrors the experience of TV researcher Andrew Browning, who claims he was attacked and intimidated by police while photographing last summer's anti-capitalist riot in the City of London. "I'd shot half a film of the barrage of missiles coming from the protesters and of the retaliatory baton charges by police, when I saw two riot officers swing towards me. Ducking around a wheelie bin, they struck me with their batons across the shoulders and grabbed my camera. I shouted that I was a journalist and asked what on earth they were doing."

Browning says the police demanded all the films in his possession, threatening him with arrest for violent disorder if he didn't comply - "totally ridiculous as I was simply taking pictures."

On the same day, Nick Cobbing, a freelance photographer, says the police deliberately damaged his camera after seizing it during a baton charge. "I'd dropped it, but was told I'd have to make a statement to claim it back," he says. "When I did recover it, the damage was criminal - shutter punctured, the hood and filter missing - far more than would result from it simply dropping to the floor."

Penman is attempting to sue the Metropolitan police for assault with the backing of the National Union of Journalists, and Browning and Cobbing have lodged formal complaints with the police complaints authority, seeking to recover the considerable costs of repairing and replacing equipment. Another journalist arrested at the protest, freelance Charlotte Wilcox, is also considering legal action after being held overnight without charge and having her video camera and tape seized. All four are part of a growing list of reporters to fall foul of the law while covering political dissent.

Since environmental activists first resorted to direct action at the Twyford Down anti-bypass siege in 1992-93, protests have attracted media attention like never before. With this, however, there has been an alarming increase in the number of journalists reportedly assaulted, harassed and even arrested by the police at such events.

Those covering road protests, hunt sabotage and action against genetically modified crops claim to have been targeted most frequently. Some say they have been arrested as many as seven times, others that they have been beaten by police, their houses raided and equipment seized. All say their press card credentials have been systematically ignored, in spite of a police-operated PIN number identification scheme.

Some journalists argue that it represents a deliberate and organised attempt on the part of the police to intimidate campaign-sympathetic reporters and to "manage" the news. Others maintain that it is simply a case of being in the wrong place at the wrong time - journalists covering illegal protests should expect to encounter problems with the law.

Most of the journalists harassed or arrested while covering protests have never been charged. Nick Cobbing has the dubious honour of being one of only two known reporters to have been convicted - he was found guilty of obstruction after reporting from the trees at the 1997 Manchester airport eviction - fuelling speculation that the primary motive of police is not to criminalise journalists outright but to prevent compromising material from being broadcast or published.

In July 1998, Ben Edwards, a freelance video journalist, was accused by police of being "the propaganda arm" of a group of environmental activists arrested after destroying a field of genetically modified crops in Devon. He was held in a police cell for more than 24 hours while police raided his house, seizing his computer, files and even documentaries taped from television, although he was never successfully prosecuted.

The NUJ says it was the case against Edwards that helped kick-start a campaign to push the issue on to the political agenda - a dossier outlining key incidents and calling for an official policy on the subject has been handed in to the Home Office. The organisation also claims to have identified a police officer who, they believe, has been responsible for intimidating journalists at political demonstrations.

Observer photographer Andrew Testa was stopped by the officer at two separate demonstrations, at a Reclaim The Streets event in Birmingham and a vivisection protest in Oxfordshire. "On both occasions he said he had seen me at other political events, implying that this was somehow illegal. He also pointed me out to a police cameraman to ensure they got a decent shot."

The NUJ is cautious, however, about supporting everyone who claims to be a journalist and has suffered police harassment. "We will intervene where there is a clear case of a bona fide reporter being prevented from carrying out their job," says spokesman Tim Gopsill. "But we can't - and do not attempt to - get involved every time someone with a video camera is arrested."

A spokeswoman for the Metropolitan police says: "Everyone who carries a video camera or uses the internet calls themselves a reporter these days, so we advise our officers to use their judgment in establishing whether an individual is legitimate or not. We are aware of the allegations of news managing, but can categorically say that this is not the case."

Hugh Lawrence, who has been researching press freedom across Europe for a forthcoming book, is more sceptical: "Although there has been an increase in the number of cases of harassment, I don't think it in any way amounts to an organised attempt to stifle reporting of the news." He says many of those targeted place themselves in compromising positions by "taking part" in actions and producing articles that amount to little more than incitement to protest. "Most of those who've run into trouble with the law are young freelancers who are often sympathetic to the aims of the campaigners, not established journalists working for an established publication. The police perceive the two groups, perhaps rightly, as very different."

webTitle: The royal family and the public purse

fields.headline: The royal family and the public purse
fields.standfirst:
Civil list: After an early history of overspending and abuse, time and public opinion have changed the dynamics of the contract

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The origins of the civil list go back to the 17th century in the reforming reign of William III and Mary II. Before they were declared joint monarchs of England and Scotland in 1689, all income derived from hereditary revenue and taxes was used to provide for the "the personal support and dignity of the sovereign" and the cost of government.
fields.body:
The origins of the civil list go back to the 17th century in the reforming reign of William III and Mary II. Before they were declared joint monarchs of England and Scotland in 1689, all income derived from hereditary revenue and taxes was used to provide for the "the personal support and dignity of the sovereign" and the cost of government.

But William and Mary's parliament established the principle that expenses relating to the support of the monarch should be separated from the cost of government.

William and Mary were initially granted £600,000 annually "for the charge of the civil government" by parliamentary resolution, and eight years later the first civil list act was passed, with the allowance increased to £700,000.

That first bill allowed for the disposal of any surplus at parliament's discretion, but more often than not the opposite applied. Queen Anne (1702-1714) overspent to the tune of £1.2m, and her debts were met by parliament. George I (1714-1727) proved equally spendthrift, incurring debts of £1.3m.

In 1760, with accession of George III it was decided that the whole cost of civil government should be provided by Parliament in return for the surrender of the hereditary revenues, principally the net surplus of the crown estate, by the king for the duration of the reign. (In 1997-98 revenue from the crown estate amounted to £113.2m which was paid to the treasury.)

George III was also noted for his abuse of the income. In an attempt to reestablish the primacy of the monarch over parliament, he used the civil list to reward his "friends" in the House. With no independent scrutiny of the civil list he was able to reward supporters with pensions, homes and other bribes.

As long as he did not end up with a surplus he was free to spend as he wished, but despite making cuts at home, he overspent by £1.1m. Parliament again bailed out the king and in 1777 raised his grant to £900,000.

The first significant reform of the list came in 1782 and followed lobbying by the statesmen and writer Edmund Burke. Many useless offices were cut, secret pensions were banned and an element of parliamentary supervision was introduced. At this time the monarch still contributed to some of the costs of government, for instance funding the secret service, but with the accession of William IV in 1830 the civil list was reduced to £510,000, and used only to cover the expense of court and family.

The tradition of direct grants to lesser royals is a relatively new one. In the last century, under Edward VII, George V and George VI, the queen was granted £40,000, while at the start of the Queen's reign the Duke of Edinburgh received a similar amount.

In 1952 the list was expanded to include allowances to Princess Margaret (£6,000 rising to £15,000 were she to marry), while minor royals who undertook official duties were granted £25,000 each.

In 1993 the Queen agreed to reduce the civil list by meeting the expenses of the bulk of the family out of her own income. At the same time she and Prince Charles, who receives revenue from the Duchy of Cornwall, voluntarily agreed to pay income tax for the first time, a measure which has never become law.

The queen currently receives £7.9m from the government, about 70% of which is used to pay staff who deal with state papers, the organisation of public engagements and receptions undertaken by the queen.

The civil list also meets the costs of royal garden parties and official entertainment during state visits.

In addition the government also provides funds for Prince Philip and the Queen Mother

The Queen herself covers the official expenses of other royals including the Duke of York, the Earl of Wessex and the Princess Royal at a cost of £1.56m.

Who gets what

Government provides £8.9m for:

The Queen: £7.9m

Queen Mother: £643,000

Prince Philip: £359,000

Queen provides £1.5m for:

Prince Andrew: £249,000

Duke and Duchess of Kent: £236,000

Princess Anne: £228,000

Princess Alexandra: £225,000

Princess Margaret (above):£219,000

Duke of Gloucester: £175,000

Prince Edward: £141,000

Princess Alice: £87,000

webTitle: The making of an independent campaign

fields.headline: The making of an independent campaign
fields.standfirst: How Ken Livingstone became independent
fields.trailText:
January 1999
"I am convinced that your administration has the potential to be a great reforming government on a par with those of 1906 and 1945," Ken Livingstone tells Tony Blair in the Guardian, publicly declaring his desire to be Labour's candidate for London mayor and asking Mr Blair to "put an end to the widespread suspicion that the rules are going to be rigged to prevent me contesting the Labour nomination".
fields.body:
January 1999
"I am convinced that your administration has the potential to be a great reforming government on a par with those of 1906 and 1945," Ken Livingstone tells Tony Blair in the Guardian, publicly declaring his desire to be Labour's candidate for London mayor and asking Mr Blair to "put an end to the widespread suspicion that the rules are going to be rigged to prevent me contesting the Labour nomination".

May 1999
Ken Livingstone's hope of becoming Labour's candidate for London mayor is boosted when Labour's minister for London, Nick Raynsford, assures the Commons that a ballot to choose the party's official candidate will be decided by one-member-one-vote.

August 1999
Keeping up his public profile throughout the summer, Mr Livingstone suggests that if he is not allowed to stand for mayor he could become ill. "It would be just like Blair to block me from standing as mayor and then offer me a job in his government," he says.

September 1999
Ken Livingstone launches his official campaign to be Labour's candidate for London mayor against the other declared nominees, Glenda Jackson and Trevor Phillips. Any mention of the Labour party is conspicuous by its absence on his green-and-white policy "pledge" card, website and poster campaign.

Mr Livingstone's supporters also threaten to mount a legal challenge against the Labour party if he is blocked from standing as Labour's candidate in the mayoral elections.

October 1999
A few months after insisting he had no intention of joining the mayoral race and attacking "anonymous liars" who claimed he was under pressure to stand, Frank Dobson announces his candidacy for London mayor.

October 1999
"My gut instinct is I will win," says Ken Livingstone as Labour rules that it will use an electoral college of MPs, union members and party members, to choose its London mayoral candidate.

Mr Livingstone urges Labour MPs to base their decision on what the party members want: "The policy of the Greater London Labour party as agreed at its conference last June was for a one-member-one-vote ballot of the party membership. This has been replaced with a system where every London Labour MP will wield a vote 1,000 times the size of that of an ordinary party member. In these circumstances I am sure that Labour MPs will feel bound to consult their members before casting their votes," he says.

November 1999
Despite speculation that the Labour party will block Mr Livingstone from its shortlist, Mr Livingstone survives several fractious party interrogations and his name joins those of Frank Dobson and Glenda Jackson on the list of potential Labour candidates. He is helped by Mr Dobson's threat to resign if Mr Livingstone is not permitted to stand against him in a fair fight.

January 2000
Mr Livingstone and Ms Jackson get access to a full list of London Labour party members, nearly three months after Mr Dobson was given exclusive access to the lists, in contravention of party rules. The data protection registrar is called in to investigate Mr Dobson.

20 February 2000
Frank Dobson defeats Mr Livingstone by 51.53% of the electoral college against Mr Livingstone's 48.47%. Mr Livingstone asks Mr Dobson to "consider his position" after this "tainted vote". Mr Dobson refuses to resign.

Mr Livingstone promises to say "nothing further until I have had a chance to listen to Londoners".

Mr Livingstone's biographer, John Carvel, predicts he will stand.. Journalist, Andrew Rawnsley, calls the two weeks that follow "the longest tantilize since Salome did her thing for Herod with the seven veils".

21 February 2000
Ken Livingstone will win 50% of the vote if he stands as an independent against Frank Dobson, who will poll just 22%, an ICM poll finds.

22 February 2000
The Labour party increases the pressure on Mr Livingstone to accept the ballot result by releasing private correspondence from recent months in which he pledged not to stand as an independent and promised to support the party's official candidate.

There are rumours that the party hierarchy may ditch Mr Dobson in favour of the popular Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet enforcer, who could be installed as Labour candidate in an emergency move at the end of March.

28 February 2000
Mr Livingstone speaks of a "comradely" two-hour meeting with deputy prime minister, John Prescott, as the party continues to pressure the Brent East MP not to go independent. Rumours that Mr Livingstone will be bought off with a minor ministerial job fail to materialise.

Two Labour MPs call on Mr Dobson to accept he was not the real winner of Labour's selection and to stand down, but the vast majority of the party lines up behind Mr Dobson. A Labour spokesman says of Mr Livingstone: "Our intelligence is that he is likely to announce he will run, on Wednesday or Thursday. If he does stand as an independent, we're going to hit him hard. The campaign will be tough and unrelenting."

3 March 2000
Mr Livingstone foils Labour "intelligence". Despite a confrontation with Mr Dobson on Question Time, he refuses to declare his independent candidacy.

6 March 2000
Ken Livingstone says he will stand as an independent mayoral candidate, an announcement perfectly timed to overshadow the official launch of Frank Dobson's Labour campaign.

fields.headline: AltaVista announces 'freephone' net revolution
fields.standfirst: AltaVista UK
fields.trailText: American firm AltaVista is set to revolutionise the Internet market in Britain by  offering unlimited free telephone access to the web for one initial signing-on fee.
fields.body:
American firm AltaVista is set to revolutionise the Internet market in Britain by offering unlimited free telephone access to the web for one initial signing-on fee.

The California-based firm, best known at the moment for its Internet search engine facility, will charge a one-off tariff of around £30 for the service.

Customers would then log onto the web through a free-phone 0800 number, with telephone charges being covered through advertising and sponsorship.

AltaVista managing director in the UK, Andrew Mitchell, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "AltaVista is announcing a pay and go service. The up-front charge will be between £30 and £50, with an annual renewal of £10 or £20.

"What we need is predictable, understandable and clear charges. The biggest reason for people not going on the Internet is the surprise phone bills.

"This industry in the UK needs to be kick-started. One in every two people in the US is online, but one in five in the UK is."

Trade and industry minister Patricia Hewitt welcomed the launch.

She told the programme: "I'm absolutely delighted. We have got one of the most competitive telephone marketplaces in the world and I have been saying for some months that I believe that competition is the best way to drive Internet prices down.

"I believe that we will see Internet usage in this country taking off very very fast indeed.

"It is already growing faster than many other places and I believe we will now see a step change."

The planned service will be announced today and launched within the next few months.

Users are expected to be limited to 500,000 in the first six months, to cope with an expected heavy demand.

fields.headline: Behind the breakup
fields.standfirst: Livingstone's biographer, John Carvel, looks at Livingstone's announcement
fields.trailText: Livingstone's biographer, John Carvel, looks behind Livingstone's announcement
fields.body:
The announcement of a divorce is always sad - and sometimes shocking for acquaintances who did not know quite how far the couple had fallen out of love.

So too with political splits. Ken Livingstone's announcement today that he would leave the Labour party to stand as an independent in the London mayoral election has been brewing for a very long time.

It would have come sooner if Tony Blair had decided to block Livingstone from the Labour shortlist of candidates. A year ago in the biography Turn Again Livingstone I said the former GLC leader had already made the psychological leap towards accepting the possibility of a future outside the Labour party.

Blair's advisers spent months dismissing that idea as far-fetched, but realised their mistake in time to devise an alternative method of stopping Livingstone getting the Labour nomination.

The electoral college mechanism did what was intended. Livingstone's majority among party members and trade unions was narrowly overturned by the whipped vote of MPs, MEPs and Blairite candidates for the Greater London Assembly.

For the past fortnight it has been 95% certain that Livingstone would react by standing as an independent, although he was in danger of looking indecisive when he failed to announce the fact last week.

The immediate reason why Livingstone is making the split is a sense of outrage that his party is stopping its most popular candidate for ideological reasons. But there are longer-term factors at play. He thinks the Blairites have hijacked the party he has served for more than 30 years. In his mind, Labour left him long ago as it abandoned socialism on its move towards the centre ground.

Livingstone has been struck by the impact of Scottish nationalists on the Labour party in Scotland. He thinks they reduce the Blairites' freedom of manoeuvre by providing Scottish voters with an alternative. Looking ahead, Livingstone wants the left in England to create a similar restraining force.

In the short term that idea is fanciful. In this divorce, Tony Blair keeps the house, the furniture and all the family's closest friends. In other words, he has the party, its electoral machine and the support of all Labour MPs.

But, according to the opinion polls, Livingstone has the sympathy of Londoners who have watched him being battered by the Labour leadership and have drawn their own conclusions about whom to blame.

That sympathy may not survive the campaign Labour is about to unleash on Livingstone. His poll lead will almost certainly shrink before the vote in May. But Livingstone is taking a walk into the wilderness with a decent chance of reaching the other side.

John Carvel, Guardian education editor, is Ken Livingstone's biographer. Turn Again Livingstone, Profile Books

fields.headline: Have I got news for you, Labour
fields.trailText: If I were an ITV mogul, I would be puzzled by what the government expects of me. On the one hand, we are told that the UK's exports of programmes are held back by our lack of scale, both in terms of runs of series and of size of distributors. Yet on the other hand, when we try to merge, all proposals are referred to the competition authorities, with share of audience and share of advertising governed by different sets of rules.
fields.body:
If I were an ITV mogul, I would be puzzled by what the government expects of me. On the one hand, we are told that the UK's exports of programmes are held back by our lack of scale, both in terms of runs of series and of size of distributors. Yet on the other hand, when we try to merge, all proposals are referred to the competition authorities, with share of audience and share of advertising governed by different sets of rules.

In the same way, we are promised a light-touch regulatory regime under the new legislation for broadcasting proposed for the next parliament. Yet when we try to rationalise the ITV schedule by moving our main news bulletin to fit the changing viewing habits of our consumers, we are hauled before Commons inquisitors and publicly barracked by the prime minister and the culture secretary.

Of course, Gerald Kaufman's latest investigation into News At Ten - following hard on the heels of his committee's reports on BBC funding and the Wembley fiasco - is designed at least as much to win headlines as arguments. His magisterial theatricality is well suited to "Have you stopped beating your wife?" situations. If you make changes in the schedule that win an extra £70m of annual revenue, are you a hero or a villain? If the overall audience goes up, but the ratings for news and regional programmes goes down, are you applauded or booed? If 24-hour channels and the internet (so close to Gerald's heart) are marginalising the whole idea of fixed news bulletins, why does it matter where a particular bulletin is placed?

And what does it have to do with the government, anyway - other than their irritating habit of having views on everything that might be talked about in the pub? (If you remember our Tony on Richard and Judy calling for the Weatherfield One to be freed, you will not have been surprised to see junior minister Yvette Cooper on GMTV this week, wittering on about the latest Coronation Street crisis, Sarah-Lou's teenage pregnancy.)

Chris Smith, of course, would say that even ministers responsible for broadcasting are entitled, like all other citizens, to have (and express) views on broadcasting - which is a bit like Leon Brittan urging the BBC governors in the 1980s to ban the controversial programme about Northern Ireland, At the Edge of the Union, disingenuously denying that he was writing in his capacity as home secretary.

In fact, the government has no say in deciding whether News At Ten is restored: the power lies solely in the hands of the ITC, which is currently engaged in that very process. But its intervention exposes the weak flank in this administration's entire approach to broadcasting issues.

The Davies Report, for all its virtues, was isolated from the political process because its tight timetable and remit ensured that it failed to address the crucial issues that should have set the framework of its approach. What is the role of public sector broadcasting in the digital age? Will a whole range of public service obligations continue to be imposed on ITC-licensed broadcasters, even as the value of their ITC-granted spectrum diminishes? What part does the BBC play in both those arguments? How much funding for the BBC and the public sector as a whole is appropriate in an expanding broadcast market? And how should such funding be generated?

Davies was forced into short-term thinking and short-term solutions because the full-scale inquiry into broadcasting was not scheduled until 2002/3 - by which time most of the questions it might have dealt with will have been overtaken by events. The News At Ten affair is another casualty of that procrastination.

In practice, it matters little whether or not News At Ten is reinstated. Whatever audience it used to capture will inevitably have been eroded by its year-long absence. Any of the benefits to the schedule of clearing the 10pm roadblock - and there have been disappointingly few - will disappear if the clock is turned back. The Canute-like posturing of ministers will surely be swamped by public indifference, if not the sweep of new viewing opportunities. The compromise being mooted - of a News At Ten-Thirty, head to head with Newsnight - would serve little public purpose, and leave ITV in a half-nelson rather than a full nelson.

Like Dr Watson, the ITC would be well advised to listen for the dog that did not bark, rather than the predictable growlings of ministers who should know better. ITV's commercial competitors - who had viewed with some trepidation the prospect of News At Ten's abolition - have been tellingly silent in the run-up to the ITC's decision on reinstatement. ITV's ratings collapse in 2000 - which has caused alarming cost inflation for advertisers - suggests that its decline will not be cured by one bold gesture, however effective that may have been in shoring up ITV's relationship with its customers for a couple of years. And that is the real news.

 David Elstein is chief executive of Channel 5.

fields.headline: The best schoolyard scene
fields.standfirst: American Beauty
fields.trailText: During their lunch break, high school students Jane Burnham (Thora Birch) and Angela Hayes (Mena Suvari) discuss extra-curricular activities.
fields.body:
During their lunch break, high school students Jane Burnham (Thora Birch) and Angela Hayes (Mena Suvari) discuss extra-curricular activities.

"I'm serious," exclaims aspiring model Angela. "He just pulled down his pants and yanked it out. Like 'Say hello to Mr Happy'". Jane looks nauseous.

"Gross."

"It wasn't gross. It was kinda cool."

"So, did you do it with him?"

"Of course I did. He shoots for Elle on, like, a regular basis. It would have been so majorly stupid to turn him down."

"You are a total prostitute."

"Hey, that's how things really are!" rages Angela. "You just don't know because you're this pampered little suburban chick."

"So are you!" Jane spits. " You've only been in Seventeen once! And you looked fat !"

Anglea pouts bitterly.

"I am so sick of people taking their insecurities out on me."

Suddenly, Jane's neighbour Ricky Fitts (Wes Bentley) appears in the distance.

"Oh my God," Jane whispers, "that's the pervert who filmed me last night."

"Him? No way, he's a total lunatic. We were in the same lunch shift in ninth grade. And he would always say the most random, weird things. And then one day he was just, like, gone. Connie Cardule told me his parents put him in a mental institution."

"Why? They can't put you away just for saying weird things."

"You little slut! You've got a crush on him!"

See also: The Belles of St Trinians

Don't see also: Sister Act 2 - Back In The Habit

Pointless trivia: Before her birth in 1982, Thora Birch's parents planned to have a son named Thor

fields.headline: John Gittings @ Anhui
fields.trailText: I wasn't surprised when they came in to reorganise my hotel furniture at the Ningguo County Guesthouse in Anhui province. It may be one of the smaller of China's more than 2,000 counties, in one of the less well-known provinces, but I was about to be visited by its most important person, the Ningguo Communist party secretary who outranks the head of the county government.
fields.body:
I wasn't surprised when they came in to reorganise my hotel furniture at the Ningguo County Guesthouse in Anhui province. It may be one of the smaller of China's more than 2,000 counties, in one of the less well-known provinces, but I was about to be visited by its most important person, the Ningguo Communist party secretary who outranks the head of the county government.

They shifted two leather armchairs apart, placed a small table in between with a huge vase of flowers, and put a low stool behind for an obligatory "interpreter" - just like a diplomatic meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

There was a stir in the corridor and the PS entered wearing an expensive coat and brown shoes. He spoke for half an hour, pleasantly but very fast, on how Ningguo needs to develop further and attract more investment. He only paused to take calls on his mobile phone - I counted three in two minutes.

Afterwards we smiled and said goodbye. I promised to advertise Ningguo's attractions for foreign business and my companions told me I was being treated as an honoured guest.

This kind of treatment is flattering but exhausting, particularly the banquet part of it. Cynics say that these are just occasions for local officials to have a splendid dinner, but this is probably no longer the case - now they eat well whenever they choose. The goodwill seems genuine and the drinking rituals are no different from those being indulged in by other parties in the same restaurant, whether they are workers or entrepreneurs.

The only permissible drink is the aptly named bai jiu - white spirit. It is drunk from tiny glasses, but a large quantity is also splashed into individual tumblers so that everyone can refill more quickly.

Little polite speeches are made across the table: everyone thanks everyone else for working so hard. It is important to get people's titles right and give them a slight promotion: deputy mayor Li should be addressed as mayor. Sometimes the host explains to his guest that he hopes to make him drunk.

Conversation is not meant to be serious. Typical subjects include a comparison of western and Chinese eating habits, a brief introduction to local "famous sights", questions about whether there is still fog in England and was Princess Diana murdered.

In the Ningguo Guest House (the only three-star hotel at the county level in China) there was a TV set in a corner of the room, quietly playing karaoke with disconcerting snatches of mild porn. The end draws near when the guest is offered "rice or noodles". It might be thought polite to decline as a sign that one has eaten one's fill. But everyone likes to slurp their noodles or knock back a full bowl of rice, moistened with the remains of the soup.

I was being shown rural health services in Anhui, having cleared up a small misapprehension. The translation for the Guardian is weibao. The bao means newspaper; the wei is part of a two character word meaning "to guard". But it is also used in another compound word to mean health. I have to explain that we are a daily newspaper, not a medical journal.

I am always well looked after: two helpful health officials from the provincial capital travel with me in one car, joined by a local medical cadre (not a doctor). In a second car, a senior official comes along as part of the honourific package. A third conveys cadres from the foreign affairs bureau, keeping a careful eye.

In spite of the crowd, the ordinary people one finally meets are usually quite relaxed. There no longer seems such anxiety not to say the wrong thing. Locally elected peasant leaders who have squeezed themselves into jackets and ties are keen to explain everything about their village. New mothers go willingly into detail about their births. The only problem is if the senior official gets impatient, and his aides start murmuring: "Let's go."

fields.headline: If the cowboy hat fits...
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: It is high noon tomorrow. The "Super Tuesday" shoot-out is in the Republican primaries in 11 states with 571 delegates up for grabs out of the 1,034 needed to win the presidential nomination at the party convention at the end of July. America is having serious trouble figuring out which of the two candidates from cowboy states - John McCain (Arizona) and GW Bush (Texas) - is wearing the white stetson. It is important because the next president will be elected by the votes of the centre, but it is hard for the voters to figure out who's what.
fields.body:
It is high noon tomorrow. The "Super Tuesday" shoot-out is in the Republican primaries in 11 states with 571 delegates up for grabs out of the 1,034 needed to win the presidential nomination at the party convention at the end of July. America is having serious trouble figuring out which of the two candidates from cowboy states - John McCain (Arizona) and GW Bush (Texas) - is wearing the white stetson. It is important because the next president will be elected by the votes of the centre, but it is hard for the voters to figure out who's what.

When the scrap began, popular sentiment and the press had cast GW Bush as the good guy, the self-styled compassionate conservative out to avenge his daddy's defeat at the hands of that rascal Wild Bill Clinton. McCain's attack on the lobbies and tobacco appealed to middle opinion, and his war record appealed to everyone, but he was seen as too much of a hair triggerman of the right. This was a fair assessment of his 85% lifetime conservative, voting record - against gun control, against a mother's choice on abortion, against environmental protections. But as they have competed in the bewildering state primaries, some of which are open to Democratic and independent voters, the two men have been swapping hats.

Fresh from his defeat in the open primary in New Hampshire, where McCain had outflanked him on the left, Bush put on the black hat for South Carolina. His now notorious grand-standing at the Bible-thumping Bob Jones university was a gamble that the Christian fundamentalists, if aroused, could swamp the independents.

He was right for South Carolina, but wrong for the national mood. Failing to distance himself from the Bob Jones anti-papist propaganda cost him the Catholic vote in Michigan, where he lost, so he has since reached for the white hat, apologising to Catholics and making a point of speaking to Hispanic audiences to blur the implied endorsement of Bob Jones' prohibition of interracial dating (now abandoned).

Now comes the difficult part, gauging the impact of McCain's subsequent sensational denunciation of the "evil" influence of the "agents of intolerance". He was referring to Bush's Christian Coalition ally, Pat Robertson and the moral majority's Rev Jerry Falwell. Will it be seen as an act of pique after losing? Or a tactical ploy to appeal to the moderate Republicans in the big primaries tomorrow in California and New York? Or was it genuine moral revulsion; or even part of a master plan to save the soul of the Republican party?

If perceived as pique or tactical, he would be judged to be playing the kind of politics he has denounced and he will be punished tomorrow. If it was moral, why did it take him so long, and if it was part of a master plan, why did the straight talker follow up by apologising for "evil", saying he meant it as a joke? Out west, as McCain should know, it is best, on delivering an insult, to follow the hero's injunction in Owen Wister's The Virginian: "When you say that, smile!"

It's true that "nutty" would have been a better word for Falwell, who made money selling videos accusing Clinton of murdering the White House counsel, Vince Foster. But the more adroit Robertson's writings are full of insidious menace for Catholics and Jews.

He has warned "cosmopolitan, liberal secular Jews" of the fate they will suffer for assaulting Christianity with smut and pornography and the murder of the unborn. Again and again, he has made it clear how careful Jews should be in America - and no leading Republican has ever before denounced his hate speech.

Whatever the ambiguities of motive, McCain has once again let fresh air into the Republican party, very much as Teddy Roosevelt did, but you'll need your abacus to work out whether he has a chance still against the big money and the party machine. For McCain to survive, he must at least win in New York's closed primary (101 delegates), and the open primaries in Connecticut (25), Massachusetts (37), Rhode Island (14) and Vermont (12). That would take him to 300.

Bush, with 194 already, is favoured to win California's Republicans (162), Georgia (54), Maryland (31), Missouri (35), Ohio (69) and Maine (31) which would give him a total of 576. But watch the joker in the pack (the Democratic and independent vote in California). Those votes will not be allowed to decide Republican delegates, but a McCain majority in the popular vote would give him something like the momentum that real cowboy and straight shooter Teddy Roosevelt began to gather in 1912.

webTitle: 'Damn your principle. Stick to your party'

fields.headline: 'Damn your principle. Stick to your party'
fields.standfirst: Livingstone's campaign in quotes
fields.trailText: Today
fields.body:
Today

"I have been forced to choose between the party I love and upholding the democratic rights of Londoners. I have concluded that defence of the principle of London's right to govern itself requires that I stand as an independent candidate for London mayor on 4 May."

After the Labour vote

20 February: "In the interests of uniting the Labour party, I hope Frank Dobson will consider his position over the next few days. He must decide whether he is willing to accept this tainted result or stand down in the interests of Labour and London.

27 February: "All the polls show I can win. I desperately want it. Almost every aspect of my waking life is thinking about the nuts and bolts of how you would now run London."

2 March: "This is the most difficult decision in my life. I don't want to break my word, but at the same time I am being deluged by ordinary people in London who want me to stand."

On the shortlist

17 November: "If there is any doubt about this, let me spell it out. If selected as Labour's candidate for London mayor, I will stand on the manifesto agreed by the Labour party, as must every candidate. I would not dream of withdrawing if I were to be chosen as Labour's candidate."

7 January, letter to Labour chairman, Vernon Hince: "If Frank Dobson wins the vote in the electoral college, however narrowly, I will support his campaign for mayor.''

13 December, on Frank Dobson's access to Labour membership lists: "It is clear evidence of collusion at the highest level of the party to assist one candidate to disadvantage myself and Glenda."

19 January: "When I'm mayor, I'm going to make sure the sun always shines, even at night."

Fighting to stand

29 January, 1999, open letter to Tony Blair: "I want to put such absurdities to rest once and for all and give you a categorical assurance that, if Londoners voted for me to be their first elected mayor, I would work with your Government, not against it. It is important that such guarantees are on the record, rather than simply part of some private understanding between us.

7 September: "I have no doubt on the basis of conversations with MPs and officials that I will not be weeded out. Every contact with Labour suggests I will be allowed to stand."

15 October, on a poll that put him ahead in the mayoral race: "If I could have done my fantasy poll, this would have been it."

7 November: "There's a difference between wanting Frank Dobson and a British prime minister rigging an election in full view of the world."

On his past

5 August: "I've had very few depressions in my life, but they follow a pattern, and I look and feel awful for a few months. One such depression was in 1979, when I didn't get elected to the Commons. Another was in 1983 when the national executive committee barred me from standing in Brent East. The other was when we lost the election in 1992."

19 November: "I'm a moderate. Blair's memory of the 80s is distorted."

The rival camp, in their words

Frank Dobson, 9 July: "I am the secretary of state for health, I intend remaining the secretary of state for health."

Trevor Philips, 30 September, now Mr Dobson's deputy: "If there is going to be a loyalty test, there should also be an independence test because Londoners want to be sure that the mayor is their mayor not Tony Blair's.''

Middlesbrough want Australain international central defender Steven Laybutt.

Bixente Lizarazu will join Liverpool in the summer. The French left back has told his Bayern team-mates that he'll only talk to them in English, preparing the 30-year-old for a £3m move.

fields.headline: The Antichrist
fields.trailText: 1. One of the leading candidates to succeed the current pope, John Paul II, says the Antichrist is walking among us, the Times reports.
fields.body:
1. One of the leading candidates to succeed the current pope, John Paul II, says the Antichrist is walking among us, the Times reports.

2. Cardinal Giacomo Biffi, the Archbishop of Bologna, says the Evil One is using the guise of a prominent philanthropist.

3. Prominent philanthropists who might also be the Antichrist? Bill Gates, or George Soros may spring to mind. Indeed a search on Google.com for "root of all evil" will give you - well, see for yourself.

4. Waggery aside, the Cardinal says the Antichrist is not a monster, but a "fascinating personality" (thus ruling out Bill Gates, presumably) who promotes ecumenical contact between the various Christian churches.

5. Cardinal Biffi is one of the outside runners for the pontifical succession. An outside chance in part because of his ultra-conservatism; he objects to Mozart's masses because the composer was probably a Mason.

6. His comments may be seen as an attack on other churches, or even rival candidates for the papal throne, such as the liberal Jesuit Cardinal Martini, or the Nigerian Francis Arinze, who had an animist upbringing.

7. On the other hand, the news that the Antichrist is a vegetarian and a supporter of animal rights will doubtless have teenage girls up and down the country examining their conscience.

8. For the record, the book of Revelation says that the Antichrist will deceive many with false miracles, and will impose a number on all men, without which they may not by nor sell. By which reckoning, H.M. Treasury seems a good candidate.

9. Early Protestants such as the Swiss Francis Turretin, meanwhile, long suspected Whether it can be proven the Antichrist is the Pope of Rome.

10. But on today of all days, it is evident who will be denounced from the pulpit of St Albion's; step forward Mr Ken Livingstone, who today announced he will be running for Mayor of London.

webTitle: You've got to hand it to Hansie

fields.headline: You've got to hand it to Hansie
fields.standfirst: Tim de Lisle on a historic result in India
fields.trailText: In Bangalore this morning, South Africa completed one of the great Test victories, and India sank to their lowest ebb in the Tendulkar era.
fields.body:
In Bangalore this morning, South Africa completed one of the great Test victories, and India sank to their lowest ebb in the Tendulkar era.

Since Tendulkar emerged, a decade ago, India had never lost a home series, although they did go down to Pakistan in a one-off game last year as part of the Asian Test Championship. Visiting India had become almost as hard as visiting Australia. Even the modern Aussies themselves have never won a series there.

Now Hansie Cronje has achieved what Allan Border and Mark Taylor never did. You could argue that India had been softened up by their mauling at the hands of Brett Lee and co. But they have always been a different team on home soil, or rather home dust. With Mohammed Azharuddin resuming his rightful place, they again had a middle order of unlimited gifts. They also have better seam bowlers than most Indian teams of the past, and a wrist spinner of great guile and experience in Anil Kumble.

South Africa left home without two of their mainstays and talismen - Jonty Rhodes, the world's best outfielder and a salvage artist with the bat, and Paul Adams, who we thought was their only decent spinner. Their batsmen see little top-class spin, and the best of them, Daryll Cullinan, missed the first Test. Above all, the team had recently been destabilised by the selectors' brusque handling of Cronje. A month ago, their hope of joining the Australians at the summit of the Wisden World Championship seemed a faint one.

But they didn't just beat the Indians, they hammered them. A two-Test series is too short for there to be talk of a whitewash, but given India's poor record away from home, South Africa's achievement has to go down as an even greater one than Australia's 3-0 win over the same opponents at Christmas.

This result has already had one significant consequence: it has pushed India down to seventh in the Wisden World Championship, only three and a bit years since they were joint-second.

It ought to have several more consequences. Cronje, still only 30, should be restored to full authority. Paternity leave, which was the reason Rhodes was not there, should become an accepted part of the international game (David Graveney please note). And the idea that you can accept a man's resignation as captain and then keep him on as a lame duck is unlikely to be tried again in a hurry. For Indian supporters, the most numerous and passionate in the cricket world, there is only one consolation: at least they're still ranked above England.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

fields.headline: Livingstone's declaration of independence
fields.standfirst:
Key extracts from his announcement
'Why I've decided to run': Ken Livingstone in the Evening Standard
fields.trailText: Key extracts from his announcement in the Evening Standard
fields.body:
"Disraeli once said: 'Damn your principle. Stick to your party.' I do not agree with that. I have been forced to choose between the party I love and upholding the democratic rights of Londoners. I have therefore concluded that defence of the principle of London's right to govern itself requires that I stand as an independent candidate for London mayor on 4 May."

"Tony Blair became leader of the Labour party promising one member one vote and saying that the candidates we put forward should be acceptable to the electors. We were urged to listen to the voters. Yet quite clearly on the issue of who should be Labour's candidate and the issue of the tube, the government is refusing to listen to Londoners."

"I want to make it absolutely clear that I do not want anybody to leave the Labour party. Members who have been appalled by the conduct of Labour's selection must stay and fight to ensure that nothing like this ever happens again."

"I am standing as an independent solely in order to ensure that we have real devolution to London."

"In Labour's selection, wherever a trade union balloted its members my lead was overwhelming. 60% of Labour's individual members voted for me. If we add up the votes of all Labour party members, trade unionists and MPs who voted in this contest, I received 74,000 votes to Frank Dobson's 24,000. That's three times as many votes."

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Bruce Willis joins Matthew Perry in Friends, movie auction raises laughs but no cash, Antony Hopkins shows no hard feelings, Mission Impossible II trailer to be premiered on internet sites, and, on the casting couch, Pierce Brosnan, Michael Caine, and Courtney Love
fields.body:
 Following their collaboration in mobster comedy The Whole Nine Yards, Bruce Willis is to join his new good buddy Matthew Perry in three episodes of Friends, set to air in the US in May. The big-hearted actor will be donating his fee to charity.

 The world's first live movie auction of independent films drew laughs and a few bids, but not a single film was sold at last Friday's event in California. The 15 films on offer included a tale of four 20-something sunbathers talking about sex, and a documentary starring live rodents from the nation's capital. Many of the works were first time projects, and 11 had been aired at various film festivals. Hal Kessler, a lawyer and partner in the group that staged the event, said that representatives from reputable companies had approached him after the auction and told him to let them know which films were still available, and deemed the event a success despite the lack of sales.

 The very latest on Antony Hopkins and Hannibal comes courtesy of Ain't It Cool News. Apparently Hopkins gave an indepth interview at the Santa Barbara Film Festival, and Jodie Foster was sitting in the audience. Hopkins apparently spoke of how excited he was to be reprising his role as Lector, admitted that he was disappointed that Foster was not going to be along for the sequel, but said that he understood her decision. "There wasn't even a hint of animosity between the two," continues the spy. "In fact they seemed to share a genuine friendship."

 Tom Hanks is due in Memphis next month to film parts of Cast Away, in which he plays a workaholic executive who survives a plane crash and is stranded on a desert island. The film began production in early 1999 with scenes in Los Angeles and Moscow, but took an eight-month break while Hanks lost more than 40 pounds to give his character a gaunt look when he returned to civilisation.

 Three of the internet's top film sites have been selected by Paramount to jointly premiere the new trailer for Mission: Impossible II. Dark Horizons, Ain't it Cool and Coming Attractions will be previewing the Tom Cruise action movie on Thursday (US Time), the day before the official site.

Casting couch

 Pierce Brosnan will produce and star in Blood and Champagne, a period romantic drama about war photographer Robert Capa. Writers David Bernath and Alex Kershaw based their screenplay on Kershaw's article Up Close and Personal, published in the Guardian's Weekend section in July 1998.

 Courtney Love is in negotiations to star opposite Lili Taylor in the Shooting Gallery's Julie Johnson, an indie feature from director Bob Gosse. Based on Wendy Hammond's stage play, the film tells the story of a housewife who gains the courage to leave her husband and follow her dreams of becoming a computer scientist, discovering, along the way, her sexuality with another woman.

 Michael Caine has signed up for Miss Congeniality, a comedy starring Sandra Bullock as an FBI agent who goes undercover at a beauty pageant.

 Roger Avary, who shared a best screenplay Oscar with Quentin Tarantino for Pulp Fiction, will direct Bill Paxton in Mexicali, a thriller that will begin production this summer.

Apparently Hopkins gave an indepth interview at the Santa Barbara Film Festival, and Jodie Foster was sitting in the audience. Hopkins apparently spoke of how excited he was to be reprising his role as Lector, admitted that he was disappointed that Foster was not going to be along for the sequel, but said that he understood her decision. "There wasn't even a hint of animosity between the two," continues the spy. "In fact they seemed to share a genuine friendship."  Tom Hanks is due in Memphis next month to film parts of Cast Away, in which he plays a workaholic executive who survives a plane crash and is stranded on a desert island. Dark Horizons, Ain't it Cool and Coming Attractions will be previewing the Tom Cruise action movie on Thursday (US Time), the day before the official site. Casting couch  Pierce Brosnan will produce and star in Blood and Champagne, a period romantic drama about war photographer Robert Capa. Writers David Bernath and Alex Kershaw based their screenplay on Kershaw's article Up Close and Personal, published in the Guardian's Weekend section in July 1998.  Courtney Love is in negotiations to star opposite Lili Taylor in the Shooting Gallery's Julie Johnson, an indie feature from director Bob Gosse. Based on Wendy Hammond's stage play, the film tells the story of a housewife who gains the courage to leave her husband and follow her dreams of becoming a computer scientist, discovering, along the way, her sexuality with another woman.  Michael Caine has signed up for Miss Congeniality, a comedy starring Sandra Bullock as an FBI agent who goes undercover at a beauty pageant.  Roger Avary, who shared a best screenplay Oscar with Quentin Tarantino for Pulp Fiction, will direct Bill Paxton in Mexicali, a thriller that will begin production this summer.

fields.headline: Charles Pick
fields.standfirst: A life in publishing, turning talent into bestsellers
fields.trailText: Charles Pick, who has died of a brain tumour aged 82, was one of that rare breed of publishers who seem to operate by instinct. He turned writers as diverse as Graham Greene, JB Priestley, Olivia Manning, Isak Dinesen, Monica Dickens - the first person he asked to write a book (One Pair Of Hands, 1939) - Paul Gallico, Richard Gordon, the young John le Carré, the even younger Michael Holroyd and Wilbur Smith into household names.
fields.body:
Charles Pick, who has died of a brain tumour aged 82, was one of that rare breed of publishers who seem to operate by instinct. He turned writers as diverse as Graham Greene, JB Priestley, Olivia Manning, Isak Dinesen, Monica Dickens - the first person he asked to write a book (One Pair Of Hands, 1939) - Paul Gallico, Richard Gordon, the young John le Carré, the even younger Michael Holroyd and Wilbur Smith into household names.

His career was a mix of high style and parsimony. He loved smoked salmon and champagne, the Connaught restaurant, where Graham Greene, he said, always ordered Irish stew, Glyndebourne, the Savile Club, and custom-made suits from Savile Row. Yet his attitude to staff salaries and authors' advances was, at best, the result of his father going bankrupt when Charles was 10, leaving his wife, two sons and daughter to fend for themselves.

At prep school, Charles sat at a desk carved with the name of the previous incumbent, William Heinemann. At 16, he went to work for Victor Gollancz. Family connections ensured that his name was on a list of eligible young men invited to wealthy Anglo-Jewish soirees. But the mothers of daughters in Portman Square would have been vexed had they known of his courtship (decorously, by letter) of Miss Beryl Hobbs, of Hove, whose mother owned the popular St Catherine's Lodge hotel and whom he later married.

After the second world war, spent in Burma, India and on Mountbatten's far-eastern war crimes commission, Pick joined the firm of Michael Joseph, where he cultivated mid-list authors beloved of libraries and middle-brow readers. He suavely initiated many a young editor, besides myself, into the complex rites of the publishing lunch and had a reputation for wiliness, cultivating a manner best described as opaque.

At Heinemann, he disapproved of the snooty attitude of Penguin Books to a TV tie-in, The Forsyte Saga, which sold more than 1m copies, the first TV series to influence sales. More seriously, he was deeply suspicious of the leftwing orthodoxy of Penguin editorial, which he had seen revealed in 1967 when he had bullied Randolph and his son Winston Churchill into writing The Six Days War in little more than the time it had taken to fight it . When Charles found himself up before an anti-Israel establishment that did not want to publish the book, he went - scandalously, we thought - over editorial heads, direct to Allen Lane. Penguin published, and had an instant bestseller.

Charles's career can be seen as a series of valiant attempts to preserve traditional hands-on publishing from the threat of monopoly takeover. When the Canadian newspaper tycoon Roy Thomson bought the company which owned Michael Joseph, Charles, with co-directors Peter Hebdon and Roland Gant, resigned on principle. What could a news paperman know about books? An attempt to buy Jonathan Cape fell at the last hurdle, and in 1962 Charles went to Heinemann. But, in his 23-year reign over the powerful Heinemann Group, that too was subjected to a series of takeovers, finally selling to Hamlyn's Octopus.

Charles had welcomed Hamlyn and together they published Heinemann's most popular writers in the brilliantly successful omnibus editions. But he soon became disillusioned with Octopus's manner of dealing with his cherished authors.

Many of the new publishing practices were anathema to him. But he certainly approved of Macmillan's recent and successful handling of Wilbur Smith, and admired the new browser-friendly bookshops, which - as he saw it - had returned to a bookselling style he had last seen in the 30s, when people played chess seated in the windows of bookshops in Cecil Court.

Resourceful as ever, as an agent Charles dedicated his final years to making Wilbur Smith into an international bestseller and to looking after his wife, Beryl, through nine years of decline. He leaves a daughter and a son.

Charles Samuel Pick, publisher, born March 22 1917; died January 14 2000

webTitle: Palestinian poet drawn into Israel's culture wars

fields.headline: Palestinian poet drawn into Israel's culture wars
fields.trailText: Israel's opposition yesterday issued a challenge to the inclusion on the national curriculum of the Palestinians' most celebrated poet, Mahmoud Darwish, saying his verses of longing and loss were a threat to the Jewish state.
fields.body:
Israel's opposition yesterday issued a challenge to the inclusion on the national curriculum of the Palestinians' most celebrated poet, Mahmoud Darwish, saying his verses of longing and loss were a threat to the Jewish state.

"In every word of every song, there is hatred of Zionism and the people of Israel," said Reuven Rivlin, the parliamentary whip of the Likud party.

"It's possible to learn about the enemy, but I do not think we should be reading these poems like Shakespeare or any other author. He is the worst enemy of the Zionist entity."

Darwish, author of My Homeland is a Suitcase and other nationalist poems, returned from 25 years of exile to the West Bank in 1995, although he was banned from entering Israel until last December.

While he is pleased at the decision this week to include his work on Israel's high school literature curriculum, he said yesterday that he fears he has become caught up in Israel's culture wars.

"The right are using me to make a scandal, as a pretext to attack the government," he said. They are saying: 'How dare they teach the works of a national poet like me who is not in love with Zionism?'"

Mr Rivlin has given the prime minister, Ehud Barak, 48 hours to retreat before calling a vote of confidence in his government.

In his opposition to Darwish, Mr Rivlin has drawn support from beyond Israel's right wing, attracting allies from within Mr Barak's ruling coalition, including parties generally regarded as liberal.

"The point is that if I want to teach German then I teach Goethe and Schiller, not Horst Wessel [writer of the poem that became the Nazi anthem]," said Tommy Lapid, who belongs to the Shinui party, and who is known for his secular views and his battles against the influence of religious parties.

"Why take the most vociferous enemy of this country in order to teach Arab literature. If it was under curricula of history - know your enemy - then this would be acceptable."

The furore over Darwish's work - which religious parties denounce as "Bolshevik" - marks the second time in a week that the unity of Mr Barak's coalition has been put to the test.

Last week, three parties defected from the coalition to support an opposition bill that would make it more difficult for Mr Barak to win a future referendum on a possible peace deal with Syria. That vote, too, was the result of anger against Mr Barak's education minister, Yossi Sarid, who has sought to exclude religious parties from any say in schooling.

Mr Barak's coalition is unlikely to lose this week's vote - even Mr Rivlin admits opponents of Darwish will translate their displeasure into abstentions - but the showdown is an unwelcome distraction from the prime minister's preoccupation: a peace agreement with Syria, followed by a deal with the Palestinians.

Mr Sarid argues that the changes to the high school literary curriculum - the first in 20 years - are intended to reflect Israel's multi-cultural society. Aside from Darwish and other Palestinian poets, he proposes including works by immigrants from the former Soviet Union, and residents of development towns.

"The basis for adding a multicultural curriculum is so every child will be able to find himself, his roots and his culture in what he studies in school," Mr Sarid said. "The Palestinians are part of our life and culture and it's important to know your neighbours."

Mr Darwish agrees, although he is sceptical that students will be receptive. "If they read deeply, and in an innocent way, not a political way, they may find we have something in common," he said. "They will know that this country had a history and a culture and a collective memory and this country was not empty when the Zionist project was made."

But this is precisely the danger of putting Darwish on the curriculum, according to Mr Rivlin, who fears the works would undermine the Zionist premise that Israel was created as an exclusive homeland for the Jews.

"Sarid is really acting the cosmopolitan. He is part of post-Zionism. Many voters of Sarid are part of the Arab people, and he is expressing the idea that there is more to being Israeli than being a Jew," he said. "Once you start talking on the basis that maybe we were not right in creating a Jewish state than those young people also might come to think: 'Maybe Darwish is right, and we should not have come here.' We are in the struggle for the existence of the state of Israel."

webTitle: Stars could appear in shorts on the net

fields.headline: Stars could appear in shorts on the net
fields.trailText: Negotiations are in place for the likes of Will Smith, Julia Roberts, Eddie Murphy, and Mike Myers to appear on a computer screen near you
fields.body:
Negotiations are in place for the likes of Will Smith, Julia Roberts, Eddie Murphy, and Mike Myers to appear on a computer screen near you. The stars could be featuring in original, exclusive programming for pop.com, a comedy-themed Netcaster scheduled to launch this spring with one- to six-minute animated and live-action short films, games, and pay-per-view Webcasts.

The site is described as a showcase for new talent, which could grant writers and directors entry into more traditional TV and film venues, and the dot-com company has a stack of script pitches it has solicited for Smith, Roberts, and Murphy. Myers would presumably write his own material.

Variety reports that Ben Affleck and Matt Damon recently turned down an offer made by Pop.com. Affleck, who already has his own official site, is readying his own dot-com venture, says the trade paper.

webTitle: Blame the murderer, not the novelist

fields.headline: Blame the murderer, not the novelist
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland on holding literature responsible for crimes
fields.trailText: Last Tuesday the Guardian took us "Inside the mind of Britain's most reviled murderer" with an article based on 150 letters from Myra Hindley to Duncan Staff. They were a once-in-a-lifetime journalistic coup for him and were clearly designed by her as a fresh line of defence to coincide with her latest appeal.
fields.body:
Last Tuesday the Guardian took us "Inside the mind of Britain's most reviled murderer" with an article based on 150 letters from Myra Hindley to Duncan Staff. They were a once-in-a-lifetime journalistic coup for him and were clearly designed by her as a fresh line of defence to coincide with her latest appeal.

Hindley retains copyright in her letters and the extensive quotation of them is by her explicit permission (she may by now have a literary agent to handle such matters).

In earlier pleas for mercy, Hindley has presented herself as the hypnotised victim of Brady-Svengali: a rabbit to his stoat. Her letters to Staff now offer a version of the more modish Menendez defence. Hindley was so brutalised by Brady, the letters divulge, that she lost all independent will. Eric and Lyle Menendez advanced the plea in the mid-90s that childhood molestation and abuse by their father and mother left them so powerless there was no choice but to shoot them both, pocket the insurance money and buy themselves watches and Ferraris.

Most commentators thought it the most preposterous defence since the assassin of San Francisco mayor, Harvey Milk, claimed he was driven to do it by eating too many Twinkie candy bars. But it got the Menendez brothers off on their first trial and will probably mean they regain their freedom while they are young enough to enjoy it.

In her letters Hindley now records that on their first sexual encounter, Brady raped her. To prepare her for their first murder he anally violated her and, by way of climax, urinated in her vagina.

Her "descriptions of sexual violence", Staff notes, "are more detailed and extreme than in the confession she made to the police [in 1986]". There was no hint of them in the 60s trial testimony. Another new piece of evidence is that Brady "introduced her to the idea of killing" by giving her a book called Compulsion. In it a 12-year-old child is abducted and murdered. "I told him it was a very disturbing book," Hindley recalls, "but why exactly had he wanted me to read it?"

Staff divulged no other details about this "disturbing book". In the partnering BBC2 Modern Times programme, Compulsion was again prominent. Viewers were shown the dustjacket of a 60s edition but - tantalisingly - only the title was visible. The author's name was blanked out.

At the time of the trial, in the late 60s, much was made of the Moors murderers' reading matter. But interest focused on Brady's possession of a paperback of De Sade's Justine (newly available since the Lady Chatterley obscenity trial) and a bootlegged copy of Mein Kampf. The mysteriously poisonous Compulsion was not alluded to. What kind of book, readers and viewers must have wondered last week, would incite a good Catholic girl to murder little children? Compulsion was, in fact, the third-bestselling novel of 1957 in the US. It was read by millions. Compulsion was written by Meyer Levin and is based on the 1924 Leopold and Loeb murder case (Levin, then a young journalist in Chicago, covered the trial).

Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb, two young men from wealthy and cultivated Jewish families, resolved to commit a kidnap for ransom and a "perfect murder". They bungled (as perfect murderers invariably do) and were easily caught. Clarence Darrow, the greatest defence lawyer of his time, saved them from the death penalty with his dazzling oratory. Compulsion has been filmed twice - most memorably in 1959, starring Orson Welles - and turned into a play, Rope.

L evin novelised the crime to forestall libel action from the murderers' (still powerful) families. For similar reasons, Levin's authorship and other details were glossed over by Staff and the BBC programme makers. Levin is a writer of impeccable liberal credentials, the principal populariser in the US of Anne Frank's Diary. It beggars the imagination that the Jew-hating Brady would have admired Levin's book or that anyone could read it as an incitement to serial torture and murder. Compulsion is a bleeding-heart, anti-capital punishment tract.

Why does Hindley introduce it to us at this late juncture? Because thematically the book's title, not its contents (of which reader and viewer are prudently kept ignorant), fit in with her latest defence scenario. She was not seduced into murder; she was compelled. Perhaps. It's for their lordships to decide.

But the notion that Levin's Compulsion compelled her belongs with the Twinkie defence and the dog ate my homework excuse.

fields.headline: Everett frustrated over writing credit
fields.trailText: In the latest case of an actor fighting for script control, Rupert Everett claims that he and writing partner Mel Bordeaux reworked key elements of The Next Best Thing but were denied a writing credit
fields.body:
In the latest case of an actor fighting for script control, Rupert Everett claims that he and writing partner Mel Bordeaux reworked key elements of The Next Best Thing but were denied a writing credit.

"It went to arbitration and the original writer won, so I can't really talk about it," says Everett of the Writers Guild decision that gave Thomas Ropelewski sole 'Written By' credit. "But I did personalise this script for [costar] Madonna and myself." Madonna is backing her friend: "Rupert had lots to do with writing this story," she says, "and we all know it."

Ropelewski counters that Everett's script changes were minor. "He did a polish, but he didn't change anything structural," the screenwriter told Entertainment Weekly. "The WGA knows that Everett and Bordeaux didn't contribute enough to deserve credit." Everett frustrated over writing credit

"It went to arbitration and the original writer won, so I can't really talk about it," says Everett of the Writers Guild decision that gave Thomas Ropelewski sole 'Written By' credit. "But I did personalise this script for [costar] Madonna and myself." Madonna is backing her friend: "Rupert had lots to do with writing this story," she says, "and we all know it." Ropelewski counters that Everett's script changes were minor. "He did a polish, but he didn't change anything structural," the screenwriter told Entertainment Weekly. "The WGA knows that Everett and Bordeaux didn't contribute enough to deserve credit."

webTitle: The comedy's as you like it

fields.headline: The comedy's as you like it
fields.standfirst: The Reduced Shakespeare Company have been wowing West End audiences with their irreverent take on the Bard for five years.  Veronica Lee catches up with them
fields.trailText: The Reduced Shakespeare Company have been wowing West End audiences with their irreverent take on the Bard for five years. Veronica Lee catches up with them
fields.body:
What's short, funny and five years old? No, not the latest member of the Macaulkin acting clan, but the Reduced Shakespeare Company, about to begin another year in the West End with their 97-minute version of The Complete Works of Williams Shakespeare (Abridged). Andrew Lloyd Webber knows a thing or two about long runs in the West End, but it's rare for a non-musical to get a longevity prize. Except, of course, The Mousetrap.

RSC's American co-founder Adam Long rocks with laughter at the idea that his brainchild - a sort of Marx Brothers meets Shakespeare on speed - might be bracketed with that old creaker. "What matters is that we genuinely connect with an audience," he says.

The RSC came out of early-80s street theatre in California. "There were these Renaissance Faires," says Long, "run by a bunch of deadheads and Ken Kesey leftovers who used to re-create Elizabethan villages in the woods at weekends. I had a stuffed dog that I used to do an acrobatic act with at the time." Some friends were doing a four-person version of Hamlet, when the female member of the cast broke her ankle; Long had seen the show twice and offered to go on, donning a wig and false bosoms as Ophelia. He stayed with the group, and he and two of the cast developed the idea that became the RSC. "We were just sitting around one afternoon and a friend suggested we did the complete works of Shakespeare. It sounded like such a funky idea that we said, 'Yeah, why not.' "

That was 1986 and Long, then a political activist and an accountant (no, really), wrote the show with Jess Winfield, a law worker, and Daniel Singer, a graphic artist, never expecting it to be "more than a laugh at weekends". They took it to the Edinburgh fringe the following few years and it took off. The RSC toured the US, Japan and the UK, then a year-long residency followed at the Arts Theatre in London, moving to what now looks like their permanent home at the Criterion Theatre at Piccadilly Circus in 1986. On Wednesday they celebrate five years in the West End with a charity gala.

It's probably true that only Americans would have had the chutzpah to meddle with Britain's greatest playwright. "Americans aren't afraid of making fools of themselves," says Long. "But it's not Shakespeare we're sending up, it's ourselves. We're commenting on the mentality of Americans, who can barely deal with anything that's longer than 90 seconds." Perhaps "with no respect for institutions" Long and co were able to cut through to Shakespeare's core. "We first condensed the plots of every play, but quickly realised that was impossible because we could only devote two minutes to each. Then Daniel worked out that the comedies all had the same plot devices - twins, mistaken identities, fairies' spells - which could be mushed into one massive play - the Tale of Two Well-measured Gentlemen Lost in the Merry Wives of Venice on Midsummer's Twelfth Night in Winter." In their most inspired segment, the histories are presented as an American football game, with the crown of England being passed from one generation to another and Lear being sent off as a "fictional character on the field". Is such minimalising like the high-concept pitch for a Hollywood movie, in which Hamlet would be "Denmark: crazy place, crazy people"? Long laughs. "We're not quite as canny as that. It's more like a 10-year-old was trying to sell it, so it would be: "There's this guy and his father's dead and he doesn't know what to do and he ends up killing everybody and he dies too and it's over'.'

The RSC's audiences are a strange mix of home-grown fans, school parties and tourists. Now their show forms part of the tourist trail, but also provides welcome slapstick relief for teachers trying to engage bored pupils with the Bard. For their efforts, they are routinely picked on during the show's audience participation section.

The RSC has spawned many imitators; every year, there is a slew of student groups at the Edinburgh fringe with reduced this, abridged that in their titles. Long's perfection of the genre has led to some interesting commissions - he was invited to do a reduced history of the Labour Party for its recent centenary, but had to cry off. "I would have had to use the word 'socialism'. So I passed."

The Reduced Shakespeare Company performs at the Criterion Theatre, London W1. Box office: 0171-369 1747.
