webTitle: Waves of truth in Chaucer fiction

fields.headline: Waves of truth in Chaucer fiction
fields.trailText: A physicist believes he has solved an astronomical mystery at the heart of one of Chaucer's Canterbury tales.
fields.body:
A physicist believes he has solved an astronomical mystery at the heart of one of Chaucer's Canterbury tales.

Deep in the text of the Franklin's Tale, a story of magic, blackmail and forbidden love in 14th century Brittany, the poet may have secreted evidence of one of the earth's highest-ever high tides.

Writing in the April issue of Sky and Telescope magazine, Donald Olson of South-West Texas state university argues that what scholars had regarded for 600 years as pure romance might be based on a real event.

In the tale, the beautiful young wife Dorigen, pining for her absent husband, makes a foolish vow about the treacherous rocky coast with the words "woulde God, that all these rockes blake, were sunken in helle for his sake". The youth Aurelius, sighing with lust, does a deal with a magician to indeed make the rocks disappear - and "through his magic, for a day or tway, it seemed all the rockes were away".

This event happened in the "colde, frosty season of December". Of course, it left the young Dorigen obliged to pay the usual Chaucerian fee of sacrificing her virtue - and presented modern astronomers with an interesting challenge.

The challenge is that the magician who did the apparently supernatural deed "knew the rising of his moon well". Prof Olson was aware that Chaucer knew a thing or two about astronomy, had once written a treatise on an astrolabe, or star-finder, and might have used a real event for his plot: an abnormally high tide that submerged the rocks.

He and two colleagues calculated that on December 19 1340 not only were the sun and moon aligned to produce an eclipse, but each body was very nearly at its least possible distance from the earth - a rare combination that must have led to exceptionally high tides. This type of alignment has occurred only a handful of times in recorded history. It will not happen again until 3089.

Medieval astronomers had already noticed a link between the conjunction of sun and moon, and high tides. Chaucer was known to have visited France several times in the 1360s and 1370s and must have been familiar with Brittany's dramatic tides. He was born in 1340 or early 1341 and as a grown man, the scientists argue, he would have certainly checked his horoscope.

If he had calculated the positions of the sun and moon at his birth, he might well have discovered the unusual tide-raising configuration of December 19 1340, and used it as the hinge of his plot for the Franklin's Tale.

For those who want to know the story's ending, Dorigen confesses to her husband and prepares to keep her promise, but Aurelius proves far too much of a gentleman to claim his reward. The magician waives his fee and all ends happily.

webTitle: US weekend box office fails to amuse

fields.headline: US weekend box office fails to amuse
fields.trailText: The US studios were not, for once, laughing all the way to the bank this weekend. Three of the four top box office slots were occupied by comedies, but ticket sales are half what they were a year ago. Top of the US box office was, for the third week, mobster comedy The Whole Nine Yards' with $7.3m in ticket sales.
fields.body:
The US studios were not, for once, laughing all the way to the bank this weekend. Three of the four top box office slots were occupied by comedies, but ticket sales are half what they were a year ago. Top of the US box office was, for the third week, mobster comedy The Whole Nine Yards' with $7.3m in ticket sales.

The Madonna/Rupert Everett comedy The Next Best Thing took second place with $6 million, and Drowning Mona with Bette Midler, took fourth with $5.9 million.

Mike Nichols's star-studded comedy What Planet Are You From? made a very poor debut, taking on $3m, and coming in at thirteenth in box-office figures

It was a lacklustre weekend. The same weekend last year, Analyze This opened with $18.4m.

More than half the films in the top 10 were comedies, and the audience just wasn't large enough to go around, said Paul Dergarabedian of Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc., which tracks box office receipts.

"There's just so many of these adult-oriented comedies out there that audiences were sort of pulled in a lot of different directions,'' he said.

"This is not the audience that goes out and sees three films in a weekend. ... not the most voracious moviegoers,'' Dergarabedian said. "Older audiences will come out in big numbers if the film becomes a must-see. None of these openers really fell into that category.''

fields.headline: Benefiting from the break
fields.standfirst: Each Monday we ask a cricketer what they've been up to in the close season. This week we talk to Mark Ramprakash, who probably thought he'd be spending the whole time in South Africa
fields.trailText: Mark Ramprakash, 30, is one of England's most technically correct batsmen. He has won 38 Test caps but his career has been one of two halves. He averaged 16.65 in his first 19 Tests, scoring just two fifties, but has since averaged 41.33, making one century and eight fifties. He is the only English batsman in the top 20 of the WCM form rankings. Although controversially left out of the tour to South Africa, he was one of only twelve players awarded a central contract by England.
fields.body:
Mark Ramprakash, 30, is one of England's most technically correct batsmen. He has won 38 Test caps but his career has been one of two halves. He averaged 16.65 in his first 19 Tests, scoring just two fifties, but has since averaged 41.33, making one century and eight fifties. He is the only English batsman in the top 20 of the WCM form rankings. Although controversially left out of the tour to South Africa, he was one of only twelve players awarded a central contract by England.

"I spent the first two months of the winter taking time out from what had been a fairly difficult season - I hadn't played particularly well against New Zealand, Middlesex had struggled and I resigned the captaincy, and then of course I was left out of the tour party.

But after going on holiday with my wife to Dubai, I threw myself into working for my benefit, particularly the brochure. It was a big wake-up call dealing with business people and the real world. It was a good thing to do as it is very easy to get completely immersed in your cricket life. It was quite hard work organising articles and stuff. Some players were excellent but others never got back to me. The brochure came out in early January and I was really happy with it.

I had my first benefit dinner a couple of Thursdays ago at the Hilton. Jim Davidson spoke and people were very generous. I stood up and said some thank yous. I don't really enjoy speaking but the thanks were very necessary.

Last Thursday, we played some indoor cricket at Highbury, then went up the road to an Italian, and then came back to have a little tour of the ground and to watch the match [5-1 to Arsenal against Deportivo La Coruna in the UEFA Cup] on the big screen. I tried to get in touch with some of the Arsenal players - Tony Adams and Lee Dixon - who were rumoured to like cricket, but I didn't have much luck getting through.

We're also going to have some golf days, a day at John Paul Getty's ground, Wormsley, a six-a-side game at the Nursery ground at Lord's, and then there are the dinners.

In December, there was that little unexpected excursion out to Cape Town. We had been building up for a really big family Christmas and then suddenly I was in Durban and it was about 35 degrees. I didn't consider saying no; it was just a case of getting my head around the call when we had already made plans for the holiday period. On New Year's Eve we went to a team function put on by Vodafone. My wife came out and it was lovely. We watched the fireworks there, and then came back and watched the celebrations in London on the television.

I practised and trained a lot in South Africa, and we started back at Middlesex in January. Unlike across the road at The Oval, there are quite a lot of us around. I am feeling in good nick but more importantly I am really looking forward to next season.

My ultimate aim each season is to play for England, but the first thing I want to do is to enjoy my cricket for Middlesex. If I don't enjoy that I might as well forget everything else. Then if other things come along, well great.

I saw bits and pieces of the tour, but one day I'd been out all day and was then called in to do some punditry for Sky. It was quite an interesting evening considering I hadn't seen any of it. I didn't really keep in contact with any of the players in South Africa, though I sent a fax to Alex Tudor saying 'keep your head up'.

What else have I been doing? I've played a couple of football matches for Arsenal in an ex-professional and celebrity team. It was great to have a run around. I've always been a football fan and played quite a lot when I was at school and college - I've always enjoyed kicking things. I've followed Arsenal for quite a few years and I've been to a couple of games this season.

I spend a lot of time with Cara, my two-and-a-half-year-old. It is great fun. She is running about and bossing me around all over the place. It has been very nice to spend some time at home - I've been touring for the last two winters. I haven't really seen that much of my Middlesex colleagues socially: we all do our own thing during the winter. I think we need a break after seeing so much of each other over the summer, but you always look forward to meeting them again come February or March."

Mark Ramprakash was talking to Tanya Aldred

fields.headline: Internet firm offers free access
fields.trailText: British internet users will today be offered free access to the internet once they have paid an initial fee of about £30.
fields.body:
British internet users will today be offered free access to the internet once they have paid an initial fee of about £30.

The move by the American company AltaVista may herald a revolution in internet use in Britain if it prompts a spate of copy-cat offers.

AltaVista, an internet search engine specialist, plans to offer British users what Americans take for granted.Once a user has paid the initial fee, it will give them connection to a freephone 0800 number for internet use. It expects to recoup the money from advertising on the web sites.

The service will be announced today and is expected to be up and running in a few months. The company will initially limit the number of free surfers to 500,000 to prevent system overload.

Other companies have launched flat rate services, but AltaVista says this is the first single-fee deal.

It is estimated that the new deal could save Britain's 17m internet users up to £700m a year in telephone charges. It could woo millions more Britons on to the net.

At present about a quarter of Britain is connected to the internet, but we still lag way behind the United States, where almost half of the country uses the web regularly.

In the US local calls are free and computer users, connected to a local server, can surf for free. Most service providers charge a monthly fee, but Americans still pay about half as much as their British counterparts when it comes to using the internet.

Telephone costs mean that British internet users only spend an average of 17 minutes a day online. This limited use has been blamed for stifling British web firms, which struggle to keep up with their competitors in the US.

In America many surfers leave their computers online around the clock, and they are much more likely to buy services or products via the internet.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, should be pleased with the new service because he told financiers last month that high call charges were to blame for doubling the cost of web surfing in Britain.

British Telecom had reacted angrily to the chancellor's comments, but a ruling by the telecom watchdog, Oftel, last December means that BT can no longer dictate the call charges that internet providers hand down to their customers.

BT recently launched its own web deal, offering free off-peak surfing for a flat rate of £6 .99 a month, or unlimited surfing for a monthly fee of £34.99.

The new AltaVista deal will mean that BT and other internet providers may have to reconsider their offers or face an exodus of customers.

When Freeserve first offered call-charge-only internet access, its competitors rushed to provide similar services. Freeserve became the country's favourite service provider because it stole a march on its rivals. The internet industry will be keen not to let AltaVista do the same.

webTitle: Chained body on beach was sex-change father

fields.headline: Chained body on beach was sex-change father
fields.standfirst: Fingerprints identify former friend of Thomas the Tank Engine author
fields.trailText: Police investigating a mysterious chained, naked body found on a Suffolk beach have identified it as that of Christine Chappel, who was formerly known as Bryan Hooley before undergoing a sex change operation in 1994.
fields.body:
Police investigating a mysterious chained, naked body found on a Suffolk beach have identified it as that of Christine Chappel, who was formerly known as Bryan Hooley before undergoing a sex change operation in 1994.

Ms Chappel, 28, was from Roxwell, near Chelmsford. As a man she was married with a child. Police say that she was known to have lived and dressed as both a man and a woman.

She was last seen alive on February 22, by her ex-wife, Alison, at her home in Roxwell and police would like to speak to anyone who saw her after that date.

Ms Chappel once claimed to have co-written some of the latest books from the Thomas the Tank Engine series, but lost a court battle with Rev Christopher Awdry, the son of Thomas' creator, the late Rev Wilbert Awdry. Ms Chappel claimed in 1996 that she had had a two-year relationship with Christopher Awdry, who is 60, after meeting him at a model railway show in Chelmsford, Essex.

The alleged relationship ended when they disagreed over who had written the successful new Thomas books.

The new scripts were used for the television series narrated by Ringo Starr and saw the introduction of the first female engine as well as a helicopter character. The Rev Awdry insisted at the time he had only been helping Chappel write a book based on Star Trek.

The court found in favour of the Rev Awdry and Ms Chappel was said to be very bitter about the decision.

She was thought to be living alone and unemployed when she died.

Ms Chappel's body was identified from the police finger print data-base but it is not clear whether she had a police record.

Her body was found by a woman out walking her dog along the beach on Thursday. It had been wrapped in a heavy gauge chain and three gym weights. A Home Office pathologist said she had been alive when she went into the water but had died from drowning.

She had extensive bruising to her head and face but it is not known whether these were caused by an attacker or simply by the chains and weights banging against her in the water.

Police are continuing to treat the death as suspicious and are appealing to the public for information.

Detective Superintendent Adrian Braddy, of Suffolk police, said: "Confirming the identity of the body is a major step forward. However, there are still many unresolved issues surrounding this incident and we are continuing to treat the death as suspicious.

"We would particularly like to hear from anyone who saw [her] on or after Tuesday February 22."

Police are carrying out toxicology tests on Miss Chappel's body to see if she was drugged before going into the sea.

Officers hunting the coastline for the woman's clothing have found nothing so far.

Mr Braddy said an investigation into tidal conditions had revealed that the woman must have gone into the water in the Kessingland area if she had been in the sea for less than 48 hours.

"If she had been in the sea for any longer she could have gone into the water some distance away in either direction," he added.

"We cannot rule out that she might have gone into the sea in outlying waters away from the coast, possibly from a boat or ship."

webTitle: Right place, wrong time as British aid finally arrives

fields.headline: Right place, wrong time as British aid finally arrives
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: It was stretching it a little, but the former major was determined that no one should question the value of any of Britain's belated aid to flood-stricken Mozambique.
fields.body:
It was stretching it a little, but the former major was determined that no one should question the value of any of Britain's belated aid to flood-stricken Mozambique.

The waters may have fallen and almost all of the tens of thousands of people who were stranded in trees, clinging to roofs or packed on to tiny islands may now have found dry land, but Nigel Appleton, one of four British emergency response officials, was adamant that the self-inflating life rafts designed for cross-channel ferries would still be useful.

"There may not be much water left but even if they are dropped on dry ground they can provide shelter. People can live in them," he said.

Britain's contribution to the flood relief in Mozambique spent a few hours piled on the tarmac of Maputo airport yesterday before being dispatched to where it would have been most useful a week ago.

Dozens of outboard motors, boats and the inflatable life rafts were on hand for use by the firefighters, lifeboat rescuers and paramedics flown from the UK. But in the past two days, the flood waters have dropped significantly and the emphasis now is on relief rather than rescue.

However, the commander of the British helicopter squad, Baz North, was not discouraged by the change in mission. "We're really pumped up for this," he said.

The British have based themselves in the port of Beira where there will also be a strong US presence. The Mozambicans have been told to expect the US commander, a general, today, accompanied by a fighter escort. Perhaps he mistook Mozambique for Somalia. Meanwhile, foreign aid workers grumble about the German troops walking around with guns on their hips.

The extensive western airlift has overshadowed a host of other contributions as varied as the only plane in the Lesotho airforce delivering bottled milk, and a 1943 Dakota that flew in the Berlin airlift bringing donations from a South African supermarket.

Inevitably, there is a growing band of religious organisations. The Jesus Alive! Ministeries and the South African Salvation Army have arrived to offer spiritual comfort.

Not all the British teams were eagerly awaited. Volunteers from the emergency response team, Rapid - including Cornish lifeboat rescuers and British International Rescue Dogs (Bird), who did not bring the dogs - were left sitting at the end of the runway after two days of delay, having arrived ahead of the rest of the British contingent.

Rapid hoped to have its job done and to leave on Thursday but spent much of the weekend stuck in Maputo's naval club waiting for air transport after a dispute with Britain's department for international development (DfID).

John Miller, the Rapid team leader, says the organisation offered its services to DfID after the surge of water swept down the Limpopo and Save rivers, but was told "maybe next time".

Rapid and Bird told the British government they were going anyway, only to arrive in Mozambique to face a fresh row with DfID for "failing to give 72 hours notice". And then came the wait.

"It's very, very frustrating," said Mr Miller, who was clearly a little disappointed that the boats and equipment humped from the UK might not be needed after all.

Mr Appleton, a former major in the Royal Logistics Corps, said he knew nothing of Rapid's plight. "I don't know what their agenda is. We've come out as part of the official British delegation and we're cracking on with the job," he said.

fields.headline: Taming the waters
fields.standfirst:
How to stop floods becoming disasters

Mozambique floods: special report
Disaster Relief - MOD site
Disasters Emergency Committee - Mozambique Floods Appeal
Department for International Development
fields.trailText: Disasters cost lives and blight economies for years to come. Compassion is expensive, too. Disaster prevention, on the other hand, is relatively cheap.
fields.body:
Disasters cost lives and blight economies for years to come. Compassion is expensive, too. Disaster prevention, on the other hand, is relatively cheap. There are well-tested international protocols for sharing meteorological information: even the poorest countries are warned, and warn each other, when hurricanes, tropical cyclones and typhoons threaten. But astonishingly, there is no international obligation, nor much international machinery, to share information about what happens after water hits the ground running and heads downstream.

There are problems even when there is goodwill. How much water can a watershed hold? How much can the soil absorb? How fast is the run-off? How long does it take to run down the river valleys? Yet the world is now ringed by satellites with instruments to measure soil moisture levels to detect imminent drought, and river levels to an accuracy of about 5 cms to warn of flood dangers.

The 1990s was the UN's decade for natural disaster reduction. Despite 10 years of worrying at the problem by engineers and scientists, climate-related disasters claimed more lives and damaged more homes and businesses and croplands at the end of the decade than at the beginning. That was because the world grew warmer - more warmth means more evaporation which means more wind and rain - and because the number of potential victims grew by almost 1bn.

The lesson from Mozambique is that things can only get worse. Every year, 46,000 cubic kilometres of water runs down the world's rivers. A bit more serious, practical study of this flow of liquid capital would be a tiny drain on budgets. It costs money to amass, monitor and analyse hydrological data and pass it on to the people who need it most. But it might be a lot cheaper than flying out helicopters and lifeboats, blankets, bottled water, medical supplies, food, tents, doctors and engineers, to a nation already practically washed away by disaster.

webTitle: Food now priority as waters drop

fields.headline: Food now priority as waters drop
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique floods: special report
Disaster Relief - MOD site
Disasters Emergency Committee - Mozambique Floods Appeal
Department for International Development
fields.trailText: Dozens of helicopters and about £25m of other supplies were finally dispersed across Mozambique yesterday as the operation to rescue flood victims from imminent death turned into a massive airlift to feed and shelter them.
fields.body:
Dozens of helicopters and about £25m of other supplies were finally dispersed across Mozambique yesterday as the operation to rescue flood victims from imminent death turned into a massive airlift to feed and shelter them.

The British and other contingents arrived with boats, life rafts and other sea rescue equipment besides helicopters. But over the weekend the flood waters dropped sharply and large numbers of those who were trapped were able to walk to safety.

With conditions in many of the makeshift refugee camps deteriorating, logistical difficulties loomed over fuel supplies and lack of coordination.

The threat from cyclone Gloria has receded after it broke up over Madagascar, killing an estimated 30 people there.

But meteorologists are predicting heavy rains early this week which could again flood the Limpopo and Save rivers, hampering the relief effort and again swamping homes.

About 60 helicopters and planes, including four British Pumas flown via South Africa, are now either working in Mozambique or are expected shortly. About 600 American troops are also on their way.

While the international assistance was being gathered last week, the presumption was that it would be dedicated to plucking stranded Mozambicans from trees and roofs, as the South African air force had been doing for days.

The priority now is to get food, clean water and medicines to the scattered camps.

Some house 50,000 people, many with malaria. Others are sheltering just a few hundred. At least 250,000 people will require regular supplies of food until they can replant their swamped fields.

The World Food Programme has 8,000 tonnes of food stockpiled in Mozambique and says the problem now is how to distribute it, with roads and railways wrecked by the floods. Much will be dispersed by helicopter, and possibly some by boat to smaller or more remote riverside communities.

The United Nations is trying to persuade people not to return to their homes immediately, because of the threat of further flooding, and because it will be much harder to distribute food and clean water to dispersed communities.

"We are trying to discourage them from going back by giving them support in the camps," said Ross Mountain, the UN special humanitarian envoy. "But we recognise that it's a very human reaction to want to get back to your home as soon as possible."

Rescue workers began recovering the first bodies from Chokwe, one of the towns worst hit when water surged down the Limpopo river more than a week ago. Among the victims discovered by Médecins Sans Frontières was a man who had been chained because the locals said he was "violently insane".

"When people are walking into their homes they are finding a body or a dead relative," said Chris Horta of MSF. "As water levels fall, bodies emerge. There is news of a lot more along the main road and also in the fields."

Aid agencies have criticised a lack of coordination among the foreign contingents. The UN, which is overseeing the operation with the Mozambique government, concedes that there are problems.

"Things are coming together. There's no such thing as perfect coordination, but this is now under control," Mr Mountain said.

webTitle: Of course humanity cares: it's people you can't rely on

fields.headline: Of course humanity cares: it's people you can't rely on
fields.standfirst:
The so-called world community was less than united on the floods

Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: What does it amount to, this "world community" we constantly invoke? The world community that must act/hasn't acted swiftly enough/has shamefully failed to act. And what would I think about it if I'd been stuck up a tree in Mozambique for nine days?
fields.body:
What does it amount to, this "world community" we constantly invoke? The world community that must act/hasn't acted swiftly enough/has shamefully failed to act. And what would I think about it if I'd been stuck up a tree in Mozambique for nine days? The coinage of such community, slipping easily from the lips of politicians who become "world" statesmen when they use it, seems simple enough. Nation shall combine with nation to defend human rights and save human lives - because we are all human beings, locked immutably together on the same planet. But words don't make communities. That's people business.

I ran a small, frail, people test this weekend, sampling the headlines on dozens of newspaper websites around the globe. News choices are indicative. They tell you what professional editors (who make a buck, day after day, by providing reportage that sells in their cities and countries) think will turn their paying community of customers on.

A reassuring test - at least at first sight - for Britain. Our serious newspapers, following a vivid TV agenda, have led time and again on the waters engulfing the flat lands along the Limpopo. They are interested in aid and they are interested in finding out how it has flowed. Their readers, meanwhile, are stumping up lots of cash.

Stray a little wider afield, though. The Los Angeles Times is the greatest paper in America's richest state: a land of swimming pools and helicopter pads. It is excited about gang warfare on 18th Street, sleazy contributions to the Democrats and Jerry Seinfeld buying a $40m home in the Hamptons. It covers the world from Pinochet to Poland's ban on pornography: but Maputo is not high on that list.

Ah! Miami. Another rich city, and one that knows all about floods, storms and natural disasters. Big news for the Miami Herald: the CIA is updating its psychological profile of Fidel Castro, a hungry eel is threatening the everglades and Pinochet is home. (Helicopters do make it on to the frontline - but this is a TV news chopper crashed in Kendall, Florida).

To Europe and Turin, Italy: La Stampa has a controversial death sentence on its hands; a city centre Sunday sees all cars banned; there's a "petrolio record" with "benzina a 2.140 lire"; and 37 Russian soldiers would seem to have died in Chechnya. El Mundo in Madrid has an election poll and Pinochet.

Sydney, Australia? It's gay and lesbian Mardi Gras day for the Morning Herald (and the prime minister is "scratching his head" over dotcom share prices). Toronto, Canada? Some Canadian troops in Kosovo have had a difficult time with "ethnic tension boiling over", as it does. Drug prices may be going up because of a World Trade Organisation ruling.

New Delhi? The Times of India brings you political crises in Patna, a censorship row over the film Elizabeth, a bomb in the Punjab and confirmation that Bill Clinton will be staying at the Sheraton when he passes through India in a couple of weeks.

Even Africa has other things on its mind. Nairobi's Daily Nation offers bank frauds, runaway Mombasa drug tycoons and Colin McRae's rally car getting stuck at a river crossing, but no wider disasters. "Kenya won't have floods, says forecast".

It is vital, I think, to see what these samplings say - and don't say - about us, all of us.

No moral absolutes. They don't glibly portray a global phalanx of bad samaritans passing by on the other side of the road. There are a few decent stories from Mozambique buried deep in some of the sites. This is not a crude matching of selfishness against compassion, insularity against internationalism. The equation is a damned sight more complicated than that.

Whatever we may conveniently believe, we don't act or think like a world community because no such "community", in any meaningful sense, exists.

Every thought we have about the world, indeed, starts from our immediate surroundings and interests. A bomb in the Punjab matters if you are a Punjabi reading the Times of India. Readers of the Miami Herald want to know if Fidel's losing his marbles. Utterly natural, inescapable, blameless. Even British concern over Mozambique, on closer examination, operates to the selfsame rhythms. In the beginning there were stretching square miles of water and tens of thousands of destitute human beings huddled on tin roofs or lying along tree branches. But see how the focus shifts.

By Saturday (the lead story in the Times): "Britain's emergency aid programme to Mozambique ran into trouble yesterday when a simmering row between Clare Short and the ministry of defence exploded in public." By Sunday, the Observer has our Whitehall masters "cynically attempting to manipulate public opinion" through double counting aid money - while the Conservatives chunter on about "clumsy efforts to regain the moral high ground".

Bring those strands together in a Sunday Times leader comment. For all the "disaster area" in our own bureaucratic backyard, "Britain can hold its head high in Mozambique". We didn't play "time-wasting diplomacy" like South Africa. We didn't, like France, have a helicopter carrier in the region and do nothing. Our ministers, like Mozambique's own, didn't waste time on "fact-finding" missions.

"Britain should take the lead in finding new ways to react more speedily." London would make an ideal headquarters "for a new international rescue centre, working with the United States, the UN and the EU". And "action man himself, Paddy Ashdown, would be the ideal candidate to head it".

See how effortlessly, over a few days of mounting tragedy, this "world story" has become just another of those British stories full of bitter cabinet intrigues, dozy foreigners, soundbites from Francis Maude and potential employment prospects for Captain Ashdown. Meanwhile, the South African press is leading on the Pretoria summit coordinating present and future disaster planning between South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe and Mozambique - and Britain, strangely, doesn't rate a mention.

News choices, of course, aren't reality: but they are versions of a perceived reality which matters. Television needs pictures. Newspapers have to relate to the lives of their readers. And the only consistent information you can be sure of picking up on a hotel cable TV or from the newsstand in the lobby anywhere in the world is the closing prices in Japan, Frankfurt, Wall Street and points west.

London won't become Rescue HQ International, with Paddy at the helm. Such notions are built on an edifice of British self-perception (and self-importance) which doesn't travel beyond Dover. The misery of Mozambique looks different from country to country and continent to continent. There is no common understanding or reaction. One world? Not without the people who live in it, there isn't.

"Kenya won't have floods, says forecast". It is vital, I think, to see what these samplings say - and don't say - about us, all of us. No moral absolutes. They don't glibly portray a global phalanx of bad samaritans passing by on the other side of the road. There are a few decent stories from Mozambique buried deep in some of the sites. This is not a crude matching of selfishness against compassion, insularity against internationalism. The equation is a damned sight more complicated than that. Whatever we may conveniently believe, we don't act or think like a world community because no such "community", in any meaningful sense, exists. Every thought we have about the world, indeed, starts from our immediate surroundings and interests. A bomb in the Punjab matters if you are a Punjabi reading the Times of India. Readers of the Miami Herald want to know if Fidel's losing his marbles. Utterly natural, inescapable, blameless. Even British concern over Mozambique, on closer examination, operates to the selfsame rhythms. In the beginning there were stretching square miles of water and tens of thousands of destitute human beings huddled on tin roofs or lying along tree branches. But see how the focus shifts. By Saturday (the lead story in the Times): "Britain's emergency aid programme to Mozambique ran into trouble yesterday when a simmering row between Clare Short and the ministry of defence exploded in public." By Sunday, the Observer has our Whitehall masters "cynically attempting to manipulate public opinion" through double counting aid money - while the Conservatives chunter on about "clumsy efforts to regain the moral high ground". Bring those strands together in a Sunday Times leader comment. For all the "disaster area" in our own bureaucratic backyard, "Britain can hold its head high in Mozambique". We didn't play "time-wasting diplomacy" like South Africa. We didn't, like France, have a helicopter carrier in the region and do nothing. Our ministers, like Mozambique's own, didn't waste time on "fact-finding" missions. "Britain should take the lead in finding new ways to react more speedily." London would make an ideal headquarters "for a new international rescue centre, working with the United States, the UN and the EU". And "action man himself, Paddy Ashdown, would be the ideal candidate to head it". See how effortlessly, over a few days of mounting tragedy, this "world story" has become just another of those British stories full of bitter cabinet intrigues, dozy foreigners, soundbites from Francis Maude and potential employment prospects for Captain Ashdown. Meanwhile, the South African press is leading on the Pretoria summit coordinating present and future disaster planning between South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe and Mozambique - and Britain, strangely, doesn't rate a mention. News choices, of course, aren't reality: but they are versions of a perceived reality which matters. Television needs pictures. Newspapers have to relate to the lives of their readers. And the only consistent information you can be sure of picking up on a hotel cable TV or from the newsstand in the lobby anywhere in the world is the closing prices in Japan, Frankfurt, Wall Street and points west. London won't become Rescue HQ International, with Paddy at the helm. Such notions are built on an edifice of British self-perception (and self-importance) which doesn't travel beyond Dover. The misery of Mozambique looks different from country to country and continent to continent. There is no common understanding or reaction. One world? Not without the people who live in it, there isn't.

webTitle: Online companies spent £150m on advertising last year. Did it work?

fields.headline: Online companies spent £150m on advertising last year. Did it work?
fields.standfirst: Oliver Rowe  reports on the business of getting your dot com company recognised in the real world
fields.trailText: Oliver Rowe reports on the business of getting your dot com company recognised in the real world
fields.body:
It is one of the most important questions you have to face. You are setting up an internet business. Everybody tells you that marketing and advertising the site will make or break you. There is no point having a good idea if nobody hears about it.

So you siphon off a large part of your launch budget for the purposes of building your brand. Domination of your market is what you seek. And to achieve that you pay advertising companies lots of money to tell the world that you have arrived.

But does it work? Advertising and media agencies up and down the country have certainly enjoyed a windfall over the past few months. But new figures revealed here show that many companies, whatever they spend on advertising their wares, are not getting the immediate brand recognition they crave.

As we all know, brand is king. "The only effective barrier to entry in e-commerce is branding," says Simon Murdoch of Amazon. David Taylor, head of digital branding at the Added Value Company, a leading brand consultancy, concurs. "Dot com companies have a real need to develop a clear positioning and identity to survive and prosper in the long run."

Data from ACNielsen MMS, which records advertising expenditure, shows that online companies spent in excess of £150m on advertising in 1999 - not including direct mail, spon sorship or promotions. This has all been spent advertising online brands in the real world of traditional media. It represents a threefold increase in what was spent in 1998. However the issue now is whether these companies are getting value for money.

This should cause some alarm for online companies because what naturally preoccupies all advertisers is how effective their advertising spend actually is. One key measure of advertising effectiveness is awareness of the brand amongst the public. Research undertaken in the last two weeks by CIA MediaLab as part of its Sensor study has analysed what the UK's major online companies spend on advertisers and compared it to people's awareness of the brand.

What is clear from this analysis is that the public's awareness of your brand and the amount you actually spend on advertising are certainly related. But, more worryingly for those spending precious resources telling the public "We're here!", some brands have got more recognition bang for their advertising buck.

Let's look at the figures. Four major brands, AOL, Yahoo!, Freeserve and BT, all achieve awareness of over 40% amongst the UK adult population. The amount each has spent on advertising differs hugely, raising the question: who has the most effective advertising? Of course the level of recognition also reflects other factors such as the time since each launched and the amount of press coverage they have received.

Looking specifically at internet service providers (ISPs) we find that AOL has only been outspent by Freeserve. The two have very similar awareness levels despite the fact that AOL has been around much longer than Freeserve. AOL's recent merger with Time Warner will certainly have helped general awareness levels. What is clear is that Freeserve has been more aggressively going after market share, but AOL has decided to fight back with a spend of around £1.4m in the past two months.

It should be made clear that advertising needs to play a different role in the marketing mix as the brand moves through its cycle from an initial launch, to growth to maturity. These ISPs are still growing but are using advertising to help attract both existing and new internet users.

The fascinating part of all this is not only trying to work out why differing levels of advertising spend have delivered different results, but also why so many companies are spending so much on advertising. The perception is that there is currently an opportunity to build online brands, and thus market share, more quickly and easily (and cheaply) than in a year or two's time when the internet will be a bigger place. When a market is being launched it is cheaper to buy a share while it is still small than try and steal it off competitors once the market has matured. It is for this reason that venture capitalists are keen to give promising young internet start-ups large sums of money to spend advertising their brand before someone else gets into that sector of the market.

A prime example of the advantage of being first to market can be seen in the differences in awareness levels and advertising spend between Amazon and BOL. Despite spending nearly £3.7m on advertising in the last 12 months BOL only has an awareness of 27% amongst people who used the internet in the past month. This compares to a significantly higher awareness of 75% for Amazon from a slightly smaller spend.

Maintaining awareness is an easier job than gaining it in the first place. Also, the amount BOL has spent on advertising does not compare favourably to other online brands such as Lastminute which has a 29% awareness from a £1m spend. Meanwhile, online retailer Boo has spent more than £750,000 in the past two months and has failed to show any significant change in awareness amongst CIA's sample.

To be fair, asking people whether they are aware of a brand at a particular moment in time is a relatively crude measure of advertising effec tiveness. However, doing it amongst a pre-defined target audience that has been agreed by the brand owners and the media agency is a good place to start, but media agencies do get judged by the awareness they deliver. Even so, as for AOL and Freeserve, achieving awareness may only be the first part of the advertising process. As well as achieving awareness, advertising needs to communicate some brand values which should help drive share and loyalty.

The temptation for brands is to launch with a fanfare to the world, but without any budget left they cannot follow it up. The result is that brand awareness will quickly decay. It could be argued that some brands should use their advertising budget more wisely.

Media agencies could more accurately target the right consumers, possibly using other media and over a longer period of time, thus satisfying the joint media requirements of frequency of advertising exposure and recency. But does this excite investors, or the MD, as much as blowing the annual budget on a few weeks of high-profile TV advertising?

One sector that is moving wholeheartedly online is banking, and its experience with advertising and brand building holds some important lessons. As yet unreleased research by CIA shows that amongst those that have already opened an online bank account or who intend to open one in the next year, 89% of those aware of Egg say it appeals to them as a brand. This compares to only 60% for the parent brand Prudential. The Smile brand appeals to 70% of those aware of it in this target audience compared to 58% for parent Co-operative Bank. Smile has shown impressive awareness growth in the last two months on the back of a £1.2m advertising budget.

Advertising is clearly establishing new values for a new brand while trying not to cannibalise the existing customer base of the parent.

As the internet audience grows, then so the amount brands will be encouraged to spend on advertising will increase until those that can't afford to play the spend game drop out or get bought up. Make sure your brand works. Spend money on advertising. But make sure it works.

webTitle: What the hell is Rupert up to?

fields.headline: What the hell is Rupert up to?
fields.standfirst: A year ago he was   branded anti-net after  claiming it would destroy companies. Now he's       flirting with Yahoo!.  Edward Helmore          wonders...                    What the hell is Rupert up                                                                               to?                                                                                What the hell is Rupert up                                                                               to?
fields.trailText:
A year ago he was branded anti-net after claiming it would destroy companies. Now he's flirting with Yahoo!. Edward Helmore
wonders...
What the hell is Rupert up
to?
What the hell is Rupert up
to?
fields.body:
The news last week of Rupert Murdoch's unconfirmed flirtation with Yahoo!, the internet's largest portal, comes as little surprise in the wake of the $181bn (£120bn) AOL/Time-Warner deal. No old-media company feels safe in the world of new media and the partnerships now being formed between the two often appear to be less predicated on strategy than on sheer panic.

But though Murdoch has been a late starter in recognising and embracing the internet, he now appears ready to commit to an effort to broaden his focus from television, print and film, and to build a web presence for disseminating News Corp content as the medium itself develops into a comprehensive, interactive delivery system.

Under a News Corp-Yahoo! deal, which was reported by the New Yorker last week, Yahoo! may take a 5% stake in Murdoch's global satellite-television systems that are being consolidated into a new $35bn company, Platco. In return, Yahoo! would get satellite distribution around the world in places that are not wired for cable and receive content from Murdoch's Fox and News Corporation operations.

"Media companies must now look to be total media companies, which includes the internet, and they must be on a global scale as well," says Barry Hyman, an analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum in New York. "AOL-Time-Warner has proved that the internet is a real dis tribution point, and what News Corp has is tremendous content and distribution."

Though no merger is likely - Yahoo! remains deeply dubious about forging any singular alliance, especially with a traditional media company that would slow down growth - the fact that Murdoch is now actively seeking to get hip to the internet is, as has been noted previously, a remarkable shift in attitude. Just over a year ago, speaking at a forum in Singapore, he dismissed internet stocks as overvalued and warned that the net "will destroy more businesses than it creates".

But, interestingly, in an interview with this month's Wired magazine, Murdoch says that his scepticism over the medium was overplayed. "I was thought to be anti-internet, which I never was at all," he says. "I did say I don't know how you justify the price of some of these stocks - which I still say, but I've been wrong."

Murdoch's conversion - one steered by his son James, head of News Corp's digital media arm - is one that's clearly mindful of avoiding the pitfalls of trying to create a substantive internet presence that other old-media giants have experienced. Before merging with AOL, Time-Warner sank millions of dollars into its Pathfinder portal without much success, and Disney's Go Network has yet to produce a significant web presence. News Corp itself lost millions of dollars in the now forgotten information service, Delphi, and nearly pumped $400m into Pointcast, the technology firm that recently sold for just $20m.

According to people close to News Corp, the phone-lines to internet firms, communications giants and investors from the company's mid-Manhattan tower are open and it has been in talks with an A-list of investors including Microsoft, Nokia, Vodafone AirTouch and the giant Japanese investment firm Softbank.

"They've been taking their time trying to figure out what's the best thing for their company," say Charlene Li, an analyst at Forrester Research. "The portal war is over. Yahoo!, AOL, and to some extent MSN, dominate the market. It doesn't makes sense to try to compete with them, so you're better off as partners."

Media analysts have long wondered how Murdoch would make his net plans play. A deal with Yahoo!, while modest by comparison with others in the media world, at least gives Murdoch the imprimatur of web credibility and shows that he's serious about the internet. "News Corp gains a key partner, and respect, and possibly an internet strategy which could be expanded over time," says Barry Hyman.

As television and the internet merge with the advent of broadband distribution, Murdoch appears perfectly positioned to enter the game. Spinning off the satellite systems should generate enough cash to turn the business - which includes 40% of BSkyB and Asia's Star TV - into a global powerhouse for the digital delivery of high-speed internet access, television, email and e-commerce.

Moreover, by partitioning the business between content and digital distribution systems (Platco), Murdoch would reap a stratospheric market valuation that has eluded News Corp as a single company. "One of the undervalued parts of News Corp was always their wireless satellite-based business and that was the reason to separate, so that each would get its proper valuation," says Hyman.

And a higher valuation protects Murdoch from aggressors. In a recent interview he described News Corp as a "minnow". "I have to work harder than ever to have my values recognised by the market, so that we don't become a breakfast snack for these other big companies," he said. It may turn out that Murdoch's laissez faire attitude to the internet may was more sensible - or just more lucky - than most observers thought. "Given their brand name and their content, I think they have amazing advantages over the early movers," says Jessica Reif Cohen at Merrill Lynch.

"And they didn't have to spend the money to see how the market would develop." But does Murdoch regret not getting into it earlier, such as when he turned down a stake in a nascent AOL? "Sure. In hindsight, it would have been lovely to have a big stake of Yahoo! when it was only worth $500m or something, or AOL or whatever," he told Wired. "But a lot of people put too much money into this too early."

Over the last six months, News Corp has bought stakes in more than dozen dot coms, most notably a 10.8% stake in Healtheon/WebMD, a company that sells health care services over the internet. But News Corp's future path is not without problems. In the US, Murdoch does not have the kind of distribution he enjoys in the rest of the world. Satellite distribution is tiny compared to cable, which Time Warner and John Malone dominate. Murdoch will have to make do with a future that lies in distributing news and entertainment outside the US in less well connected regions, like Europe, Asia and South America.

In China, Murdoch is on potential collision course with Richard Li, the son of Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's most powerful businessman. Last week, Li won a bid for the Hong Kong television and internet provider HKT defeating a Murdoch-backed bid. Given Star TV's bumpy ride with the Chinese government, and the $1.5bn Murdoch has sunk into it since 1995 without seeing a profit, it's no wonder that he views the internet as a medium with more revolutionary potential.

"Governments can regulate satellites. You have licensing of the spectrum, and you can identify people with dishes. But once the internet starts to pass through, it's pretty hard to do much about it," he says. "You can't afford to say, 'We won't develop a telephone system so people can't have the internet'. You'll just rot as a country, you'll be left so far behind."

Murdoch's link-up with Yahoo! is likely to be the first of many, dispelling the notion fostered by AOL/Time-Warner that it's necessary to merge in order to marry content and distribution. Analyst Barry Hyman suggests that News Corp is now poised to reap the benefits of years of investment in everything from movie studios to satellites.

"Rupert Murdoch has always had an aggressiveness, he's never been afraid to expand and take on debt to get to another level," he says. "He's been building something that may not be appreciated for years, and that seems to be the case with all the wireless acquisitions he's made in Europe, Asia and South America. Now they're coming to the forefront because we are moving towards a wireless world."

fields.headline: Repelling the space invaders
fields.trailText: American eye
fields.body:
The telephone calls started a few weeks after I moved to the US last year. Several times a week, my home answering machine would repeat chirpy messages from strangers telling me about some offer I would be a fool to turn down.

It was annoying but also profoundly disturbing. I had no idea how these people knew my name or home telephone number. Then a friend told me that the next time a salesperson called, I should cite my legal right to have my details erased from their telemarketing lists. It worked and I've only had a handful of calls since.

The problem with the internet and the wealth of personal information collected about us online is that few of my friends, or anyone else's, know exactly how to stop businesses collecting personal information and doing what they want with it.

This basic sense of unease about the amount of information being gathered and lack of control over it has been one of the biggest failures of online companies to date. For the first time, companies are able to track our behaviour as well as buy our vital statistics and their use of such information is still unclear. Chief among the culprits are online advertisers, who sell information about users to enable their clients to target advertising.

Last month, US regulators launched an investigation into DoubleClick, the world's biggest online advertising company, because of its plans to link the surfing habits of individuals to their personal information. The public outcry has forced the company to delay its plans until new privacy standards are agreed.

But it has argued that its sophisticated tracking capabilities ultimately benefit consumers who want to receive relevant ads. On a broader level, it accuses anti-ad web surfers of being naive because ads keep the web free.

This argument, which touches on the much larger issue of online privacy in general, could shape the way the web is used by media and information companies.

These industries tend to base their business plans on the sale of personal information and are busily working out how best to capitalise on the new information-gathering potential of the web.

My telephone headaches could have come from the welter of sub scriptions I took out on arriving in New York, as well as from the number of new services I signed up for.

Europans enjoy greater legal protection against privacy invasion. But the row over DoubleClick suggests that there is still a need for more information and clarification about an issue which leaves most either nonplussed or vaguely worried.

A draft European privacy directive is set to insist that all online companies notify consumers about what information they are collecting and provide them with the choice of opting out.

The problem with notification is that a company's privacy policy is hardly the first thing that jumps out of a typical home page. How many people have ever bothered to find one, let alone read it and opt out before buying that belated birthday present?

DoubleClick, which has agreements with more than 1,300 websites in 22 different countries, says that about 15 people a day opt out of its data collection scheme. The company argues that this low figure reflects the fact that people like targeted ads - fly fishermen receiving information on rods, one assumes. But it also reflects the fact that few people realise that DoubleClick exists, let alone that it is able to collect a vast amount of information about them.

We do not have to read and refuse every company's online information policies. We can also follow an apparently simple procedure of changing our identities ("cookies") on our computers so that we are no longer recognised by individual websites.

The essential problem with this approach is that the vast majority of people in the UK and US think of cookies as either chocolate chip or plain rather than a piece of computer code.

Once you do disable your individual identification biscuits you also wipe out your web preferences. In simple terms, this could mean that you would have to type in your password every time you clicked onto your favourite website.

Advocates of privacy argue that this is a small price to pay, but I'm not so sure. The problem is that most people want their web surfing to speed up, not slow down.

Most people who accept advertising as a necessary online evil would rather be targeted by ads about things they're interested in. The problem starts when this activity appears secret - as with DoubleClick - or becomes annoying, as with the home phone calls. In both cases, acquiring our own information can often make the problem go away.

Online companies would be wise to compete for the clearest, most obvious privacy policies as well as the cheapest prices. Most companies produce a privacy statement but fail to advertise it. Events over the past few weeks have suggested that they should.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
Steve Outing, Stop the Presses
www.mediainfo.com
In last week's column about how print publications need to adapt to survive in the internet age, I closed out with a small bit of advice:

"Accept the fact that your printed newspaper or magazine is only one piece in the information stew being served up to future news consumers. Try to guide them through our information-rich culture, rather than trying to hold on to them solely - which is a lost cause in a media environment where there are so many choices."

Dale Pearson of The FSBO Store & Magazine wrote in with this reaction: "I'd strongly suggest that you move (that) point to the top of the list. This should not be an afterthought. This IS the heart and soul of the matter! This is what is causing headaches for newspaper editors. Unfortunately, until the old-timers retire or die off, the industry will be stuck with this thinking." He's right.

Jon Katz 'Middle Media'
www.slashdot.org
For years, Old Media dismissed electronic competitors as frivolous and temporal. Then new media appeared to be burying its predecessors for good. It appears both notions may have been wrong. The boundaries between new and old media are getting fuzzy, as a hybrid middle media emerges between the two.

Most "old" media now have "new" appendages, adjuncts and outlets, especially on the web. And the people using new media still acquire information and use culture in traditional forms - they go to megaplexes, read magazines, follow books.

One small but telling example was reported in American Demographic magazine's March issue, which reported that dot com companies - Garden.com, Wine.com, Tavolo.com and jewelry retailer Miadora.com, among others - are successfully experimenting with print catalogues.

Another indication of an emerging middle media is the fact that the journalistic move from paper to e-news has gone from a trickle to a flood. Reporters are leaving newsrooms all over the country to work for online information sites. These reporters, leaving papers like the Wall Street Journal and New York Times and smaller papers in chains like Gannett, are bringing traditional journalistic sensibilities to e-news, which until now has been much more free and raucous than the offline press.

ePeople expect to contribute to and participate in their information media, and to hold pundits, columnists and other information-givers accountable for what they report, think and write.

But as Garden.com's sweet-smelling catalogues show, the boundaries between old and new media are getting tougher to find. What is visible is a new and hybrid information structure, a new media species all its own.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText:
Stress at the top
If you are stressed at work, spare a thought for your boss. A report from the Institute of Management paints a picture of overworked, under-resourced executives struggling to meet daily challenges. Top of the list of stress factors for Britain's bosses include meeting deadlines, constant interruptions, lack of support, and incompetent senior managers. But today's "macho" culture means few can admit they are not coping. The Taking the Strain report says seven in 10 managers have more work than a year ago, and over a third feel unable to cope with the workload.
fields.body:
Stress at the top
If you are stressed at work, spare a thought for your boss. A report from the Institute of Management paints a picture of overworked, under-resourced executives struggling to meet daily challenges. Top of the list of stress factors for Britain's bosses include meeting deadlines, constant interruptions, lack of support, and incompetent senior managers. But today's "macho" culture means few can admit they are not coping. The Taking the Strain report says seven in 10 managers have more work than a year ago, and over a third feel unable to cope with the workload.

Personnel in practice
With 350 exhibitors, the Human Resource Development 2000 exhibition promises a wealth of resources for those involved in personnel issues. Taking place from 4-6 April at Olympia in London, the show launches a new interactive arena, with 45-minute training taster sessions on various topics. Visitors can try out the activity zone, offering hands-on experience of different tools and techniques. More details from www.ipd.co.uk/conferences or call 0208 263 3434.

Travellers' tales
Women executives still get a raw deal compared to male colleagues when they travel. Both men and women reported in a survey for Company Barclaycard that men are treated better - they are more likely to be offered hotel and flight upgrades, are generally served first in bars, and are given better restaurant tables. Worse, women are repeatedly perceived as "employees" whereas men are assumed to be "employers". Helena Dennison, chair of Women's City Network, says, "It's depressing to see how little attitudes have changed."

A chance to shine
Are you the one who has all the good ideas, while your boss gets the credit? Here's a chance to shine - and perhaps win a holiday at the same time. 3M, manufacturer of Post-It notes, and Executary International, magazine has launched a campaign to recognise PAs' bright ideas, and there are three European city breaks up for grabs for the winners. If you've had a brainwave about better office administration or management, or you want to nominate a colleague, email jbw@executaryinternational.com for an application form.

DTI clarification
As reported last week, the DTI proposes replacing the system of "temp to perm" fees paid by employers to agencies with an extended hire period for temps, followed by a free transfer to permanent status. But the DTI wishes to stress that it was never its intention to abolish the fee outright.

 Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: Desktop icons
fields.standfirst: No 9: Filing trays
fields.trailText: It was a big year, 1969. Humans made it to the moon. British troops were sent into Ulster. Ho Chi Minh died. And the Avery Systemtray 44 was invented.
fields.body:
It was a big year, 1969. Humans made it to the moon. British troops were sent into Ulster. Ho Chi Minh died. And the Avery Systemtray 44 was invented.

You have to admire the lack of self-consciousness of Avery, manufacturer of the first ever plastic filing tray. Its press release rates the innovation of its office equipment alongside Armstrong and Aldrin walking on the moon, as if daring us to judge which event was the more significant.

It is fair to say, after all, that the immediate benefits of the lunar expeditions are still unclear - the cure for cancer was not, alas, discovered among the tonnes of moonrocks that the Apollo missions brought home (although Nasa did establish once and for all that it wasn't made of green cheese, which must have had significant scientific ramifications).

Plastic filing trays, on the other hand, have obvious benefits, as 10m users have discovered in the intervening 31 years. They allow you to file vertically. And, well, that's about it. Not exactly multifunctional, but as we become more demanding of our implements - expecting pens to double as torches, keyrings and satellite homing devices - there is surely much to be said for simplicity of purpose. Put a file in a plastic filing tray, and - unforeseen factors being removed from the equation - it should still be there the next day. We don't ask much of our filing systems, but being able to find a piece of paper where you left it should never be underestimated.

Complicating features being nil, plastic tray owners are free to concentrate on the really important details. Three trays or four? Black, grey, navy or (you devil, you) red? And perhaps most importantly, what goes on top - In, Out or Pending?

Little cuddly toys, incriminating photos from the Christmas party and copies of the National Enquirer should, of course, be carefully filed at the bottom of a drawer.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: As the daughter of a diplomat, Lysette Herrera's background is certainly cosmopolitan. She has lived in Venezuela, France and Brazil, and for the past eight years she has been based in Las Vegas where she recently graduated with a degree in psychology from the university of Nevada. Her ambition to become a neurologist has been put on hold as she takes time out of studying to travel.
fields.body:
As the daughter of a diplomat, Lysette Herrera's background is certainly cosmopolitan. She has lived in Venezuela, France and Brazil, and for the past eight years she has been based in Las Vegas where she recently graduated with a degree in psychology from the university of Nevada. Her ambition to become a neurologist has been put on hold as she takes time out of studying to travel.

"I came to London on an exchange programme last year and have been working for Westminster adult education services." Based in Maida Vale in west London, Herrera's job as a data inputter is, she admits, not difficult - and can be repetitive. But she enjoys the college atmosphere and having hundreds of students milling around. "Classes take place throughout the day, from arts to computing to sport, and it's good to see 90-year-olds doing exercise classes."

She has just finished inputting information into the institute's prospectus for the next academic year, and although her typing speed is only 45wpm, she thinks she finished faster than her employers expected. But the work keeps on coming. "I've been typing up all the blurb. Once the students have enrolled, they fill in extensive forms with information such as the fees they've paid, their addresses, phone numbers, marketing and medical information. We get all student records from our six main centres and around 13 community venues."

Herrera is no newcomer to data inputting. In Las Vegas she worked at the world's most expensive hotel, Bellagio's, which cost $1.6bn (£1bn) to build. "I used to work in the reservations department and I would input customers' bookings. The hotel has 3,000 rooms and there were always long telephone queues. I once won a contest - the company offered a room in the hotel to the person who made the most bookings. I won and stayed in a 1,500-ft square suite."

Working at a computer terminal all day can be monotonous - and unhealthy too. Herrera offers the following tips:

* If you are working long hours, it is important to take regular breaks.

* If possible, do some other aspect of your job such as filing during those gaps. Stretch your legs, or go and get a drink.

* Go easy on the eyes: blink often, and take regular screen breaks.

* It helps if you have a radio in the office, and even if you play it at a low level it passes the time.

* Maintain good posture: sit upright without slouching into the back of your chair. Use a footstool for further comfort.

* Have something inspiring on your desk, be it a small plant, a flower, a picture or a book.

* Get out at lunchtime and go for a walk, no matter how short.

fields.headline: Why go out to work?
fields.standfirst: It is no longer essential for support staff to be in the same place as their bosses. As a result, more PAs are choosing to stay at home.  Bill Saunders  reports
fields.trailText: It is no longer essential for support staff to be in the same place as their bosses. As a result, more PAs are choosing to stay at home. Bill Saunders reports
fields.body:
Many of the received wisdoms about secretaries have been proved wrong in recent years. They are not all women, many are highly qualified, and they certainly do more than take memos all day. But while the role of the office support worker may have changed beyond recognition, we at least expect them - by definition - to work from the office.

Increasingly, even this assumption cannot be relied on. As developments in communications outstrip the importance of being on the premises, a new generation of secretaries has realised that they can report to work without ever leaving the house.

Paula Graham, a senior secretary to a director of a department in the Royal Mail, is something of a pioneer in this area. She has worked from home for six years - since the days when email was new to most of us - and describes the original decision as "a wild Friday afternoon idea". But her manager had the imagination to see it might work, and after a successful six-week trial, Graham established her office at home.

Having linked her PC to the office main frame for such traditional jobs as diary management, she is available to answer the telephone from 9am to 5pm. But she also has the time to take her daughter to school. There is a great deal of flexibility on both sides, she says. "Sometimes I will work for an hour or two at weekends." But never more - "because it's not fair to my family".

You don't necessarily need a flexibly minded employer in order to work from home. "Portfolio employment" - working for more than one employer on a consultancy basis - was one of the buzz concepts for managers in the 1990s. And now secretaries are following the example.

Sarah Pugh made this move out of necessity. Last February her youngest son, aged eight, was left temporarily paralysed after being knocked down by a car. With the prospect of five or six hospital visits a month, she felt it was no longer fair to her family or employer to continue as a PA at Lewisham College.

She decided her skills would suit freelance life, invested £1,500 in computer equipment, and set up an office in what had been the au pair's bedroom. So far she has worked mostly for "small local companies where there is a shortage of hands". But her work is concerned more with professional advice than taking in typing. "I help put in systems for people who aren't necessarily systems-minded," she says.

Jane Littlefield, head of the secretarial division at City recruitment firm Joslin Rowe, says the freelance PA is a growing trend. "With advances in technology increasingly allowing people to work from home, it is now possible for someone to have a secretary or PA who supports them from a completely separate location," she says. "For small companies, those in remote locations, or for any business where full-time secretarial support is either unnecessary or too costly, freelance PA or secretarial services are becoming a popular alternative solution."

BT has even launched a website designed to encourage employees to work from home, cleverly marketed as a way to stop work taking over your life in "a world where time has become the most valuable commodity". The attractions to BT are not hard to fathom - all those extra phone, fax and internet lines if more of us worked from home - but the site is nonetheless a well-designed and informative resource for workers wanting to investigate the possibility of working more flexibly.

But even if the technology is available, some of us will never be suited to working from home. It demands a certain self-sufficiency, agree both Graham and Pugh, and many people find it difficult to motivate themselves when isolated from colleagues. Graham goes into her office once a week, "because it is important to keep the social link". But, accustomed to working at her own pace, she admits she now finds the constant interruptions of office life distracting: "I usually have to find a quiet corner to work in!"

 BT's Timesmart website can be found at www.bt.com/timesmart

"I help put in systems for people who aren't necessarily systems-minded," she says. Jane Littlefield, head of the secretarial division at City recruitment firm Joslin Rowe, says the freelance PA is a growing trend. "With advances in technology increasingly allowing people to work from home, it is now possible for someone to have a secretary or PA who supports them from a completely separate location," she says. "For small companies, those in remote locations, or for any business where full-time secretarial support is either unnecessary or too costly, freelance PA or secretarial services are becoming a popular alternative solution." BT has even launched a website designed to encourage employees to work from home, cleverly marketed as a way to stop work taking over your life in "a world where time has become the most valuable commodity". The attractions to BT are not hard to fathom - all those extra phone, fax and internet lines if more of us worked from home - but the site is nonetheless a well-designed and informative resource for workers wanting to investigate the possibility of working more flexibly. But even if the technology is available, some of us will never be suited to working from home. It demands a certain self-sufficiency, agree both Graham and Pugh, and many people find it difficult to motivate themselves when isolated from colleagues. Graham goes into her office once a week, "because it is important to keep the social link". But, accustomed to working at her own pace, she admits she now finds the constant interruptions of office life distracting: "I usually have to find a quiet corner to work in!"  BT's Timesmart website can be found at www.bt.com/timesmart

fields.headline: The low down
fields.standfirst: The best managers
fields.trailText: The best managers
fields.body:
The suggestion that feminine qualities are better suited to modern management is well known. But last week research from the Industrial Society appeared to give the idea real substance.

The results of a survey published by the society showed that the best leadership came from women, the under 35s, and those working in the public sector. The study, the result of three years' research, asked workers to list the qualities they believed were important in management, and rate these against the skills of their current bosses.

Things are not quite that simple, of course. If women managers seem to have the qualities that workers admire - trustworthiness, delegation and the ability to set out clear goals - it does not necessarily follow that the qualities are intrinsically feminine. "We're not saying men can't do this," says Debra Allcock, head of campaigning at the Industrial Society.

By the same token the emphasis on youth can appear misleading. The fact that best management practice was seen to be concentrated among the under 35s is probably as significant as the anomaly that the best management practice was found in Scotland. It is most likely to be related to the fact that more open leadership was generally found lower down the corporate hierarchy, among teamleaders and supervisers, than among senior management. In fact when rated on trust, managers under 25 came out with the lowest rating, while those over 55 achieved the best.

It is clearly not a question of age alone, but of the qualities themselves, tempered by experience. The "command and control" style of management is gradually giving way to a more flexible and collegiate, and arguably more "feminine", approach. And managers of all ages must learn to adapt. "Whether they are 20, 40, or 60, they must accept that they have a limited shelf-life if they don't," says Allcock.
