webTitle: Industry in plea to Brown for budget priority

fields.headline: Industry in plea to Brown for budget priority
fields.standfirst:
Fears over dot-com mania

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Industry last night urged chancellor Gordon Brown to promote manufacturing in his budget two weeks tomorrow in the face of the increasing obsession with the dot.com economy.
fields.body:
Industry last night urged chancellor Gordon Brown to promote manufacturing in his budget two weeks tomorrow in the face of the increasing obsession with the dot.com economy.

But, as if to rub the old economy's nose in its own demise, a sextet or more of new economy stocks, the TMTs (telecoms, media and technology shares) such as Freeserve, the internet service provider, are set to join the FTSE 100 this week - at the expense of venerable companies.

Baltimore Technologies, the internet security firm, Capita, the support services company, Emap, the publishing house, Kingston Communications, the local Hull-owned phone company turned B2B pioneer, Psion, the handheld computer maker, and Thus, the telecoms arm of Scottish Power, join the big boys.

But out will go PowerGen, the energy group, Scottish & Newcastle, the brewer, Hanson, the building materials group, Thames Water, the utility group, Imperial Tobacco, Wolseley, the engineering company, and Whitbread, another brewer.

With industry stocks losing up to half their value in the last few months, the Engineering Employers Federation and 23 smaller bodies representing more than 10,000 firms and 2m employees, warned Mr Brown the strong pound could force production overseas.

In a joint submission they asked the chancellor to boost investment in manufacturing through a series of measures designed to encourage greater research and development. They want the budget to make first year allowances for small and medium-sized enterprises investing in or leasing plant and machinery made permanent.

They also want the proposed enterprise grants increased by £250m, the R&D tax credit extended to all manufacturing firms at a cost of £350m and the differential on road fuel duty with the rest of the EU gradually reduced.

Martin Temple, EEF director-general, said: "The government needs to recognise that whereas the economy overall may have continued to expand, manufacturing industry continues to suffer disproportionately to the rest of the economy through the imbalance of economic policy."

But, according to the 3i UK enterprise barometer, confidence among British commercial groups is at its highest for two years.

Almost two-thirds (64%) of firms backed by 3i expect to see an increase in the numbers they employ by the end of this year, many believe the time is very propitious for starting a new business and most see the climate for expanding existing businesses as better.

But non-manufacturing groups are more upbeat than manufacturers, with firms in the south the most optimistic about turnover and profitability prospects.

webTitle: I had one in the back of my cab

fields.headline: I had one in the back of my cab
fields.standfirst: In-car entertainment is a full-time job for Jackie Cleary. She tells  Eve Vamvas  about her vision of the future
fields.trailText: In-car entertainment is a full-time job for Jackie Cleary. She tells Eve Vamvas about her vision of the future
fields.body:
It's a frequent dilemma for commuters - how to pass the time while stuck in a black cab, with nothing to concentrate on but the fast advancing £s on the meter. Wouldn't it be great if you could watch the telly? Now that a test group of 100 cabs has been fitted with screens, that prospect is a little closer. CabVision offers a selection of programmes, from tourist information to music and classic comedy, to alleviate the gridlock boredom. It is expected to be in 1,000 cabs by the end of this year.

Jackie Cleary, 28, joined the company behind CabVision as it began to develop the technology and content for the project. As PA to Richard Dale, managing director at MEI Design, she has been involved in CabVision's production and management from its inception through to launch.

Cleary's route to her current post was circuitous. After leaving school she had a range of casual jobs - but knew that being a barmaid was not her long-term career choice. She invested in an intensive computer course and joined a financial services company as a 'junior'. "Because I'd had a few career false starts, I was a bit old to be a junior really, but that was the position my skills and experience merited. Being surrounded by school leavers actually made me more determined to learn quickly and move on."

She progressed through the administrative and secretarial ranks over the next four years to become PA to the director. When her boss took a promotion at a new private bank, Cleary was invited to go with her. But despite enjoying the job, she soon realised that her opportunities to progress any further in the finance industry were limited. Her boss was very encouraging about her need to make a move, recommending Cleary to colleagues in other industries. MEI was a client and when Dale heard of Cleary's plans to change direction, he 'poached' her to become his own PA.

Even though she had some prior knowledge of the company, Cleary found the first couple of months working in a new industry quite a shock. "Initially, I just didn't know where to start. The financial services sector tends to be ordered and routine, but here I never know what to expect when I walk into the office."

As well as performing PA functions such as diary management, Cleary can get involved in any aspect of a client project. She spends a lot of time on the phone, researching videos and CDs for soundtracks and showreels and sourcing props for conferences and exhibitions. One of her more unusual projects was finding 500 square metres of wind permeable material to be made into a huge All Blacks rugby shirt during the rugby world cup, and then coordinating an abseiling team to rig it up on the side of New Zealand house. For CabVision, some of Cleary's tasks involved liaising with the BBC to organise footage for the in-car entertainment sequence and helping with the additional filming by going up and down Bond Street acquiring empty designer carrier bags for the shopping stills.

"I feel that the work I do here is much more visible. CabVision is a good example of that and the rugby shirt stunt was a great success - I can actually see the results of my efforts. I like the range of clients and events, working with sporting manufacturers and nightclubs on launches and publicity drives is infinitely more sexy than the bank. I also really appreciate the informal atmosphere and the buzz of being located in Covent Garden."

Cleary has also discovered the advantages of working in a small organisation. "I am learning all the time by getting involved with as many projects as I can. There isn't a career structure here as such, but it is easier to have your efforts spotted and rewarded than in a large, hierarchical organisation. I want to progress from doing the legwork and into production, liaising with clients and managing projects myself. The marketing director started in my job 10 years ago and now owns part of the company, which I find very encouraging."

webTitle: Blair says internet must not remain preserve of elite

fields.headline: Blair says internet must not remain preserve of elite
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will tomorrow urge the development of a "people's internet" as new research shows that Britain's on-line population is dominated by well-off teenagers and twenty-somethings.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will tomorrow urge the development of a "people's internet" as new research shows that Britain's on-line population is dominated by well-off teenagers and twenty-somethings.

In a speech to trades union and business leaders, the prime minister will warn of the danger of the internet-driven knowledge economy becoming the "preserve of an elite".

Though Britain is the biggest internet market in Europe, he will say, it must have an "internet for the people" to make sure everyone benefits from the new economy.

The prime minister's intervention comes as a new report from management and technology consultants Booz, Allen and Hamilton shows that Britain is top of the "e-league", coming ahead of all its European neighbours in terms of internet use and revenue gained from e-commerce.

However, Mr Blair will tell a TUC-CBI conference on the knowledge economy that statistics from the same study show 45% of those on-line in Britain are aged 15-24. Almost half British net users are in the top AB social group, statistics also show, leaving a vast swath of the older, poorer population excluded from the technology that the government repeatedly claims will drive the nation's future prosperity.

Other studies have also warned that internet use is dominated by men, and that ethnic minority groups are less well represented among users than their proportion in the population would suggest.

The prime minister will urge wider use of new technology, stressing that Britain must continue take advantage of its opportunities now to avoid being left behind. He will tell the conference: "There is no time to lose. The new economy is the future. I strongly believe that the new knowledge economy is our best route for success and prosperity."

But Britain must be wary of making "a fundamental mistake," he will add. "We must not believe that because the knowledge economy is the future it will happen only in the future. That is not right - the knowlege economy is here and it is now."

 Software company Knowledge Support Systems is to float on the stock exchange in a listing estimated to value it at £100m. The Manchester-based group, which hopes to raise £30m, plans to increase its 45-strong workforce to 200 by the end of 2001.

webTitle: Undercover pensioners test bus service quality

fields.headline: Undercover pensioners test bus service quality
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Forty pensioners from Kensington and Chelsea have been recruited by the cabinet office to work as "mystery passengers" and inspect bus services in the latest stage of the national "Better Government for Older People" initiative.
fields.body:
Forty pensioners from Kensington and Chelsea have been recruited by the cabinet office to work as "mystery passengers" and inspect bus services in the latest stage of the national "Better Government for Older People" initiative.

They will test comfort, efficiency and friendliness (or lack of it) to passengers above retirement age - "everything from the bus stop, what it's like for shelter, seating and information, to whether the driver sets off jerkily when passengers are still standing," said the cabinet office. The operation will lead to an award for the best bus route in the west London royal borough and public raspberries for those that fail to come up to scratch.

The operation follows a successful galvanising of older people in Kensington and Chelsea by the cabinet office, which has 500 local "reporters" over retirement age, who are prepared to monitor services and regularly meet for two-hour discussions.

The borough is one of 28 piloting ways to make life easier and services more thoughtful for older people; other initiatives will be highlighted at a conference in London today.

fields.headline: Put down your gun, Gerry
fields.standfirst:
Mr Adams must forget history and rescue his people's future

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: I was brought up to believe that "everything back to normal" was good news - the comforting reassurance that after the night's Blitz, the visit of my aunt or a sudden attack of infant asthma, the world had reverted to its familiar course.
fields.body:
I was brought up to believe that "everything back to normal" was good news - the comforting reassurance that after the night's Blitz, the visit of my aunt or a sudden attack of infant asthma, the world had reverted to its familiar course.

But in this, as in so much else, Northern Ireland is different. A statue of a masked gunman masquerading as a memorial has been unveiled in Derry. President Clinton hopes for a Saint Patrick's Day breakthrough. The bodies of young men - brutally murdered in reprisal for some unspecified crime - are left to rot. The secretary of state, battling to keep hopes of permanent peace alive, is accused of prejudice by politicians who want him to be biased in their favour. Rocket-launchers are found near to the married quarters of the British troops who guarantee the peace.

While politicians discuss the destruction of long-held arms and ammunition, new weapons are imported into the province. Everything is back to normal. Optimists insist that "the law-abiding majority want peace". The majority has rarely been so silent. Is Reverend Ian Paisley deluged with messages warning him that unless he assists in the creation of a power-sharing government he will be defeated at the next election? Do members of the Orange Lodge stop David Trimble in the street and tell him that compromise is common sense? Are Sinn Fein supporters demanding that Gerry Adams forgets about the Dublin General Post Office in 1916 and starts to think of Ulster schoolchildren now?

The most charitable answer is that the voices of sanity are drowned by nonsense about "no surrender" and "Ireland unfree will never be at peace". Instinct and logic both make me a republican. I want to see a united Ireland. That aspiration would be brought significantly closer to realisation by full implementation of the Good Friday agreement. Much as I deplore their attitudes, I understand why intransigent unionists want to postpone the inevitable unification of their divided nation.

But why does Sinn Fein jeopardise the greening of Northern Ireland? The only plausible explanation is that their judgment has been warped by history. That does not excuse denunciations of Peter Mandelson for his decision to suspend the Northern Ireland parliament and executive. They must know that the alternative to temporary limbo was permanent extinction. Once David Trimble had resigned and walked out, it would have been impossible for him to walk back in again. For once, it is hard not to sympathise with unionist impatience.

Progress to lasting peace has been waylaid by republican hubris - the refusal to destroy arms which they say will never be used. The IRA's determination to protect every Armalite rifle and preserve every ounce of Semtex is so indefensible that Mr Adams was forced to defend the decision with arguments which even he (not the most sensitive of men) must have found embarrassing. An undefeated army, he said, has never surrendered its arms. I have no idea whether or not Mr Adams is a reliable military historian. But I know that when he spoke of the IRA in that vainglorious language, he sounded like a schoolboy playing soldiers in the park. I have always thought of him as both cynical and sinister. But never, before his theatrical excuse for what is inexcusable, have I thought of him as silly. Only in the world turned upside down are the lives of innocent men and women - not to mention the peace and prosperity of a whole province - put at risk by palpable silliness.

One explanation of Mr Adams's conduct is the suggestion, put to me in Belfast 10 years ago, that he is no longer a free agent. I met him shortly after he had acted as pallbearer at an IRA funeral - paying homage to a man who had killed himself, as well as two little boys, in a bomb attack on a shop which had been wrongly identified as Orange paramilitary headquarters. When I asked Mr Adams how he justified treating such a man as a hero, he was too angry to reply.

But the bodyguard, who escorted me from the derelict factory in which we met, told me to remember Michael Collins - murdered in 1922 because ultra-republicans thought him insufficiently extreme. That comparison may go some way towards diagnosing the cause of Mr Adams's conduct. But it does nothing to increase confidence in Northern Ireland's suitability for civilised self government.

No doubt Peter Mandelson and the prime minister will go on trying to secure a lasting peace. And so they should. Win or lose, their continued efforts are much to their credit. But the rest of us will remain bewildered about why so many people should so regularly choose to turn their backs on peace and progress and conclude that "back to normal" in Northern Ireland means a return to murder and mayhem.

webTitle: Railtrack in joint plan to introduce double-decker trains

fields.headline: Railtrack in joint plan to introduce double-decker trains
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Railtrack plans to introduce double decker trains into Britain for the first time in more than 40 years to cope with a 25% increase in commuter traffic coming into Waterloo station from the outer London surburbs.
fields.body:
Railtrack plans to introduce double decker trains into Britain for the first time in more than 40 years to cope with a 25% increase in commuter traffic coming into Waterloo station from the outer London surburbs.

The group confirmed yesterday that together with South West Trains, it is spending £5m on a feasibility study into the idea. The plan is part of SWT's bid to obtain a 20-year franchise to run trains into Waterloo after the current one expires in 2003.

SWT, a subsidiary of Stagecoach, the bus and train operator, has submitted its bid to Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority. The bid is being considered by the SSRA, and Sir Alastair has said that he is excited about the prospects of improving access to Waterloo. Railtrack stressed that the plan before the SSRA was either for SWT to build double decker trains, or for platforms to be lengthened at Waterloo to accommodate longer trains.

The double decker train plan is a multi-million pound project, and is being considered seriously because of the rapid rise of rail passengers coming into London.

Since privatisation four years, passenger numbers on some services have risen by a quarter, confounding official forecasts that the industry was set to decline.

Double decker trains have been used before in parts of Kent, but only on a limited basis. If SWT and Railtrack agree to proceed with the plan, they are likely be introduced extensively on the heavily populated commuter line through Basingstoke to Southampton and Bournemouth.

Railtrack, which is examining the development of double decker trains in France and other parts of mainland Europe, said that adjustments would probably have to be made to tracks and bridges.

"The main difference between a normal train and a double decker is that passengers usually step down on to a double decker,' said a spokesman.

The other potential solution at Waterloo - building longer platforms - poses problems for Railtrack. Only limited room is available outside the station, and the planners are struggling to find the best compromise.

SWT's bid is among a group of three rail franchises which the SSRA is re-negotiating. It is expected to decide upon one in the summer.

The idea of double decker trains appeals to the SSRA because it means that in return for a 20-year franchise, a company such as SWT is prepared to match this big concession with considerable investment.

fields.headline: Safe as soya
fields.trailText: George Monbiot (Just say no to biotech business, March 2) clearly misunderstands glyphosate and the regulations governing its use. In 1996, the European Commission set a maximum residue level of 20 parts per million on glyphosate residues, based on internationally agreed safety standards.
fields.body:
George Monbiot (Just say no to biotech business, March 2) clearly misunderstands glyphosate and the regulations governing its use. In 1996, the European Commission set a maximum residue level of 20 parts per million on glyphosate residues, based on internationally agreed safety standards.

It is standard practice to set the permitted level for residues at the minimum detectable level. This is 0.1 parts per million (ppm). Had Mr Monbiot read the current report of the UK Working Party on Pesticide Residues (www.maff.gov.uk) he might have been more enlightened about this issue.

The report shows that, in 1999, no samples of GM soya tested contained glyphosate above the 0.1 ppm level of detection, let alone the EU level of 20 ppm. In other words, the levels of glyphosate found in GM soya were actually 200 times lower than the permitted safety levels.

Thus to suggest that glyphosate residues in GM soya are a "menace to public health" is not only untrue, it's also irresponsible.

Tony Coombs
Director corporate affairs, Monsanto

fields.headline: A song for Sir Stanley
fields.trailText: I read with special interest John Ezard's moving description of Stanley Matthews' funeral (Sir Stan - a hero passes into folklore, March 4) because the song quoted, "Stanley Matthews, the greatest of them all", was written by me for a Keele university charity record. It was inspired by seeing Stanley Matthews score the goal, against Luton Town, which clinched promotion for Stoke City at the end of the 1962-3 season. The song was performed by our folk song group, The Keele Row.
fields.body:
I read with special interest John Ezard's moving description of Stanley Matthews' funeral (Sir Stan - a hero passes into folklore, March 4) because the song quoted, "Stanley Matthews, the greatest of them all", was written by me for a Keele university charity record. It was inspired by seeing Stanley Matthews score the goal, against Luton Town, which clinched promotion for Stoke City at the end of the 1962-3 season. The song was performed by our folk song group, The Keele Row.

Stanley Matthews was the greatest but he was also the returning local hero, who inspired a struggling second division team and their supporters. It was a fairy tale that none of us, who were lucky enough to be there, will ever forget.

Richard Barton
Kinsham, Powys

 Last Saturday I stood for a minute's silence to mark the passing of gentleman footballer Stanley Matthews: this Saturday I saw a cinema advert, selling sports equipment, which featured current Premiership star Paulo di Canio. He was joking about his notoriety since pushing over a referee in a televised match. Luckily I was too shocked to remember the name of the product.

M Dixon
London
mjdixon@glenshiel.demon. co.uk

webTitle: How to beat the hole in the wall

fields.headline: How to beat the hole in the wall
fields.trailText: The banks bemoan the 30p cost per transaction at an ATM machine (Bank heist, Jobs and Money, March 4). ATMs were introduced, not with the good of the consumer in mind, but as a way to close branches.
fields.body:
The banks bemoan the 30p cost per transaction at an ATM machine (Bank heist, Jobs and Money, March 4). ATMs were introduced, not with the good of the consumer in mind, but as a way to close branches.

Recent advice to use supermarket cashback facilities to withdraw cash and thereby avoid the ATM charge is all well and good, but it will not actually affect the banks.

If banks are to reconsider their policy then they should be hit where it hurts, ie the shareholders' pockets. One way to do this is by using the new data protection act. Under the act companies are obliged to provide copies of details held on paper and on their computer systems, including backup information.

Assuming that banks hold their main customer data base on a mainframe and that they have 12 months' worth of backup material, they will have to run 12 separate jobs. Each different job will have to load the relevant database and trawl this to select your record - a time-consuming task and also an expensive one. There are other technical considerations if the data layout has changed.

Given that many of the banks have several systems your request is going to cause work for people in different departments and the results of those efforts must be co-ordinated. The print must be meaningful to the recipient - a straight data dump will often not suffice. The prints must be checked before being despatched. The resulting amount of paper will be quite considerable.

By all means use the supermarkets to save your money but put £10 of it to good use and request a data protection print. You will find out what information the banks hold on you and you could cost them several hundred pounds in processing and manpower effort. That is not good news to the shareholders.

Steven Milligan
Derby
nomercy@clara.net

 While the current indignation continues over the charges proposed by the banks for the use of their ATMs, can anyone explain why customers of French banks can use any ATM free of charge, apart from an annual (or biennial) flat fee for the card itself?

Dr FP Greenwell
London

webTitle: Counting on confusion over the unemployed

fields.headline: Counting on confusion over the unemployed
fields.trailText: We all love a good moan, and for those on the left there were few better subjects to moan about in the 80s and 90s than the unemployment figures. Month after month Labour raged at the way the Conservatives lopped people off the dole queue by moving the goalposts. Fiddle, they said, as the claimant count was reduced by making groups ineligible for benefit. Insult to the real unemployed, they claimed, as the out of work were re-classified as long-term sick.
fields.body:
We all love a good moan, and for those on the left there were few better subjects to moan about in the 80s and 90s than the unemployment figures. Month after month Labour raged at the way the Conservatives lopped people off the dole queue by moving the goalposts. Fiddle, they said, as the claimant count was reduced by making groups ineligible for benefit. Insult to the real unemployed, they claimed, as the out of work were re-classified as long-term sick.

That particular avenue of enjoyment has since been closed off to us. The government now publishes the claimant count in conjunction with an internationally-agreed measure of unemployment that is less susceptible to official massaging (and which shows the jobless total to be around 50% higher). But for those who still feel a twinge of nostalgia for the good old days, Gordon Brown arranged a stroll down memory lane last week. According to the treasury, there are jobs for all in the humming British economy, with as many unfilled vacancies as there are unemployed looking for work. Moreover, there is little variation between one region and another. And how has the chancellor come to this conclusion which, on the face of it, suggests that not only has Labour cracked unemployment but has eliminated the north-south divide, to boot?

Why, through our old friend the claimant count. What the treasury has done is take the number of people out of work and claiming benefit - around 1.15m - and treated that as an accurate measure of unemployment. Then it arrives at a similar number of vacancies by taking the number of jobs officially notified to Jobcentres (340,000) and multiplying by three on the assumption that the authorities only get to know about a third of all the positions actually available.

No hiding place

So there we have it. In the modern Britain, there is no excuse for the able bodied to be idle and there should be no hiding place for the workshy. "I say to the unemployed who can work - you must now meet your responsibility to earn a wage," Brown said last week. The chancellor needs to be careful with this sort of stuff. Very careful indeed. He is as passionate as anybody about reducing unemployment and breaking the cycle of joblessness and poverty. As the budget later this month will show, he is forever thinking up new ways of helping people to find work. He is no Norman Tebbit, but one of the jokes doing the rounds last week was: "What's the difference between Tebbit and Brown? If you're poor enough, Gordon will buy the bike for you."

From the TUC, there was an instant and well-justified slap on the wrists "The real figure shows that there are four people who want a job for every vacancy", said John Monks, the TUC general secretary. "No one much trusted the claimant count unemployment figures under the last government, it would be a mistake to start believing them now."

Monks is right. A prolonged period of economic growth means that there has been an impressive fall in the claimant count - from a peak of almost 3m - over the past seven years. But the official figures fail to capture the whole picture, in particular those people who have dropped out of the labour market completely. Here, the figures vary considerably from one part of the country to another.

For example, 28% of men over 50 - around 1.3m people - are now classified as economically inactive, which means that they don't show up in any unemployment figures. In 1975 the figure was 7%. In addition, around 8% of non-student men under 50 - another 1m people - are outside the labour market, against 1% in 1975. In Britain's unemployment blackspots, the social housing estates, 30% of men are inactive and only 54% are in work.

According to the government's own labour force survey there are now some 2.3m men of working age, excluding students, who are economically inactive. This is twice the number of unemployed as measured by the claimant count and almost six times the number of men outside the labour market 20 years ago. Is this because these men are inherently lazy? If that is the case, there would be little doubt that the government's carrot and stick - a mobile phone to keep in touch with the Jobcentre, an earnings top up plus the threat of loss of benefit for the workshy would be justified. But there are two important questions here. Are the jobs on offer, even with the relatively generous working families tax credit - paying enough? Most of the jobs on offer in the high-unemployment areas tend to be minimum-wage occupations in industries such as catering and care.

All the evidence shows that while people are prepared to commute vast distances for well-paid jobs in the City, they are not prepared to fork out £10-15 a week for jobs paying £3.60 an hour. Or as one labour-market expert put it: "People don't travel long distances for crap jobs." The second point is whether there really are jobs everywhere. The answer is no, as even the government's own paper admits when it says there are real problems in the run-down seaside towns, the mining villages and some urban conurbations. The workless rates for prime-aged men on Merseyside, for example, are horrific.

If the claimant count is under-estimating the number of people really out of work, then the government's vacancy numbers also look dubious. A study by the Greater Manchester Low Pay Unit has suggested that both the regional and national vacancy data are far from accurate, finding little correlation between the number of vacancies on display and the official vacancy data for particular Jobcentres. Since last summer, the office for national statistics has stopped publishing individual Jobcentre vacancy statistics because of the unreliability of the data, but as the GMLPU says: "If individual Jobcentre figures are unreliable, then the overall figure of which these are components, must also be unreliable."

In addition, the TUC argues that the Employment Service is now more efficient and better at capturing job vacancies in parts of the country. For example, the number of official vacancies in the north-east rose by 104% in the year to December 1999, compared to 19% in the south-west and a fall of 4% in the north west. In other words, the real situation on the ground is much less favourable than the government figures would suggest.

The TUC says that there is a "vast discrepancy in the employment rates of working age people, especially men, across the UK and it is clear that the decline in production and manufacturing industries in those regions outside southern England has been a key factor driving this trend."

While welcoming government initiatives such as the new deal, the TUC said: "We believe the overall success of welfare to work programmes, especially in those regions with below average employment rates, also depends on a demand side ensuring an adequate flow of jobs as well as a supply side of welfare and labour market reform.

It is therefore imperative for those regions that the current nascent recovery in manufacturing is not prematurely arrested by a sustained overvaluation of sterling."

Part of the culture
As the government knows, there was a huge shock to the labour market in the 80s. In some parts of the country, long-term unemployment has become part of the culture and is not simply a supply-side problem. In the south-east there are enough rich people to create spillover low-skilled service sector jobs; on Merseyside many of the high-earners have upped and left for other parts of the country. People can be retrained and given tips on interview techniques, but if there are no jobs for men in their 30s, 40s and 50s then there are no jobs

This is an issue that governments have been grappling with for almost a century. There are really only two choices: move the people where the jobs are, or move the jobs where the people are. We've tried the former and it hasn't worked. The government should recognise that the real problem is not motivation or defective interview skills, but a lack of jobs that only a coherent mix of macro-economic, supply-side and regional policies can address. Using dodgy figures to cover up the true picture is not helpful.

People can be retrained and given tips on interview techniques, but if there are no jobs for men in their 30s, 40s and 50s then there are no jobs This is an issue that governments have been grappling with for almost a century. There are really only two choices: move the people where the jobs are, or move the jobs where the people are. We've tried the former and it hasn't worked. The government should recognise that the real problem is not motivation or defective interview skills, but a lack of jobs that only a coherent mix of macro-economic, supply-side and regional policies can address. Using dodgy figures to cover up the true picture is not helpful.

fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: If it is true that Pinochet fooled the "eminent" physicians who said he was unfit to stand trial, I believe they should do the honourable thing and resign (Pinochet 'was coached on how to fool doctors', March 4). Jack Straw ignored interpretations of the medical data by doctors from other countries in Europe, which said that he was fit enough to stand trial. If he has also been fooled by Pinochet, he should also do the honourable thing and resign.

Jack Straw ignored interpretations of the medical data by doctors from other countries in Europe, which said that he was fit enough to stand trial. If he has also been fooled by Pinochet, he should also do the honourable thing and resign.

As for Pinochet, he is just a coward.

Mark Hellen
London
m.hellen@euroseek.com

 Has the Pope been informed of the miracle that apparently took place on the aircraft that carried General Pinochet back to Chile?

GL Samson
Abingdon, Oxon
gerald.samson@dtn.ntl.com

 Pinochet "tricked" doctors into believing he was senile and arrives home to a hero's welcome, big smiles all round? To quote cuddly Frank Dobson, "Ooooooooh, you amaze me!"

Andy Smith
London
acsmith@ic24.net

 Doesn't General Pinochet look well, bless him. Clearly the sound of mocking, triumphalist laughter as your plane takes off is the best medicine.

D Gardiner
Brading, Hants
debgardiner@iwlabour. fsnet.co.uk

 Since the arrest of Pinochet is a precedent-setting event (Leader, March 3), the most obvious candidates now are Mikhail Gorbachev, because of the Tbilisi, Baku and Vilnius massacres (1989, 1990, 1991) and the war in Afghanistan (1985-89), where millions were killed or had to flee the country; and Boris Yeltsin, for his two brutal wars against Chechnya. The cruelty and scale of torture employed in Afghanistan and Chechnya make the circumstances of the Chilean coup pale entirely by comparison.

Those cases of blatant violation of human rights took place, both geographically and chronologically, much closer to Britain than those in Chile.

Oleg Gordievsky
London

 To Lady Thatcher and others of her persuasion the only aspect relevant to the legitimacy or otherwise of Pinochet's detention is the assistance he gave to Britain at the time of the Falklands war. These blinkered mainly ex-politicians appear untroubled by the fact that at least one UK citizen was horribly tortured by the general's henchmen, not wanting such an unfortunate one-off occurrence to blight Anglo-Chilean relations.

The baroness herself of course may have fears of her own about global travel, envisioning herself before a court or tribunal in Buenos Aires should one of her international flights be unfortunately diverted to the Argentine capital.

Bill Jackson
Nottingham

 Joe Charnock (Letters, March 4) considers that "if somebody is well enough to entertain Baroness Thatcher, it is reasonable to suppose they are well enough to stand trial." I would have thought this was pretty powerful evidence of terminal mental (and moral) collapse.

Dr Richard Carter
London
thecarters@waitrose.com

 I see that it has been suggested that General Pinochet be offered the alternative of being declared insane or standing trial. Would it be in order to suggest that the same alternative be offered to Margaret Thatcher?

Dalkey, Ireland
ringrob@eircom.net

fields.headline: Rights and wrongs
fields.standfirst: Chinese visit leaves a sour aftertaste
fields.trailText: The heavy-handed policing of last October's state visit by China's President Jiang Zemin was widely condemned at the time. Now an internal Scotland Yard inquiry into the affair seems indirectly to confirm what many suspected: that foreign office officials, in a series of meetings with the Met, urged that a tough line be taken with human rights demonstrators in the Mall and elsewhere to avoid upsetting their illustrious guest.
fields.body:
The heavy-handed policing of last October's state visit by China's President Jiang Zemin was widely condemned at the time. Now an internal Scotland Yard inquiry into the affair seems indirectly to confirm what many suspected: that foreign office officials, in a series of meetings with the Met, urged that a tough line be taken with human rights demonstrators in the Mall and elsewhere to avoid upsetting their illustrious guest.

During an earlier visit to Switzerland, Mr Jiang angrily suggested that the effrontery of his hosts in allowing protesters to enter his line of vision had harmed bilateral relations. The government clearly wanted to avoid a similar problem here. Disgraceful scenes of harassment of peaceful demonstrators, shown on television around the world, and a tarnishing of Britain's reputation for fairness and tolerance, followed in short order.

The Scotland Yard report, to be presented to Jack Straw this week, eschews direct criticism of individual ministers. Robin Cook and John Battle have maintained that no political pressure was applied during the meetings, which were also attended by Chinese officials. For the Met formally to contradict those statements would be to suggest that one or both men was not telling the truth. But significantly, the report does propose that in future, detailed minutes of planning meetings between officials and police be kept - surprisingly, this was not the case last autumn. Mr Straw should have no difficulty in accepting this recommendation. He should also ensure that the Yard's report is published.

Luckily for the government, an opportunity to redeem Britain's reputation as both a respecter and champion of human rights is at hand. China's appalling record, which has deteriorated sharply in the past 18 months, will come under scrutiny on March 20 at a meeting of the UN human rights commission in Geneva. Concerned at continuing crackdowns on political dissidents, Muslim and Christian minorities, Tibetan nationalists, Falun Gong practitioners, and at China's excessive use of capital punishment, the US is seeking to pass a formal motion of censure against Beijing. The Chinese government, in turn, has launched a vigorous, worldwide diplomatic offensive to block the censure. The government should resist this pressure and support the US. There must be no more kowtowing on rights - even if that upsets the terribly important Mr Jiang.

fields.headline: Doctors' call
fields.trailText:
The news that communication within the medical profession is so bad that a consultant can be appointed to report on an inexcusable disaster (Surgeon heading kidney inquiry faces action himself, March 4) while involved in legal proceedings for a similar mistake is extraordinary. 
Meanwhile, the British Medical Association and the General Medical Council are at odds over how to restore public confidence. Can patients be effectively protected by self-regulation, or is this merely a long-standing privilege which has no place in modern medicine?

fields.headline: Further beyond our Ken
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: I note that you are continuing to carry reports containing the suggestion that Ken Livingstone could still become Labour's candidate for London mayor (Tribune tells Dobson to quit, March 2). The Labour party announced the result of our mayoral selection on February 20. We elected Frank Dobson as our candidate and he will fight the election for us on May 4.
fields.body:
I note that you are continuing to carry reports containing the suggestion that Ken Livingstone could still become Labour's candidate for London mayor (Tribune tells Dobson to quit, March 2). The Labour party announced the result of our mayoral selection on February 20. We elected Frank Dobson as our candidate and he will fight the election for us on May 4.

I am sorry if Ken Livingstone has not understood this but I have explained it to him. However, there is no reason why you should continue to suggest anything other than that as the position is clear-cut.

Margaret McDonagh
General secretary, Labour party

 When I was a member of the Association of Metropolitan Authorities policy committee 20 years ago, Ken Livingstone was known in the Labour group not as Red Ken, but as Corkscrew Ken. Interesting to see that he still displays the inability to come to a decision.

Clive Wilkinson
Birmingham

 In 1964 Patrick Gordon-Walker, Harold Wilson's designated foreign secretary, had to be provided with a safe Labour seat. Leyton, with a majority of over 20,000, was selected, and Joe Sorensen, the long-standing MP, was elevated to the peerage.

The electors of Leyton for the first time returned a Tory. What was demonstrated was that Londoners will not be dictated to. The good people of Wales have recently demonstrated that they will not be dictated to either.

If New Labour (what a horrible term - why doesn't Blair just admit that it is the old Social Democratic party of the infamous Gang of Four?) persist with Frank Dobson, then the people of London will do exactly what the voters of Leyton did in 1964.

Alan Millington
Blackpool

fields.headline: The next oil crisis
fields.standfirst: An alternative strategy is badly needed
fields.trailText: Surging oil prices - which could soon push the price of petrol to £4 a gallon - have come as an overdue reminder to industrialised countries of just how dependent their economies still are on a single source of energy.
fields.body:
Surging oil prices - which could soon push the price of petrol to £4 a gallon - have come as an overdue reminder to industrialised countries of just how dependent their economies still are on a single source of energy. And, more to the point, how little they have done about it since the last energy crisis.

It is ironic that just when the west is starting to feel confident that it has emerged from the hyper-inflationary effects of the last oil crisis more than 25 years ago, it could be faced with a new one. No one who lived through the consequences of the previous oil shock would want to see one again. Quite apart from electricity cuts and queues at the pumps, it was responsible for numerous, dire knock-on effects, including wages chasing prices in an upward spiral that triggered economic recession and price inflation of well over 20%.

The world economy, though outwardly robust, could easily succumb to a stock market crash induced by the pricking of the internet share bubble. If oil prices continue to zoom, it will be doubly vulnerable. Yet what is the right price for oil? We all want it cheap at source (to stem inflation and prevent producers from making unearned fortunes), yet expensive at point of sale to discourage profligacy and provide revenues to support the welfare state. Even at $30 for a 27 gallon barrel - and transported half way round the earth - oil works out at only 6.5p a pint. Try buying mineral water at that price.

If left to "market forces", with producers freely supplying the needs of consumers, oil would undoubtedly be much cheaper than $30 a barrel. But very cheap oil would be the economics of myopia. As recently found oilfields in the west run down - with no obvious new discoveries to replace them - we will become increasingly dependent on Opec countries as their share of the global market rises steadily above 50%. Russian oil and gas (the profits of which bankrolled the Chechnya war) will account for much of the rest. There have been too many false alarms in the past about the speed at which non-Opec reserves would be run down. This has spawned complacency. But in the longer term, there is no doubt that the balance of power will swing decisively to the east.

What should be done? Two vital things, for a start. First, Opec must be politely reminded that it is a cartel and that abuses of power by a cartel (such as its current, artificially low production quotas) cannot be tolerated, especially in a world driven by free trade and globalisation. Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest oil producer, is expected later this year to join the World Trade Organisation, the very body that ought to be investigating cartels that do not operate in the (international) public interest.

Second, the surge in oil prices should be taken as a wake-up call to the west to redouble its efforts to find alternative sources of energy against the day when oil runs down. Two areas offer outstanding potential but need far more resources thrown behind them. They are the development of hydrogen (the waste product of which is water) as a fuel to drive cars; and solar energy, where interesting advances are being made. Even in less sunny climates like the UK, solar energy has big possibilities. But in "sunshine-rich" developing countries, the potential is truly huge. To achieve this may require a degree of (unfashionable) planning between the private sector, governments and academia, but it has to be done, and quickly. The long-term consequences of not doing so are almost too terrible to contemplate.

fields.headline: Fayed and the rubbish question
fields.trailText: Writ large
fields.body:
Dustbins - or, indeed, black rubbish bags - do not usually play a prominent part in the law. I'm glad to see that they're achieving a modicum of publicity for their alleged part in the Hamilton-Al Fayed story. It's still far from clear who'll be paying how much towards Mohamed Al Fayed's legal bills, but it's the new rubbishy angle I want to explore.

It appears that Fayed had some prior knowledge of what the Hamilton side's legal tactics were to be, even to knowing some of the questions he might be asked in court. And that's because he'd seen a draft of them, which - I'd better use up a few more allegedlys, pity to let them go to waste - had allegedly been chucked into a Gray's Inn dustbin, not a million miles from Hamilton's barrister's chambers, and been recovered by a well known bin-scrabbler, who had allegedly sold them to Fayed. The police are now investigating, and as a result the proceedings over legal costs have been postponed until the facts become a little clearer.

Exploring rubbish to find evidence for use in court is an old trick. It was used, for instance, on behalf of Sir James Goldsmith when he was suing Private Eye in the mid-70s. Celebrities are constantly having their binned throwaways examined. But what's legally interesting is that taking something from the bin or bag is theft. Why? If you throw away your rubbish, do you not abandon it in law, in effect saying "I have no further use for it, or claim on it. I am leaving it outside, expecting it to be taken away"?

Well, no. You are still the owner of your rubbish and it remains under your control until it's removed by the people you've in effect designated, the garbage removers. You haven't agreed to anyone else taking it. The same goes for stuff you've put out in your own skip. But if you put something into, say, a council skip or take rubbish to a tip, it ceases to be yours and becomes the property of the skip or tip owner. The Hamilton side is saying that if - if - a crime has been committed which has benefited Fayed (no-one's suggesting he instigated it), it puts a whole new complexion on the costs issue.

So ends the longest ever mispronunciation in legal history. I won't go on about the most positive aspect of the Pino-Tchett (not Pino-Shay) affair, the legal precedent and warning it provides for other ex-dictators, but I am still puzzled - if Pinochet was to be tried in Spain, why was our home secretary applying an English test of whether or not he was fit to stand trial? Otherwise, Jack Straw done good.

A few weeks ago I related the story of the memorial, in an Ottawa public park, to "women murdered by men", which included the name of a dead woman whose husband was still awaiting trial for her murder. He, understandably, complained that this statement of his guilt, carved on a stone plinth (each alleged murderee has a separate mini-memorial by the central big one), was deeply prejudicial to his forthcoming trial.

The man has now been freed and the charge dropped, for reasons which have nothing to do with the memorial. But now that he is officially innocent, he is angry at the permanent defamation which can be seen by every visitor to the park, and has demanded its removal. The people who put up the monument agree. Only, they can't comply. It gets very cold in Ottawa in winter. So cold that the ground gets so severely iced over that they can't remove the offending defamatory stone; not until the thaw. I know of no other example of a continuing libel caused by the weather.

webTitle: Barak's cabinet votes to leave Lebanon by July

fields.headline: Barak's cabinet votes to leave Lebanon by July
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's cabinet yesterday rallied behind the prime minister, Ehud Barak, in his determination to bring the country's soldiers home from an 18-year misadventure in Lebanon, voting for a withdrawal even if a wider agreement with Syria is unachievable.
fields.body:
Israel's cabinet yesterday rallied behind the prime minister, Ehud Barak, in his determination to bring the country's soldiers home from an 18-year misadventure in Lebanon, voting for a withdrawal even if a wider agreement with Syria is unachievable.

"The Israeli defence force will deploy on the border with Lebanon by July 2000 and from there will secure the safety of the northern towns and villages of Israel," a cabinet statement said.

The vote essentially ratifies stated policy by Mr Barak to end, by the first anniversary of his coming to power, the occupation of Israel's self-styled "security zone", which is widely seen as so senseless that it has become known as "Israel's Vietnam".

The former army chief of staff has left no doubt that he would favour undertaking the withdrawal with Syria's blessing. So would Lebanon's prime minister, Salim al-Hoss. Although he welcomed yesterday's decision, he said: "We prefer the withdrawal to take place under an agreement... because we do not trust Israel's intentions if the pullout takes place without a deal."

However, with Israeli-Syrian talks suspended since January, the cabinet yesterday said that if "conditions will not be conducive to an Israeli defence forces redeployment in the framework of an agreement, the government will convene at an appropriate time to discuss the method of implementation of the above-mentioned decisions".

fields.headline: Access denied
fields.standfirst: When parents split up, the courts may order that a father can see his children but they can't make it happen.  Clare Dyer on a system under fire
fields.trailText: When parents split up, the courts may order that a father can see his children but they can't make it happen.  Clare Dyer on a system under
fields.body:
John Beale has seen his five-year-old son only three times since May 1998. The last time was five months ago at a contact centre, neutral ground on the warring parents' battlefield. After that he was supposed to be allowed to take his son to McDonald's on a Saturday, but the boy and his mother didn't show up.

The problem for the 35-year-old accountant isn't convincing the court to allow him to see his son. He has a pile of court orders granting him contact. But how can you make court orders stick if a mother is determined that the father should play no part in the child's life? Last Friday he was in court for the 34th time, asking the judge to take action to enforce the orders. He came away empty-handed.

Beale and the boy's mother weren't married or even living together when she discovered she was pregnant. "The relationship didn't work but I decided I wanted to be a proper father to my son," he explains. His name was put on the birth certificate as the father. He wanted to see his son regularly and take him for days out and holidays, but from the beginning his ex-girlfriend was unhappy with the idea.

Beale went to court and first won the right to contact when his son was six months old. But each time an order was made, he says, it was complied with only for a short time before he had to seek the court's help again. "Very close friends couldn't believe this could happen. My anger is not with the mother - she can't anger me any more. It's with the judicial system for not doing anything about it."

Fathers, and the organisations that represent them, claim they get a raw deal from courts which pay lip service to a child's need for a relationship with both parents, but are spineless when faced with a mother who is determined to buck the system. In the opposite corner are campaigning women's groups, such as Rights of Women, which maintain that judges are too ready to allow contact by unsuitable fathers, even those with a history of violence to the mother.

Dawn Austin's case provoked media outrage four years ago when she was jailed for six weeks by Judge William Poulton for defying order after order allowing her ex-lover, Lee Norton, contact with the couple's four-year-old daughter, Troy. Austin claimed that Norton had threatened to throw her and Troy over a balcony and that he was not interested in his daughter, merely "trying to keep tracks into my life". Judge Poulton, who heard all the evidence and saw the welfare reports, declared: "It would be far less damaging for Troy to see her mother go to prison than to grow up without a father."

The media, which saw none of the evidence, pilloried him, though the Court of Appeal later upheld his decision. Appeal court judge Lord Justice Ward said: "She has been given endless opportunities to comply, with sympathetic attempts by the judge to meet her flimsy objections to contact taking place. She has spurned all those attempts."

While Austin was in Holloway, social workers arranged for Norton to see his daughter. Austin then agreed to contact, saying she feared Norton's mother would apply to have Troy live with her if Austin stayed in jail. But it takes a brave judge to jail the mother of a young child for contempt of court.

Nobody would deny that there are violent fathers, though men who have lashed out in adult relationships will not necessarily pose a threat to their children. But the debate has become fiercely polarised on gender lines, with groups like Families Need Fathers seeing the cards as stacked against men, while women's organisations claim the courts' insistence on fathers' rights puts them and their children at risk from violent and controlling men.

The Equal Parenting Party, which campaigns for automatic rights to contact when a relationship breaks down, stresses that mothers whose children live with their father can also face problems. Christine, who left her husband for another man two and a half years ago, has not seen her son and daughter, now 10 and 13, for two years.

Jim Parton, chairman of Families Need Fathers, acknowledges that fathers with day-to-day care of their children can put just as many obstacles in the way of a mother seeking contact as vice versa. "There's no more certain way of getting to the other parent than through the children. The evil in the system is the winner-takes-all aspect of it. There's plenty of evidence that men are just as bad if they get the chance."

Judges and lawyers have a tag for the most obdurate parents: "implacably hostile". The children act lays down that the child's best interests are paramount in deciding what, if any, contact to order. Judges are guided by a body of research showing that children do better if they have a relationship with both parents, so there is a presumption that the parent they don't live with will be allowed to see them regularly. They do best of all if their parents can co-operate in a civilised way in sharing their time.

But many parents are unaware of the effects of using children as weapons, says Peter Harris, chairman of the national council for family proceedings. Before his retirement last year as official solicitor, he was called in to some of the most contentious cases in the courts.

"Adults often don't realise the impact on the child of what they're doing. The classic situation is where the mother has found a new partner. She may have very good reasons for feeling angry with her former partner and merely wants to get this horrible man out of her life, overlooking the fact that this horrible man is the father of her child and probably much loved by the child."

He warns that mothers may store up trouble for themselves in later life by denying their children a relationship with their father. "Children can become extremely resentful in adolescence and turn against the parent who's been nurturing them through childhood. It puts at risk not only the child's immediate future but their long-term ability to form relationships and have successful adult lives."

The courts are growing more aware of the phenomenon of parental alienation, in which children side with the parent they live with and take on his or her feelings of anger towards the other parent. "The child is faced with a conflict of loyalties," says Harris, "which they will often resolve by lining up with the parent caring for them and rejecting the other parent. It often becomes an issue for them in later life when they re-establish contact with the other parent and find he's not so bad. They may feel extremely resentful of the parent who claimed their loyalty. "

In the US, psychiatrists recommend that courts should firmly enforce contact in these cases, thus removing the onus from the child, who can say: "I didn't want to see him but the judge forced me." A more drastic step is to switch homes, letting the children live with the other parent. This is a solution which English courts will use only in the most extreme cases - in Peter Harris's experience as official solicitor no more than one a year.

Barrister Caroline Willbourne has been in two such cases, each time acting for fathers. She says mothers often claim to be happy for the children to see their father, but then "pull the plug" when the time comes. Children will express hostility to the father, but show different behaviour in his presence.

One of her cases involved an English family living in Florida with three children aged between three and eight, who were abducted by their mother back to England. An English judge ruled that the father could take the children back to Florida to live with him. In the second case, a former social worker, who went to great lengths to deny her first husband access to their daughter after she remarried, decided to take the child to South Africa, along with her baby by her second husband. Both children were allowed to live with their respective fathers. Strikingly, neither mother tried to see the children again once they had been "won" by their fathers.

The appeal court will hear four cases on contact in a fortnight, and lay down guidelines for judges in these fraught cases. The human rights act, which comes into force next October, will enshrine a right to respect for private and family life in English law. Meanwhile, John Beale is still hoping for the chance to have a family life.

fields.headline: Disabled child care
fields.trailText: Case of the week
fields.body:
Last November the House of Lords ruled that parents who had an unwanted birth - for instance, after a failed sterilisation - could not claim the costs of bringing up a healthy child. The ruling caused much surprise because it reversed a line of cases in the Court of Appeal which had decided the opposite.

But what if the child was not healthy but handicapped? The Lords left that issue open. Now the High Court has ruled that the parents of a disabled child are entitled to the full cost of the upbringing and future care.

Mr and Mrs Rand sued east Dorset health authority for not passing on to them the results of a routine scan which showed that the baby Mrs Rand was carrying was likely to have Down's syndrome. Had they known, they said, she would have had an abortion.

The High Court judge, Mr Justice Newman, held that the fact that parents had the right under the Abortion Act to terminate a pregnancy if the baby was likely to be born disabled put a duty on the health authority to make sure parents had the information to exercise that choice. East Dorset was under a duty as far as possible to save the parents from the consequences of having a disabled child.

Before the House of Lords case, brought against Tayside health board in Scotland by George and Laura McFarlane, lawyers had collected compensation for scores of English families who had had healthy babies after failed sterilisations or vasectomies over the previous 15 years - in some cases even including the cost of private schooling.

The same day the lords delivered their ruling, the High Court awarded £1.3m to Gail Taylor, who gave birth to a handicapped son, John, after a sterilisation operation that went wrong. The money is meant to cover the cost of looking after John, her fifth child, for the rest of his life. After the Lords' ruling in the McFarlane case, Shropshire health authority appealed against the award to Mrs Taylor.

Will the Court of Appeal judges take the same line as Mr Justice Newman in the Rand case? We predict they will. It's one thing if a hospital's negligence leaves you with a healthy child to bring up, but quite another to be left with the lifetime's burden and costs of a disabled child through someone else's fault, and be denied compensation.

webTitle: Foreign office bans Galloway's flight to Iraq

fields.headline: Foreign office bans Galloway's flight to Iraq
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign office unexpectedly stepped in yesterday to ground a flight carrying medical supplies to Iraq.
fields.body:
The foreign office unexpectedly stepped in yesterday to ground a flight carrying medical supplies to Iraq.

The flight, organised by the Labour MP George Galloway and scheduled for next Saturday, would have been the first between London and Baghdad since the Gulf war in 1991.

The foreign office yesterday dismissed the mission as a "Saddam Hussein publicity stunt" and refused to refer the case to the UN sanctions committee for the approval needed for the flight to go ahead.

International sanctions have been in place against Iraq since the war, in spite of widespread concern that the sanctions are not achieving any political ends but are causing suffering among civilians.

The US and Britain are adamant that the sanctions will not be lifted until the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, allows in weapons inspectors.

Mr Galloway, who is opposed to the sanctions, is proposing to take the foreign office to the high court over the ban, claiming that there are no legal grounds on which to prevent British citizens travelling to Iraq.

Relatively amicable discussions between the foreign office and Mr Galloway had been continuing for weeks. But a hitch developed at the end of last week when the foreign office objected to the fact that there would be 207 passengers on the plane, arguing that this figure was incompatible with a humanitarian mission and claiming it would be in breach of the sanctions.

The foreign office has told Mr Galloway to get the numbers down to about 20 or 30, an ultimatum he regards as impossible. He said yesterday: "On the face of it, it is the most appalling breach of good faith I have ever encountered in parliament in 13 years."

Having met with an initially positive response from the foreign office, Mr Galloway suspects a hidden hand - either from the US or from another part of Whitehall - behind the sudden decision.

The Iraqi government wins either way. If the flight had gone ahead, it would have been a propaganda coup for President Saddam. A banned flight provides equally good publicity.

The foreign office says the sanctions are flexible enough to allow Iraq to sell enough oil to permit a reasonable standard of living. If civilians are suffering, the department says President Saddam's administration is to blame.

Accompanying Mr Galloway on the flight were to have been Dennis Halliday, a UN official who had been based in Baghdad and who resigned in protest at impact of sanctions on the civilian population, and John Nicol, one of two RAF crew captured by the Iraqis during the Gulf war, who also opposes sanctions.

Also on the passenger list were 20 journalists, 30 people from the United Arab Emirates, including the crown prince of Dubai, representatives of non-governmental agencies, Iraqi expatriates and anti-sanctions campaigners.

The plane, supplied by the UAE, had been due to fly from Heathrow to Baghdad via Dubai, with £150,000 worth of medical supplies on board.

An acrimonious exchange of letters took place over the weekend between Mr Galloway and the foreign office minister, Peter Hain. The two, both on the left of the party, had been relatively friendly for years.

A foreign office source said yesterday: "If this was a genuine mercy mission, as opposed to a Saddam Hussein publicity stunt, then nine-tenths of the plane would be filled with medical and other humanitarian supplies. Instead, we have the entire cabin filled with hangers-on when all the space could be used for equipment to help the people of Iraq."

He added: "We will not put it forward to the sanctions committee. We would have no credibility if we did."

In a letter to Mr Galloway, Mr Hain said: "I was very keen to support a humanitarian mission to Iraq. I was especially keen that all the medical supplies you have obtained reach Baghdad. I will ensure that they do so whether or not your flight is given the necessary clearance."

The medical supplies could be ferried through the UN.

Mr Hain added: "A humanitarian flight should be just that, not an excuse for all sorts of people to fly into Iraq and breach international sanctions."

Mr Galloway said that, if he was forced to write off the flight, he would look at alternatives, such as taking the medical supplies on a scheduled flight to Dubai and then continuing by ferry to Iraq. But in that case the number of people able to accompany him would fall to around a dozen.

He said yesterday the ban would be badly received in the Arab world and accused the government of "pretending to go along with the project and then attempting to ground it on spurious grounds".

Mr Galloway said that, if he was forced to write off the flight, he would look at alternatives, such as taking the medical supplies on a scheduled flight to Dubai and then continuing by ferry to Iraq. But in that case the number of people able to accompany him would fall to around a dozen. He said yesterday the ban would be badly received in the Arab world and accused the government of "pretending to go along with the project and then attempting to ground it on spurious grounds".

fields.headline: Little girl lost
fields.standfirst: Bonnie Langford says she wants to be seen as an adult.  Anita Chaudhuri  on why we won't let women act their age
fields.trailText: Bonnie Langford says she wants to be seen as an adult.  Anita Chaudhuri  on why we won't let women act their age
fields.body:
It's a tough life being a recovering child star - just ask Bonnie Langford. Twenty-five years after she found fame playing the insufferable Violet Elizabeth Bott in TV's Just William, she is still begging to be allowed to join the grown-ups.

As a last-ditch bid for rehabilitation into adult life, she has taken the unprecedented step of placing an advert in The Stage newspaper to promote her new, non-lisping self. "If you don't start taking me seriously as a mature woman, I'll scweam and scweam until I'm thick!" screams the ad. Actually, it doesn't say that at all. It says, "No more ringlets, no more squeaky brat... just pure talent."

The accompanying colour photograph features the revamped Langford reclining in a raunchy pose, her shirt unbuttoned to her navel. "People are fixed on how I used to be 25 years ago," she says. "What I am saying is look at me now and forget the past and the misconceptions." Alas, to look at Ms Langford now is a faintly disturbing experience, not least because, with her dodgy perm and "bad girl" make-up, she looks suspiciously like a contestant in a Suzi Quatro lookalike competition.

"I am no longer a little girl," she protests. "I don't know why people are reluctant to see that I've grown up. I have developed in all areas since then - all areas." This may be true: she has recorded an album, available from her website, www.bonnielangford.co.uk but she claims casting directors are not interested in her because of her ignominious past.

The problem for most child stars is that there is absolutely zero public demand for them to grow up. And for female child stars this is particularly true, since they are often cast alongside middle-aged men. Recent TV footage of Lena Zavaroni singing and dancing her heart out with Morecambe and Wise served as a reminder of how far female stars are pushed into a daddy's girl fantasy where the simpering cutie-pie must forever be nine years old.

Zavaroni paid the ultimate price for bowing to this pressure to stave off puberty. Her battle with anorexia was a direct consequence of an obsession to hang onto her infantile figure for the sake of her career.

Hollywood reference books are littered with cases of child stars who were never allowed to grow old in public. Linda Blair, the angelic child possessed by the devil in The Exorcist, was suddenly viewed as unwholesome and pensioned off to a life of hard drugs and being stalked by crazed fans.

And woe betide those girls who dare to explore pubescent sexuality - a lifetime guarantee to send directors running for their lives, with visions of Roman Polanski looming large in their minds. Sue Lyon, cast as the original Lolita when she was 14, vanished into obscurity, married a life prisoner and spent her savings on renting a motel room next to the prison. Brooke Shields, cast as a 12-year-old prostitute in Louis Malle's Pretty Baby, was never to repeat that dubious success either.

Interestingly, Jodie Foster, who played a prostitute in Taxi Driver when she was 12, did survive being a child star. But that was surely because the way she played the role was not at all infantilised: as with her role of Tallulah in Bugsy Malone, she was clearly a child playing a grown-up. There was no flirtation with pubescent sexuality.

Other girl stars have survived, of course. Christina Ricci, now a hot Hollywood property, made her name as Wednesday in The Addams Family, but again this wasn't a child-like role at all: it was just plain weird. Drew Barrymore and Patsy Kensit have also survived childhood careers, but only just.

At the heart of the matter is a reluctance in the entertainment industry to allow women to act their age. At the other end of the scale, Kathleen Turner - soon to play Mrs Robinson in The Graduate in London's West End - complained bitterly this week that there were no parts being written for women of 40 plus. Of course, we are all aware that Hollywood only wants a woman to be one age - the age at which she can rot in boyfriend hell and where Meg Ryan, for example, has spent her entire career. After that, as Susan Sarandon once quipped, "it's Driving Miss Daisy".

Which brings us back to Bonnie Langford, who is now 35. She is hoping that someone will commission one of the two new dramas that have been specially written for her before she has to start playing OAPs. She is married, with a stepchild of eight. More than grown up enough to take on adult roles.

Married! Violet Elizabeth Bott? How old does that make the rest of us feel? And that, in a nutshell, is probably why none of us can really stomach the idea of seeing her grown-up self on screen.
