fields.headline: Let's talk about sex
fields.standfirst: When abortion rates soared after Millennium Eve, it was put down to alcohol-fuelled folly. But, argues  Angela Phillips, the evidence points to our ongoing struggle to find a language of desire
fields.trailText: When abortion rates soared after Millennium Eve, it was put down to alcohol-fuelled folly. But, argues  Angela Phillips, the evidence points to our ongoing struggle to find a language of desire
fields.body:
Do British women really need to get smashed in order to have sex? According to the Marie Stopes clinic, abortion figures rise every year as the annual fall-out from New Year's Eve parties take their toll and this year the figure rose by a staggering 20% extra. If we discount the apocalyptic few who expected the world to end - and didn't think they would live long enough to take a pregnancy test - what was going on in the minds of the others?

Given the hype surrounding the evening in question, there is little doubt that large numbers of people were desperate to get laid. After all, if this was to be the most remembered night in 1,000 years, you would want to be doing something memorable - and there is something rather cheering about that fact that so many people still think that creating their own fireworks is preferable to watching those organised by the government.

But how sad that so many were clearly unable to admit what they really wanted and instead left it all to alcohol and chance. Three decades on since the swinging 60s and the women's liberation movement, we still don't seem to know whether sex is nice, naughty or just something nasty done to women by men.

If sexual assertiveness can be measured by the degree to which women seem to be in control of their fertility, then the English-speaking countries are not doing well. All over the developed world the age of first birth has risen and the number of births to teenagers has dropped as women's rights and educational opportunities have improved. The UK rates dropped just like all the others - at first - but at the start of the 80s they started to rise again. We now have the highest level of teenage births in Europe and even this is better than the situation in Canada, New Zealand and the United States.

Sexual ambivalence is something that seems to be passed on, like a virus, via the English language. This is not a north-south thing. Italy is up there with the Dutch and the Swiss in an unlikely triumvirate of countries that can (with the Scandinavians) boast low rates of teenage pregnancy. Is this just because these teenagers don't have sex, or is it because they have learned that sex is something to treasure, to feel positive about and to prepare for?

We tell girls that they should buy a certain shampoo because "they are worth it". We should be telling them to treasure their bodies in the same way, for the same reason.

There was a time when it looked as though that is exactly what we were doing. In the 60s and early 70s feminism was positive about sex. The Pill and abortion liberated a whole generation from the fear of pregnancy and we hadn't yet discovered a sexually transmitted disease that we couldn't cure.

Women were starting to talk to each other about their sexual experiences and learning the difference between having sex done to you and actually enjoying it. I don't think I had ever heard of (let alone felt) a female orgasm until my friend lent me a book by Mette Ejersen called I Accuse, which explained the function of the clitoris. Then came The Myth of the Vaginal Orgasm, closely followed by the Hite Report by Shere Hite and Nancy Friday's compendium of sexual fantasies called My Secret Garden.

Women were talking about what they liked and trying it out, too: some with men, some with women, some with both - and some by themselves.

A list of articles in Spare Rib magazine included: Good Vibrations (on the joys of the vibrator); Unlearning Not to Have an Orgasm and Making Changes, Making Love. There were ads for vibrators and "pre-orgasmic therapy". In the first British edition of the women's health textbook Our Bodies Ourselves, there is a section called Learning to Masturbate - commonplace now, perhaps, but so revolutionary then that, when the galleys came back, the section had to be completely rewritten because the typesetter had been unable either to type or to see straight. Or perhaps he (in those steam-driven days before computer setting, it nearly always was a he) had been following the instructions and got carried away.

Then, almost overnight, the mood changed. Out of America came a succession of books about rape, sexual exploitation and pornography, and here in Britain we discovered the nasty secret of domestic violence. The joy seemed to go out of sex and that happy coalition between those who had campaigned for greater sexual freedom and those who wanted more economic freedom began to fray.

Worse still, this new mood coincided with a tide of political conservatism. Anti-sex feminism in coalition with the God squad seemed to set the political and intellectual agenda. Where young women in the early 70s were starting to learn that assertiveness was the best defence against sexual exploitation, now optimism was being replaced with fear and women were once again learning to see themselves as victims. Education authorities went into retreat over enlightened sex education programmes and only the government's fear of Aids, it seems, prevented the anti-sex message from turning back all the advances.

For young people the messages have become hopelessly confusing. On the one hand they are exposed to movies and magazines that tell them sex is the best fun you can have. On the other they are told by politicians and the news media that sex issomething to be feared as a source of disease and shame: teenage mother (bad), sex on a beach with Leonardo DiCaprio (good).

In the middle is a government that, according to its recent report on teenage pregnancies, would like to help but doesn't know where it stands. Does it want to pacify the Daily Mail (by insisting that sex education should teach the importance of marriage and the arguments for delaying sex), or does it want to help teenagers by giving them the confidence to "judge what kind of relationships they want and put that into practice"?

A group of 700 teenagers in Brighton were asked what they wanted by researchers at the town's university and their answers were clear: they wanted to be able to talk about lust and desire, emotions and relationships - not just conception and disease and how to prevent them.

It is in schools that we see just how stuck the British sexual revolution has become. Over 90% of parents and children see school as the best place for sex education and yet 68% of children have learned most of what they know from the media. The policy vacuum of the past 20 years has left young people to the tender mercies of moviemakers and magazines - and the tabloid press, which ensures that we never forget that the truly British expression for sex is the snigger. Boys learn, via soft porn, that women "want to be dominated", girls learn from teen mags that boys "only want one thing", schools reinforce the message by concentrating sex education almost entirely on what boys might "do" to girls that the girls don't want.

In the midst of all this we forgot to tell our children that good sex is the most pleasure that two people can give to each other. No wonder they need to get drunk before they can do it.

webTitle: Communist puppet and drug-user prove to be beyond satire

fields.headline: Communist puppet and drug-user prove to be beyond satire
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report
The Onion
fields.trailText: The Vietnamese government is quietly celebrating the fact that John McCain, the "Manchurian candidate" they brainwashed and programmed to seize power in the United States is only a few steps away from their goal. His chief rival, George W Bush, who plans to free all drug offenders if elected, has a new strategy to woo Latino voters: he is doubling his normal tip in Mexican restaurants.
fields.body:
The Vietnamese government is quietly celebrating the fact that John McCain, the "Manchurian candidate" they brainwashed and programmed to seize power in the United States is only a few steps away from their goal. His chief rival, George W Bush, who plans to free all drug offenders if elected, has a new strategy to woo Latino voters: he is doubling his normal tip in Mexican restaurants.

As the campaign for the Republican and Democrat nominations reaches its likely climax in California and New York tomorrow, the satirical rumour mills have been grinding even more energetically.

It is not surprising that the notion of Mr McCain as a brainwashed tool of the communists should have a certain frisson. John Frankenheimer's 1962 film The Manchurian Candidate explored the idea of an American hero of the Korean war who had been programmed by the communists to return to the US and kill a politician. Starring Lawrence Harvey, Frank Sinatra and Janet Leigh, the film caused waves at a time when the US was recovering from its McCarthyite anti-communist witch-hunts. The wicked rumour that Mr McCain, a prisoner of the Vietnamese for five and a half years, was the new "Manchurian candidate" has been given its biggest airing by his own supporters, who have publicised it as an example of how dastardly some opponents can be in spreading such obvious nonsense.

Mr Bush was an early victim of the dirty rumour mills. A website, gwbush.com, which purported to be his, claimed that in his first year in office he would empty the jails of the country's 400,000 drug offenders. Citing the fact that one in nine children in the US has a parent in jail, he was said on the site to want to become "the president who gave those kids their parents back".

"Recreational drug users - like I used to be - are serving life sentences because dealer friends made up stories to get a lighter sentence," says "Mr Bush" on the bogus website. "If this were happening in China, we'd probably start bombing them for human rights violations. We have to let these people go."

Mr Bush's attempts to win the Latino vote prompted The Onion, a Wisconsin-based satirical newspaper and website, to run the story: "Bush reaches out to Hispanic community with generous tip."

The Onion records that "Bush extended the hand of friendship to the nation's Hispanic community by leaving a larger-than-customary tip for waiter Ramon Gonzalez after eating at La Galeria, a trendy Chula Vista bistro". The Onion, which has 1m readers, suggested that Mr Bush's "$20 gratuity on a bill of $83.42, working out at 24%, is the largest tip the Hispanic community has ever received from a Republican presidential candidate". Mr Bush was quoted as saying: "It is my way of acknowledging the many valuable things Hispanics bring to the table - from appetisers to drinks to main courses."

The Republican frontrunner was also mocked after a rally in Michigan last week, when a Canadian television reporter told Mr Bush that he had won the endorsement of the Canadian prime minister, Jean Poutine. Mr Bush was flattered and told the reporter: "I'm honoured... He understands that I want to ensure our relationship with our most important neighbour to the north of us, Canadians, is strong. We will work closely together."

Alas for Mr Bush, the real Canadian prime minister is Jean Chrétien - while Poutine is a high-calorie, fast-food French-Canadian dish of chips covered in gravy and cheese curd. The "journalist" was the Canadian comedian Rick Mercer who operates in a similar way to Britain's Ali G and often pokes fun at Americans' ignorance of Canada. Mr Bush's gaffe was gleefully transmitted in Canada last week. He was targeted after he failed to identify the leaders of India and Pakistan in interviews.

But if Mr Bush continues to run, comedians may be redundant anyway. He is, after all, the "compassionate conservative" who last week gave the go-ahead to execute a great-grandmother in Texas.

As satirist Tom Lehrer said when Henry Kissinger won the Nobel peace prize: "Who needs satire?"

webTitle: Bush set to eclipse rival McCain in do or die primaries

fields.headline: Bush set to eclipse rival McCain in do or die primaries
fields.standfirst:
Countdown to Super Tuesday: Day of reckoning looms for maverick Republican presidential candidate

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: John McCain's campaign to wrest the Republican presidential nomination from his rival George W Bush appeared yesterday to be running out of steam, if not invective, in the days leading up to the biggest test of his credibility.
fields.body:
John McCain's campaign to wrest the Republican presidential nomination from his rival George W Bush appeared yesterday to be running out of steam, if not invective, in the days leading up to the biggest test of his credibility.

The Arizona senator, trailing in most polls in advance of primary elections in 13 states tomorrow, concentrated on claiming a victory for his integrity.

He accused Mr Bush of distorting the electoral process and came close to saying that the Texas governor had run a dishonourable campaign.

The Arizona senator and Vietnam war hero was up to 20 points behind in California, the biggest prize on "Super Tuesday" and lagging by up to 8% among members of his own party in New York, the next most valuable state in terms of delegates.

Mr McCain put a brave face on the failure of his maverick campaign to outflank Mr Bush and his allies in the Republican establishment.

"I think there's a lot of volatility out there," he said. "Being a little bit behind in some polls is sometimes helpful because then if you do better, they say 'McCain exceeded expectations'."

But even his own advisers expect him to come second in in the poll of California Republicans, which has 162 delegates, though he might still win the non-binding popular vote.

He is considered unlikely to take more than a few New England states and maybe half of New York's 101 delegates. Mr McCain again ruled out any interest in becoming vice-president and said he would not attempt to capitalise on his popularity among independents and Democrats by running as a third-party candidate.

"I would not under any circumstances consider being vice-president of the United States," he said. "The vice-president has two duties: the first is to inquire daily into the health of the president and the other is to attend the funerals of third world dictators."

Mr Bush decided not to risk blowing his lead by appearing on television, leaving Mr McCain to rail against his opponent's tactics.

First Mr McCain seized on a $2.5m (£1.6m) advertisement attacking his record on the environment and which was paid for by a Texan billionaire.

"George Bush ought to be ashamed of that, of his Texas cronies who came in and tried to deceive the voters," he said.

"America deserves better than what's coming out of the Bush campaign."

The McCain camp's disdain will test Mr Bush's slogan "I'm a uniter, not a divider" between now and November's presidential election. David Lawrence, a professor of political science at Fordham university, said yesterday: "I think George W Bush is going to have a very difficult time putting back together the Republican coalition when this is all over."

A few months ago in New York, for instance, it was all very different. Then the state's Republican establishment was solidly behind Mr Bush.

If anyone was going to break the grip of the party machines it looked more likely to be Bill Bradley, whose challenge tfor the Democratic nomination faded as Mr McCain's star rose and who is now expected to drop out at any moment.

But since then "the world's most unusual university," an ailing cardinal, a late-night talk show host and a breast cancer patient have divided the state's Republican party.

Mr Bush had to repair the damage done by his appearance at the Bob Jones university in South Carolina and his failure to denounce its anti-Catholic attitudes and its discrimination against black people.

The appearance cost him the support of such figures as Rudolph Giuliani, the mayor of New York, and Peter King, the Long Island congressman.

Mr Bush wrote a mea culpa to New York's revered cardinal John O'Connor. But the Bush people had not checked to see whether he was fit to read the letter. After a brain tumour, the cardinal's hearing is failing and he has trouble reading.

Mr Bush's common touch was employed next on Late Night With Letterman, a routinely unchallenging rite of passage for any serious political candidate.

"'A uniter, not a divider' - what exactly does that mean?" David Letterman asked the Texas governor. Mr Bush replied: "When the time comes to sew up your chest cavity we use stitches as opposed to opening it up. That's what that means." Letterman is recovering from heart bypass surgery.

Finally a Bush advertisement starring a former breast cancer patient made selective use of Mr McCain's voting record to indicate that he was hostile to breast cancer programmes. But Mr McCain said that his sister had been treated for the condition.

Asked if he really believed that his opponent was against breast cancer research, Mr Bush was forced to admit: "No, I don't believe that."

webTitle: Spotlight shines on architectural riches locked behind bars

fields.headline: Spotlight shines on architectural riches locked behind bars
fields.trailText: A hidden treasury of British architecture which most people hope they will never experience personally will be exposed in a book on prisons published next week.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
A hidden treasury of British architecture which most people hope they will never experience personally will be exposed in a book on prisons published next week.

"We did it because we were surprised to realise that nothing like it existed," said Allan Brodie, the architectural historian who has spent five years visiting every working prison, former prisons including Georgian lockups, and any new public and private sector prisons being built.

They include former stately homes and medieval castles, and a seaside camp built in the 1930s by boys who were marched 50 miles from their borstal, and lived in tents until they built their accommodation huts. "Some of the buildings are magnificent, and of great historical importance," Mr Brodie said.

With photographer James Davies, and the rest of the team from the royal commission on the historical monuments of England/English Heritage, he got unprecedented access to every prison.

The prisons included the cathedral-like spaces of HMP Preston, a mid-19th century prison designed by Alfred Waterhouse, and the chapel for over 1,000 at Wormwood Scrubs in west London.

These are contrasted with the starkness of modern prisons such as Featherstone in Staffordshire, two-story blocks with featureless walls except for the ranks of barred windows. Featherstone, like most 20th century prisons, was intended to replace the much criticised Victorian prisons.

Mr Brodie found that the modern cells were often smaller, that sanitation, ventilation and heating were only now returning to the level of the original 19th century designs, and that staff and inmates preferred the light and space of the open-landing Victorian prisons.

The project began in the mid-1990s, when the royal commission realised that drastic alterations were taking place at many Victorian prisons which had never been photographed or recorded. Originally the team intended just to record a sample, but it has become the first commission project to record every example, and the archive will be updated as new prisons are added.

Originally it was intended purely as an architectural record, but it evolved to include daily life in the prisons.

fields.headline: Weekends in kitchen for women
fields.trailText: Weekends mean relaxation for men while for women they are for household chores, a survey shows today. Working mothers with schoolchildren still get the toughest deal when it comes to managing their home and following a career
fields.body:
Weekends mean relaxation for men while for women they are for household chores, a survey shows today. Working mothers with schoolchildren still get the toughest deal when it comes to managing their home and following a career

The Whole Woman survey was carried out to launch Germaine Greer's book of the same name published in paperback by Anchor.

Six-in-ten agree that men regard Saturday and Sunday as time off, according to the poll of 500 women.

And while the British male indulges in his favourite activities, his partner is more likely to be doing the washing or cleaning the sink.

The nationwide survey found almost 60% of women cast doubts over the masculine capacity for self-reliance. Most women still agree that "men don't shop, even for their own underpants".

The survey suggests feminism hasn't won yet.

Working women in their 30s and 40s, with a family and children, are most likely to feel hard done by compared with women in older age groups and women who do not work.But 70% still believe their lives are better than those of their mothers.

fields.headline: Alcohol fires 'almost half of pregnancies'
fields.trailText: Almost half of all children are conceived by parents who at the time are over the drink drive limit, a survey out today reveals.
fields.body:
Almost half of all children are conceived by parents who at the time are over the drink drive limit, a survey out today reveals.

More than four in 10 couples had been drinking on the night life was created, with the woman having had on average four drinks and the father five.

The survey, for Pregnancy and Birth magazine, also found that 73% of couples made no attempt to improve their health while trying for a baby.

The findings, based on questionnaires from 2,000 women, reveal that the average age of a British mother is 28 years, and 31 for her partner. Two-thirds of children are born to married couples, 26% to cohabiting parents, and one in 10 babies are born to single mothers.

On average a mother has slept with six men before settling down with the one to father a child, and 84% say he is the best lover they ever had. One in five first time pregnancies were unplanned, but 81% of women said they were happy to be expecting. Some 87% of pregnant women admitted they were frightened of giving birth and 48% said they would be disappointed if they could not have a natural labour.

The survey also found that most parents-to-be did not change their lifestyles before conceiving and were unprepared financially for the arrival of their baby. But once they discover they are pregnant, 57% of women give up drinking and 26% cut down.

Half of couples (one or both) smoke before conception. While 50% of women give up, one-in-five continue to smoke an average of nine cigarettes a day.

Some 88% of prospective parents acknowledged a baby would change their life, but only 42% had made any long-term savings plans, said Valery McConnell, editor of Pregnancy and Birth magazine.

"Babies need smoke free zones. Smoking in pregnancy means you're three times more likely to have a low-birthweight baby," she said.

webTitle: Inquiry over instruments in CJD birth

fields.headline: Inquiry over instruments in CJD birth
fields.trailText: The department of health has launched an inquiry after surgical instruments used to deliver the baby of a woman subsequently found to have the human form of mad cow disease were used by maternity ward staff for two months after the birth.
fields.body:
The department of health has launched an inquiry after surgical instruments used to deliver the baby of a woman subsequently found to have the human form of mad cow disease were used by maternity ward staff for two months after the birth.

The equipment was properly washed and sterilised between operations, but there was still a possibility that it was contaminated with the agent that causes new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Rod Griffiths, West Midlands director of public health, said the risk that other women, thought to be fewer than 10, had been infected during subsequent births was "vanishingly small".

Staff had followed proper procedure, removing the instruments from use as soon as the mother's condition was known, he said. The prion that caused CJD was usually removed simply by washing before sterilisation.

The mother gave birth last year, but neither she nor the hospital can be named for legal reasons. Her baby is believed to have a neurological disorder and is being tested for CJD.

fields.headline: £910 to do business in London
fields.trailText: London remains the most expensive European city to visit, despite costs having fallen slightly in recent months, new research shows.
fields.body:
London remains the most expensive European city to visit, despite costs having fallen slightly in recent months, new research shows.

The average cost to an executive for a two-night business trip to London is £910, according to statistics in the latest edition of Business Traveller magazine.

The figure, based on September 1999 statistics, showed London prices had fallen 4.56% compared with a similar survey in September 1998.

But London is still the third most expensive city in the world for executives. The most expensive is Tokyo, where a two-day business trip costs £1,212. Next dearest is Beijing at £1,002.

The costs are based on two nights at a top hotel, two lunches, two evening meals, two international newspapers, one local newspaper, one news magazine, eight three-mile taxi trips and taxis to and from the airport.

The European city cost comparisons are: Amsterdam £602, Barcelona £543, Brussels £653, Frankfurt £688, London £910, Milan £648, Moscow £749, Paris £815, Prague £577, Stockholm £536, Zurich £650.

webTitle: BBC shows India how to cook curry

fields.headline: BBC shows India how to cook curry
fields.trailText: The BBC has sold a cookery programme on how to make curry to an Indian cable channel.
fields.body:
The BBC has sold a cookery programme on how to make curry to an Indian cable channel.

Millions of Indian viewers will be able to tune in to cookery lessons by Madhur Jaffrey in her show Flavours of India.

The programme is part of a £700,000 deal with Broadcast Worldwide in India, which will air 260 hours of original BBC documentary programming a year on its four satellite and cable channels from mid-April.

Broadcast Worldwide will transmit the programmes five days a week for the three-year contract.

It is the first time that a series of BBC programmes will be shown in India and the rest of South Asia.

The programmes will be dubbed into Gujarati, Marathi, Punjabi and Bengali - another first for the BBC.

The package will consist mainly of documentary, natural history and other factual programmes.

fields.headline: Solway sinking spurs safety action
fields.standfirst: Superstition or macho image stops crews from wearing life jackets or learning to swim
fields.trailText: Superstition or macho image stops crews from wearing life jackets or learning to swim
fields.body:
The man on the quayside cannot swim. Like other fishermen clambering off trawlers in Peterhead harbour he makes a living from the sea but could not survive in it, choosing not to prolong the horror of a death in frigid water.

"My father and uncle were fishermen and neither of them could swim," he added.

It is just one superstition still held by some of those who work in what is now one of the riskiest professions. In the past year 21 vessels have been lost, 26 fishermen have died and 93 have been seriously injured. The loss of the Solway Harvester with all hands in January was the latest tragedy, but it has also been the spur for the industry's biggest safety clampdown.

The preliminary report into the sinking by the marine accident investigation branch identified a number of apparent lapses on the scallop dredger, including too few life jackets and lack of crew training.

The maritime and coastguard agency has since been ordered to check all British fishing vessels, more than 6,500 boats. Two of the Solway's sister ships have already been detained in harbour for alleged safety lapses and more boats are expected to follow.

Fishermen's leaders are seeking ways to improve safety standards, but coastguards say nothing less than a complete cultural change will work. And if fishermen will not respond, their families will be targeted.

Mark Clark of the coastguard service said: "If you go along to Peterhead, you'll see they spend a fortune on their gear and not a lot to do with their own personal safety. If you swim you're seen as a wimp. It's just daft and it's been very frustrating for us.

"There would be nothing worse than for a child to ask his father: 'Dad, have you got your life jacket on today? Is your boat watertight?' That's the sort of pressure that might actually work."

Some of those in the industry admit a hardman culture. "There is this macho man image, certainly with the younger lads," said one fisherman. "They'll be out working on the boat in a T-shirt and if you put a life jacket on, it's like, what's wrong with you then?"

Others said they could not afford not to take their own safety seriously. "We've been issued with hard hats and life jackets," said one crew member from the trawler Ryanwood, newly docked in Peterhead, the hub of the Scottish fishing trade. "To start with you're not keen to be seen to put them on, then someone will have theirs on and it goes from there. We have to take it seriously, the insurance is starting to crack down now."

The Royal National Mission to Deep Sea Fishermen, which deals with the aftermath of fishing tragedies, is raising funds for a safety training centre in one Scottish fishing port. It said critics did not understand the realities of clawing a living in such a dangerous environment.

"You can't put a cost on lives but when you're trying to make ends meet and you're getting pushed tighter and squeezed by quotas, safety does not always get the priority," said a spokesman. "They don't deliberately take risks. However, all the safety equipment in the world is not going to have any effect against a wall of water."

But George Clark, an Aberdeen-based claims specialist whose firm is involved in legal action over the sinking of the trawler Sapphire off Peterhead in 1997, in which four men died, said the industry was still stuck in its ways.

"It's almost a Klondyke atmosphere, a little bit of the Wild West. It's a difficult and dangerous environment they work in and it's very difficult to make it entirely safe, but attitudes have been slow to change.

"It's a close community, the fishing community; they grieve their losses, they look after their own and I think they believe these are just things that happen, that once in a while there is going to be a disaster."

fields.headline: Teenage drug use 'starts to decline'
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: After steadily increasing for more than a decade, drug-taking by younger teenagers has started to decline, according to a study into the habits of 14- to 15-year-olds published today by the schools health education unit at Exeter university.
fields.body:
After steadily increasing for more than a decade, drug-taking by younger teenagers has started to decline, according to a study into the habits of 14- to 15-year-olds published today by the schools health education unit at Exeter university.

Although young people are more likely than ever before to be offered illegal drugs, they are less likely to start experimenting with them, the unit found.

Its director, John Balding, has tracked the behaviour and attitudes of this age group since 1987 when less than 5% admitted to having tried an illegal drug at least once.

By 1996 the proportion had risen to 33%, fuelling anxieties among parents and politicians that there was an unstoppable drugs epidemic.

But over the following two years the numbers steadied and last year the proportion fell to 21% for both boys and girls. Although the unit is cautious of interpreting a trend from a single year's figures, it concluded: "We are confident there has indeed been a levelling off and possibly even a downturn in this age group's experience of drugs."

There was a similar reduction in the proportion of drug-taking by 12- to 13-year-olds, with 5% of boys and 4% of girls saying they had taken an illegal drug at least once.

Mr Balding said the figures were "tremendous good news", suggesting that publicity around cases such as Leah Betts who died after taking ecstasy and the appointment of a drugs tsar might be reasons for the change.

The unit's findings are based on questionnaires completed each year by about 40,000 pupils aged 9 to 15.

In 1999 more than 40% of 14- to 15-year-olds said they had been offered drugs, usually cannabis. Although this was higher than before, the researchers think this may be the result of changes in the questions asked.

About 8% said that at some point in their lives they used cannabis regularly and just over 1% said the same about amphetamines and solvents.

When young people were asked if they knew where to obtain different illegal drugs, 18% of 12- to 13-year-olds and 39% of 14- to 15-year-olds said they knew where to get at least one.

webTitle: Top private school for whip's son

fields.headline: Top private school for whip's son
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A government whip has become the latest Labour politician to face charges of hypocrisy over education.
fields.body:
A government whip has become the latest Labour politician to face charges of hypocrisy over education.

Keith Bradley, MP for Manchester Withington, moved his son after four days at Parrs Wood high school, a comprehensive where he is said to have been unsettled, to Manchester grammar, one of the top five boys' independent schools and which lost significant state support when the government abolished the assisted places scheme.

The MP told the Sunday Times: "My son comes first ... this is a personal, family decision which has been taken in the best interests of our son's future well-being and happiness."

Theresa May, shadow secretary for education and employment, yesterday called the decision "typical Labour hypocrisy".

She said: "Senior Labour politicians send their children to independent schools and at the same time they abolish the assisted places scheme, stopping children from less well-off backgrounds from having the same opportunities," she said. "It is do as I say, not do as I do."

Mr Bradley received backing from an unexpected quarter yesterday when the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, told GMTV's Sunday Programme that the MP was "courageous" in putting the interests of his child before the political difficulties he would now face.

The MP is unlikely to face censure from the prime minister. Tony Blair sends his two sons across London to the former grant-maintained Oratory school, though there are other Catholic schools nearer to Downing Street, while the defence minister Baroness Symons and the cabinet office minister Lord Falconer both have children at private schools.

webTitle: Spire's fall from grace gains pace

fields.headline: Spire's fall from grace gains pace
fields.trailText: British scientists who have helped to stop the gradual tilt of the leaning tower of Pisa are now facing a challenge closer to home.
fields.body:
British scientists who have helped to stop the gradual tilt of the leaning tower of Pisa are now facing a challenge closer to home.

A structural survey of the bizarrely twisted spire of Chesterfield parish church in Derbyshire has found that snail-like movements in the timber have accelerated in the past 25 years.

Allegedly grabbed and wrenched sideways by the devil, after a local cobbler drove a nail through his foot while fitting new shoes, the crooked spire now leans over nine-and-a-half feet from its true centre. "It seems likely that the twist is the result of the timber frame warping under the weight of the lead cladding," said lecturer Mike Tomlinson, whose team last checked the bent timbers in 1973.

The use of green, unseasoned timber and a failure to add cross-bracing beams is thought to have led to the original slew.

The spire, which makes the building the largest church in Derbyshire, has corkscrewed 45mm to the west since then and 10mm to the south. The shift is not thought to present any danger yet to the church, which was built in 1234 and dedicated to St Mary.

The leaning tower of Pisa's 800 years of gradual tilting, at the rate of 1mm a year, were stopped for the first time last year by a system of pulleys and counterweights developed by John Burland and a team at Imperial college, London.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Four arrests as GM ship docks
Four Greenpeace activists were arrested, allegedly trying to get in Liverpool docks, when a ship with a cargo of GM soya arrived yesterday.
fields.body:
Four arrests as GM ship docks
Four Greenpeace activists were arrested, allegedly trying to get in Liverpool docks, when a ship with a cargo of GM soya arrived yesterday.

The Iolcos Grace from the US had been boarded a week ago by Greenpeace off Anglesey.

Crossing folly caught on film
A Railtrack trial of cameras at unmanned level crossings found a "widespread lack of cooperation".

In nine days at eight crossings in Scotland 64 offenders in separate incidents drove through red lights warning of an approaching train; one was a school bus. It is up to police to prosecute. [Keith Harper]

Prints identify body in chains
Police believe they know the identity of the woman whose body was found in chains on a Suffolk beach last week.

She will be named today after formal identification, but a fingerprint check identified her as in her late 20s and from Chelmsford in Essex. She had not been reported missing.

Newly born girl found dead
Grampian police are treating as suspicious the death of a newly born baby girl whose body was found in a house in Bishopmill, Elgin.

They were not able to say if the baby's parents were in the house or if they had been notified of her death.

Two win £3.3m each on lottery
Two tickets won £3.3m each in Saturday night's lottery with winning numbers 11, 13, 19, 26, 28 and 47. The bonus was 8. A further 35 tickets won £58,500 each. There were no Thunderball winners.

fields.headline: Photos 'could clear Rosemary West'
fields.trailText: The lawyer representing Rosemary West claimed yesterday that new evidence could help to clear her of serial killings.
fields.body:
The lawyer representing Rosemary West claimed yesterday that new evidence could help to clear her of serial killings.

Leo Goatley said photographic evidence, which he claimed was kept from defence lawyers, could show that West was not involved in murders she was convicted of committing with her husband, Frederick West. She is serving 10 life sentences for killing young women and girls in Gloucester and is seeking to have her case referred back to the court of appeal.

She is also applying to the criminal cases review commission, which investigates possible miscarriages of justice.

Mr Goatley told BBC Radio 5 Live: "The issue is whether Rosemary West got a fair trial. She has always maintained her innocence. There are a number of issues I feel deserve review."

He believed the two dozen pictures in an album were "voyeuristic snap shots" taken by Fred West when his victims died. If the pictures had the time printed on them they would help his client to prove she was not there.

Mr Goatley said he hoped to secure legal aid to have the case papers reviewed by counsel before making the submission.

Frederick West committed suicide while on remand facing 12 murder charges.

The chief constable of Gloucestershire police, Tony Butler, said: "As far as we are aware, Mr Goatley has not approached us at all about photographs in recent weeks. We believe that all material was disclosed to the crown prosecution service during the case.

"We have no idea what the current issues being raised by Mr Goatley are, and suggest he contact us through the proper channels."

Rosemary West was jailed for life in November 1995 after a trial at Winchester crown court. Her appeal in 1996 was dismissed after 15 minutes.

The crown's case had rested on the fact that the couple had acted together. Their victims were sexually abused before being murdered.

fields.headline: Scientists angered by 'arts mafia' influence
fields.standfirst: 'Two cultures' claim over cash for Tate but not for Science Museum
fields.trailText: A new row threatens to stir up the once-notorious two cultures debate and set science chiefs against an arts-loving government minister. The problem stems from the government's policy of free access to national museums.
fields.body:
A new row threatens to stir up the once-notorious two cultures debate and set science chiefs against an arts-loving government minister. The problem stems from the government's policy of free access to national museums.

While art lovers who had expected to pay to see the new £135m Tate Modern on London's Bankside will enter free of charge from May 12, people queueing at the Science Museum in South Kensington for the opening of its new £50m Wellcome wing in June could find admission prices increased.

Last month culture secretary Chris Smith announced an extra £5m for the Tate to ensure free entry. But it looks very unlikely that he will announce a similar sum for the Science Museum, despite the museum's initial expectation that they would get £5m to fulfil the government's post-election pledge of free entry.

The trustees of the South Kensington museum have refused to authorise the museum's latest budget, which called for raised entry prices and cuts in the repairs to interactive exhibits, and other damaging steps. They see the department of culture, media and sport as favouring the arts above science.

Dame Bridget Ogilvie, head of the royal society's committee for the public understanding of science, and one of the trustees, said: "Things are very serious. We begin to ask the question: is the arts mafia - which is very strong in terms of the chattering classes - getting the ear of our political masters rather more effectively than the scientists?"

Sir Neil Cossons, director of the Science Museum for the past 14 years, said both institutions had been required to put forward business plans before they could get the government nod for their new showplaces. Both expected to generate extra revenue by charging.

The only difference was that the Tate had always been free, whereas the Science Museum, like the Natural History Museum next door, had installed turnstiles as the Tory government cut museum funding.

Then came Labour's landslide victory, and a declaration by Mr Smith that museums and galleries were to return to the people. The science and natural history museums began letting children in free last April. Pensioners will be admitted free from this April. According to the government's plan all the great museums would be free from April next year.

But not, it now seems, for the South Kensington museums. Instead of scrapping the £6.95 adult charge, the Science Museum will have to increase the admission price to £8.50 to keep the museum running.

The science and natural history museums and the Tate all have Victorian origins, and all have millions of visitors each year.

Sir Neil said: "I would rather run a museum that charged and was good than one that was on principle free, and lousy. The difficulty is the art museums are not lousy. They are absolutely first class and they have traditionally been free and their supporters have enabled them to stay free."

He saw dangers of polarisation between the arts and sciences, an issue raised by the scientist and novelist CP Snow four decades ago. "It's a serious issue and it has been brought into sharp focus by the peculiarities of next year and the year after. The public who enjoy places like this are being told they are second rate citizens: if you want to enjoy science, you pay.

"I'm surprised because here we are still fighting the crazy battles of half a century, a century, and a century and a half ago. Of course there has to be access to art. But science has to thrive, and it has to thrive in terms of popular access, at a time when there is more interest than there has ever been - and astonishing and challenging new developments are taking place which will touch every man, woman and child in the country."

When the Wellcome wing was first announced five years ago it was described as a showcase for science that had yet to be invented. It will open with exhibitions devoted to the questions raised by the revolution in information technology and communications and in the new science of human genetics.

But the museum itself is devoted to the growth of British science from the 17th century to the present, including the industrial revolution that changed the world.

Both the Natural History Museum and the Science Museum were forced to impose charges to maintain standards. Both have had to make huge cuts and at the same time attract extra visitors. The argument in South Kensington is that there is no fat left to cut.

The director of the Natural History Museum, Neil Chalmers, hopes for generosity from Mr Smith when the the first phase of a £100m Darwin centre opens in 2002.

The department of culture said its priority was to see that museums that were already free remained free.

"We are not quite clear on what we are going to be doing for anyone."

But the Science Museum was not excluded because of its subject matter.

Contrasting exhibitions

Science Museum Wellcome wing

Opening : June 27
Funding: Project cost £50m. Heritage lottery fund gave £23m and Wellcome Trust, world's largest medical charity, donated £17.8m. Further support from main sponsors Intel, Agfa UK, Glaxo Wellcome, Pfizer, Toshiba, Mobil and Nature. Additional support from Garfield Weston Foundation.
Attractions: Aims to become the world's leading centre for public presentation of contemporary science, and claims to give its visitors information needed to debate major scientific questions of the day.
Wing will include 450-seat 3D Imaxcinema, space simulator,galleries on digital technology, biomedical science and future of science, and rapid news section.
Admission : £6.95 (to museum as whole), expected to rise to £8.50
Visitors : More than 2m a year

Tate Gallery of Modern Art at Bankside

Opening : May 12
Funding : Project cost £134m. Millennium commission contributed £50m, arts council of England £6m, English Partnerships £12m, and Southwark borough £1m; rest raised from private sector.
Attractions : Aims to be one of world's foremost modern art museums, and claims opening will be equivalent to that of Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1920s. Will house Tate's collection from 1900 to the present, and exhibit new art as it is created.
Admission : Free
Visitors: Tate galleries (Millbank, St Ives, and Liverpool) attract more than 2m a year

webTitle: Met and FO at loggerheads over Tibet protest tactics

fields.headline: Met and FO at loggerheads over Tibet protest tactics
fields.trailText: The level of distrust between the foreign office and the police has reached such a low that all future meetings should be minuted to avoid a repeat of the controversy over heavy-handed tactics used against Tibetan protesters during last year's Chinese state visit, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The level of distrust between the foreign office and the police has reached such a low that all future meetings should be minuted to avoid a repeat of the controversy over heavy-handed tactics used against Tibetan protesters during last year's Chinese state visit, it emerged yesterday.

A report by Scotland Yard on the affair, to be presented this week to the home secretary, Jack Straw, is said to pin the blame on the foreign office, accusing it of political interference. It recommends that future meetings between the foreign office and the Met be minuted.

But the foreign office was adamant yesterday it had not intervened and that all operational decisions had been left to the police. A foreign office source yesterday portrayed the police as the culprits and dismissed the move to blame the foreign office as "a heavy-handed attempt to cover up operational mistakes".

The government was criticised last October when Tibetan demonstrators were pinpointed for special attention by the police during a visit by the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin. The British visit was politically sensitive, following on from one to Switzerland in which Mr Zemin said he was unhappy that the authorities had failed to shield him from demonstrators.

In London the Tibetan demonstrators were singled out in an apparent attempt to minimise the protest. Some officers were seen confiscating Free Tibet flags and parking their vans to stop the president seeing protests against China's human rights record.

In the ensuing row the home office, foreign office and the police swapped the blame. Before the visit there had been meetings between the foreign office and the police, but there is no record of what was said.

The police, in a briefing to the Sunday Telegraph, claimed they were uncomfortable over the heavy pressure they came under from the foreign office.

But the foreign office, which has seen a draft of the report, which is expected eventually to be made public, insisted that no blame was attached in the report to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, or the foreign office minister directly responsible for China, John Battle.

The spokesman said: "It is certainly our understanding that the report will clearly show that, as we said all along, the purpose of the discussion and meetings that the foreign office had with the police was to take the police through the proposed programme for the Chinese state visit so they could take decisions on operational matters. There is no question of foreign office interference in these decisions."

A Metropolitan police spokesman said: "The report is due to be published shortly and it would be inappropriate to comment further."

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, said: "If any minister is subsequently shown to have misled Parliament over this issue, or if any ministers ordered or pressured the police to try to deny basic rights to human rights protesters, then those ministers should resign."

webTitle: World obese catch up with the underfed

fields.headline: World obese catch up with the underfed
fields.trailText: For the first time in history, the world's total of overweight people equals the total of those who are underfed. Up to 1.2bn people eat more than they need, and as many go hungry each day.
fields.body:
For the first time in history, the world's total of overweight people equals the total of those who are underfed. Up to 1.2bn people eat more than they need, and as many go hungry each day.

It is a sure sign that humanity is in a worsening global epidemic of malnourishment - hunger and overeating - with profound consequences for societies, according to an authoritative US social and environment research group that has compiled figures from around the world to give an overview of malnutrition.

Hunger and overeating together account for more than half the world's diseases, with hundreds of billions of pounds having to be spent annually to combat the social, educational, environmental effects of poor diets.

Britain is rapidly catching up with the US as the most obese country in the world, says the Worldwatch Institute in Washington.

It reports 23% of US adults are officially classed as obese, 55% are officially over weight, and 20% of children are obese or overweight .

In Britain, one in five women and one in six men are officially obese, with 45% of men and 33% of women overweight. Malnutrition costs the national health service more than £1.7bn a year, with £3bn more being spent on the indirect health affects of bad diets.

Treating the effects of obesity in the US costs more than £60bn a year, or more than 10% of the nation's bill for health, says the report. A further £20bn is spent on diet drugs, while each year more than 400,000 Americans resort to liposuction. Research shows that underweight and overweight people visit doctors far more than others.

In Britain, the numbers of obese people has doubled in 10 years. Most other western countries are overeating, and the developing countries are fast catching up. Overeating, however, is not exclusive to the rich; in the US, Hispanics and African Americans have obesity rates twice as high as white populations.

Hunger is classed as the worst form of malnutrition by the report, because it often cuts short lives barely begun. The UN's food and agriculture organisation, reports that 790m people - roughly one in five of all people - are chronically hungry, down from 918m in 1970. But more recent figures suggest that this figure is an underestimate. The report suggests 150m children in the developing world, one in three, are underweight with numbers rising.

In India, 49% of adults and 53% of children are believed to be underweight. A World Bank study found hunger cost the Indian economy between £6bn and 18bn in lost production - equivalent to 9% of the economy's output. Progress has been made in reducing hunger in the past 20 years, mostly in Asia and Latin America, but, says the report, there are more underweight people in Africa than ever.

Malnourishment in rich countries is linked closely to the powerful food industry, which spends many billions on marketing nutritionally-poor "junk" foods. "The corporations have made a food environment in which unhealthy food is ubiquitious. The industry has shaped consumer demand, largely by advertising," says the report.

Eating habits are changing around the world. In 1996, only one in four Americans ate a proper three meals - the rest snacked and ate "junk food"; in Britain, sales of crisps, nuts, and snacks have risen 25% in five years.

The report paints an extraordinary picture of how Britons may eat in a few years, if we follow the US model. We can expect many thousands of adults to have never have eaten a meal cooked with fresh ingredients, portions of food to be far bigger, cars to become the second most preferred place to eat after restaurants, and schools to have exclusive contracts with fast food establishments.

Clinical measure of overweight
The body mass index is the most commonly used method for classifying obesity. It is a relationship between a person's weight and height.

To work out the index, the weight in kilos is divided by squared height in metres. Ideally it should fall between 20 and 25, and a rating over 30 is considered clinically obese.

According to a widely accepted definition, men with more than 25% body fat and women with more than 35% are obese.

A person may be within the accepted range for body weight relative to height and frame size, but may have a high percentage of fat. In contrast, body weight can exceed the ideal because of large muscle mass.

webTitle: Three versions of the story so far

fields.headline: Three versions of the story so far
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Ros Mark's statement:
fields.body:
Ros Mark's statement:

I wish to make clear that I did not give to the Mail on Sunday the manuscript from which they have taken material about my time with the Blairs. Nor have I ever asked for or received any money.

Indeed when I talked with the literary agent Jonathan Harris about this, before terminating my discussions with him on February 24, I made clear I did not want anything published without the family's consent and that any proceeds should go to the Refuge charity.

I have had my fingers burned by this experience and I do not intend to speak to any of the journalists now knocking on my door and telephoning me.

I'm absolutely devastated that something I wanted to be nice about the Blairs and my time with them has been presented in the way that it has and has caused them upset.

But instead of harassing me, the press should be asking Mr Harris, the only person to whom I showed the manuscript, how it came into the hands of the Mail on Sunday.

It certainly got there without my consent or knowledge and I'm absolutely sickened by what has gone on.

Statement by literary agent Jonathan Harris:

My attention has been drawn to the controversy surrounding publication today by the Mail on Sunday of a piece about the Blairs' former nanny Rosalind Mark.

Some months ago we received an unsolicited manuscript from the Mark family.

After discussing the project with them and having been duly appointed, we then discussed the project with a select number of publishers.

Last month we ended our relationship quite amicably and we exchanged letters to that effect.

They remained very anxious to achieve publication of their work and I wished them well in their endeavours to do that.

I played absolutely no part whatsoever in the story carried today by the Mail on Sunday.

Extracts from the Mail on Sunday statement:

Last night at 2am, 10 Downing Street gained an injunction preventing publication of our story about Ros Mark's book.

We were denied the opportunity to put our case before the hearing despite making it abundantly clear that we wished to do so. The process used is called an ex parte injunction, one of the most draconian instruments in English law.

Over Friday and Saturday we spoke to Ros Mark several times. She talked to us openly, confirmed she was seeking a publisher for her book and discussed its contents. She was fully aware we were writing a story and posed for pictures.

We believe that anyone who cares about press freedom should be concerned about the way ex parte injunctions are increasingly used to suppress stories.

We plan to pursue this matter through the courts.

webTitle: The nanny, the publisher, a Sunday tabloid, and a family called Blair

fields.headline: The nanny, the publisher, a Sunday tabloid, and a family called Blair
fields.standfirst:
How No 10 went into overdrive to stop fly-on-the-wall tale

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Cherie Blair, at home in Downing Street for the weekend while her husband worked in his Sedgefield constituency, was in bed when a phone call came through from the prime minister's official spokesman shortly after 10pm on Saturday evening.
fields.body:
Cherie Blair, at home in Downing Street for the weekend while her husband worked in his Sedgefield constituency, was in bed when a phone call came through from the prime minister's official spokesman shortly after 10pm on Saturday evening.

Alastair Campbell had bad news for Mrs Blair: a tabloid Sunday newspaper had published in its first edition a "fly on the wall" account of life in the prime ministerial household by the family's former nanny, Ros Mark. The details of the 451-page "memoir", splashed across the front and inside pages of the Mail on Sunday, amounted to gossipy anecdotes about cabinet ministers and vignettes of Downing Street life written by a young employee whom the Blairs had treated almost as part of the family. Nevertheless, the account clearly breached the carefully-guarded privacy the Blairs have repeatedly sought to ensure protects their three children, to be joined in May by a fourth brother or sister.

Mrs Blair, resting in the seventh month of her pregnancy, opted to act immediately, and was soon taking part in an emergency conference phone call with Mr Campbell and cabinet office minister Lord Falconer. As both a lawyer and a close family friend of the Blairs, Charlie Falconer was well placed to offer guidance as the three reached a decision to seek an injunction blocking further publication of the story on the grounds that it breached a confidentiality agreement signed by Ms Mark when she moved with the Blairs to Downing Street in May 1997 and covering her entire time with the family. At 11.15pm, Mrs Blair issued the instruction to solicitor Val Davies, another longstanding legal friend, to contact the Mail on Sunday's lawyers and launch the process.

A flurry of phone calls followed as the paper attempted to block the move, but by 1.45am yesterday - as the Mail's presses were churning out the paper's final edition - the duty judge at the royal courts of justice has issued an injunction in Mrs Blair's name barring all English newspapers from publishing details of the story on the grounds that it breached Ms Mark's confidentiality agreement.

Legal proceedings are due to begin this morning against the paper, Ms Mark and literary agent Jonathan Harris, whom the nanny claims is the only other person apart from her mother to have a copy of the manuscript. Mrs Blair could also opt to sue all three for damages, though she may well decide that that would only attract more of the publicity she is anxious to avoid.

Mrs Blair's decision to block publication of the nanny's tale comes as no surprise: the prime minister and his wife have repeatedly shown themselves willing to fight for their children's right to privacy. Only last month, the Press Complaints Commission upheld their complaint at the Daily Sport's publication of a picture of their son Euan, 15, kissing a girl in a nightclub, and in July last year, the press watchdog similarly endorsed their protest over a Mail on Sunday report claiming their then-10-year-old daughter Kathryn had received preferential treatment over choice of secondary school.

In a powerful statement issued via his spokesman yesterday, Mr Blair underlined his own and his wife's determination to do "whatever it takes" to protect Euan, Nicky and Kathryn. "I am not just the prime minister, but also a father and husband", he said, stressing his own and his wife's determination to ensure their children were not "fearful that any and every aspect of their lives past, present and future is liable to become public".

But while there was no doubt over the Blairs' concern, nor over the determination of the Downing Street machine not only to act but to justify its actions, confusion remained last night over how exactly details of the nanny's memoir had ended up in print.

Ms Mark insisted she had not given the manuscript to the Mail on Sunday, nor consented to its publication. The 30-year-old, now training as a teacher after amicably ending four years of employment with the Blairs in 1998, claims she merely wanted to record her experiences as "the first nanny in Downing Street" and to publish them in a book whose proceeds would go to a children's charity.

Mr Campbell, warned of the story on Saturday, yesterday insisted that he had not been told that the report would contain details of the memoir, and had therefore not alerted Mrs Blair until he saw the first edition of the paper at 9.40pm.

The Mail on Sunday, meanwhile, condemned the "draconian" injunction, and insisted Ms Mark had "misrepresented her position". The paper said in a statement: "She talked to us openly, confirmed she was seeking a publisher for her book and discussed its contents. She insisted that confidentiality would not be a problem. She was fully aware we were writing a story, posed for pictures and gave us two photographs of her with the Blairs.

"We took great care to ensure that nothing in our story intruded into the privacy of the Blairs' children or family life."

Ms Mark's former literary agent Jonathan Harris said he had played "absolutely no part whatsoever" in the MoS's story.

webTitle: 'I'm not just PM but also father and husband'

fields.headline: 'I'm not just PM but also father and husband'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The statement issued yesterday by Tony Blair:
fields.body:
The statement issued yesterday by Tony Blair:

"As prime minister I obviously accept there's a great deal of media interest in me and my family.

"But I'm not just the prime minister but also a father and husband, and Cherie and I are absolutely determined, no matter how unusual our own lives may be because of the nature of my job, that our children have as normal an upbringing as possible.

"In this we are asking for no more than any family is entitled to. We cannot allow a situation where the children are fearful that any and every aspect of their lives, past, present or future, is liable to become public.

"We do not seek injunctions lightly and we will do whatever it takes to protect the legitimate privacy of our family life and to protect our children from unwarranted intrusion in their lives.

"I have spoken to Ros, who remains a good friend of the family and who is deeply upset herself at what has happened. I know she's a good person who will not have intended any harm, and I'm only sorry that her good nature has been exploited by others."

fields.headline: Royal services 'free for 3 years'
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen is set to offer the services of the royal family and the royal household for free for up to three years because of the surplus she has made from taxpayers' funding of the civil list.
fields.body:
The Queen is set to offer the services of the royal family and the royal household for free for up to three years because of the surplus she has made from taxpayers' funding of the civil list.

The deal, expected to be announced to Parliament later this year, would include the year of the Queen's golden jubilee in 2002.

It is expected to be announced alongside an "open government" move by the treasury which will allow Parliament to scrutinise the finances of the civil list - one of the last areas of expenditure closed to public gaze.

The Queen's financial health follows a generous settlement between Lady Thatcher, John Major and the Queen in 1990.

Under the deal, which runs out this year, the government made an annual fixed payment to the Queen to cover the staff costs of the royal household and royal expenses. Some 70% goes on the salaries of what is effectively a separate royal civil service.

The deal assumed inflation would continue to average 7.5% over the decade. The payments were meant to be generous for the first few years and the surplus was intended to fund a deficit in the costs at the end of the 90s.

But, apart from 1991, inflation has dropped dramatically, so the Queen has effectively had a rolling surplus every year to re-invest. With inflation held to around 2.5%, the Queen's surplus has grown faster under Gordon Brown than under his Tory predecessors. Official figures for the surplus have not been released since 1996 but it is thought to be around £30m. In 1996 it was already £16m.

Details of the surplus will have to be released to MPs before October 15, when the royal trustees make their 10-yearly review of civil list spending. The government will also have to announce the next decade's settlement.

A briefing from treasury officials requested through the House of Commons library by Alan Williams, Labour MP for Swansea West and deputy chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, reveals a dilemma.

According to the document: "It seems pretty certain that a substantial surplus will be available to carry forward into the next 10-year arrangement. However, it is important to note that without primary legislation, this could not be used to cease paying the civil list completely. Under the current legislative framework, these payments have to continue to be paid at the current cash value. Any review and change can only be upwards and not a reduction or cessation."

The government can either include a civil list bill in the Queen's speech next November to change the law to halt the civil list for a number of years or ask the Queen to reimburse the money.

The latter is the more likely as precedent favours the Queen's reimbursing all the money. She agreed to hand back money in 1994 after a controversy about the funding of minor members of the royal family from the civil list led the Queen to decide to pay them out of her personal fortune. Some £1.5m has been returned every year.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Flying Vets 8.30pm, C5

TV can't get enough of vets. Rolf Harris, for example, can't keep away from sick animals. Congratulations, then, to C5 for turning up the heat by finding a Yorkshire firm of vets that specialises in exotic animals and flies around the world to look after them. This week, we get to see a killer whale being born.

Police Investigations 9pm, C4

A calm but telling documentary about two white detectives trying to catch the murderer of a 15-year-old black boy in Philadelphia. The killing is just the first part of this tragedy of poverty, drugs and guns. "It's the same way with roaches," says Detective Baker in philosophical mood. "You kill one, at least it's one less and it's not going to make any more."

Paying The Price - The Killing Of The Children Of Iraq: A Special Report by John Pilger 9.30pm, ITV

John Pilger tells us that our oh-so-ethical Foreign Secretary didn't "want to appear in a film with dying babies". That certainly rules him out for this, John Pilger's look at what sanctions against Iraq have done to the children that Britain and the United States claim they don't want to hurt.

You get very much what you expect to get from Pilger - visits to hospitals where children are dying for want of medicines, talks with United Nations officials who have resigned in disgust at what sanctions are doing to the people of Iraq, trips to remote areas where the RAF seems to be bombing shepherds and their sheep. Was Tony Blair elected to make Iraqi children suffer? I don't think so, but here we are, stuck with a policy that really does punish a whole nation.

It doesn't hurt Saddam Hussein - "a son of a bitch but our son of a bitch", as the Americans once said - but the US and Britain have to show that they can take tough decisions and not allow their resolve to weaken, even when children die as a consequence. Robin Cook wanted a ten-minute, uncut section at the end of Pilger's film to explain why Pilger is wrong about Iraq. Thank God we haven't had to listen to that.

That certainly rules him out for this, John Pilger's look at what sanctions against Iraq have done to the children that Britain and the United States claim they don't want to hurt. You get very much what you expect to get from Pilger - visits to hospitals where children are dying for want of medicines, talks with United Nations officials who have resigned in disgust at what sanctions are doing to the people of Iraq, trips to remote areas where the RAF seems to be bombing shepherds and their sheep. Was Tony Blair elected to make Iraqi children suffer? I don't think so, but here we are, stuck with a policy that really does punish a whole nation. It doesn't hurt Saddam Hussein - "a son of a bitch but our son of a bitch", as the Americans once said - but the US and Britain have to show that they can take tough decisions and not allow their resolve to weaken, even when children die as a consequence. Robin Cook wanted a ten-minute, uncut section at the end of Pilger's film to explain why Pilger is wrong about Iraq. Thank God we haven't had to listen to that.

fields.headline: Force of habit
fields.standfirst: As the latest TV theme season, Kick The Habit, gets under way,   Mark Lawson sees the positioning of documentaries on Class A drugs alongside chats with chocaholics as a loss of nerve by the BBC
fields.trailText: As the latest TV theme season, Kick The Habit, gets under way, Mark Lawson sees the positioning of documentaries on Class A drugs alongside chats with chocaholics as a loss of nerve by the BBC
fields.body:
L ike the US tobacco barons - who solemnly told a Congressional hearing that they did not believe cigarettes to be addictive - television executives have always been nervous of admitting that the medium influences the behaviour of viewers. This declaration of impotence is necessary to permit them to go on screening violent and sexual material. But, as clean-up campaigners are quick to point out, the schedules are full of other programmes apparently made on the assumption that people will do what they are told.

Adverts are the example traditionally used - commercial television depends entirely on an assumption of the credulity of viewers - but there are more intriguing contradictions. Last week, television images of a flood emptied the pockets of viewers in the direction of Mozambique, just as pictures of famine steered cash to Africa in the 80s. And this week sees the launch of another BBC season based on the belief that people will copy the example of the box. Kick The Habit is a kind of 12-step festival, offering advice about resisting excessive consumption of cigarettes, drink, drugs and food.

Regular viewers may feel that senior television executives will soon be checking into the Priory to be treated for excessive use of theme nights and months. But, even by the standards of recent single-subject festivals, Kick The Habit uses a very wide umbrella.

So a new documentary about the death of Leah Betts, Ecstasy's most famous victim - beginning a factual trilogy called Children Of Drugs (Thursday, 9.30pm, BBC1) - is included alongside five old episodes of the pathology drama Quincy (daily, 2.05pm, BBC1), in which the doc's cases include an alcoholic colleague and a supermodel who slimmed to death. There's also Casualty Kicks The Habit (daily, 11am, BBC1), in which, with the kind of confusion between actor and role which now seems standard, Equity members currently playing doctors and nurses investigate various fitness and detox regimes.

The season's main weakness is the sense that all addictions - smoking Marlboro or crack-cocaine, breakfasting on vodka or running up large debts on a credit card - are being given equal weight. Yet this is an extremist position held only - at the very opposite ends of the table in the debate - by some doctors who treat addiction and by those who campaign for the legalisation of currently banned drugs.

The result is uneasy shifts of tone and subject: from Dale Winton's camply agonised struggle to give up his 40 fags a day to the terrible death of Leah Betts, via the diary of a Casualty actress trying to live without chocolate.

The likeliest reason for this is that the BBC - after the tabloid exposure of television presenter Richard Bacon and radio host Johnnie Walker for using cocaine - was nervous of a strand dealing only with illegal substances, which might have given newspapers the chance to investigate presenters and executives for possible hypocrisy. But the BBC's nervousness about drugs is not limited to the fear that presenters will be blood-tested by the press. Terrified at any suggestion of condoning or promoting drug- use by the young, the Corporation shakes like an addict on their first day in detox when they come near to the subject of narcotics. Although sometimes facetious in tone, Channel 4's recent cocaine-related season at least dared to explain why users are drawn to it.

In contrast, BBC1's Leah Betts documentary - The Girl Next Door - is marred by a desperate concern not to be seen to be advertising Ecstasy. On the model of American investigations, the film talks to every possible source - from Leah's friend to the paramedic who collected her and the doctor who admitted her - and produces powerful material, including an extraordinary interview with Leah's young brother, who confesses to having seen her take the fatal pill while spying on her party.

But the chosen editorial line - this could have been your daughter, your sister, yourself - prevents detailed examination of what happened in this case. Intriguing hints about Leah's state of mind and family medical history are not fully explored in case they give the impression of a freak tragedy. A documentary about a serial killer tries to tell you why that person murdered, but The Girl Next Door - strenuously pushing its entirely sensible message that young people are stupid to take drugs - fails to give any explanation of why they do. Drug culture goes uninvestigated because of a fear of encouraging a lethal curiosity in viewers.

There's an obvious irony in the programming of Kick The Habit, because the use of themed seasons is one of the ways in which television schedulers try to encourage what is known in the industry as habit viewing. But the uneven range and nature of the programming suggests that you would have to be an obsessive watcher - the licence- paying equivalent of someone who doesn't mind if they drink vodka or nail varnish - to watch regularly across the month.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
The further shores of the advertising and marketing business are explored by Hugh Dennis in a new four-day series. His role is that of a manufacturer launching a new tropical biscuit which he hopes will sweep the teenage market. Open On A Palm-Fringed Beach (3.45pm, Radio 4) (the setting for the eventual television ad) helps to steer Dennis through the processes that lie between an innovator's bright idea and the supermarket till.

Ruth Wyner, head of a Cambridge hostel for the homeless, and John Brock, one of her managers, were given long gaol sentences in December for allowing heroin to be supplied in their hostel. The High Court has refused them per mission to appeal against their conviction. Court evidence of Wyner and Brock's persistent refusal to inform against residents they suspected of supplying drugs has sent alarm bells ringing among social workers across Britain. John Waite (pictured) examines the issues for Face The Facts (8.0pm, Radio 4)
