fields.headline: Keeping it in the family
fields.trailText: The Wyvern Mystery | Bloodlines | Coronation Street | Justice In Wonderland
fields.body:
It occurred to me during the longueurs of Gormenghast that what that place needed was a thorough bottoming, as my grannie would say. Given a halfway decent daily, two elderly ladies should have been discovered starving to death in the west wing sooner rather than later. Of course, good help is hard to keep with cats, owls and actors all over the place. Dorothy Parker's maid, encountering an alligator in the bath, left a stiff note. "I cannot work in a house where there are alligators. I would have told you this before but I didn't suppose the question would ever come up." It came up in spades at Gormenghast.

The mansion to which Charles Fairfield eloped with off-the-shoulder Alice, his virginal bride, in The Wyvern Mystery (BBC 1) was just such a cavernous warren. His father, the wicked squire (Derek Jacobi wearing a sort of thatch) called it "that rundown piece of misery". Just the place to stash a forceful French first wife with a bad skin condition. There was a housekeeper, but very much in the boot-faced Manderley mould, given to veiled hints about family scandals. Georgian gentry evidently had as much elbow room in their lives as in their houses.

There is a great deal of galloping about in all directions, particularly by the thatched squire ("You'll not marry her, if I have to hunt you both down like animals! Aye, run, run!") which gives no-one time to stop and ask, like Arthur Daley, "What is occurring, Terence?". What seems to be occurring is that the forceful French wife is suffering from some disfiguring disease I can't quite put my finger on and, in any case, I'd much rather not. Blind, malign and trailing black bombazine, she haunts Alice's dreams and, in the well-worth-waiting-for last minutes of the first episode, crashes though her bedroom wall, like a secret, black and midnight missile. You cannot but feel that Aisling O'Sullivan, moulting magnificently like a sick eagle, is having a high old time. I don't know Sheridan Le Fanu - not to speak to, that is - which makes the whole thing much jollier and less predictable.

Those, beside snakes, who enjoy the sensation of their skin crawling can indulge themselves in Bloodlines (BBC 2). A chartered surveyor from Bognor - and they don't come much more staid than that - has spent 17 obsessive years investigating his great-great-great-grandfather, the public hangman William Calcroft, and expects to spend 17 more "putting flesh on the skeleton", as he phrased it - for he is not overburdened with humour.

And meanwhile, back in Coronation Street (ITV), Ken Barlow, who is writing a local history ("The truth is out there, Deirdre!"), has dug up, so to speak, the fact that Fred Elliott's grandfather was hung for murder. As Fred is a butcher, this could reflect adversely on the sale of Elliott's prime pork pies ("You won't get better! Ah say, you won't get better!"). People are so... well, they are, aren't they?

It seems to have escaped the locals' attention that Coronation Street is cobbled with the stiffening corpses of the slaughtered. There was, let's think, Emily's husband gunned down in a robbery... Gail's stabbed outside a nightclub... Natalie's killed in a brawl with drug dealers... Deirdre's knifed beside the sour canal... and Rita's flattened by a tram while chasing her across Blackpool Prom with fell intent and a loaded firearm. If Ken called his book The Curse Of Coronation Street, he could make a killing. Run coach trips. Sell black armbands. Lay on a pork pie buffet.

If you can't afford the best barrister to represent you, then at least make sure you get the best actor to play you - for that is how the world will remember you. Justice In Wonderland (BBC2)

was a dramatised version of the Neil Hamilton vs Al Fayed libel trial, punctuated with "whoomphs!" like a racing car as it accelerated past the less gripping bits. All the protagonists should be pleased with their sympathetic portrayal, particularly Charles Dance's Hamilton, emotion played almost entirely with the eyelids, and Kenneth Cranham's Carman QC, more fatal than in the flesh.

It felt as ruthless and relentless as Calcroft's speciality, a public hanging. If the condemned man lingered, Calcroft swung on his boots.

"The guy has a heavy English accent. He could be a fruitcake." - Walter Matthau in The Taking Of Pelham One Two Three (BBC 2).

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satelllite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Gandhi (Richard Attenborough, 1982) 6.55pm, Sky Cinema
An epic biography, charting the life of the Mahatma from his London studies to confrontation with the apartheid regime of South Africa, and the main contest: the non-violent rebellion against the British rulers of his native India: "You have been guests in our home for long enough. Now we would like you to leave." The crowd and massacre scenes are hugely impressive, but at the core is screen debutant Ben Kingsley's majestically understated performance. His best actor Oscar was one of eight the film garnered, including best director and best picture. Great cast includes Candice Bergen's American admirer, Edward Fox's brutal English colonel, Geraldine James as a disciple, and the stalwarts: Gielgud, Mills, Hordern and Howard.

Hoop Dreams (Steve James, 1994) 10pm, FilmFour
A three-hour documentary about two young basketball players might not seem a riveting evening's sport, but James's film is extraordinary. We meet the pair of young hopefuls (William Gates, Arthur Agee) on their way to high school at the age of 14 and watch their struggle over four years for the sporting success that will take them out of Chicago's inner city, the love and high hopes of their parents both a blessing and a burden.

Barb Wire (David Hogan, 1996) 3.05am, FilmFour
Pamela Anderson Lee as the babe (whoops, sorry)... as a bar owner scratching a living in the usual future subworld, the result of a second American civil war. Soon she's helping freedom-fighting pals hunt the contact lenses which will sneak them past the security eye scanners to tackle the evil... oh, never mind. Basically, Pam is Barbarella with attitude, kitted out in raunchy leather, kicking ass and gamely distracting attention from the film's basic lack of invention.

webTitle: Tory peers venture into new domain

fields.headline: Tory peers venture into new domain
fields.trailText: In the House of Lords, where modernity means allowing the Lord Chancellor to wear trousers instead of knee breeches, the 21st century is shortly to make an impact.
fields.body:
In the House of Lords, where modernity means allowing the Lord Chancellor to wear trousers instead of knee breeches, the 21st century is shortly to make an impact.

Conservative peers, many of whom look more at home in the age of Gladstone than Bill Gates, are soon to launch their own website, provisionally titled ermine.com.

The 232 Tories in the upper house, who are still wounded from the abolition of the hereditaries late last year, are hoping the new site will allow them to make public their efforts to discomfort the government.

Net users will be able to find biographical information and pictures of Conservative peers, together with the latest news on the party's stance on controversial elements of legislation.

There will even be scope for "e-lobbying", by which the public can register support for individual causes and suggest topics on which the peers may campaign.

The development, to be launched this spring, will also mean every Tory peer will have access to email, which party chiefs will use to inform members which way to vote. "This is the start of virtual whipping," said one source close to the project.

Senior Tories in the Lords, who held a meeting last week with a "teenage whizzkid" charged with designing the site, dismiss suggestions that many of their peers do not know a website from a woolsack.

Lord Strathclyde, Conservative leader in the Lords, said: "Around 70% of our members already use new technology because in the Lords, where we have far less money for office costs than the Commons, computers are the most efficient way of getting things done."

Though accepting that the party may have to find a zappier domain name (grousemoor.com has been ruled out), he claimed: "There is a thirst for knowledge on what is happening in the Lords. People will want to know what we are up to."

The Tory peers' site will add to the growing political war in cyberspace.

Last month, Tony Blair - a self-confessed new technology novice - launched a No 10 website, on which he makes weekly "webcasts".

The main parties are also in creasingly making use of internet technology to recruit and inform members and activists, saving money on leaflet printing and postage.

The prime purpose of ermine.com will be to needle the government, and particularly the leader of the Lords, Baroness Jay, over the continuing power of the second chamber to challenge government policy.

Ministers have found it harder to dismiss government defeats on issues such as restricted rights to jury trial after saying the upper house has greater legitimacy following the axeing of the hereditaries.

The Conservatives will use a Lords debate tomorrow on future reform of the second chamber to press ministers to move swiftly to second-stage reform of the current "interim house".

webTitle: Chilean calls grow for Pinochet trial

fields.headline: Chilean calls grow for Pinochet trial
fields.standfirst:
President-elect outraged by the army's welcome for ex-dictator

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Chile's prosecutors last night faced increased pressure to put General Augusto Pinochet on trial after the heads of the armed forces received the ex-dictator like a returning hero.
fields.body:
Chile's prosecutors last night faced increased pressure to put General Augusto Pinochet on trial after the heads of the armed forces received the ex-dictator like a returning hero.

The civilian authorities were incensed that he was met at the airport by the military's top brass, and that his helicopter diverted from its scheduled flight plan to buzz the presidential palace.

A senior presidential adviser, Jose Miguel Insulza, compared the 84-year-old general's ceremonious return to "Nazi troops" invading western Europe, while the foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, called the episode "disgusting" and a national disgrace.

In an effort to pressurise the government to prosecute Gen Pinochet, some 5,000 people marched on the presidential palace yesterday. The protest was organised by a coalition of Chilean human rights groups which is urging the state to take legal action against him.

A dozen armed commandos patrolled the high fence surrounding Gen Pinochet's residence in an exclusive suburb of Santiago. One of the guards confirmed yesterday that he remained inside with his close family. He has not been seen in public since late on Friday, when he was discharged from a military hospital after medical tests.

The "images of Pinochet, surrounded by elite troops have just one point," said a leading human rights lawyer, Hector Salazar. "The army is saying that this man is untouchable. That is the message from the armed forces."

Up to 61 different criminal complaints against Gen Pinochet have now been accepted by the investigating judge, Juan Guzman. The number continues to rise almost daily. Should the court cases against him go forward, he might well die during the process.

The incoming Socialist president, Ricardo Lagos - who takes office on Saturday - said that his government would make "tremendous efforts" to show the world that Chile was run by civilian officials and had "a disciplined and obedient armed forces".

He said the army welcome had set back the transition to a fully democratic state and "cost 10 years of democratic government". He was blunt in his criticism of Gen Pinochet. "History will judge his legacy badly," he said.

The immediate efforts to try Gen Pinochet, now "senator for life", will begin with a petition to have him stripped of his parliamentary immunity from prosecution. If the petition is accepted by Judge Guzman, the appeals court will vote on whether to strip him of his immunity and open the way for investigations.

Under Chilean law a defendant's ailing health is not a bar to prosecution. Only if the defendant is mentally incapable of understanding or participating in the trial can the case be dismissed.

fields.headline: George Duning
fields.standfirst: Composer whose romantic scores accompanied Hollywood's lyrical love scenes
fields.trailText: As a lone couple make love after a swim on a deserted beach in Hawaii, lush background music rises and breakers roll towards the shore. The passionate tumble on the sand over, the music subsides, and there is only the sound of the soft lapping of the surf. The scene, one of the most vivid examples of sexual symbolism in the cinema, from Fred Zinnemann's From Here To Eternity (1953), is considerably enhanced by the score of composer-arranger George Duning, who has died aged 92.
fields.body:
As a lone couple make love after a swim on a deserted beach in Hawaii, lush background music rises and breakers roll towards the shore. The passionate tumble on the sand over, the music subsides, and there is only the sound of the soft lapping of the surf. The scene, one of the most vivid examples of sexual symbolism in the cinema, from Fred Zinnemann's From Here To Eternity (1953), is considerably enhanced by the score of composer-arranger George Duning, who has died aged 92.

Duning's most famous film score was for Joshua Logan's Picnic (1955), with its sweeping love theme and the sensuous use of the jazz standard, Moonglow, to accompany the sultry, suggestive, come-hither dance between muscular William Holden and voluptuous Kim Novak. According to the critic of the New Yorker: "Mr Logan's notion of an outing in the corn country includes a choir of at least 100 voices, and a sound track let loose in the most formidable music I've heard in my time at the movies."

Duning's scores for From Here To Eternity and Picnic were among five Oscar nominations he received, the others being for Jolson Sings Again (1949), No Sad Songs for Me (1950) and The Eddy Duchin Story (1956). From 1947 to 1962, Duning was the leading composer at Columbia Pictures, and with the assistance of Morris Stoloff, the music director, created some of the studio's best scores.

Duning, both of whose parents were professional musicians, was born in Indiana, but educated at the Cincinnati conservatory of music, where he majored in theory and composition with Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco. After graduating, he earned money playing the trumpet with jazz groups and dance bands, where he gained his first experience as an arranger.

His big break came as musical director and supervisor of the popular NBC radio show, Kay Kyser's Kollege Of Musical Knowledge. Later, he did the arrangements for two movies, That's Right You're Wrong (1939) and You'll Find Out (1940), starring Kyser, the unfunny, bespectacled bandleader. In 1942, Duning joined the US navy and, as a conductor-arranger with the armed forces radio service, was involved with a great variety of programmes. When he returned to civilian life in 1944, he signed with Columbia Pictures as an arranger and orchestrator. However, it took him three years to convince his bosses that he could also compose, and his first original score was for Robert Rossen's debut feature Johnny O'Clock (1947), an atmospheric film noir starring Dick Powell.

From then on, besides displaying his brilliance as an arranger in musicals such as Pal Joey (1957), though purists balked at the 50s sound given to 40s material, he wrote original scores for westerns such as Cowboy and 3.10 To Yuma (both 1957), comedies like Bell, Book And Candle (1958) and dramas such as Strangers When We Meet (1960).

With the breakup of the studio system in the 1960s, Duning went freelance, working mainly in television, notably writing the theme for The Big Valley, starring Barbara Stanwyck, and composing a great deal of music for the first Star Trek series. Whenever the producers had a heartthrob story they called on Duning, whose lyrical romantic writing, largely for strings, contrasted with more agitated music for scenes of action.

A modest, retiring man, he is survived by his wife and two daughters.

fields.headline: Lionel Salter
fields.standfirst: Child prodigy behind the musical flowering of the BBC
fields.trailText: Lionel Salter, who has died aged 85, was an all-round musician who had a long association with the BBC; he became assistant controller of music and was perhaps best known to music lovers as a reviewer for 50 years for the magazine Gramophone. As well as being a pianist, harpsichordist and conductor, he was also a broadcaster, lecturer and administrator.
fields.body:
Lionel Salter, who has died aged 85, was an all-round musician who had a long association with the BBC; he became assistant controller of music and was perhaps best known to music lovers as a reviewer for 50 years for the magazine Gramophone. As well as being a pianist, harpsichordist and conductor, he was also a broadcaster, lecturer and administrator.

Salter was a descendant of Solomon Sulzer, a composer friend of Beethoven and Schubert; his father was a language teacher and his mother worked for a small record company. He clearly inherited genes that shaped his astonishing career, which began as a child-prodigy pianist.

The approaches of his first teachers, Stanley Chapple and Yorke Trotter (1923-31), were based on sight-reading and aural training, vital elements in the development of musicianship. At the age of 14 he won a piano, the junior prize in a competition organised by the Daily Express, and demonstrated his prodigious memory by winning another competition after reading the score for a mere 10 minutes.

After a year at the Royal College of Music in London, Salter studied with Professor Edward Dent at St John's College, Cambridge (1932-5), where he graduated with first-class honours in music and modern languages. During that time he played some 100 concerts, acted as music critic for Granta, co-founded the university gramophone society, studied the harpsichord with Boris Ord, the piano with James Ching (a Bach specialist) and Arthur Benjamin, the viola and the organ with Arnold Goldsborough and orchestration with Gordon Jacob. Returning to the royal college for another year, he studied conducting with Malcolm Sargent and Constant Lambert.

Salter then worked for London Films at Denham, editing Arthur Bliss's score for Things To Come, orchestrating, composing, acting as chorus master and playing what actors were miming on the screen. He also learned about camera techniques and film-cutting, and in 1936 was offered work in Hollywood. Unenthusiastic about the prospect and having heard that "the wireless was going in for pictures", he instead accepted the post of accompanist to the world's first TV station at the BBC, where he later became chorus master, répétiteur and general assistant.

During the second world war, he worked in intelligence and education, screening those who returned from Dunkirk and teaching codes - while also playing and conducting. Seconded to Algiers in 1943, he was also chief guest conductor of the Radio France Symphony Orchestra, then in exile.

Salter returned to the BBC in 1945 as assistant conductor of the BBC Theatre Orchestra. He played (unrehearsed) the piano part of Stravinsky's Petrushka, under Ernest Ansermet, and directed all the BBC vocal ensembles for a month before the Proms. In 1948, he became BBC European music supervisor, covering 42 language sections, personally contributed many talks (in English and French), interviews and features on diverse musical topics, and reviewed new records.

Elsewhere on BBC territory he accompanied recitals for international artists, conducted the BBC Singers, and composed the music for two English-by-radio pantomimes of George Miles and several radio plays. He was the first person to play a fortepiano in the Royal Festival Hall, and accompanied Pablo Casals at his home in Prades, where, as co-editor with Roberto Gerhard for a 26-part series on Spanish music, he persuaded the cellist to record for the BBC.

Salter remained with the corporation until 1974. His responsibilities covered a diverse range of posts from artists' manager, head of overseas music, opera producer for the BBC and the European Broadcasting Union, head of TV music (for which he laid down the "grammar" of camera technique), and assistant controller of music.

He contributed articles to encyclopaedias (including Grove) and journals, translated the libretti of 126 operas and texts of countless lieder, prepared performing editions of baroque operas and instrumental works, worked as a conductor in TV and films, composed music for radio plays, and became familiar as a lecturer, broadcaster, and adjudicator in festivals across Britain and abroad.

For many years, Salter was editor for the associated board of music, of the BBC Proms programmes and those of the Edinburgh Festival. His books, including Going To A Concert, Going To The Opera and The Young Musician And His World were bestsellers. He also wrote thousands of programme and liner notes for record companies.

In an article in the book Gramophone: The First 75 Years, Salter wrote: "The question of honesty looms large in many aspects of reviewing". To this he might have added "depth of knowledge and experience", which lay at the roots of his own work. Deeply respected by colleagues and readers, he was generous to others, had liberal tastes in a wide range of the arts, and a gourmet appreciation of wines and other good things in life.

Lionel Salter married Christine Fraser in 1948. She died in 1998 and he is survived by their three sons, Graham (a professional musician), Adrian and Brian.

fields.headline: Arnold Meier
fields.standfirst: Nazi refugee whose teaching skills fostered peace with old enemies
fields.trailText: Arnold Meier, who has died aged 95, was a great schoolmaster and an outstanding philologist. He was also a Jewish fugitive from Nazi Germany who, as soon as possible after the war, invited young Germans to stay in the homes of his English pupils and play them at football, to begin a sequence of annual matches that has continued without interruption for almost half a century.
fields.body:
Arnold Meier, who has died aged 95, was a great schoolmaster and an outstanding philologist. He was also a Jewish fugitive from Nazi Germany who, as soon as possible after the war, invited young Germans to stay in the homes of his English pupils and play them at football, to begin a sequence of annual matches that has continued without interruption for almost half a century.

Meier taught French and German brilliantly to the boys of Bury grammar school; as much as anything, however, he taught morality by example and admonition. He was the only master in the 1940s who never once used the cane or the slipper.

Instead, and typically, Arnold used words to obtain the desired effect. He would trade jokes with his boys (his were always delivered with a foxy grin and a muted cough, to signal that we were allowed to laugh with or at him for a moment or two). Other masters were invariably identified by their nicknames but no one ever referred to Meier as anything but "Doc".

Meier was born near Troisdorf, south of Cologne, where one of his earliest memories was of the village schoolmaster, with tears in his eyes, telling his pupils that Germany had lost the first world war. In spite of the fact that the French were partly responsible for post-war hardship during their occupation of the Rhineland, Arnold became a Francophile and, after taking his first degree at Cologne University, continued his studies at the Sorbonne.

Back in Germany as a young teacher, he read Mein Kampf and realised what was likely to follow. In 1933, he decided to leave for England and advised the rest of his family to do likewise; some did, though others stayed and mostly perished. His sister Erna was one of these, having been turned back by the British when she attempted to join Arnold, who was awaiting her arrival at Dover.

He had obtained a post in Brighton, where he taught and cared for German refugee children. He also continued to work for his PhD by long-distance correspondence with his old professor. His thesis suggested itself one day in a Sussex graveyard, when he noticed the number of Ruths, Rebeccas, Samuels and Davids buried there, Old Testament names which had been retained by English Christians, unlike their German co-religionists.

When war broke out Arnold was interned on the Isle of Man; his wife Irma Ranzenberg, whom he had married in 1937, was left to fend for herself and their child. He arrived at Bury in 1941, where he was delighted to discover that Lancashire boys could manage a very decent French accent when exposed to his (then revolutionary in England) oral method of teaching.

His most remarkable extra-curricular contribution came when the war was over. On the first day it was possible to telephone Germany again, Arnold rang his old school and, finding that the Nazi headmaster had been sacked, made an offer to the man's successor. "Now we must build bridges," he said, "and we have a rather good football team here. I suggest you come over and play us as soon as possible." So began the sequence of games between the Neusprachliches Gymnasium Koeln-Deutz and Bury grammar school, which are played alternately in each country, and before which every visitor spends a week living in the home of his opposite number.

Meier never emotionally abandoned his native land. There were German POWs in a camp beside the river Irwell, and, one foggy day as he walked along the towpath opposite, he heard them talking. Recognising Cologne accents, Arnold began a conversation through the gloom in the same dialect. He was always an ardent European and was later indignant at Mrs Thatcher's attitude to the continentals.

After retiring as senior languages master at Bury in 1969, Arnold devoted himself to his abiding passion, what he called "linguistic archaeology", producing learned papers which traced, for example, the evolution of the Hebrew word sha'ar - a gate in a city wall where disputes were settled and animals counted as they entered and left - through Sanskrit and Latin to the modern French cour and the English "score". In his 90s, frustrated historians asked him to decipher some newly discovered notes written up by German battlefield surgeons in the first world war.

Arnold enjoyed two extremely happy marriages. With Irma he had a son, David, now a circuit judge. After she died in 1952 he married another refugee, Trude Moritz, with whom he had Jonathan, now head of languages at the Verulam school, St Albans. In retirement, the Meiers continued to live at Whitefield, a couple of miles from the school whose pupils across two generations owed Arnold Meier a very considerable debt. Trude and his two sons survive him.

Arnold Meier, teacher and philologist, born December 21 1904; died February 19 2000

webTitle: Volunteers strike over toxic risk from Breton oil slick

fields.headline: Volunteers strike over toxic risk from Breton oil slick
fields.standfirst: Anger mounts as tanker spill threatens livelihoods
fields.trailText: A burst of bright pre-spring sunshine did little to lift the gloom along the oil-splashed stretch of Breton coast where it never rains but it pours. Since the Maltese-registered Erika oil tanker sank in an Atlantic gale just before Christmas, every week has brought more bad news.
fields.body:
A burst of bright pre-spring sunshine did little to lift the gloom along the oil-splashed stretch of Breton coast where it never rains but it pours. Since the Maltese-registered Erika oil tanker sank in an Atlantic gale just before Christmas, every week has brought more bad news.

This weekend hundreds of clean-up volunteers went on strike after reports of a high cancer risk from the ship's cargo of "No 2 fuel". A national committee which recruits anti-pollution workers alleged, on the basis of laboratory tests, that the ship was really carrying toxic waste from the Franco-Belgian oil company TotalFina's refineries. The company continues to insist the cargo was industrial fuel.

The government has reacted to reports of sickness caused by fumes with plans to check the health of thousands of volunteers.

"We plan to pursue the oil company for fraud," the Anti-blacktide Committee's lawyer, Alexandre Faro, said, after a meeting was told of the urgent government plan.

On the Croisic peninsula, roughly at the centre of a drift of small oil slicks spread over 250 miles, there has been a sharp drop in the number of people prepared to scrape the tar-like spill off the granite rocks along Brittany's Côte Sauvage, or wild coast. According to officials, only a third of the 3,000 people needed to clear up before the spring holidays were at work.

A potential Easter and summer tourism disaster threatens to add to a string of setbacks in a region that depends on the sea for its livelihood. Since December Le Croisic, a holiday centre of 4,500 people, has seen its 50-strong fishing fleet, shellfish industry, oyster beds and the adjoining sea-salt and eel farms endangered.

At the tourist office, Françoise Mouriaux was as upbeat as possible as she coped with anxious telephone calls about the risks that the Erika, 120m (395ft) deep, would release another 12,000 tonnes of leaking cargo to add to the 11,000 tonnes already released.

"Yes, the beaches will be clean and the breach in the Erika's tanks will be sealed up," Ms Mouriaux told inquirers wanting to visit a town where hotels have covered their carpets with yards of plastic sheeting to stop goo being traipsed into the rooms.

But the mayor, Christophe Priou, was less reassuring. "We are in unknown waters," he said. "Slicks are coming ashore every day, demoralising volunteers and conscripts from the army. Two-thirds of the work has been done but it's going to be difficult to project an objective image, especially to foreign visitors."

About a dozen of the best-known Atlantic resorts, including Concarneau to the north and Ile de Ré in the south, believe they have escaped the worst, but a walk around the five-mile Le Croisic peninsula is depressing. Granite outcrops and low cliffs are covered with the evil-smelling tar-like oil.

With all-round losses to the sea industry, it is surprising that the Bretons and their southern neighbours from the Vendée did not take the matter onto the streets until last week. A visit by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, to Nantes attracted 20,000 protesters shouting discontent at government fumbling.

But despite a promise of some £100m in emergency aid, there has been no let-up in discontent about a string of delays.

Many oyster farmers face bankruptcy because of public misgivings; nearly a thousand shellfish beds have been closed; and holiday bookings at some resorts are down 80%. The sea-salt industry between Le Croisic and La Baule is threatened by polluted water and, for sea birds, the impact has been greater than the Amoco Cadiz sinking 22 years ago when 233,000 tonnes of oil was spilled. The count of dead birds, mostly guillemots, reached 58,000 this weekend - 20 times more than in 1978.

With local elections in a year's time, the leftwing government's underestimation of the impact of the Erika sinking may prove the most politically expensive mistake since it won the general election in 1997.

"There has been an absolute waterfall of announcements about what is going to be done and practically nothing concrete happening where it matters," François Fillon, the president of the Loire region, said. "Everybody - electors and elected alike - is exasperated."

During the Nantes demonstrations, anger focused on TotalFina, which chartered the Erika. Led by the leftwing Confédération Paysanne, marchers demanded that the company pay for the damage and threatened to dump thousands of tonnes of waste on the doorstep of the company's Paris headquarters if it refused.

There was also anger at the failure of preventive measures despite supposedly tighter controls since Amoco Cadiz. Following the latest disaster, the government has promised to increase the number of seaworthiness inspectors from 60 to 120 - a move considered derisory by Roland Andrieu of the merchant seaman's union.

"Two thousand seamen die every year because of rotten conditions in these ships," he said, recalling that the Erika was reported by Dutch inspectors to be little more than a rustbucket. "Malta is now the worst offender and it's not surprising that the Erika was a floating wreck. You should see some of these ships - no compasses, hulls full of holes, broken down engines.

"The only way to stop them is to establish a coastguard service on the US model."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Chechen rebels kill 31 Russians
Thirty-one Russian soldiers have died in fierce battles with Chechen separatists in the Argun gorge, south of Grozny, a Russian general said on television yesterday.
fields.body:
Chechen rebels kill 31 Russians
Thirty-one Russian soldiers have died in fierce battles with Chechen separatists in the Argun gorge, south of Grozny, a Russian general said on television yesterday.

Gennady Troshev, the first deputy commander of Russian forces in the north Caucasus, said the clashes had occurred in the last few days near the villages of Ulus-Kurt and Selmentausen, with Chechen fighters trying to break out into Chechnya's flatland.
Reuters, Moscow

Pope beatifies martyrs
From 11 Polish nuns gunned down by Nazis to 30 victims of 17th century religious warfare in Brazil and missionaries in Asia, Pope John Paul II yesterday honoured 44 martyrs in a beatification ceremony in St Peter's Square, the last formal step before the process of sainthood can begin.

Since becoming Pope in 1978, John Paul has beatified or canonised more than 1,200 faithful.
AP, Vatican City

Albanians mark 1998 massacre
Tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians yesterday commemorated a massacre in which a founder of their rebel movement, the Kosovo Liberation Army, was killed.

Ethnic Albanians from across Kosovo gathered in Prekaze, 25 miles west of Pristina, to mark the 1998 killings of 50 people, including Adem Jashari.
Reuters, Prekaze

India catches spying hawk
India's border security force has, for the second time, caught a hawk allegedly used by Pakistan for spying purposes, the Press Trust of India said yesterday.

In a report from Jaipur in Rajasthan, the agency said: "The BSF caught one more spy hawk fitted with antenna and a live transmitter flying across the international border."
Reuters, New Delhi

Tokyo gripped by PlayStation2
A Tokyo schoolboy became the first person to be robbed of a PlayStation2 game console at the weekend, when two men on a motor scooter snatched it from his hands. Hundreds of thousands of people mobbed stores across Japan to buy the first 1m PlayStation2s to hit the market.
Reuters, Tokyo

fields.headline: Up in smoke
fields.standfirst: 70,000 take refuge as Philippine volcano threatens more eruptions
fields.trailText: US and Filipino soldiers began building tent cities yesterday to help ease overcrowding among nearly 70,000 people evacuated from villages near the Mayon volcano in the Philippines.
fields.body:
US and Filipino soldiers began building tent cities yesterday to help ease overcrowding among nearly 70,000 people evacuated from villages near the Mayon volcano in the Philippines.

The volcano, 190 miles southeast of Manila on the island of Luzon, remained dormant after a week of eruptions which spewed lava and super-heated ash over a wide area.

Some of the refugees who fled from their homes on Mayon's slopes are housed in school buildings about six miles from the volcano. Others are staying in shelters made of iron sheets which turn into virtual ovens during hot weather.

Two military transport planes flew into the provincial capital, Legazpi, carrying the US troops, tents, building materials and 20,000 masks to protect refugees with respiratory illnesses from ash falls.

Despite the lull, scientists continue to record dozens of small quakes every day and Mayon's slopes remain swollen from the pressure of rising magma, indicating that the threat is not over.

Mayon's last major eruption, in 1993, killed 77 villagers.
Reuters, Legazpi

webTitle: Zhu targets corruption and cults in China

fields.headline: Zhu targets corruption and cults in China
fields.trailText: Rampant corruption that has reached crisis proportions among Chinese officials was denounced yesterday by the country's prime minister, Zhu Rongji.
fields.body:
Rampant corruption that has reached crisis proportions among Chinese officials was denounced yesterday by the country's prime minister, Zhu Rongji.

Presenting his annual report to the national people's congress, Mr Zhu admitted that the government fell short "of what the people expect of us" and that "fighting corruption is still a tough task".

Listeners in Beijing welcomed Mr Zhu's strong words, but many believe that the entire Communist party-run system is infected.

"Some people say that there is corruption because the emperor is far away in Beijing," said a professor at Beijing teachers' college. "The truth is that every county or small town head has become an emperor too!"

Members of the congress say they have been told the government is at last preparing an anti-corruption law, demanded at last year's annual meeting. But it was not mentioned by Mr Zhu and may be subject to further delay.

Recent notorious corruption cases include a deputy governor of Jiangxi province sentenced to death for embezzling £500,000 and a scandal in Fujian province involving at least 100 officials which is under investigation but has hardly been reported in the press.

While Mr Zhu addressed the congress in the Great Hall of the People, more than 30 supporters of the banned Falun Gong cult were taken away by police on the edge of Tiananmen Square. Several had attempted to unfurl banners beneath the portrait of Mao Zedong in front of the Forbidden City.

Reflecting the Chinese leadership's paranoia about the Falun Gong, Mr Zhu said in his speech that "evil cults must be banned and attacked according to the law".

In what Falun Gong supporters will regard as a revealing error, the English version of his speech translated the word "attack" to "persecute".

Mr Zhu delivered a relatively mild warning to Taiwan in contrast to the recent Chinese white paper that threatened to use force if the island delayed negotiations on rejoining the mainland indefinitely.

He said: "We will not sit idly by and watch any serious separatist activity aimed at undermining China's sovereignty and territorial integrity, such as those advocating the 'two-state theory' or 'the independence of Taiwan'."

Relations with the US were referred to only in two sentences. Last year's downturn in US-China relations caused by Nato's bombing of China's embassy in Belgrade strengthened the hand of conservative critics of Mr Zhu - who had only recently returned from the US.

Mr Zhu's attack on corruption in yesterday's report showed the outspokenness for which he is admired by millions of Chinese. In the most striking passage, Mr Zhu said that all corrupt officials, high or low, should be investigated and "severely punished". He targeted one of the most common - and unpopular - the misuse of public funds by officials who "travel, entertain and dine in a luxurious style at public expense in the name of all sorts of invented activities".

Other parts of the report, including those on unemployment and pollution, were less hard-hitting. Analysts suggest he may feel it wise to confine his efforts to a few issues, leaving Taiwan and other sensitive matters to the president, Jiang Zemin.

"Mr Zhu is a good leader," said a Beijing worker in the square after the speech, "but he can do nothing under President Jiang Zemin. Too many at the top think only of themselves."

Delegates to the congress's sister body - the Chinese people's political consultative conference, which meets simultaneously - expressed criticisms of government policy yesterday after Mr Zhu's report.

Speakers at a discussion group for Chinese academic leaders complained that there was no effective public monitoring of government budgets, plans and performance. "The NPC should control the budget like they do in the US," said a Beijing professor. "If officials can't keep within the budget they just spend outside it."

There were complaints that government cadres lacked education, that factory managers had too much power and that both got away scot-free if they performed badly.

"Unless you close off the route of corruption," said the president of a Shanghai university, "the economic reforms will be useless."

A professor from Beijing's Qinghua university raised the delicate subject of public support for the Falun Gong, saying that "feudal attitudes are still widespread. It was right to dissolve the Falun Gong but we have to ask why it arose."

While some speakers expressed polite approval of Mr Zhu's speech, saying it was realistic, others complained of a lack of detail and said they wanted to see an improvement next year.

Mr Zhu's report will be discussed by delegates to the congress and the consultative council before an amended version is brought back to the full congress in 10 days time for a vote.

No one expects there to be many amendments or abstentions in the vote. But delegates may increase pressure behind the scenes for more effective action to follow next year.

webTitle: France's Spitting Image team walk off in a huff (allegedly)

fields.headline: France's Spitting Image team walk off in a huff (allegedly)
fields.trailText: For 12 years, the lifesize latex puppets of Les Guignols, France's hit equivalent of Spitting Image, have savaged Gallic celebrities with impunity. Now they are getting a dose of their own medicine - and the satirical show's writers are so upset that they have run off in a huff.
fields.body:
For 12 years, the lifesize latex puppets of Les Guignols, France's hit equivalent of Spitting Image, have savaged Gallic celebrities with impunity. Now they are getting a dose of their own medicine - and the satirical show's writers are so upset that they have run off in a huff.

The programme's presenter, a rubbery lookalike of the popular newsreader Patrick Poivre d'Arvor, shocked the nation on Friday by apparently announcing the end of the nightly series. The disclosure left bewildered broadcasting executives hoping it was just a joke and that the show would return tonight.

"Democracy is threatened. Human rights are imperilled. Justice is at risk," the puppet said sombrely at the beginning of an unusually short edition of the show. "Aware of our responsibilities, we prefer simply to stop. Okay. There we are. Good night. Goodbye."

The response was immediate. "Guignols commit suicide live on air," screamed the headline in France Soir. Liberation wondered whether this was "their last gag, or yet more attention-seeking."

The news took the show's broadcaster, Canal Plus, completely by surprise.

"If it's a joke, it's quite good," said the head of programmes, Alain de Greef. "If not, I'm not laughing. Whatever happens, we will carry on - with a new team if necessary." None of the show's trio of scriptwriters has been available for comment.

In a country where most of the mainstream media treat politicians with deference, Les Guignols became a smash hit as soon as it was launched in 1988. It is watched by an average 2.8m viewers.

The show's current crisis follows a growing number of complaints. First, a journalist from Le Monde, Sylvie Kerviel, revealed that the show's senior writer, Bruno Gaccio, had made a pass at her while she was trying to interview him.

Then a former television presenter, Guillaume Durand, claimed the show "harassed me morally and psychologically, drove me to the brink of breakdown". A slew of newspaper articles followed, denouncing the programme as gratuitously rude, vindictive and unfunny, while an opinion poll showed 49% of the public thought it went too far.

Newspaper editorials say the show's writers have simply got too big for their boots. "Les Guignols's heads have become too inflated for the television set," said Liberation. "It's time they learned to take some of the stick they've given everyone else."

webTitle: Pollution blamed for deaths of thousands of flamingos

fields.headline: Pollution blamed for deaths of thousands of flamingos
fields.trailText: A putrid smell hovers over the shoreline of Lake Bogoria. Pink feathers flutter in a breeze over rotting carcasses lying half submerged in mud, splayed out on rocks or impaled on the thorns of bushes.
fields.byline: David Gough  at Lake Bogoria, the Great Rift valley
fields.body:
A putrid smell hovers over the shoreline of Lake Bogoria. Pink feathers flutter in a breeze over rotting carcasses lying half submerged in mud, splayed out on rocks or impaled on the thorns of bushes.

A group of men and women, shrouded in the drifting steam that rises out of the hot springs on one side of the lake, dig shallow graves in the volcanic mud where they lay dead birds saved from the scavengers.

A group of tourists looks on. A little girl turns to the man next to her and asks: "Why are the flamingos dying?"

For the third time in seven years, tens of thousands of flamingos who inhabit the soda lakes of Kenya's Great Rift valley are dying of a disease believed to be caused by industrial pollution.

"We think there could be as many as 600 dying per day," said Moses Cheruiyot, a World Wide Fund for Nature researcher who has spent the last three years studying Lake Bogoria - home to more than a million flamingos. "Nobody knows exactly what is causing this. But clinical studies suggest that industrial pollution is the probable cause."

A conservative estimate puts the number of dead at 30,000 - but the real figure could be twice as high.

What scientists do know is that the deaths began in July last year and set alarm bells ringing for conservationists who remember the flamingo crises of 1993 and 1995 when 50,000 birds died.

They say that the latest outbreak could be the worst yet.

The flamingos migrated to Lake Bogoria two years ago when unseasonable rains disturbed the delicate ecosystem of their preferred habitat of the nearby Lake Nakuru national park.

That park was established with the specific purpose of saving the flamingo and was Africa's first bird sanctuary, boasting, until recently, millions of the colourful creatures. Now there are just a few thousand.

A joint study by the WWF and Egerton university in Nairobi found significant traces of pollutants in Lake Nakuru which originated from industries based near the town.

Until recently, waste was dumped into the lake and scientists have found high levels of mercury, chromium, copper, lead and even arsenic.

Gideon Motelin, a professor at Egerton university, suspects that the pollutants in Lake Nakuru are the cause of the outbreak. "Lake Nakuru is heavily contaminated, and although we can't be certain, there is a very strong feeling that pollution is the main cause of the deaths."

Jackson Raini, a WWF programme officer, said that Nakuru's industries recently signed an agreement to preserve Lake Nakuru's ecosystem, but that years of toxic dumping in the area would take decades to correct.

"We have found traces of metals in the tissue of the birds who have died at Bogoria which match the metals we found in Nakuru."

This has led the researchers to conclude that the birds carried the pollutants with them from Lake Nakuru and that some recent stress-catalyst has triggered the mass poisonings.

"There is a severe drought in the area and a shortage of fresh water on which the flamingos depend. It's very possible that the lack of fresh water is the stress catalyst that is causing the deaths."

But David Harper, a biologist at the university of Leicester, who is leading a survey of Lake Bogoria, believes that this scenario is unlikely. "We can't rule out the chemical pollutants as the cause but I believe that a bacterium is much more likely."

"The fact that the disease keeps reappearing shows that the problem is chronic," said Professor Motelin. "For the long-term security of the species it's crucial that we get to the bottom of this."

They say that the latest outbreak could be the worst yet. The flamingos migrated to Lake Bogoria two years ago when unseasonable rains disturbed the delicate ecosystem of their preferred habitat of the nearby Lake Nakuru national park. "The fact that the disease keeps reappearing shows that the problem is chronic," said Professor Motelin. "For the long-term security of the species it's crucial that we get to the bottom of this."

fields.headline: Just a regular guy
fields.standfirst:
Norwegians are republican by instinct yet there is no national debate about the monarchy. As far as he can, the king lives a life like any other citizen - and the people love him for it. Matthew Engel asks whether other royal families would benefit from a life more ordinary
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Norwegians are republican by instinct yet there is no national debate about the monarchy. As far as he can, the king lives a life like any other citizen - and the people love him for it.  Matthew Engel  asks whether other royal families would benefit from a life more ordinary
fields.body:
As the second hand on the station clock swept past midday, the guest of honour walked in. "He's never late," whispered my neighbour. Unlike the trains. This was the official opening of a new railway station in Oslo: National Theatre. So naturally there were various cameos, including the inevitable snatch of Ibsen performed by actors from the building next door. Plus, this being Norway, there was a succession of over-long speeches. The minister spoke, then the head of the railways, then the mayor. Finally came the guest of honour.

There was nothing in his demeanour or delivery (or, apparently, his content) that distinguished his speech from any of the others. He was a tall 62-year-old in a grey suit, with an egg-shaped head, bald apart from a less-than-fetching gingerish tonsure. He looked as though he might be the railway's deputy chief accountant, passed over for promotion, and longing for his pension.

When the minister left, there was a flurry of cameramen because he was in the middle of a huge controversy involving the abortive merger of the Norwegian and Swedish telecom companies. When the guest of honour left, the media contingent did not stir, save for the crew making an official record for the railway. Thus ended another engagement for His Majesty King Harald V, master of the art of monarchy for the new millennium.

To British eyes, the Norwegian royal family seems extraordinary: uncharismatic, low-key, slimline to the point of being cheapskate. It is not a bicycle monarchy because none of them rides a bicycle. It is, however, a railway monarchy. National Theatre station is just below the Slott, Oslo's very plain royal palace. In his speech, the king congratulated everyone on building such a handsome new station and then challenged them to improve the service (while behind him the indicator board recorded embarrassingly that the 11.58 to the airport was running 61 minutes late). This was not just an abstract line of oratory: the king regularly uses the airport express. The modern world has its worries even here so a phone call has to be made and a carriage cordoned off. Otherwise, he just comes down, usually with one detective and an aide-de-camp, and gets on to the platform like everyone else.

To anyone accustomed to the House of Windsor, it is a style which seems unpretentious almost to the point of pretentiousness. But it works. There is no debate about the monarchy in Norway. The people support both the idea of the royal family and the reality. It used to be said that soon there would only be five kings left: the king of England, hearts, spades, clubs and diamonds. No one makes that crack any more. There have been moments over the past few years when it has seemed doubtful that there would ever be another king of England.

Yet the adroitness of King Juan Carlos has been a major factor in helping Spain escape from a traumatic recent history. King Albert II of Belgium, has provided at least some kind of unifying factor in a country where people can agree on nothing. And in Holland, Denmark and Sweden, the monarchy has become ever more entrenched. The lesson is that success does not depend on grandeur. It seems strange that Scandinavia, a region with a reputation for rationality, should be so attached to royalty. It seems doubly strange in Norway, which has been independent for less than a century. It extricated itself from Swedish rule only in 1905. There was a referendum, which opted for a monarchy rather than a republic by 3-1.

"There was a little sentimentality, a dream of a golden age," says the historian Karsten Alnaes. "They wanted the return of the great old times."

But the great old times were more than 500 years behind them: the Norwegians hadn't had any monarchs since the 14th century. They had to find one. Prince Carl of Denmark had the right CV and no prospects in his own country. The Norwegians traditionally get on well with the Danes (they are less keen on the Swedes) and admire the English. Carl's mother was Queen Maud, youngest daughter of Edward VII. He got the job. And he did it brilliantly. He put himself into the line of medieval kings by taking the very Norwegian title Haakon VII, and the motto "All for Norway", and reigned for 52 years. Two moments defined his position. In 1928 there was a governmental crisis, which could only be solved by royal intervention. The Social Democrats, then strongly Marxist, had the largest grouping and, despite furious opposition, the king asked them to take charge. They only lasted 14 days in power, but the gesture had been made. "You have to remember," Haakon said famously, "that I'm king of the communists too."

In 1940 came forces not susceptible to the royal touch. The Nazis wanted the king to stay and do their bidding. He and his family escaped instead, having given them a simple answer: "No."

Haakon used his exile to act as a rallying point. (His fame did not spread. When he went into Bush House in London to do one of his broadcasts for the BBC, the receptionist was somewhat harassed: "Sorry, dear, where did you say you were king of?")

Haakon returned to Norway, more popular than ever, and the post-war reconstruction was led by the now much-moderated Social Democrats. His earlier gesture was the springboard for an alliance between the monarchy and the Left that has never seriously wavered. His son, Olav V, who reigned from 1957 to 1991, had a similar instinct for the crucial symbolic gesture. During the oil crisis of 1973, Olav was planning a very Norwegian day out, cross-country skiing just outside Oslo like everyone else. He caught a tram and paid for his ticket. It was an act of solidarity at a difficult time. A newspaper photographer just happened to be on the tram and took one of Norway's most famous pictures. It says a great deal about the Norwegians that most of them still regard this as one of life's happy coincidences and not a pre-arranged stunt.

In eight years on the throne, Olav's son, Harald, has never quite shown the same knack. His speech last year to Clinton, Barak and Arafat when the Middle East peace talks returned to Oslo was surprisingly eloquent; Norwegians thought it sounded magnificently sincere, even if it was drafted by the foreign ministry. Overall, though, he is regarded as shy, a bit awkward, a touch dull, perhaps. In other words, Norwegians seem to think, rather like most of them. And that's the secret.

There is no aristocracy in Norway; most of the nobles were wiped out by the Black Death and the rest were abolished in the 19th century. This makes the place very different from, say, Denmark, which is full of barons. It is hard even to notice much of an upper class, as ostentatiousness is a national no-no. The king was an Olympic yachtsman and still sails avidly but he makes sure the crew represents Norwegian society as a whole. There are no minor royals: the only ones on the (modest) payroll are the king, queen and their two children. This is royalty tailored to a country whose instincts appear wholly republican.

Harald married Sonja, the daughter of an Oslo shopkeeper, a fairly grand one, but a shopkeeper none the less. There is hardly any private schooling, so the royal children went to ordinary state schools, starting at a municipal nursery, and they led, to an extent unthinkable among our royals, ordinary Oslo childhoods. Crown Prince Haakon, now 26, lives in an ordinary, if smart, bachelor flat, in a ordinarily run-down area of Oslo. Prince Charles once dismissed the Scandinavian monarchies as "grander, more pompous, harder to approach than we are". This remark makes no sense.

But the very ordinariness of the Norwegian royals has its drawbacks. Currently, the palace is being refurbished. There have been huge cost overruns, and one of the tabloid papers led a campaign blaming the queen for interfering and insisting on absurd extravagances like gold leaf in the ballroom. "This country is absolutely two-faced," said one Briton who lives there. "If you're going to refurbish a palace, you have to do it properly. Everyone knows that, but she gets the blame. On the one hand, they adore her as one of them. On the other hand, they think she's just a jumped-up squirt, she's no better than we are."

As they say in our own royal circles, a counter-jumper.

Only occasionally, though, have the Norwegian royals brushed with the press in the manner with which we are so familiar. The king's daughter, Princess Märtha Louise, was once cited in a divorce case but royal prerogative meant she didn't have to go court, and the scandal was stifled. King Olav was a widower known to entertain ladies of a certain age. The crown prince is a rich bachelor with his own pad. "We are not at all working in the paparazzi manner," says Kjell Arne, royal correspondent of Norway's top-selling weekly magazine, Se øg Hor. "We don't follow them."

If one of the paper's photographers happened to see the crown prince in a restaurant with a new girlfriend, would he or she take a picture? "No," says Arne. If someone sent him such a picture, would he use it? He paused. "Not necessarily."

"Of course, we have had incidents with the press," says the king's private secretary, Magne Hagen. "But in general we have been very happy. The crown prince has spoken out clearly once or twice about what he feels is right and what is intrusive, and it has been understood."

The Norwegian press is not the world's most ferocious and the rest of the world cares little about Norway. Who on earth would want to chase their royals into a Paris underpass? This is a country with only four million people: a place that is together, in more than one sense of the word. Theoretically, the king has considerable power to intervene in politics; with elections by proportional representation and a lot of coalition-building to be done, he could easily be interfering all the time. He doesn't have to, because the Norwegian instinct for consensus renders it unnecessary.

That consensus extends to the monarchy. It can be seen best on Norway's national day, when all the children parade past the Slott waving their flags, while the royals wave back until their arms almost drop off; in less than a century, the monarchy and the country have become indistinguishable. An Oslo journalist I know tells people at parties that he is a republican: "They just laugh at me," he says.

This is the way it was in 50s Britain. Perhaps Britain has moved on too far for those days to come back. It seems hard to imagine the Norwegian model being transplanted to a larger, less cohesive, more disputatious, more alienated, more class-ridden country - even one with a deep affection for its monarchy despite a certain disenchantment with the current dynasty.

But what if another north European country were to regain its independence after hundreds of years? A place not far from Norway, with many ethnic and economic connections? A place that, like Norway, had had its own kings? A place of similar size, and not dissimilar climate?

Far be it from me to suggest how an independent Scotland might run its affairs. But Norway offers the proof that monarchy "on the face of it an irrational choice for a new country" can provide a very rational way of making it work.

fields.headline: SAS grab death camp boss
fields.standfirst: Omarska deputy commander awaits transfer to the Hague for war crimes trial
fields.trailText: An SAS team yesterday helped to snatch a Bosnian war crimes suspect who is accused of murder, rape and other war crimes at the infamous Omarska internment camp.
fields.body:
An SAS team yesterday helped to snatch a Bosnian war crimes suspect who is accused of murder, rape and other war crimes at the infamous Omarska internment camp.

Dragoljub Prcac, 62, the camp's former deputy commander, was last night at a British base in Banja Luka, awaiting transfer to the Hague for trial by the international war crimes tribunal.

British forces, spearheaded by the SAS, have seized a string of war crimes suspects in the last few years. Mr Prcac's arrest was the result of a long, carefully planned operation.

It took place just outside the village of Jelicka. Soldiers broke a window of his vehicle and dragged him and his companions outside. According to a local news agency, he was with his wife and a neighbour, both of whom were subsequently released.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, issued a joint statement congratulating the troops. "This detention shows that the international community has not forgotten one of the most gruesome episodes of the war and is determined that those responsible should be brought to justice," they said. "We call on all those who know they are indicted to surrender themselves to the tribunal."

Twenty operations have been mounted against war crimes suspects by international peacekeeping forces in Bosnia. Eighteen indictees have been transferred to the Hague and two have been shot dead. Twelve of the operations involved British forces.

Of the 79 people indicted for war crimes, 29 remain at large. At the top of the wanted list are Radovan Karadic, the former Bosnian Serb leader, who is believed to be living in Pale, near Sarajevo, and his former military commander, General Ratko Mladic. He is believed to be living in Serbia.

There is unspoken tension between Britain and France over the failure of French troops to pursue suspects in their sector with the same rigour as the British.

The statement said that at the Omarska camp, where non-Serb prisoners, mainly Bosnian Muslims, were held, "severe beatings were commonplace, and prisoners were frequently tortured, sexually assaulted and killed".

Pictures of emaciated Muslim prisoners in Omarska and two other camps in 1993 fed international outrage against atrocities committed in the Bosnian war. They led to the setting up of the UN war crimes tribunal, and to Nato intervention two years later that helped to end the war.

The Hague tribunal issued an indictment in 1995 for Mr Prcac. He was accused of being criminally responsible for the acts of his subordinates in wilfully inflicting great suffering, humiliating and degrading treatment, and unlawful imprisonment on the Omarska prisoners. Before the war, he had been an official at the ministry of the interior in Prijedor.

Nato's secretary general and former British defence secretary, George Robertson, said yesterday that the arrest - the fourth in three months - was a warning to other suspects still at large that "it is time to turn yourself in".

The trial began last week in the Hague of four other Bosnian Serbs accused of crimes at three Serb-run camps during the war, including Omarska.

fields.headline: No: 1587 Joan of Arc
fields.trailText: Born: Around 1412 in Domrémy, northern France.
fields.body:
Born: Around 1412 in Domrémy, northern France.

Also known as: The Maid of Orleans; Jean la Pucelle; St Joan.

Appearance: Manly. Soldierly. Saintly.

Personality: An infuriatingly precocious child. While her 12-year-old contemporaries were listening to boy bands and smoking furtively in the lobby of the Domrémy Warner Village, Joan was hearing voices instructing her to cut her hair short, dress as a man and lead France to victory against the English in the Hundred Years War.

A notion her parents soon talked her out of, presumably. Not likely. Joan persuaded her uncle, Robert de Baudricourt, to wangle her an audience with Charles, the heir to the throne. He - depressed at the thought that the war had 23 years left to run - agreed to the plan. Joan led the French to a miraculous victory against the Brits at Orléans in 1429, and Charles VII was crowned the same year. Not that she was rewarded.

She got her fingers burnt? Rather more than that, actually. She was captured by the Burgundians in 1430 and sold to the English who, after a 14-month trial, burnt her at the stake in the marketplace at Rouen. That's got to be the most exciting thing that's ever happened in the marketplace at Rouen.

These voices. God's, presumably? That's what everyone thought - and why Joan was posthumously absolved in 1456 and canonised in 1920. But according to a new movie, they may actually have been Dustin Hoffman's.

Come again? Hoffman plays Joan's conscience in a gory new biopic by Luc Besson, presenting a psychoanalytic view of Joan (Milla Jovovich). As Charles, John Malkovich - in a radical departure from his screen persona - plays a camp, self-absorbed and rather sinister figure.

Weren't Besson and Jovovich married? Yes, but rumours that Besson cast Jovovich to be burnt at the stake as part of some marital tiff are unfounded.

fields.headline: The no-sweat approach to protest
fields.trailText: The demonstrations in Seattle against the World Trade Organisation talks only seemed like a return to the 1960s. This time, it was the union movement organising the demonstration and the students joining in.
fields.body:
The demonstrations in Seattle against the World Trade Organisation talks only seemed like a return to the 1960s. This time, it was the union movement organising the demonstration and the students joining in.

Much to the chagrin of us oldsters who see each new demonstration as a replay of our own youth, today's students know little about the history of union organising, and nothing of the ideological battles that split the American left. They are not able to argue the finer points of Marxist theory, but they do have a sense that their world is controlled by multinational capital and they don't like it.

These young people see unions as a way of fighting corporate domination. The unions are responding by working with the students, anxious for a transfusion of new energy. More than 1,000 young people have gone through the AFL-CIO "union summer," programme in the past four years. Since Unite, (Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees) began it stop-sweatshops campaign four years ago, support groups have proliferated at US and Canadian college campuses. United Students Against Sweatshops have organised at more than 160 colleges, and often getting their university to support the students' demands to ensure that college-licensed apparel be produced under decent working conditions.

These students are not rowdy and they are not disrespectful. The demonstrators come to sit-ins equipped with laptops to do their homework and cell phones to call reporters. At the Penn sit-in, students posted signs asking demonstrators to be respectful of university property.

Union leaders have enthusiastically supported the students. My own union even sent pizza deliveries into the Penn administration building for the students. Leaders from the newly formed Usas (United Students Against Sweatshops) have addressed the AFL-CIO convention and other union gatherings.

While the 1960s generation saw the university as a war machine, students today see their universities as corporations. The students have an international perspective, but also lend support to local union campaigns.

At the end of last year, when the Usas students got Nike to agree to open their contracting shops to outside inspection, the students understood how much business Nike stood to lose if their universities cancelled the company's licensing contracts.

Students do not want their university buying-schemes to be responsible for keeping young people in other countries in poverty.

Many of the students who began their campus activity by fighting sweatshops are now aiding union campaigns on campus in support of cafeteria staff and other service workers.

This activity is also making a difference regarding young people joining unions. For the first time in years, polling shows the new generation to be union-friendly. No wonder, in a world where 78% of young people see corporations, directors and shareholders gaining more from the growing economy than do the employees. Seventy-seven per cent of workers aged 18-24 believe America's money and wealth should be distributed more fairly and one-third believe that the condition of poor families is the most important gauge of a good economy.

They don't see much of the new economy working for them. Only 45% of young workers with college degrees and 39% without degrees have employer-provided health insurance and only 43% of graduates (36% non-graduates) report having an employer-contribution pension plan. For young people of colour, the situation is worse. Roughly half of all young African American and Latino American workers - compared with 39% of young white workers - earn less than $20,000 (£12,600) a year.

With numbers like these, it is likely that the new alliance between workers, their unions, young people, and students will grow in this new century. It is a movement fit for today's global economy.

 Jo-Ann Mort is director of communications for Unite.

webTitle: Asda extends price cuts to clothing range

fields.headline: Asda extends price cuts to clothing range
fields.trailText: Asda will today step up its assault on the traditional fashion market by slashing the prices of many of its George clothes by 15%.
fields.body:
Asda will today step up its assault on the traditional fashion market by slashing the prices of many of its George clothes by 15%.

The supermarket chain's promotion will encompass more than 4,000 items, reducing prices by a total of £17m.

Asda's Rollback promotion began a year ago but has concentrated on food so far. Total price cuts have exceeded £200m. The company is now attacking the clothes market, backed by a television advertising campaign beginning on Thursday.

The chain has gained customers at the expense of struggling rivals such as Somerfield, which yesterday responded to suggestions that chief executive David Simons was plotting to take the company private by saying: "This really is just rumour and speculation."

The report suggested that Mr Simons was holding talks with private equity firms, including US group Apollo and Oaktreee Capital Management.

The company's market capitalisation is £315m, having plunged over the last year after a botched takeover of smaller retailer Kwik Save.

Shareholders will get the chance to question Mr Simons today at an extraordinary general meeting to vote on the sale of 45 of its larger stores for £305m.

 Boots has launched a website dedicated to men's grooming and fitness: <A HREF="http://www.boots-men.co.uk"" TARGET="_NEW">www.boots-men.co.uk

webTitle: Tucker lines up new Storehouse team

fields.headline: Tucker lines up new Storehouse team
fields.trailText: Monaco-based car parks millionaire Stephen Tucker is in talks with institutional shareholders about installing new management at Storehouse, the under-siege retailer which owns Mothercare and Bhs.
fields.body:
Monaco-based car parks millionaire Stephen Tucker is in talks with institutional shareholders about installing new management at Storehouse, the under-siege retailer which owns Mothercare and Bhs.

Mr Tucker has lined up a team including Nigel Whittaker, the former finance director of rival retailer Kingfisher. The pair yesterday denied speculation that they were plotting a takeover of the company but admitted they had "held some discussions with certain people about Storehouse".

In a statement, they added: "Those discussions have not yet been concluded".

They believe they could achieve more value by over seeing a controlled sale of the group's prized assets than by allowing it to succumb to a bidder.

Several predators are circling the company. Iceland has said it wants to buy Bhs, while Italian retailer Prinatal is understood to be interested in Mothercare.

Another Monaco-based businessman, Philip Green, yesterday refused to rule out an offer. When asked if he was bidding, he said: "I watch what's going on. I will have a look when it's appropriate."

Knutsford, the shell company with former Asda chairman Archie Norman on its board, has indicated it is not interested. Insiders are playing down talk of an offer from venture capital firm Alchemy Partners.

Storehouse has been with out a chief executive since July last year, when Keith Edelman was ousted. Chairman Alan Smith has been running the business but he has struggled to halt its plunging share price. The company is currently valued at £195m.

Large shareholders such as Franklin Resources and Prudential are believed to be keen for change in order to inject some momentum.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

The London stock market will lurch further into the new economy on Wednesday when a clutch of brewing, cigarette and building companies are ejected from the FTSE 100 index in faviour of telephone, internet and computer companies.

British Airways moved this weekend to quash rumours that professional head-hunters have been briefed to find a replacement for chief executive Bob Ayling. As influential institutional shareholders expressed support for such a plan because of the company's disastrous financial performance, airline executives denied that Mr Ayling plans to leave in the summer.

Sunday Times

The American internet search engine Alta Vista will announce today that it plans to be the first company in Britain to provide free telephone access to the internet after one upfront charge.

British Airways, in the ultimate spin-off, is considering floating its London Eye ferris wheel on the stock market in a move that could value it at £250m.

Sunday Business

Luke Johnson, head of the Belgo restaurant chain, made up to £150,000 because of a share ramp by the Mirror's City Slickers after the two journalists involved had invested themselves. Mr Johnson denies any contact with the Mirror team.

GEI International's price jumped from 12p to 21p on the tip by Anmil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell last December. Mr Johnson then sold his 4% stake on which he had been showing a loss.

John Hardy will come under intense pressure this week to resign as chief executive of Link, the inter-bank cash dispenser network, made up of 34 member banks and building societies.

Sunday Telegraph

Noddy, the children's character who celebrated his 50th birthday last year, is set to enter cyberspace. Chorion, the leisure group which owns the rights to Enid Blyton, his creator, is poised to invest £12m to build a digital version of Noddy and Toyland.

Powergen is preparing to sell its entire international business outside America and a big British power station in a move to raise £1.5bn towards paying for the $5.4bn purchase of LG&E, the Kentucky-based power group.

Mail on Sunday

BBC Worldwide is to launch a commercial network of internet sites this spring in a move that could transform it into Britain's leading player in the cyber economy.

The initiative will lead to the creation of a series of internet service providers and access sites - or portals - with a potential market value of billions of pounds.

The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, looks set to make an embarrassing climbdown from his much-trumpeted campaign to end "rip-off Britain" and give consumers a fairer deal.

IoS

Phillips & Drew, the fund manager, is facing legal action from clients furious at the way it dumped its stake in Huntingdon Life Sciences for a tenth of their value following complaints by "animal rights" activists.

Land owned by British Waterways is set to be developed under a partial privatisation plan being drawn up by the government. The canal company could end up jointly owning commercial property worth more than £1bn.

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText:
What is the point of the International Monetary Fund?
It was set up in June, 1944 at a milestone conference attended by 44 nations at Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, USA, to supervise the system of exchange rates pegged on the dollar and to bail out countries facing balance of payments crises.
fields.body:
What is the point of the International Monetary Fund?
It was set up in June, 1944 at a milestone conference attended by 44 nations at Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, USA, to supervise the system of exchange rates pegged on the dollar and to bail out countries facing balance of payments crises.

At the same time the World Bank was set up to help prepare for the reconstruction of Europe after the devastation of the war.

What is a balance of payments crisis?
A shortfall between how much a country spends on foreign goods and services and how much it earns from exporting its own goods and services. In a fixed exchange rate system, countries have to borrow money or devalue their currencies to cover the gap .

However, since the Bretton Woods system broke up in the early 1970s and most countries floated their exchange rates, bail-outs from the fund have become less important.

Why?

Because in floating exchange rate system, currencies usually depreciate when the current account is facing a shortfall.

What did it do then?
Like all institutions whose original purpose has been superceded, it has reinvented itself. In the 1980s, the Latin American debt crisis gave it a toehold in the economies of the developing world. It bailed out the debt burdened countries and in return they agreed to reform their economies according to the IMF's rule book.

Concessional lending throughout most of the developing world followed, hand in hand with structural adjustment.

Was it a success?
According to the fund, yes, according to most development agencies, no. Sub-Saharan African economies, with a few notable exceptions, don't seem to be performing any better after a decade of structural adjustment.

So what should the fund do?
The US wants it to get out of development lending completely and return to its original role as a firefighter for countries facing currency crises. The US agenda will be a big challenge for whoever becomes the fund's next head.
