fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Schroders staff defect
fields.body:
Schroders staff defect

Schroders, in the final months before it sells its investment bank to Salomon Smith Barney, has suffered the defection of six executives to Goldman Sachs.

In what will be interpreted as a sign of disgruntlement with the takeover by the US bank, associate directors Steve Wallace, Scott Bell and Nick Reid will join Goldman Sachs as executive directors in the mergers and acquisitions department. They are joined by three less senior colleagues.

Alexander takes Sanctuary

Entertainment group Sanctuary will today signal its intention to become a serious dot.com player by recruiting Nick Alexander, 44, a former boss of Sega's European arm, to run its internet business.

webTitle: BP in sell-off to save Atlantic deal

fields.headline: BP in sell-off to save Atlantic deal
fields.standfirst: US company's $6bn Alaskan interests may go to avoid clash with regulator
fields.trailText: BP Amoco is to make substantial concessions over its $30bn (£19bn) merger with American group Atlantic Richfield to avoid a courtroom clash with the Federal Trade Commission.
fields.body:
BP Amoco is to make substantial concessions over its $30bn (£19bn) merger with American group Atlantic Richfield to avoid a courtroom clash with the Federal Trade Commission.

In a radical reworking of the deal, BP is considering selling all the US company's Alaskan interests - which could be worth up to $6bn. BP had previously insisted it would only sell about a quarter of the assets in the Arctic state - which is rich in natural oil reserves.

It is understood that a bidding deadline for the assets passed on Friday. BP will spend this week considering the level of offers - tipped to include bids from Shell and from US groups Chevron, Phillips and Andarko.

The FTC is worried that the merger could give BP Amoco too much power over oil refiners on the west coast, which could push up prices disproportionately.

A court hearing is scheduled in two weeks, but BP's executives are hopeful that legal action could be suspended. Atlantic Richfield's Alaskan businesses include the large Prudhoe Bay oilfield.

Analysts believe BP was originally willing to part with this, in order to concentrate on extracting gas from the state's North Slope. This untapped reserve is considered extremely valuable in the long term.

However, a surge in the crude oil price has helped convince the company that it could get an attractive price by selling both the oil and gas businesses. A barrel of crude now costs around $28, compared to $10 when the companies originally agreed to the deal.

An insider said: "There has been a lot of speculation. You have to see what price you can get before making decisions about these kind of things."

BP originally said that 20% of the $1bn savings from the merger would come from Alaska. It is believed that the tie-up could still be attractive with $800m of savings. Atlantic Richfield also has a swath of operations across the US, together with interests in Malaysia, China and Russia.

BP Amoco is keen to avoid a lengthy legal battle over the merger. Such a process would make the matter more political, which the company fears could encourage the regulator to scupper the deal.

The issue could quickly escalate into a high profile battle: presidential candidate Al Gore has expressed concern about the growing power of oil companies, in his attempts to show his environmental colours.

Concerns over the Atlantic Richfield deal have contributed to a sharp fall in BP Amoco's share price. They closed at 494p on Friday, having slipped from over 600p since the new year.

webTitle: Rate hope as competition stymies service sector firms

fields.headline: Rate hope as competition stymies service sector firms
fields.trailText: Stiff competition is preventing service sector firms from raising prices, a survey shows today, raising hopes that the Bank of England will keep interest rates on hold when its monetary policy committee meets this week.
fields.body:
Stiff competition is preventing service sector firms from raising prices, a survey shows today, raising hopes that the Bank of England will keep interest rates on hold when its monetary policy committee meets this week.

Firms in the sector are facing heavy pressure on their margins, according to the Confederation of British Industry. "There is little sign of service sector inflation, although profits are being squeezed as cost pressures are felt," said Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's associate director of economic analysis.

"With competition strong, companies may not get the prices rises they expect, therefore interest rates can be kept on hold."

Meanwhile a separate survey showed that the level of wage settlements has fallen since a year ago, a further sign that inflationary pressures in the economy are easing. Two thirds of pay deals so far this year have been between 2% and 3.5%, according to Incomes Data Services.

The Bank's monetary policy committee has been concerned about the official figures for average earnings which jumped last month. However Alastair Hatchett of IDS said the earnings figures had been boosted by exceptional Christmas bonuses.

The CBI survey showed service sector firms are still recruiting, but at a slower pace than three months ago. "Consumer firms expect a further slowdown, while business and professional firms expect more rapid job creation," the CBI said.

The monetary policy committee will announce its decision on interest rates on Thursday.

fields.headline: Keep to the pointe
fields.standfirst: La La La Human Steps shocked dance audiences in the 80s with their disregard for the rules. But as their new show comes to the UK,  Keith Watson  finds them flirting with traditional ballet
fields.trailText: Legend has it that a veteran dance critic took one look at the goths and punks turning up for an early La La La Human Steps gig in 1985 at London's Town & Country Club, refused to set foot out of the taxi and told the driver to return to Covent Garden forthwith.
fields.body:
Legend has it that a veteran dance critic took one look at the goths and punks turning up for an early La La La Human Steps gig in 1985 at London's Town & Country Club, refused to set foot out of the taxi and told the driver to return to Covent Garden forthwith.

Enigmatic Canadian choreographer Edouard Lock and his muse (and sometime lover), shock-blonde dervish Louise Lecavalier, had taken modern dance away from the polite silence of theatres out to a post-punk rock audience. Fuelled by the extraordinary presence of Lecavalier, a ferocious athlete given to making triple-twist crashes to the floor and chest-pressing her male partners above her head, La La La's wild and unpredictable performances kicked against a dance establishment that prized craft and commitment above emotion and energy.

It was no surprise when Lock went on to choreograph David Bowie's 1990 Sound and Vision tour, Louise Lecavalier's trademark physical derring-do providing a perfect counterpoint to the rock stylings of the Thin White Duke.

Riding that wave, La La La Human Steps has become a global dance phenomenon. Their new show, Salt, which opens in London tomorrow before moving on to Edinburgh, is in the second year of a world tour that takes in more than 150 dates in 60-plus cities, stretching from Lock's native Montreal to cities as far afield as Rio and Tokyo.

With a mighty fan base built on the kinetic excitement of shows such as Human Sex and New Demons, it would be easy for Lock and Lecavalier to set the controls on autopilot. But, after six months working on the show Lecavalier has left, unwilling to commit to such a demanding tour. The focus has also shifted: for Salt, Lock has decided to use six women performing on pointes, ballet's traditional, establishment stock-in-trade. What's the point? Lock, who had no classical training himself, seems surprised by the question. "Ballet technique is just that, a technique. I'm fascinated by the way the body can move and the way we perceive it. I think we're kind of over looking at ballet as the enemy - why can't any choreographer use it?"

It's a fine theory, but what comes as part and parcel of traditional balletic technique is that a male and female duet comes down to a man holding up a woman. And to take that on board is quite a leap for a company that has carved out a reputation based on physical egalitarianism. "It's true that in some ways the men are sometimes there just to provide a physical compensation for the women," admits Lock, "but in the end it would fall apart if it wasn't a question of mutual interdependence. When you put men and women together on stage there's always a tendency to look on it as a political statement and I don't think I'm interested in that. Even when we started, and Louise was throwing men about, it was a physical expression rather than a political one."

It is true that Salt is a world away from ballet in any conventional sense. The six women stick to pointe, but when the men are let loose from their couplings they roll and tumble in a display of gymnastic liberation. And the speed with which the women skitter across the floor, limbs jack-knifing into corkscrew vertical take-off, borders on the life-threatening. All of which runs counter to the mood of curiously aggressive sadness that Salt creates. "It's not an overly joyous piece, but then I'm not an overly joyous person," reflects Lock, ruefully. "The idea of calling it Salt was to suggest some kind of residue. It takes place as the aftermath of some undefined sad event; it's the shadow world of an emotional overspill."

That makes Salt sound almost swathed in melancholy. But it also has the sharp tang of conflict and aggression; it is not only a technical tour de force but a world of disturbed and brooding characters. The effect is backed up by the black-and-white half-lighting and a live score (by David Lang and My Funny Valentine's Kevin Shields) that ranges in style from classical minimalism to stabbing bursts of electric guitar feedback. The only light relief comes from brief filmed sections (Lock, a true Renaissance man, is the director) which feature circular screens bouncing across a black sky. The image of a smiling baby is an innocent contrast to our older, more self-absorbed selves.

Lock is clearly taken aback at dark interpretations of a show which pushes his 10 classically trained dancers through 100 relentless minutes of punishing physical rigour. Wrapped deep within the work, he talks earnestly of structures and physical abstractions, falling into philosophical silence when he ponders that most punters lack the capacity to relate to "pure" dance, when it's stripped of extraneous trappings such as music, lighting and costume.

We're heading straight for Pseuds Corner, so it's time to get back to basics. How is the tour going? "In Los Angeles they were laughing," says Lock. "Maybe it's only the English who see all this anguish."

La La La Human Steps is at Sadler's Wells (0171-863 8000), London N1, from tomorrow till March 11, and at the Festival Theatre (0131-529 6000), Edinburgh, from March 17-18.

webTitle: It's plantlife, but not as we know it

fields.headline: It's plantlife, but not as we know it
fields.standfirst: From a Daleks' home in Cornwall to a Welsh update of Kew's Victorian elegance:  Jonathan Glancey investigates hi-tech design in garden buildings
fields.trailText: From a Daleks' home in Cornwall to a Welsh update of Kew's Victorian elegance: Jonathan Glancey investigates hi-tech design in garden buildings
fields.body:
Think plants, pondlife, ecology and conservation and the architecture that plods into mind is shaggy, fuzzy and a bit wobbly looking, the tectonic equivalent of a muddy wellington boot. Geraniums in hanging baskets. Trellises. Clapboard sheds built from cheap pine. Fake-stone urns. Sad-looking terracotta pots.

It doesn't have to be like this. Kew Gardens boasts the Palm House (1844-48): a masterpiece of early-Victorian engineering and one of the finest garden buildings of all. Its jelly-mould shape is a delight, and the way the tropical plants wind and snake among cast-iron columns and spiral stairs inside its steamy glass walls is the stuff of Dr Livingstone fantasies. Here nature, in the guise of palms, rubber plants and the scary-looking trees that creep across mangrove swamps, is in a state of equipoise with architecture.

Three British architectural practices - Foster and Partners, the Nicholas Grimshaw Partnership and Future Systems - are working on expansive and ambitious garden buildings. All demonstrate their well known love of hi-tech engineering. The National Botanic Garden of Wales in Carmarthenshire, the Eden Project in Cornwall, and the Earth Centre in Yorkshire are all millennium projects, each boasts some of the most intriguing and delightful buildings to have emerged from British practices in the past five years. Together they mark the coming together of sophisticated modern design with nature, the export of an architecture bred in urban hothouses to the countryside.

Foster's elegant glasshouse in the restored 18th-century grounds of Middleton Hall in Carmarthenshire is the most straightforward of the three. This is Kew's Palm House brought convincingly up to date. It will house endangered plants from Mediterranean climates and will offer a walk along gangways and across bridges through lush vegetation in much the same way as its Victorian predecessor does. The nearly completed building demonstrates how well even a large glasshouse sits alongside a historic architecture of brick, stone and stucco; and how well their pregnant forms sit in rolling Welsh landscapes.

Grimshaw's Martian domes near St Austell in Cornwall blow like giant soap bubbles from deep inside the steep, 60-metre walls of the former Bodelva China Clay pit. Cornwall's is a particularly beautiful landscape, although pitted with unsightly remains of tin-mines, clay pits and holiday caravans. The first two are being dealt with slowly by schemes like the ambitious Eden Project; the caravans are surely there to stay.

The geodesic domes that will shelter humid tropical and warm temperate flora, algae and other primitive or simple animal life are the stuff of sci-fi fantasy. What springs to mind are those Dr Who adventures that for reasons of cost nearly always took place in disused quarries. The Eden Project looks like a home for retired Daleks - although the Daleks, keener on extermination than conservation, would never have taken to the exotic plantlife that will gestate and bloom under Grimshaw's domes.

Up to 45 metres high, these are computer-generated developments of the geodesic domes invented by the US engineer Buckminster Fuller (1895-1983), who for a time was an associate partner of Norman Foster's. Such domes, which dissolved the boundary between wall and roof, offer the maximum volume of space for least possible mass. These lightweight structures seem to match the astonishing strength, flexibility and beauty of the plants they house.

Grimshaw's domes have been morphed into exotic shapes. The spaces between the honeycomb-like components are filled with triple skins of ETFE (ethylene tetrafluoroethylene) foil, which offers greater thermal insulation than glass. It is a recyclable material that stands up well to the effects of direct sunlight. This promises to shine for much of the year on the Eden domes: solar energy is stored in the south facing 60-metre deep walls of the former clay pit and released by night.

A visitor centre at the £53m Eden Project opens in May. Given Cornwall's holiday traffic it is likely to prove very popular, drawing adults and children like butterflies to buddleia. This ETFE-generation Garden of Eden will take visitors on a tour inside and outside the domes through all the world's major ecosystems, in an area the size of 30 football pitches. It promises to be a remarkable - and only slightly dotty - experience.

As for the Earth Centre on the outskirts of Doncaster, not a lot appears to be happening. This is partly a question of location: a former waste tip for south Yorkshire coalmines is clearly at a disadvantage compared to the prospect of a trip to sunny Cornwall or the rolling hills of deep rural Wales. Doncaster used to be famous worldwide for the locomotives it built - Mallard and The Flying Scotsman among them - as well as for racing and mining. Today it has little to offer visitors.

The Earth Centre was always intended to be a long-term venture, and has been written off all too quickly for failing to draw visitors. Still, it is a millennium project funded by the national lottery, and just as people hope to become millionaires overnight, so we expect millennium projects to be packed out with millions of visitors instantly.

Sadly, the one real attraction that would have given the Earth Centre the pull on visitors it needs has been shelved, for the time being at least. This is the elegant Ark, or exhibition centre, designed by Future Systems (Jan Kaplicky and Amanda Levete, who last year won the Stirling prize for their media centre at Lord's cricket ground). Shaped like a great butterfly, the Ark was to have landed with delicacy and grace on a gently sloping hillside on the edge of the ecological gardens. It would be great to see the Ark built, if not in South Yorkshire then elsewhere in the wilds of Wales, Scotland or Ireland.

These three designs - Ark, glasshouse and computer-morphed domes - are some of the most likeable to have sprouted from hi-tech British architecture. They deserve to succeed and to be nurtured as carefully as the plants they will protect.

fields.headline: Poor show
fields.standfirst: America's welfare reforms have changed attitudes but we should be aware of the potentially negative impact of the work-first approach
fields.trailText: America's welfare reforms have changed attitudes but we should be aware of the potentially negative impact of the work-first approach
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's policy of pushing more and more claimants off benefit into jobs is American-inspired. But has New Labour been listening to the people on the far side of the Atlantic who are now saying that getting tough on welfare can end up harming programmes designed to reduce poverty and improve skills?

Sure, the United States can boast a 40% reduction in the number of those claiming welfare, saving $9bn. More American lone parents are working as a result - the rates have risen from 44% in 1992 to 57% in 1998. But other evidence says that these headline results hide worrying trends.

The main reason for fewer Americans claiming welfare is that they are often not allowed to claim and/or that huge obstacles are placed in their way. Welfare is the responsibility of state governors and mayors, most of whom have implemented an approach called Work First. It puts claimants in the position where they have actively to consider taking a job even as they make a claim for welfare.

It is often ruthlessly implemented. New York City welfare offices boast that they refuse to give out claim forms to claimants: instead they tell them to go and look for a job before they can claim; alternatively they are made to participate in job clubs where they are given a phone book and told to cold-call employers. Welfare dependency is highly correlated to lifetime poverty, poor health and poor childhood educational outcomes. Thus, in a neat reversal the Americans have changed their attitude from one of "helping hurts" to "hurting helps".

Of course the other main reason for falling numbers of new claims is that the American economy is buoyant and economic growth is creating jobs. In the year after leaving welfare between 63% and 87% are in work.

But while many welfare leavers get jobs and are better off, for some the move is no great progression. Around 20% of ex-welfare cases do not work at all and have no obvious signs of independent income. Nearly a third of those who do get jobs return to claim welfare within a year. Between a third and half of those who do work have incomes that are lower than their previous benefit levels.

Because work is the most common antidote to poverty we are told (by Labour ministers) that stricter welfare to work programmes will reduce poverty. Yet the American experience suggests that poverty is still common for many. Two thirds of Wisconsin's welfare leavers are living under the American poverty line. The centre for budget and policy priorities in Washington DC found that across the US, lone parents in the lowest income bracket have got poorer since welfare reform. The chart shows how the poorest fifth of lone parents had shown income gains during the early 90s - an extra $1,000 a year on average in the two years before welfare reform. Since Clinton's reforms came in, their incomes have fallen by almost 7%. Most of this is due to the withdrawal of benefits.

The fall in US welfare rolls has also been accompanied by a drop off in the programmes intended to help the working poor, such as food stamps and medicaid. One reason for this is strict enforcement of punitive work-based welfare policies. These foster bad relationships between claimants and administrators. If they do not respect you enough when you claim welfare, how can you trust them to deliver when you are off welfare and in work?

Both Britain and America put great store in making work pay by rewarding work with benefits rather than paying welfare during unemployment. While this distinction between in-work benefits and out-of-work benefits is clear to policy makers, many ordinary poor people just see both as part of the system that is making their life deliberately difficult. If Gordon Brown wants his working family's tax credit to be an unequivocal success, he should think long and hard about making welfare even tougher.

Recent evidence cuts away at the intellectual underpinning of the American reforms. Work First was inspired by a Californian experiment that compared programmes for welfare claimants based on education and training with those strictly fixed on getting them into jobs. It seemed to show that Work First was not only cheaper but got more people into work with higher incomes. However, these findings are now in doubt.

Researchers in California say that in the longer run, differences between education and work-first approaches even out. Other new research compared the two in Grand Falls, Michigan, and Atlanta, Georgia, but also kept the most successful site from the Californian experiment in Riverside. These showed that after two years there is no real difference in outcomes. The best welfare-to-work policies are, in the words of the congressional auditor, a mix of education and work-orientated programmes.

So why is the American experience still so influential? Part of the reason is political spin. Federal assistance has allowed states to replace local spending; tax cuts have followed. Impressive but premature headline results lead to international attention. But now that research shows another side to US welfare reform, we should be more cautious. Of course, we are wise to look to America or any other country for ideas.

But the British tradition of a comprehensive safety net prevents the appalling experience of dire poverty of Americans that fall outside or are pushed off welfare. Benefits may be low here, but they are widely available - preventing even worse poverty than we already have. Pushing people off them will always result in a substantial minority not going into work. The result is increased social exclusion and deepening poverty gaps as a more marginalised group fall further outside of the system. The worry for Britain in these weeks prior to the budget must be that we have imported too much of their misleading rhetoric already.

webTitle: Police ready for mayhem on May Day

fields.headline: Police ready for mayhem on May Day
fields.trailText: Police are getting ready for the possibility of rioting in London during a May Day protest against global capitalism that, according to activists, will be "quite different from anything that's gone before".
fields.body:
Police are getting ready for the possibility of rioting in London during a May Day protest against global capitalism that, according to activists, will be "quite different from anything that's gone before".

A four-day gathering in London, part of a series of "Mayday2k" events, will include "mayhem and a mass action in London on Monday May 1 to celebrate our diverse struggles against capitalism, exploitation and the destruction of the planet", says a website.

Rioting during last year's June 18 event brought chaos to the City of London, and there were clashes between police and protesters at London's Euston station on November 30 during a day of action against the World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle. Reclaim The Streets, the group behind those two protests in London, says on its website: "Yes, RTS people have agreed we'll [do] something, but we haven't had the idea yet. Whatever the press say, we intend it to be quite different from anything that's gone before."

Discussions, parties and publicity-seeking events will be held across the bank holiday weekend, from Friday April 28. Plans, necessarily still vague and sketchy, are being drawn up and posted through e-mail and on the internet. Up to 10,000 protesters, individuals and members of a loose mixture of environmentalist and anti-capitalist groups, could come to London for May 1, the traditional workers' holiday.

Police are making plans involving thousands of officers. A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "We are aware that a number of events are being planned. We are working with City of London police, transport police and other agencies as appropriate to ensure the necessary policing arrangements are in place."

Action is expected in cities across the world including Sydney, Toronto, Chicago, New York, Washington DC, and smaller US cities.

"Let's use the energy and contacts from June 18 and November 30 to make this the strongest show of solidarity and resistance yet!" says one website. "This day will thus continue the process of building up a strong, bold, and creative grassroots movement for a society in which people do not exploit or oppress each other, communities or the environment, but one that is based on solidarity, co-operation, grassroots democracy, and ecological sustainability."

A further protest is being planned for September 27-28, linked to a meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Prague.

fields.headline: A symbol too many
fields.standfirst:
Parsifal
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Parsifal
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In the second act of Scottish Opera's first-ever production of Parsifal, Anne-Marie Owens as Kundry attempts to lure John Murray's Parsifal in a frock which made her torso the exalted apex of a voluptuous, 15-foot, red velvet bulb. Kundry's schizophrenic sexuality may be problematic, but the solution demands a less heavy-handed approach.

Murray was also physically and emotionally static. Director-designer Silviu Purcarete turned his singers into props, no more significant than the holy spear or the stage-mirrors he gave to the Flower Maidens. Here the visual dimension replaces any real dramatic momentum.

Purcarete scales down Wagner's epic vision in the outer acts. Amfortas' castle becomes the Monsalvat mental institution, with Amfortas bandaged to a hospital trolley. This may humanise the narrative's mysterious grandiloquence, but there is little compensating theatrical or emotional power.

There are enough symbols in Wagner's music without additional layers of meaning - something conductor Richard Armstrong understands. He and the Orchestra of Scottish Opera combine in a performance of superb pacing and alert attention to detail. Matthew Best's Amfortas is outstanding and Manfred Hemm's stentorian Gurnemanz and Owens' resolute Kundry also impress. Musically this Parsifal has much to commend it: would that the same level of warmth and understanding defined the production itself.

fields.headline: Coping with turmoil
fields.standfirst: Change at work can be the source of severe stress for employees and management alike. Judi James explains how to take the strain out of the company takeover
fields.trailText: Changes to how your office is run can be traumatic. Massive change, like a company takeover or radical restructuring can cause stress throughout the entire organisation, producing a scorched-earth effect.
fields.body:
Changes to how your office is run can be traumatic. Massive change, like a company takeover or radical restructuring can cause stress throughout the entire organisation, producing a scorched-earth effect.

The more prolonged the anticipation of change lasts, the more stressful it becomes and the more staff will begin to show signs of cracking. Current business climate has made restructure and change the order of the day. So how do you survive when your entire career seems to hang in the balance?

Expect stress

Anticipating trouble can be negative, but not in this particular situation. Stress is not a necessary by-product of restructuring but is, nevertheless, all too common. Understanding what can cause it is a useful step in managing the effects.

We get stressed when things are out of our control. When decisions are being made that affect your livelihood and those decisions aren't communicated or negotiated downward, staff morale will naturally suffer.

Start to take control back by looking at your options. Make decisions, however small. Even deciding to do nothing or keep you head down is better than taking no decision at all.

Keep things in perspective by making lists. Write down what could happen in the best and worst-case scenarios. Create a failsafe by planning what steps you will take in any eventuality.

Take practical steps to deal with stress. Instead of fuming and worrying, use exercise to work off frustrations. Take quiet time every day and use music to induce calm. Allow yourself to have fun, even when the pressure is on; watch cartoons or comedy programmes; play with the kids; visit a funfair. However, getting drunk every night might seem like the answer and may relieve stress in the short term but too much alcohol can exacerbate work-related problems.

Alienation

When restructuring is first announced, the workforce will probably pull together; but don't expect that to last. Threatened redundancies or promotion prospects lead to an 'every man for himself' attitude which can be isolating.

Staff start to play cards close to their chest and trust becomes an issue, even between colleagues who are friends. Strengthen non-work friendships to help you over this stage. Although you may be obsessed with work issues and worries, you should start to cherish social relationships as they will remind you that there is life outside work and help to put problems into context. Try to avoid talking about work when you're with your friends.

Avoid the gossip

Speculation and gossip about corporate change can be destructive. Listen to both if you must, but respond to neither. All the nightmare scenarios possible will fly back and forth: Attila the Hun will be the new MD (or alternatively, the boss from hell you fell out with big-time a few months ago) and whole departments will be closed down, with yours at the top of the imagined list. Stay cool. Don't waste energy worrying or complaining at this stage; wait until the official announcements are made.

Don't suck up

Another by-product of speculation and rumour is that people start sucking up to the one they think will be the new boss. Backing the wrong horse will be disastrous, though. Never second-guess. Wait until you know.

Don't slag off

Avoid publicly criticising fellow colleagues, for obvious reasons, even if you have been assured the boss you loathe is leaving or being made redundant. Decisions can always be changed at the last minute. Seethe inwardly, instead.

Spread the word

If you feel your job is at risk look at the prospects of redundancy and start networking at an early stage. You may decide to leave anyway, or a better job might be thrown in your direction. Use the period of instability to see what else might be on offer.

webTitle: The shy and cautious City trader emerges

fields.headline: The shy and cautious City trader emerges
fields.trailText: Nick Leeson may have been a brash, high-risk gambler prepared to bet Barings bank on a rise in the Japanese stock market but, on the whole, City traders are a shy and conservative breed, according to new research published today.
fields.body:
Nick Leeson may have been a brash, high-risk gambler prepared to bet Barings bank on a rise in the Japanese stock market but, on the whole, City traders are a shy and conservative breed, according to new research published today.

Based on in-depth interviews with the London staff of four of the world's top investment banks, the research found that traders tend to be loners who are generally "traditional and concrete" in their thinking rather than loud-mouthed extroverts.

Some take risks but no more so than people in other professions. And when it comes to their own money, health or career, traders are more cautious than the general population.

"It seems likely that these patterns exist primarily because of self-selection into trading by people who like to work with a high degree of autonomy but within a framework of rules and conventions," says the study by a team of researchers at the London Business School.

The team - led by Professors Nigel Nicholson and Paul Willman - examined traders' behaviour in an attempt to find ways of better managing them.

It found that many of the traders' decisions were irrational. Despite being told to trade as if they have a flat book, that is one with no prior losses or gains, two thirds of the traders said past performance was a major influence on their behaviour.

When traders make money, they tend to assume it is due to their skill and judgment but when they suffer heavy losses they blame their strategy.

This leads to much soul-searching about losing rather than winning trades. Traders might become more effective if they paid as much attention to understanding the causes of their profits as well as their losses, says the research.

Bonuses can often act as a perverse incentive to under-perform. Half the traders interviewed said the annual bonus cycle encouraged them to be protective of their bonus towards the end of the year, not making trades that might lose money and hence reduce their bonus.

They are similarly cautious about starting off badly with loss-making trades when the new bonus cycle begins. In effect, this means that for up to six months of the trading year, opportunities to make profits are not being maximised.

The bonus system is also confusing for many traders. As well as being based on profit and loss, bonuses are used by managers to recruit and retain staff and reward teamwork. A high degree of subjective judgment leaves many traders not knowing what they are being paid for.

The least successful traders, in the opinion of managers and in terms of the amount they are paid, are those who suffer from "illusion of control" - the belief that they are unrealistically able to dictate events in the markets.

 The Individual and Contextual Influences on the market Behaviour of Finance Professionals, co-funded by the Economic and Social Research Council.

fields.headline: Terracotta
fields.standfirst:
Hampstead Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Hampstead Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Terracotta is the colour of earth, the colour of human shit, perhaps the colour of life itself. It is the colour that Nicola decides to paint part of her flat at the close of Jess Walters's new play, a beadily observed three-hander about growing up and breaking away and the damaging legacy of abuse.

Walters has little new to say on the latter subject, and the absurdity of the suddenly conjured happy ending undercuts the power of a play that for the most part is written with a good ear for the emotional eloquence of the coarsest vernacular. The play also has a curious structure: for a long time the sun-bathing Nicola is the sole presence on the roof and her dialogue is conducted through a skylight with the off-stage Ian, her cousin, who is supposed to be painting her flat. This feels like a play-writing exercise rather than a play. It is only 90 minutes long, but even so it sprawls.

In its favour, the piece plays cleverly with its potentially dangerous rooftop setting. It also has a vigorous comedy as it charts the strange, growing relationship between unhappy, damaged Nicola - who injures herself further with sunburn and cutting her flesh - and podgy poet Ian, who thinks he lost his virginity to a frozen chicken but in fact had it stolen from him aged eight on a visit to his cousin's house.

It is the acting that really carries the play, in particular Kellie Bright, who gives a revealing, near-naked performance in more ways than one. As she emerges from the darkness of her fear, a glorious, scrawny, teenage Aphrodite smothered in yoghurt, she convinces you that against all odds, Nicola may indeed have found her place in the sun.

 At Birmingham Rep (box office: 0121-236 4455) from Wednesday till March 25.

fields.headline: New London Consort/Pickett
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
J S Bach's six Brandenburg Concertos include some of his best-known instrumental music. Absolute, abstract music, one might assume. Yet Philip Pickett argues for their position as allegorical works, inspired by classical stories in the manner of much of the fine art of the day, and intended to create particular pictures.

Pickett took us through his ideas before his New London Consort performed each concerto in turn. The paintings to which he referred were projected behind the players during the relevant movement. Whether one buys into Pickett's theories or not - and some of them are more convincing than others - it was heartening to see the hall packed out with people for a concert which required them to think a bit and to be active listeners.

It wasn't too difficult to imagine the opening movement of the first concerto as a depiction of a Roman imperial procession, rather than the hunting scene that the two horns are often thought to suggest. But Pickett's explanation of the rest of this concerto required a rather more flexible imagination - could Bach really have been portraying the emperor Nero's squeaky voice with a high-pitched violin?

The seven string parts in the final movement of the third concerto could arguably be thought to represent the motion of the seven known planets of Bach's day - which were said to produce the sound of a scale sliding up and down as they journeyed round the cosmos. Certainly the brisk speed set by leader Pavlo Beznosiuk made the opening figure sound perilously close to a glissando, and there was the occasional rather earthly imprecision in intonation and ensemble.

The Consort's performances of the other concertos were more polished. Gail Hennessy's warm oboe tone was in balanced counterpoint with David Staff's controlled trumpet in the second concerto, whose the slow movement was especially affecting. And though David Roblou's harpsichord phrasing in the Affetuoso movement of the fifth was so affected as to be cumbersome, his virtuoso passages elsewhere in the concerto were dashed off with bravura.

fields.headline: Garbage in, garbage out
fields.standfirst: Bosses are taking an unhealthy interest in the diet of their staff.  Kate Hilpern reports on why they are counting your calories
fields.trailText: Bosses are taking an unhealthy interest in the diet of their staff. Kate Hilpern reports on why they are counting your calories
fields.body:
Big Brother is watching you. Not only is he counting the minutes you spend away from your desk on your lunch break, but he's checking what you eat in the office canteen. Calorie counting is no longer the preserve of the weight-obsessed - be prepared for your boss taking an unhealthy interest in your healthy eating regime.

It's a prospect to make anyone slightly queasy as they tuck into a canteen pork pie, but this is what the nutrition education company Energise believes will soon be the norm in many companies. Indeed, some larger firms are already taking a close look at their employees' nutrition. So what's going on? Have employers really become so caring that they are encouraging you to stick to that diet you've always been too weak-willed to keep up?

Not likely. Far more probable is that employers are alarmed at the latest surveys, such as those by Maine-Tucker Recruitment and Nimble, the bread-makers, revealing that a quarter of employees don't take lunch breaks and consequently don't eat properly. The result is not, as previously assumed, that staff work longer and harder. Rather, it is proven to lead to lack of productivity and an increase in absence.

"If human resources departments want to get the most out of their staff, they need to review staff diets," says Penny Hunking, managing director of Energise, which is undertaking the largest ever study of eating habits in the workplace. By getting employees to complete diet diaries, she hopes to persuade employers not only to give us time to eat, but to provide healthy stuff to tuck into as well.

"The introduction of company gyms is one example of how health and welfare issues are creeping up the management agenda," says Hunking. "The emphasis on what employees eat is, I believe, the next step."

Branding consultancy Wolff Olins is one company that has already jumped on the bandwagon. Jane Houghton, a former deputy editor of the Sainsbury's magazine and now responsible for the kitchen and restaurant at Wolff Olins, fought hard to banish stodge from the workplace canteen. Now almost everyone stops work at 1pm and resumes at 2pm, spending the interim eating fresh salads and crispbreads.

"The break is as important as the food," she believes. "It gives you a chance to socialise and network with staff at all levels in one of the only places where hierarchy is irrelevant. In any case, to be at your most creative, you need the time away from your desk during the day just as you need time away from the office during weekends."

One company has taken things even further. Deloitte Consulting now offers employees workshops on nutritional issues. Partner John Everett says: "We have even paid for staff to have private consultations with nutritional specialists to identify their own deficiencies. We have had a 100% take-up rate and absence levels have dropped significantly."

Those tempted to dismiss all this nutritional motivation stuff and rely on the four o'clock chocolate run should think again. You might feel as though the boost has done your motivation no end of good, but snacks that are high in fat, sugar, caffeine and salt all contribute to yet more imbalance in soaring and crashing energy levels.

Penny Hunking believes the trend towards breakfast meetings is the best thing support staff have introduced in years. "Not only is this because breakfast eaters have a higher health and fitness level, but because it brings attention to the correlation between food and creativity."

Anyone for bacon and fried eggs? Sorry, make that herbal tea and muesli.

fields.headline: Licence sale will raise £5bn
fields.standfirst: Treasury stands to gain equivalent of 2p income tax from mobile bandwidth auction
fields.trailText: The government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences, which begins today, could raise as much as £5bn for the treasury's already bulging coffers - equivalent to 2p off the standard rate of income tax or 20 new hospitals.
fields.body:
The government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences, which begins today, could raise as much as £5bn for the treasury's already bulging coffers - equivalent to 2p off the standard rate of income tax or 20 new hospitals.

Industry experts said a price tag of £1bn, twice the level initially expected, was being touted for each of the five licences on sale because the four established operators - BT, Vodafone, Orange and One2One - were determined to win.

"They will pay whatever it takes to get it," said Dougal Scott of Spectrum Strategy Consultants. "The hit to their market values if they fail to win a licence will be so substantial it's scary."

Some experts believe the price for the two licences with the most spectrum could go as high as £1.5bn and set off a chain of similar auctions around Europe.

If any of the four incumbents fails to own and operate one of the new licences its international expansion plans could be damaged and credibility suffer on that global stage. "It would raise questions if they fail to win a mobile data licence in their home market," Mr Scott said.

Kai-Uwe Ricke, chief executive of One2One, owned by Deutsche Telekom, also emphasised the international importance of the five licences operated under the universal mobile telecommunications system.

"The exploitation of UMTS by One2One in the UK will be a very important element in our overall pan-European strategy. We intend to maintain that position by bidding to win a UMTS licence," he said.

The auction begins shortly after 1.30pm today when the first round of bids are lodged, but the process is expected to extend over three weeks as bidders are eliminated.

Thirteen bidders are vying for the five licences. The fifth licence has been reserved for a new entrant.

Vodafone and BT have been tipped as hot favourites to win the licences that come into effect in 2002 and will permit multimedia services such as video and internet pages and perform simple computing tasks.

A cloud remains over Orange's likely success in the bidding though chief executive Hans Snook has committed the UK's third biggest mobile phone operator to winning. "It's going to be interesting," he said.

Vodafone is in the process of selling Orange to gain regulatory approval for its Mannesmann acquisition. If Orange does not win a third generation licence, the sale price Vodafone will eventually get for it will be severely depressed. BT has threatened to take legal action if it is not happy that Vodafone and Orange are bidding independently.

Spectrum Strategy Consultants says the fifth licence could fall to MCI Worldcom, Crescent, backed by the founders of Global Crossing, new owners of Racal Telecom, or Canadian mobile phone operator TIW. Those three groups have the balance sheets to allow maximum bids.

If Orange or one of the other incumbents is outbid it is expected that it would link up with one of the winning new operators which would benefit from a partner with an established UK network.

Don Millard, international business director of One.Tel, one of the potential new entrants, agreed that joint ventures were likely.

"Any new entrant has the opportunity to the extent to win one or more licences and then to form a relationship of some sort. It's a big market and people will want to have their own brand."

Not so much a phone . . .

Third generation mobile phones will allow users to access the internet, rapidly download emails, music and high quality pictures and hold video conferences on the move. Further options such as online banking or shopping via a third generation mobile phone are leading some industry commentators to say they will become the modern-day Visa or Mastercards.

The new mobiles will be run on the universal mobile telecommunications system which will give immensely fast connections of up to two megabytes of data a second. The government requires the winners of its five UMTS licences to cover 80% of the population by 2007. That kind of power and coverage could complete the mobile revolution.

fields.headline: Would you follow your leader?
fields.standfirst: If your company decides to relocate, you may be faced with a difficult choice - hours of commuting, moving house, or throwing in your job.  Annabelle Thorpe  looks at the options
fields.trailText: If your company decides to relocate, you may be faced with a difficult choice - hours of commuting, moving house, or throwing in your job. Annabelle Thorpe looks at the options
fields.body:
When Debra McAllister started her new job as PA to a television producer, the location was one of the major factors in her decision. "I'd always wanted to work in the West End," she says, "and my workplace was an easy commute on the tube."

But the good times weren't to last. "I was gutted when they suddenly announced that my department was moving to another office near Dorking in Surrey. The travelling was going to be hideous - but more than that, I was outraged by how they broke the news. We were told by email, rather than in person, and just three weeks before the move."

When a company relocates, the upheaval can be massive - whether you decide to move with the company or resign from your job. A recent IRS survey found that the average cost of relocating an employee is approximately £15,000 - and although it is commonly thought that only managers and senior staff are relocated, more than half the companies in the study said that they moved administrative and clerical staff as well.

"Its all down to what's in your contract," says Sue Nickson of Hammond Suddards, employment law specialists. "A lot of contracts will contain a 'mobility clause' - where the company reserves the right to ask you to move within a reasonable distance - and the approximate notice period they have to give."

While McAllister concedes her contract does include a such a clause, she thinks the way the company has handled the move is anything but reasonable. "They have said they'll talk to us about relocation packages, about paying our travel, and that we'll all have an individual meeting with personnel. But all they've done is collect facts - where we travel from, if we would think about moving - and more senior staff have been treated exactly the same way. Everyone is furious - but with only a week to go before we move, most people simply haven't got the time to look for another job. I'm going to have to go to Dorking - even though it's a two-hour journey each way - but after the way I've been treated, I am actively looking for another job."

So why do companies risk alienating their staff and embark on a logistically terrifying office move? One of the prime reasons to relocate from city centres to somewhere out-of-town, unsurprisingly, is the vast difference in cost. According to property company DTZ Debenham Tie Leung, office rental in Mayfair, central London, costs £62.50 per square foot, and in the City £52.50. Compare that with an average rent of £26 in Surrey and the sums calculate themselves. Rents in central London are the highest in western Europe, but according to Guy Lambert, associate director of Jones Lang LaSalle, cost is not the only factor.

"There is a trend for city-centre, big offices with everyone under one roof," says Lambert. "But there are still companies that are relocating - and not always for financial reasons. Bracknell is hugely popular for companies and a big reason for that is a lot of managing directors or CEOs live in Ascot or neighbouring areas. I have dealt with several companies which are moving simply so that the office is closer to where the MD lives."

As rents continue to rise, and the demand for office accommodation outstrips availability, there is a good chance that more companies will choose to move. According to the IRS survey, 50% of the companies they interviewed have seen an increase in employee relocation and moves - and with the increasing reliance on email and internet, being located in big cities will become less important.

It's particularly galling to have to relocate just because your MD wants to be closer to the golf club. So what rights do humble employees have if they find themselves in this position? "If you have a good reason for not being able to relocate, then the company has to make you redundant - although simply saying that you don't want to do a long commute may not be seen as reason enough," says Nickson. "It's known as 'workplace redundancy' - basically the office where you are based is no longer able to offer you a job. Again the redundancy terms depend on what is in your contract, but even if redundancy is not mentioned, you should still be eligible for statutory redundancy pay."

According to research by Dr Robin Martin, of the school of psychology at Cardiff university, companies which attempt to cut corners when relocating without providing proper support to their staff are storing up major problems for themselves. "Moving job and house can both be stressful events," he says, "but when they co-occur, high levels of stress may well be experienced by the person relocating and their family. The results of our study prove that pre-move preparation - in terms of relevant information and the opportunity to have a say in the move - can significantly improve mental wellbeing following the relocation."

For Sandie Wilmot, the relocation from north London to Docklands of her department in a telecommunications company ended as a positive experience, because her company took account of her circumstances. "I live near Harrow so the commute to Docklands was a nightmare," she says. "I have a young child and it meant my Mum having to look after him for such long hours.

"When we got news of the move, I had a meeting with my personnel officer, who was great - explained why we were moving, what support the company was offering if people wanted to move. I couldn't move, but I didn't want to leave the company. We agreed that I would go to Docklands, but if a position that suited me came up in the north London office, I could move back. Three months later I moved - into a more responsible position for more money."

But other companies may be guilty of viewing in a negative light those employees who are unwilling to relocate. "Increasingly the trend is that employees are expected to be mobile," says Nickson, "whether it's relocating to a different part of the country, or going on secondment just for a few months." But the situation is often further complicated by a partner or children who do not wish to move - although its important to realise that these are factors that the company should also take into account. According to the IRS survey, 45% of companies offered assistance in finding a job for the partner - assuming, of course, that they are happy to move.

Increasingly, relocation is becoming a fact of working life - and the best strategy for coping, say the experts, is to be aware of your rights and know what to expect. "It's important to feel you have a say, to have a chance to discuss the move with those who are responsible for managing it," says Martin.

Debra McAllister agrees, "Right from the start we've just been told how things are going to be," she says, "and that's the hardest thing. The company has been so high-handed, so careless with all of us. I've never felt so powerless in my life."

fields.headline: No sweat, no passion
fields.standfirst:
Simply Red
Wembley Arena
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Simply Red
Wembley Arena
Rating: **
fields.body:
Why is Mick Hucknall - a celebrity playboy and purveyor of white-boy soul to the suburbs - surrounding himself with Soviet iconography? His new album, Love and the Russian Winter, is so called, explains Mick, because that meteorological phenomenon saved the world from both Napoleon and Hitler. To some, the Simply Red crooner poses no less of a threat to civilisation: his lyrically vapid, honey-sodden pop has colonised Britain and infiltrated even No 10 and the dome.

The subtext of the Soviet connection - Hucknall's set suggests a vast Russian boxcar, whose corrugated wooden panels withdraw before a vista of twinkling stars - is that soul music, like all good revolutions, has eaten itself. Under the soul banner, Simply Red peddle muzak bereft of spirit or imagination, subsumed into commercial opportunism. Insofar as Hucknall meticulously reproduced his trademark pick'n'mix of reggae, R&B and lurve song his fans got their money's worth.

But no more than that. Hucknall betrays no personality on stage. His rich voice is sacrificed to the noise of 11 band-members stifling every song he sings. Hucknall begins Holding Back the Years alone on an acoustic guitar, but two verses in the band strikes up, smothering whatever frailty or feeling threatened to emerge. Elsewhere, the ruby-toothed one shimmies like an itching eel to Something Got Me Started, Money's Too Tight To Mention and a James Brown cover, Cold Sweat. There's no chance of working up a sweat here, however. Like a Russian winter, Simply Red live induces shivers.

His new album, Love and the Russian Winter, is so called, explains Mick, because that meteorological phenomenon saved the world from both Napoleon and Hitler. To some, the Simply Red crooner poses no less of a threat to civilisation: his lyrically vapid, honey-sodden pop has colonised Britain and infiltrated even No 10 and the dome. The subtext of the Soviet connection - Hucknall's set suggests a vast Russian boxcar, whose corrugated wooden panels withdraw before a vista of twinkling stars - is that soul music, like all good revolutions, has eaten itself. Under the soul banner, Simply Red peddle muzak bereft of spirit or imagination, subsumed into commercial opportunism. Insofar as Hucknall meticulously reproduced his trademark pick'n'mix of reggae, R&B and lurve song his fans got their money's worth. But no more than that. Hucknall betrays no personality on stage. His rich voice is sacrificed to the noise of 11 band-members stifling every song he sings. Hucknall begins Holding Back the Years alone on an acoustic guitar, but two verses in the band strikes up, smothering whatever frailty or feeling threatened to emerge. Elsewhere, the ruby-toothed one shimmies like an itching eel to Something Got Me Started, Money's Too Tight To Mention and a James Brown cover, Cold Sweat. There's no chance of working up a sweat here, however. Like a Russian winter, Simply Red live induces shivers.

fields.headline: Protection mooted for small investors
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Small investors could be eligible for compensation should a stock-market crash wipe out their assets, the chief City regulator has confirmed.
fields.body:
Small investors could be eligible for compensation should a stock-market crash wipe out their assets, the chief City regulator has confirmed.

Both shareholders and those owning share-based unit-trust plans or individual savings accounts (ISAs) may have a case for payouts in the event of the long-awaited fall in share prices.

Compensation would not be available to the new breed of "day traders", nor to anyone else who simply instructs a broker to buy and sell.

But any investor who was in any way advised to go into the stock market may be able to demand restitution from the individual or company concerned. With 12m private shareholders and a much larger figure owning equity-based unit trusts, ISAs and other investments, any potential bill could dwarf the £11bn total cost to the assurance companies of the 1988-94 pensions mis-selling affair.

To old City hands, the idea of being compensated for a stock-market crash may seem to mark a bizarre new development of the so-called "compo culture". But the Financial Services Authority (FSA) has confirmed that, in certain circumstances, the victim of a sharp drop in equity values may have a case for a payout.

A spokeswoman said: "There might be a case...but it would depend on what was said, by whom, and when". Compensation would hinge on the issue of advice. Nobody trading entirely on their own initiative, instructing an "execution only" broker, would be eligible.

But financial advisers -whether bankers, brokers, insurance salesman or anyone else - could land themselves or their companies with a large bill were they proved to have recommended any unsuitable investment. It could be argued that, for a risk-averse private person, the stock market in its present feverish state is, in itself, unsuitable.

The FSA explained that any investment company could cover itself against compensation claims by ensuring it followed FSA rules on suitability, which include strict "know your customer" requirements, and by displaying prominent "wealth warnings" on equity-related investments, alerting clients to the fact the shares can go down as well as up.

Any compensation claim ought to be taken up, firstly, with the company concerned. Should this fail to produce a satisfactory outcome, the investor would be entitled to take it to the FSA ombudsman's office.

In the case of alleged widespread mis-selling - as with the pensions affair - the FSA proper can take control and order an industry-wide review of all cases, with appropriate compensation.

During the past 12 months alone, the FTSE 100 index has surged from a low of 5869.18 on October 18 to stand well above 6400.
